Now, a single Dad of a six year old girl who has been blind since birth, he decides he would like to make up for his mistakes with Maisey and start again as friends. The damage to her heart and self-esteem is deep, Rafe has an uphill battle.There is a mystery in this novel, one that could make or break this family for good. There are twists and turns on every page and the suspense won't let you put the book down. The romance is very satisfying and the mystery is solved quite dramatically. If you like romantic suspense/mysteries this is a great example!I received this ARC from the publisher and NetGalley for and honest review.Pat Fordyce

3.5 StarsMaya Farlow is back in Fool's Gold after ten years. She moved back after her network producing job in L.A. was getting too easy.....she needed a change. Mayor Marsha offered her the position of Communication Director to promote their new campaign, Fool's Gold: Destination For Romance. Maya remembers her first romance in Fool's Gold, which has never left her heart, but she ran away from it. Being back floods her with memories. She's producing a video campaign and there is a celebrity spokesperson. The celebrity is Del Mitchell, the love she ran way from.Del Mitchell is known for his Extreme Sports competitions. He designed specialized equipment, started a company, then sold it for an excellent price. He's back home to visit family and help with the family business for the summer. Agreeing to do the video campaign he was stopped in his tracks when he saw Maya. The last time he saw her she was eighteen, engaged to marry him, and then she was gone. He never forgot her. Both Maya and Del are determined not to become "involved," but......Fool's Gold has a reputation.....I enjoyed this story and the characters of Fool's Gold, especially Eddie and Gladys. I am afraid that these stories are becoming a little formulaic and don't grab my attention as they used to. For me, they're enjoyable but somewhat predictable.I received this ARC from the publisher and Netgalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

The Unfolding  A Late Bloomers Short Story  Betsy TalbotThis is a quick introduction to the women, best friends since childhood, that make up the Late Bloomers. Violet, Daisy, Rose, Ivy and Lilly were raised by Moms who were best friends and lived in a commune.....hence the flower names.  They communicate frequently, all in their 40's, and in times of crisis they are always together. It's New Year's Eve in New York City and the women are lamenting the surprise divorce of Lily. Lily is a M.D. and works with Doctors Without Borders and seldom in the U.S. She's on a break and contemplating what to do next, but Lilly knows it must be with her best friends/sisters. Especially since there answer to most difficulties is "We need food, drink and sexy men to get through this crisis.......STAT!"  Each of the women are leading different lives and careers but their sisterhood is part of their soul.This series, the first being Wild Rose, takes us on a journey to Italy. I loved the beautiful love story in Wild Rose and the quiet strength of Rose. Second in the series is English Ivy, definitely looking forward to the trip to London and somewhat feisty Ivy!It's wonderful to read novels about mature women, because I am one! I would grab Wild Rose so you'll be ready for English Ivy.......Pat Fordyce

3.5 StarsKylie Edwards was on the way to her wedding in a limo with her three best friends. Sara and Ashlyn were bubbling with excitement but Jan was strangely quiet. After a few minutes Jan started to cry and told her she had slept with Kylie's fiancé Brett. She now had two best friends and never made it to the church. Her lying, cheating fiance, CEO of Trident industries was gone. Since her father was a CEO of a design firm and seemed to follow the exact same pattern, she was off men with money and credentials. She was an designer in her Dad's firm, but knew she would never make partner. Sara and Ash were dragging her to Vegas with them. A Romance Lovers Convention was scheduled, Ash was a romance writer, and convinced Kylie's Dad to let her present the new design plans for the Masquerade Hotel while she was there. Ash and Sara are determined to get Kylie out of her slump.Jake Royale is the owner CEO of Masquerade Casino. Jake had never had a relationship that ended up centering on him, only on his money and name. He was done with that.  When literally bumping into a very attractive woman who thought he was head of security his immediate thought was no strings, hot weekend. Little did he know this woman, Kylie, had told him her name was Ash, and she was there for the convention. No strings turns into a lot of messy knots!This was a sexy enjoyable read, but the twists and turns were a little confusing at times, especially with a couple other story lines introduced. Still a very fun read.I received this ARC from the publisher and Netgalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce5 Stars

This book should come with a warning label!  "Very Hot.....Proceed With Caution!"Young lovers Seth and Rowan are inseparable, until a tragic night tears them apart. Seth ends up going to prison for something he didn't do, trying to protect her and her brother, Jase. Rowan is suddenly alone, again, when her brother and Seth go to prison. Everyone important in her life eventually leaves her.Seven years later, Seth is in the Marines and realizes how his anger and cruelty nearly destroyed both of them. He needs to see her and beg her forgiveness and prove he has never stopped loving her.Rowan is strong independent and needs no one. Least of all the man she unfortunately still loves, but refuses to accept back in her life. Seth won't give up, but how long can he take Rowan's biting remarks, acting like he's invisible and belittling comments.  He breaks down her barriers and they do have sex.....but that's all it is sex, and she immediately returns to her hard cold ways.This was an emotional read for me. They both had their hearts broken, but they were so young. Seth survived prison, lived through deployments in Afghanistan and other dangerous places and finally realized what he needed to do to get his life back on course. Rowan has grown up, made a good life for herself, but just can't find it in her heart to forgive and move on. I'm afraid at times I wanted to shake Rowan and scream "listen!"This is a very sexy, at times heartbreaking novel. It's the first in a series and the second revolves around Rowan's brother Jase. I recommend this sizzling read, but you might need to keep a glass of ice water near by.I received this book from the publisher and NetGalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

The Strongest Steel  A Second Circle Tattoos Novel  Scarlett ColeI LOVED this book. Now that I have said that, I will try and review this amazing story.Harper Connelly works in a coffee shop in South Beach, does not interact with many people, only her best friend Drea and the owner Jose. Drea pretty much bullied her way into her life and now Harper doesn't know what she would do without her. Harper survived a life threatening brutal attack seven years ago. Though her body has recovered, her heart and soul and life have not. She wears clothes that make her invisible and the slightest touch, even accidentally, can send her into a panic attack.She wants to take back her life and prove she's strong and takes the unlikeliest route you would suspect.Trent Andrews is the co-owner of Second Circle Tattoo. He was mentored and taught the art of tattooing by Jr. Silver who recently passed away. Now he and Cujo, Trent's best friend from childhood are working their dream. Trent is a very good looking guy who enjoys women, beer and creating his masterpieces. He is well know for his amazing talent of tattooing over scars to cover them. At 1:00 AM on a very chilly morning as he's locking up, a young woman appears. She is small, very timid, and ready to run at the slightest hint of trouble. He reluctantly lets her in the shop, and his life is changed forever. Harper explains her wish to cover her scars. When Trent takes a look at her scars he is torn between rage that someone could do this to another person, sympathy for all she had been through and an overwhelming feeling to protect her.This is a novel that will grab you from the first few pages. It is sensual, with amazing characters, a bit of suspense, and one of the most beautiful love stories I have read this year. It is definitely on my list of best reads for 2015. I can't wait for the second in this series.Pat Fordyce

Dina Greene is running from her heartbreaking past. The only way she gets momentary relief, is meaningless hook-ups with various men. Never the same, never more than once. It's dangerous, demeaning and not helping. On one particular evening, in Nightcaps, her favorite bar, she catches the attention of Ryan Wilde, a local plastic surgeon who is drawn to help her. He issues a challenge to her. Four weeks of dating, no sex and he will prove to her how worthwhile she really is.  He sweeps her off her feet, always there, always kind. They visit museums, take long walks and visit winery's, enjoying each other's company.  On one particular night, he actually saves her life. Dina wasn't answering her phone, and Ryan feared she gave up on him, but found her nearly comatose with a possibly rupturing appendix.  Everything changed.Dina went home to Ryan's and let him take care of her. Her sleep was interrupted by a nightmare that has repeated often and terrifies her and Ryan held her while she cried. To help her, he needed the truth. So for the first time, she told her story.  Their relationship grew and they became even closer, until jealousy reared it's very ugly head and threatened the growing love between them.This was a very emotional story that also combines characters from Melissa Foster's series The Remington's.  It is a very enjoyable read and I highly recommend it.I received this ARC from the author and publisher for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

This is a very entertaining romantic suspense novel about an uptown girl and a rough town boy.Leanne Weston is her best friends Maid of Honor for her wedding and she has done a lot of studying  to make it perfect. All was well, until the groom's estranged half-brother shows up and kisses the bride. Leanne takes it upon her self to get rid of this leather wearing, motorcycle riding very hot disturbance. He agrees to leave but only after a searing kiss with Leanne.  She certainly hopes she never lays eyes on Jake Montez again........well, for a long time. Two weeks later she is bailing him out of jail. The only one around who was available.  Jake has become a mystery she is intrigued with.Jake Montez, former Army M.P, former Houston police officer, now private investigator in Philadelphia, is just as intrigued with Leanne, interior designer. He feels she is too good for him, and he is no good for her, but life has different ideas. After a mugging outside of her office, her purse and briefcase are stolen and she is knocked to the ground. Her best friend Eve, wife of Sam, Jake's half-brother, arrives on the scene with Jake. The police have arrived and are investigating. Relatively unhurt, Jake is planning on following Leanne to make sure she gets home safe. It turns out home is not safe at all. Her apartment is trashed and Leanne is frightened. All of a sudden, Jake doesn't want her out of his sight. She could get used to that.I loved this story, the characters are engaging, there are a lot of laughs, danger and sexy times. It can be read as a stand alone, but I am going back and read the first in the series Bringing Down Sam because it looks equally enjoyable! I received this book from the author for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Zara Hamilton is young woman who lost her cousin/ best friend to suicide and is out for blind revenge. The victim of her revenge? A young English Literature professor. She believes he seduced Karly, then threw her away when he found out she was pregnant. Zara has transferred to the university where he teaches and starts her plan to ruin him.Zara is living with her boyfriend Dillon. They have been dating for the last two years, and he was also friends with Karly. Since her death, things haven't been the same. He parties and drinks...a lot. Zara steps up her seduction of Noah Bain the professor and believes is the reason for Karly's suicide. She texts, calls and pretty much throws herself at him, and is getting a response.  The problem is, she is starting to like him, he's caring and gentle, he actually seems to want to help her. But, she needs her revenge. She sets up a scenario that will definitely ruin him. To her absolute amazement, she's having second thoughts. But the decision to expose him is taken out of her hands.Noah Bain is a young up and coming English professor, who truly loves teaching. He has been living with his girlfriend Shannon since their graduation, but Noah feels  is starting to feel there is something missing. Zara's attention has caught him off guard, he's constantly fighting his attraction and trying to avoid her. He starts realizing he cares for her deeply, but doesn't know what to do about it. Soon his personal life and his career are threatened.  It only gets worse. Shocking twists and turns in the last few chapters threaten all that Zara and Noah believe.I found I had a hard time liking these characters. Zara with her anger and seductions and Noah with his weaknesses. The story is told in alternating chapters by Noah and Zara so it's interesting to get inside their heads.  An interesting read with an ending that was a surprise to me.I received this book from the publisher and NetGalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Killian O'Brien is an MMA fighter that owns a training gym with his brothers and sister."The O'Briens were plentiful and embodied the term 'Fighter Instinct'. You mess with one, you messed with most of Philadelphia."  Growing up in Phillie he became best friends with Mateo Tres Santo, ( Once Perfect) and looked out for Teo's sister Sofia. Sofia had a huge crush on Killian and was a pretty happy go-lucky girl, until a tragedy in high school tore her life apart. The next two years she spent aimlessly trying to feel emotions and affection in a dangerous way. Finally, she pulled herself together, started college and worked web design to help earn money while studying interior design. There is no trace of the happy young girl any more. She is very shy, frightened of her own shadow and ashamed.Sofia has agreed to help Killian with his web page and social media. Living with her Mom back in the old neighborhood, brings back a lot of memories......some good some bad. Working closely with Killian has reawakened her old feelings for him and his shameless flirting makes her smile. She's tired of always being afraid and Killian makes her feel beautiful and wanted. He vows to protect her from being hurt ever again.This is an engaging story about families, best friends and responsibilities. How do you make up for past mistakes? This novel can be read as a stand alone, but much more enjoyable if you have read the first two, Once Driven and Once Perfect. The story lines and characters cross frequently.  Ms. Robson has once again captured my attention with these wonderful characters.Pat Fordyce

This is the newest novel by Ms. Miles set in Dare Valley, Colorado and loved by her readers. I'm no exception.Blake Cunningham lost the love of his life, Natalie Hale, when her best friend and sister-in-law, Kim passed away from cancer. Nat suffered an emotional shutdown. She needed to be numb, away from people who would try to smother or fix her. She had to get away from Blake. So, they divorced, she moved back to Dare Valley, surrounded by family and works as the head caterer for the Grand Mountain Hotel. She is working on her grief, but it's always there.Blake Cunningham, NFL quarterback, has not stopped hoping for a second chance. He will do anything. Making up his mind, he retires from the NFL, moves to Dare Valley and makes winning back Nat his highest priority. Blake's brother, Aaron, who had Downs Syndrome and was Blake's inspiration in all he did, recently passed away from heart failure. Now that he's retired it's time to think about the future. He's planning a football camp at a local university for intellectually disabled children, staffed by all his buddies from his playing days and honoring Aaron. Natalie doesn't even know he has moved until a bridge appears between her property and next door. The first thing she sees is Touchdown her beagle she stills adores. Next, Blake appears. He makes no secret of his plans. He wants to share Touchdown and prove to her they still love each other. She feels a spark at his words, maybe it's time.This novel is a very romantic love story. Blake is sweet, gorgeous and totally in love with Nat, which he tries to prove in every way he can. Nat is afraid, stubborn and still very attracted to Blake, but still pushes him away. I did want to shake her on occasion for not seeing the love right in front of her!  A very enjoyable read, and I'm looking forward to the next visit to Dare Valley.I received this ARC from the publisher for an honest review.Pat Fordyce  Five Stars

This is the second in a series and Ms. Covington again treats us to fascinating characters, sexy scenes and a strong female heroine.Carlisle Queen barely survived a terrorist attack; a bombing that cost the life of her lover and best friend and left her with shrapnel imbedded perilously close to her spine that could paralyze her or end her life. Not the life this young Olympic Medalist swimmer expected for herself. Carlyle suffers in constant pain she relieves with marijuana, heavy duty pain pills ( legal and illegal) and the oblivion they offer her. She also loves the release random sex gives her. Carlisle lives with the knowledge that someday she will be paralyzed and has decided she cannot live that way, and when the time comes she will take her own life. She has moved to Nashville to go to college, mainly to distance her self from her overprotective and smothering parents.Mateo Butler is a TA for Spanish at the university. He just so happens to have Carlisle in his class. He is fascinated by her and feels a hint of attraction from Carlisle. Her name around campus is Ice Queen. He is unsure what his life will be, he has planned to go to medical school, but the death of his beloved sister from a brain tumor has derailed his plans and left him floundering. Carlisle finally shows up at a party at his home and the Ice Queen seems to be warming up to him. They agree to a one night stand, but that night was HOT, and Mateo wants to more. He learns more about her life, pain and the need for drugs. He is not going away.Suddenly a Doctor offers a possible miracle. Should she risk it, or live or die the way she is? I can't imagine a life living with chronic pain or the threat of sudden death. Carlisle is an amazing, strong, stubborn heroine. The more time Mateo spends with Carlisle, the more he learns more about what type of man he is. Some interaction with the characters from Redemption (Nashville Nights Book #1) adds a nice touch. This is a thought provoking novel with sizzle and romance. I highly recommend it.I received this eBook from the publisher for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

This novel is the start of a new series by Ms. Valentine but filled with friends from Holland Springs.Kate Von Lichenstein has been fair game for paparazzi since she was sixteen. Daughter of a Baron, her family well connected to the Romanov's, the cameras and voices were always surrounding her. She recently inherited billions of dollars from her grandparents trust and was terrified of the fortune hunters and publicity that will take over her life.Noah Sawyer had met Kate briefly before, but was very happy to see her at the latest Romanov wedding, Sebastian and Daisy's. Kate seemed stressed and he had certainly had a very bad day, so he whisked her away for an intimate dinner. Noah had lost a lot of money when his thieving accountant took off. His business needed a influx of money quickly, but  he wasn't going to think about it now that he was with Kate. They had barely arrived at the restaurant when Kate shocked him to the core. She wanted to marry him! A marriage to save Kate from the fallout of her inheritance and perhaps save Noah's business. After some discussion and serious thought, he agreed to marry Kate, but this was not going to be a "paper" marriage. He insisted on being a real husband.They gradually realized how compatible they were, the sex was hot and they actually liked each other. Until outside forces pushed them to doubt themselves and their marriage. Her family would stop at nothing to tear them apart and almost succeeded.The story takes us to London and Holland Springs. The characters old and new are very enjoyable. I enjoy friends to lovers stories and this is a perfect example.I received this eBook from the publisher for an honest review.Pat Fordyce  4 Stars

Chaos and Moonlight  (The Order of The Nines Book 1)  AD MarrowThis novel, first in a new series, has unforgettable romance, laughter and cringe-worthy violence ( mostly) against the bad guys. Did I mention Vampires? The action starts on the first page and I think I was holding my breath for the last few.Taris is the Leader of the Nines, a group of vampires hundreds of years old and dying off. They intermingled blood with humans for so many years, it has left their females barren and if nothing is done to change this, his breed will die out. They have tried and studied many solutions but none seem to be the cure. He watches a TV report about a new discovery that is supposed to help people with rejection problems from transplants. That's it! Their cure is in their sights if he can get to the scientist before the other group of vampires who want to achieve domination of the humans and chaos to the world.Dr.'s Sara Bridgeman and Nick Patton are partners in this life changing discovery. The interview with investigative journalist Maven Jensen, who thinks she is queen of the universe goes terribly wrong. Nick was supposed to do the interview but was sick. The result of this disaster has Sarah and Nick out of their job at the hospital research facility. She arrives home exhausted and broken hearted and falls immediately asleep.She is awakened by a tall dark and devastatingly handsome man who tells her he is rescuing her and proceeds to kidnap her.  It seems he really was rescuing her as another group of big terrifying men are chasing them. This is only the first few chapters!This story is full of fascinating characters, families in upheaval and a few laugh out loud moments. The love story will melt your heart. If you like reading vampire stories, with lots of large, sometimes very angry alpha men and scary strong beautiful  women you must read this book. I personally couldn't put it down, and can't wait for Book 2.I received this ARC from the author and publisher for an honest review.Pat FordyceThis novel, first in a new series, has unforgettable romance, laughter and cringe-worthy violence ( mostly) against the bad guys. Did I mention Vampires? The action starts on the first page and I think I was holding my breath for the last few.Taris is the Leader of the Nines, a group of vampires hundreds of years old and dying off. They intermingled blood with humans for so many years, it has left their females barren and if nothing is done to change this, his breed will die out. They have tried and studied many solutions but none seem to be the cure. He watches a TV report about a new discovery that is supposed to help people with rejection problems from transplants. That's it! Their cure is in their sights if he can get to the scientist before the other group of vampires who want to achieve domination of the humans and chaos to the world.Dr.'s Sara Bridgeman and Nick Patton are partners in this life changing discovery. The interview with investigative journalist Maven Jensen, who thinks she is queen of the universe goes terribly wrong. Nick was supposed to do the interview but was sick. The result of this disaster has Sarah and Nick out of their job at the hospital research facility. She arrives home exhausted and broken hearted and falls immediately asleep.She is awakened by a tall dark and devastatingly handsome man who tells her he is rescuing her and proceeds to kidnap her.  It seems he really was rescuing her as another group of big terrifying men are chasing them. This is only the first few chapters!This story is full of fascinating characters, families in upheaval and a few laugh out loud moments. The love story will melt your heart. If you like reading vampire stories, with lots of large, sometimes very angry alpha men and scary strong beautiful  women you must read this book. I personally couldn't put it down, and can't wait for Book 2.I received this ARC from the author and publisher for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

After the War  ( Homefront #2)  Jessica ScottMs. Scott writes military romance that grabs you heart, your emotions and wrings them out. After the War is no exception.Captain Sarah Anders is stationed at Fort Hood after a training accident left her injured and fired from her previous position. Saying it wasn't her fault never cuts it. She is a widow, her husband died in Iraq and a single Mom of five year old Anna. Sarah has given the army everything, her husband, her loyalty and very nearly her life. When does it get easier? Not with Major Wilson in charge.  Major Wilson "ruled by fear and intimidation" especially with other females. Instead of giving these women a hand up, she was pushing them away . "Never in her life had Sarah imagined that being a parent and a soldier would be pulling her in completely different directions."Lt. Sean Nichols has a history with Sarah, and when they are thrown together for an investigation their past together is brought to the forefront. Sean and Sarah were very young, in love and Sean wanted to get married, but in his eyes, Sarah had to leave the Army. She loved the Army and it was her career, Sarah wasn't giving it up. Two hearts are broken.  This time when they meet they are war weary, discouraged and both so changed.The case they are working on becomes more and more complicated, the only benefit is their spending more time together and talking. Sean has a secret that is eating him alive, he's afraid what will happen if he reveals it.To me, being a female in the Army is hard enough; losing your husband, caring for your child and doing your job makes it more difficult. To have superiors making it harder is just appalling to me.  The romance is hot and spicy, second chance love always seems sweeter. I cried, I laughed and couldn't stop turning pages.I received an ARC from the author for an honest review.Pat Fordyce  Five Stars

This is the third novel in the Ethan Frost series by Ms. Wolff. It is my favorite.Ethan and Chloe have finally worked through Ethan's anger and Chloe's fear. The one danger in their relationship is Brandon, Ethan's brother. We learned in the first two books in the series of his cruelty, her family's cruelty and even Ethan's responsibility for hurting Chloe. Chloe wants to put it away and start fresh, she begs Ethan to let it go for her sake........but he can't.Now that they are together again, Ethan has planned a quick getaway to Las Vegas to get married.  Chloe's best friend Tori has invited herself along and whisks Chloe off for a day of buying and spa treatments. Ethan's PI has reported more dirt about Brandon. He's hooked into the Vegas Mafia, he's a serious gambler, thus the need for mob money, and Chloe is not his only victim.  It's tearing Ethan apart to know his brother is now running for Congress with endorsements he set up before he learned the truth. Ethan is going to take him down.This novel is edgy, very sexy and romantic. Ethan has promised to not lie to Chloe anymore, and Chloe has promised to stop running away. These promises are hard to keep, especially when the unthinkable happens and brings Ethan to his knees. This series makes you think, the romance melts your heart while sparks are flying. I highly recommend these books , but they are best read in order.Pat Fordyce

Holt Cunningham is a former marine injured by an IED in Iraq. He suffers from severe brain trauma and is lucky to be alive. Sometimes he wonders about that. He gets severe migraines, occasionally has difficulty putting words together and only gets short term relief from from meds. He's decided he likes booze and one night stands better. He is lucky to have an IT job with the Schilling Agency, thanks to a friend, and tries to keep most of his difficulties private.Lydia Thomas is, by her on words, a good girl. She just broke up with her current boyfriend after he slept with one of her friends. Of course it was her fault because she wouldn't "put out." Lydia is in a bar and spots the ex.  She heads to order a drink and sits next to a very hunky guys with nerdy glasses. She builds up her nerve and asks him to kiss her. He's a little reluctant, but when she explains, he's all in. They both are shaken to their souls. She wants more, he wants to take her home. A very hot night together, with a little of his Dom showing, which Lydia seems to enjoy. She was gone by morning, leaving a note. Holt, surprising himself, realizes he wants more.  That is, until he finds out Lydia is his best friends little sister.This is a very sexy, romantic story. Neither of them wants to admit it feels like love, but Lydia can't get over how good it feels to take care of someone who needs her. She accepts him with all his problems and for the first time in his life someone really cares. It's very enjoyable to watch Lydia and Holt work things out.I received this book from the publishers and NetGalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Cynthia Henley is the C in DMC Solutions. It's a company that manages media support, graphic design and party planning. She has two step-sisters, Dee Dee and Maddie and they are the event planners. Her sisters call her Cinderella because she is the dependable all work no play sister. Cynthia's mother passed away and her Dad remarried Joanie Cash who had twin daughters who immediately fell in love with Cynthia as their "little" sister. No cruel stepmother or step-sisters, but Cinderella she was. When she was in high school she had a major crush on Eric Anders as did all the other girls. He grew up to be a championship rodeo rider but an injury ended his career. He recently fell in love with a young woman and her baby, and had settled down. ( The Cowboy Next Door.)  Chad ( Eric's brother) and Eric have started a Charitable Foundation called Building Tomorrow. They are working with local teacher /builder Logan Stafford to finance his student staffed work re-habbing old homes for low income owners, (Finding Home.) Chad has asked Cynthia to do a fund raiser dance called The Fixer-Upper . She is handling all the media work, her sisters are supposed to be event planning, but,  Dee Dee got a call to head to NY for a modeling job and Maddie broke her ankle. So, and as usual, Cynthia does it all. The more time she spends with Chad, the more attracted to him she is, but she knows she is too plain and quiet for him, not to mention the debilitating stutter that appears when she is stressed.This story was very enjoyable to read, but I wanted to bang Cynthia's and Chad's heads together a couple times. So stubborn!  This is a great series by Ms. Snopek, especially when we get to revisit old friends in each book.I received this ARC from the publisher and Netgalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Hold Me  ( Fools Gold #16)Destiny Mills works for a software company training search and rescue teams to use their system. She travels a lot, but enjoys it and is quick to make friends for the three months she is typically in one place. She's not found a place that pulls her to settle down yet. Fool's Fold is a nice little town, but she's warned early that "everybody know's everybody's business." Her parents were country music stars, and habitually falling in love and marrying. Destiny was raised by her grandmother, and learned very early to stay out of the limelight. She loved to sing, but didn't want the hassle of the notoriety.  Just before leaving from Fool's Gold, Destiny learned she had a fifteen year old half-sister whose mother has died and their father is in Europe.  Destiny is shocked but willing to give her a home for the summer.Kipling Gilmore is an Olympic skier known by the nickname G-Force. One year ago, he was nearly killed in a devastating accident on the slopes. Mayor Marsha convinced him that Fool's Gold needed him, especially since his sister Shelby was there.  He's recovered and is now heading up the search and rescue team called HERO ( Help Emergency Rescue Operations.)  He's settling in, made some friends and likes the pace.  He and Destiny fall into an easy friendship, although Kipling is having some stirrings of attraction.Meanwhile Destiny becomes one of the regulars of Jo's bar, and meets the wives and women of Fool's Gold.  Starr, her sister is going through some team age angst and Destiny is not sure what to do. She enjoys being with Kipling a lot more than she expected, and is trying very hard not to fall for him.We reconnect with all the friends in Fool's Gold. Lots of pregnancies, and a little bit of men vs. women fighting for their own territory. As always a very enjoyable romance filled with laughter and love.I received this novel from the publisher and Edelweiss for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

This is a delightful, funny and romantic novel where we meet Beth Avery, a former party planner running from a family disaster and Rylan Cates, a Team Captain for the baseball team the Richmond Rogues.  They are in Old Barefoot William, Florida for spring training and it happens to be Rylan's home town.Beth is in desperate need of a job, so she's very anxious for this interview to go right. Rylan needs a PA to keep his appointments straight, plan some events and take care of his dogs. Not exactly what she hoped for, but workable. The dogs are a Great Dane called Atlas, a golden retriever named Rue, and two daschunds named Oscar and Nathan.  Atlas is the Alpha Dog and leads the pack, his favorite game is playing dead in the middle of the street. The dogs eat only homemade organic food made from the Organic Canine Cookbook. I have to say, some of the food sounded delicious!Rylan needs help for eight weeks during spring training, then will be moving back to Richmond for the regular season. He has done several interviews, one person ran from the house when she saw Atlas. He is thrilled when Beth agrees to the job. She's tiny and quirky and the dogs love her. She is not his type at all, so attraction is not an issue......who was he kidding?We meet some of the players, particularly Halo and Landon, who are pranksters that spend their down time getting in trouble. They both love Beth, so do their best to convince Rylan to take the plunge. It's not too long before he doesn't need any convincing. This is the latest in the Barefoot William's stories and definitely worth a read. It can be read as a stand alone, but the Cates family are so much fun, I'm starting back at Book 1.I received this novel from Kensington Publishing and NetGalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Cole Easton MMA fighter is fighting for the light heavy weight championship against a rival he wants to defeat, but also cause him pain. De'Grasse has spread malicious rumors about Cole and these stories are threatening his career.  Cole's fans erupt when he gets De'Grasse to tap out and Cole is celebrating in the ring. He suddenly feels a searing pain in his back and his legs go cold. Waking up in a hospital, he is told he has a broken back and with a lot of therapy, he might walk again, all thanks to a very illegal kick from De'Grasse. So Cole (Easton the Beast of the East) fears his career is over. After a lengthy time in rehab. he is showing some improvement, but needs to get out of the hospital and back to the real world. His manager, Marcus, has the best solution. His niece, a top notch physical therapist, has agreed to take over his rehab and get him ready to fight again. He is not happy when he finds it is Somerset, Wisconsin.Katrina Miller is forever grateful to her Uncle Marcus for helping her in the worst time of her life. She can't refuse him anything. When she meets angry, frustrated, sarcastic and drop dead gorgeous Cole Easton she's having second thoughts! Cole wants to fight to keep his title, but he wants to be on his feet tomorrow, but there is a lot of work to be done. He is fascinated by Katrina, a very strong beautiful woman who flinches every time he gets near her. He knows there has to be a terrible story to explain it, but the spark between them makes him want to keep trying. She's hiding something, and he feels the need to protect her. When some random malicious pranks start happening, she realizes her worst nightmare has found her and life is going to get dangerous. But Cole has crept into her heart and is keeping her strong.These characters and their story, make this book impossible to put down. The very hot romance, suspense and Cole's struggle to walk again pull you in and the pages fly by.  If you enjoy reading about MMA fighters, I highly recommend this book.I received this ARC from the publisher and NetGalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

This novel is set in Cornetta, a tiny kingdom on the Bay of Biscay. There is a lot of action in this short story, including a second chance at love.Brenna Tindley and Willow Arden run a public relations business. A few years ago to escape a very difficult time in Brenna's life, they left Raleigh, North Carolina and flew to Cornetta.  It was a beautiful little island that Brenna visited several years ago, and couldn't forget. Willow was pregnant at the time, the baby's father out of the picture, so she was very willing to escape from Raleigh.  Brenna is the public face of their firm, Willow the researcher and handles logistics and details. They work very well together. The Royal Family is the Vicenza's. Queen Esme, two son's Emory who is the heir apparent, and Ronan. Ronan has the reputation of a ladies man, although he feels the press exaggerates some of his exploits.Emory, thinking his microphone is turned off, makes a very controversial statement at a gathering, which immediately goes viral.  His reputation is going to be ruined. Ronan suggests contacting the PR team of Tindley-Arden to try and hopefully turn the terrible press around. Nine years ago, he met Brenna while she was touring before college, he had just graduated from college. They spent three carefree months together, Brenna only knowing him as Ron Vee and falling hard for him. One day, he was gone. Only recently did she find out Ron, was Ronan of the Royal family. Her life had taken many turns since that amazing summer, she saw no chance of going back.This is a very enjoyable read, my only disappointment  was that it was so short. There was a lot of story lines going in, and some felt rushed.  This is the first novel I have read by Ms. O'Brien, but I will be looking for more.I received this ARC from Tule Publishing and Netgalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Charlie Ryan had been let down by too many men in her life. Her Dad when he left them when she was an infant and her fiancé, caught on her couch with his secretary. Out of the blue she hears from a lawyer who tells her she has inherited a ranch in Montana from a grandmother she never knew she had. She had very little money (thanks to her fiancé) was living with her Mom, difficult at best, so she packed up and headed to Broken Falls, Montana. The ranch was called Tucked Away, and it certainly was. Finally reaching the ranch, running out of gas in the driveway, she meets Tommy Lee....a huge bull not happy to see her, who held her prisoner in her very hot car for an hour. Rescued by the foreman, Clay, tall dark and gorgeous, who pronounces her a "City Girl" and not in a good way. Just because she had on a silk blouse, high heel boots and carried a Coach bag and was terrified of mice and killer Bulls?  Her ranch life has begun.I really enjoyed this story! The beginning is lighthearted and laugh out loud funny. Charlie meets the characters, including the animals, and a very handsome Vet. She even helps deliver a calf....covered in blood and slobber.  Charlie learns more about her Grandmother, Gigi, well loved by the town and has a very strong relationship with a teen-ager from the next ranch. Her name is Sophie and she has amazing skills, learned from Gigi. She comes to love the ranch, and often feels the presence of Gigiin some magical ways. There are undercurrents of mystery surrounding Tucked Away, strange occurrences that get more dangerous. A railroad company that persistently wants her to sell, falling in love with Zack the local veterinarian and more and more about her family.This is a great read with Cowboys, lots of sweet and not so sweet farm animals anda sizzling love story, add some danger and suspense and you have an excellent story.I received this ARC from Entangled Publishing and Netgalley for an honest review.Pat Fordyce

Laura Florand writes very romantic love stories often set in one of the most beautiful cities in the world, Paris. Her descriptions of the sights and sounds draw you in and make you feel you are there. This novel is no exception, but, you might want to read this close to a source of chocolate!Celie grew up in a small town called Les Tarterets, that is infamous for drug dealers, users and heartache. She worked in a pastry shop as a teen, and had a huge crush on her brothers friend Joss. He treated her like a little sister and protected her from the danger in the streets, and even her own brother, who was arrested for drug dealing. Then after walking her home after work, he said goodnight, and the next morning he was gone. Not just gone, he joined the French Foreign Legion. Now, five years later she is the Chef Chocolatier for Dom Richard in Paris. She has won many awards, and she feels liking working in the shop is like "working in heaven." She has made something of her life, all on her own. Not a day goes by that she doesn't think of Josh, where he is, or if he's alive. Then one day, he is there. Waiting outside the shop.Josh regrets having to leave Celie five years ago, but she was only eighteen, he was a man, although a poor excuse for one as far as he was concerned. He went away, risked his life, became a hardened Legionnaire finished his commitment, and was done. He came back for Celie, hoping to prove he is worth her love now.  But Celie can't forget his leaving without a word, sent him cards for six months and he never wrote back. This relationship is not going to be easy, although they are widely attracted to each other. Stubbornness, lack of true communication and Celie's need for independence threaten both their hope and dreams.This is such a delightful story, and including Dom Richard and his fiancé Jamie Corey( The Chocolate Touch) makes it even more fun. As I said at the start, keep chocolate nearby, your going to need it.I received this ARC from the author for an honest review.Pat Fordyce  Five Stars

This novel starts by wreaking havoc on your emotions from page one. The story alternates between the present and summers in Wilmington, North Carolina some ten years ago. A boy and a girl flirting and falling in love over summer vacations; they were all wrong for each other, the poor maid's daughter, and the son of rich parents, with his Dad seeking political office. Outside influences work to tear them apart and are successful, but they meet again as adultsMia Galdon is a teenager that lives for summers. Her mother is a maid in the Covington Mansion, and she spends vacations helping her alcoholic Mom and taking care of her little sister, Ginny, who was born with Downs Syndrome. The Covington children enjoy her being around and often invite her to activities. But, she always feels out of place and uncomfortable, except with Cole Covington. Each summer as they get older, Mia and Cole are more attracted to each other. Cole is a typical teenager, he has an older brother, who he looks up to and a younger sister he watches out for. Cole is falling in love with Mia and she with him. After an amazing night spent together, with promises made, their lives fall apart. Tragedy, rejection and heartbreak send Mia away.In the present, Cole and Mia have not spoken in years. She has her RN and Ginny is in a good school and thriving. She is called by Lacey Covington with horrifying news. Cole has been severely injured in Iraq, and begs Mia's help. He has shut himself away, refusing medications, physical therapy, doesn't eat and never leaves his house.  What could Mia possibly do to help? She has never been able to forget him, how could she put herself through all that pain again. Lacey makes it impossible to refuse, so Mia agrees and hopes to finally put Cole out of her life.This is the first in a new series, and I'm looking forward to book two.  I'm enjoying the Wilmington location, I live very close and love the beach.Pat Fordyce

Mason Lawson is a former SEAL, severely wounded and very angry. Angry he is alive and his fellow SEAL's are not, angry that he's in severe pain, angry his family is interfering in his fall to the bottom of a bottle. Add a new neighbor who has the nerve to teach music to local children in her home, making irritatingly loud noise and he's becoming undone. The only beating heart he can tolerate around him is his therapy dog Bomber. He is constantly by Mason's side, not lecturing or feeling sorry for him.Skylar Jernigan was raised in the Carnie with her Dad. Her mother left when she was a child, and they moved constantly. Her Dad finally found a job with a paper mill, and they set down roots. But her Dad succumbed to one of the poisonous chemicals they used, and Skylar was on her own. She wandered for a while, then moved to Jessamine, bought a house and set down roots. She supported herself by teaching music and being a substitute teacher at the local school. Life seemed pretty normal until she finally met the "grumpy old man" next door. It was not a pleasant meeting, but after hearing Mason's story her natural instincts to help kicked in. Despite his constant complaining and bickering.There is a beautiful love story in this book, the build up only makes it sweeter. Before Mason realizes it, he needs Skylar more than he needs to breathe. The banter and quips between these two are hysterical and I found myself really falling for Mason. Skylar becomes friends with one of the McCoy sisters, Lemon, and even takes a road trip to Holland Springs.  The one thing Mason can't push from his mind is his life as a SEAL and he feels he is a danger to Skylar. He turns away, but knows it will destroy him.  The epilogue......sigh...... is perfect. If your a fan of Ms. Valentine's books, you will love this visit with the Lawson brothers. If your not, what are you waiting for?  Grab this book.

Don’t expect any displays of deductive genius here. In fact, don’t expect to find any traditional mystery here at all. There’s no body in the library – no darts dipped in curare – no snakes sent coiling down bedposts to a victim’s jugular in the middle of the night.This is about the aging Sherlock Holmes’ attempts to remember why he quit being a private consultant. As his memory fails after WWII, he tries to reconstruct the last case he took just after WWI, and the reason he decided it would be his last case.Even though there are none of Holmes’ trademark observations here - this movie is well worth watching. It’s beautifully photographed, poignantly acted – and a testament to the human spirit.

This psychological thriller gets its suspense from a glance, a look. It doesn’t depend on approaching jump-scares to keep you on the edge of your seat – although there might be a few of those. Rather, most of the suspense comes from its characters’ unsettled looks. They sense something that is going to send their lives tilt. They know something intuitively that they can’t quite articulate, can't quite admit. Even the family dog’s prolonged, doleful look will send chills down your spine.The plot evolves in the direction of a classic tale of revenge. However, who is going to get revenge on whom – or who deserves to get revenge on whom – and the why and how of it – will keep you guessing. This is an intelligent, engrossing film.

Ramsey Campbell seems as if he hasn’t sequestered himself in a room, writing all day. Rather, the keen metaphors he conjures here suggest that he’s the kind of writer who has garnered a wide experience of everyday life. It seems as if he walks around in an ordinary neighborhood, observing ordinary details, then comes home and does ordinary chores. He compares the whirling clothes in a laundry machine to “dervishes.” His windows “drooled” in the rain. He observes how a girl’s parents were waiting “on the lit stage of the porch.” The porch itself reminds him of a refrigerator as the light flicks on and off with the coming and going of the home’s inhabitants. Doors snap shut “like disapproving lips.” The shadow of the church spire “made the village square into a sun dial – 11:00 at Millie’s Woolens.”However, Campbell brings to this familiarity with the common bricks and mortar of life – a sense of the sinister that inhabits the homely. “The dark fireplaces looked ominous, prosceniums awaiting a cue.” “A roofless house stood like a rotten tooth.” “Gray clouds crawled grub-like across the sky.” The mass of clouds “had closed overhead like a coffin lid.” A person smiles “with a grin that looked pale as a crack in clay.” The faces of sheep resemble “munching skulls.’ As night falls, the lamps around the pond in the park “would have begun to dangle luminous tails in the water.” “But the silence wasn’t soothing. It was unnatural, the product of too many coincidences. It was the silence of a forest when a predator is near.”The stories in this book make great reading primarily because of these twists of detail that Campbell insinuates into his common world. The plots of the stories themselves though tend to be a little too murky and unresolved. Most of the horrors that threaten the stories’ characters are vaguely defined - crouching, encroaching, spreading. A crack on the ceiling will propagate like the threads of a spider’s web. A blotch on the wall will grow bigger. Something in a jar will become engorged and animate. Obscurity in horror stories is generally good. It’s only the half-seen that’s frightening. But in these stories, the menace tends to remain sometimes just a touch too oblique.Nevertheless, if you’re looking for good writing, eerie atmospherics, and an awakened sense of the sinister in everyday life – Campbell is here and everywhere the author for you.There are many collections of Campbell’s stories. The 21 stories included here are:Mackintosh Willy, Napier Court, Down There, Heading Home, The Proxy, The Depths, Out of Copyright, The Invocation, The Little Voice, Drawing In, The Pattern, The Show Goes On, The Puppets, Calling Card, Above the World, Baby, In the Bag, Conversion, The Chimney, Call First, The Companion.

Although J. B. Priestley had already written a lot before this book was first published in 1929, it’s “The Good Companions” that really launched him into popularity and eventually led to his being considered “the Grand Old Man of English Letters.”This is about three separate people facing rather routine lives who decide to kick over the traces and hit the open road. Circumstances cause them to converge with the members of a troupe of pierrots (a group that considered themselves to be a “concert party” rather than the more common vaudeville troupe). This Dinky Doo group is flagging, but comes to be revitalized through the efforts of its three new associates, and they launch out anew as “The Good Companions.”Much of this book is a kinder, gentler Dickens. Priestley has the same genius for catching people’s theme, the small trench of philosophy that most people seems to settle into (“It’s the Government what done it!) - and outlines them vividly. He even has much of Dickens' way with aptly naming his characters. For example, we meet Mr. Mord here, the swollen, dyspeptic husband of a difficult landlady that the troupe encounters. But Priestley doesn’t reduce his characters to caricature.There are occasional references here that date the book. Be prepared to meet a few terms that would now be considered unacceptably racist in describing black people or Jewish people. Such jolts are very rare on these pages though. More often, you might be amazed at how modern-sounding some of the activity is. Both men and women casually drive cars everywhere. Then when Inigo meets a Doomsday group on the road, they point out how the recent increase in earthquakes, floods, and droughts, proves their contention that the “end is nigh.” (Priestley makes this yet another occasion for his wry humor as he has Inigo note that, despite their dire warnings, this band of Resurrectionists has put expensive new tires on their vehicle.)Priestley reportedly wrote very fast and rarely made revisions to his sentences. So it’s all the more surprising that he came up with so many bright metaphors. He describes a morning “as crisp as a nut,” an afternoon like “painted silk,” and a night full of “owl-haunted distances.” He captures a typical 1920’s Yorkshire scene as he likens a tram that’s slowly making its way over the dales to an ancient beast who stops here and there “to swallow a few morsels of humanity,” then lumbers off to unimaginable places. Priestley sees how the wind in one dreary place “rounded up all the odd pieces of paper in the streets & compelled them to join in a witches’ Sabbath.”There’s a fair amount of Yorkshire dialect represented here, but it’s surprisingly easy to read if you sound the syllables out in your head. The book is also a long one, something of a commitment. But it tells of people who yet had the capacity to be enchanted with each other. It carries you breezily down the road, like Mr. Toad in “Wind in the Willows” as he tooled along having adventures. Priestley occasionally breaks the “fourth wall” as they call it in the theater, when he himself steps forward to comment on the characters’ gentle, life-affirming journey.

I take notes on the especially interesting thoughts I find in the books I read. I ended up with over 20 pages of notes from this book. This is a learned, perceptive series of essays on how and why so much of our modern culture has become a lax and dull place, devoid of enchantment.The first part of the book contains essays that revisit some of the classics of literature and art, showing how they shine a beacon on our modern predicament. Included here are some unusually interesting comments on “Macbeth,” as well as some on Shakespeare’s less often cited “Measure for Measure.” Dalyrmple also considers works by Turgenev, Stefan Zweig, artist Marie Cassatt, and cartoonist Gilroy.On the other hand, he tells why he considers some of the work of Virginia Woolf and D. H. Lawrence, and all of Marx, to lead away from a philosophy of personal responsibility. He also puts many modern artists in that category of anti-humanism, with their technique of dabs and splashes “letting chance do all the work for them” rather than bothering to make their works a considered, skilled expression of human individuality.The later parts of the books draw from Dalrymple’s wide-ranging experience as a doctor in places such as the poorer sections of England and in Rhodesia-become-Zimbabwe. He’s a “Conservative” thinker whose literacy and intellect might yet appeal to those who consider themselves to be politically “Liberal.” It would be difficult for those anywhere on the political spectrum not to agree with at least some of the telling points he makes about the hypocrisy and posturing he sees inherent in a lot of political correctness.There are a few places where I feel he lapses into more prosaic conservatism, as when he opposes same-sex marriage or the legalization of any drug. He has some good reasons for his opposition, especially to the legalization of drugs. But he doesn’t justify the alarm he feels at these developments as well as he does with other modern trends. Also, it’s hard to fully credit the bleak picture of widespread dissolution and decadence he sees existing in England, France, and in cities such as Amsterdam, where many drugs are legal and where generous social allotments have made many people dependent on the government.His statistics about the consequent increase in crime might also be open to some question.  So many other social commentators maintain that total crime rates have likely remained pretty much constant over the span of recorded human history. It’s just that when individual crimes decrease, state-sponsored crimes (all the up to and including genocide), often increase. So people who say that at least the machinery of the Third Reich quelled street crime in the form of purse-snatching, etc., are overlooking the elephant of crime that was rampaging through the streets.However, when it comes to targeting the broad malaise of our age, Dalyrmple is generally cogent to the core. Just to give a brief taste of some of his pithy insights:”Turgenev saw men; Marx saw classes of men. People were like snowflakes in an avalanche to Marx; instances of a general force, conditioned by circumstance.”“Marx is filled with vehement rage, as if to cloak the synthetic nature of his feelings.” He “had a firm grip on unreality.”“The stance of being shocked by nothing is itself a convention now.”Our decent into vulgarity and irresponsibility has been gradual. “Rome wasn’t destroyed in a day.”“A sensation can’t strike twice in the same place. You have to go above & beyond your last presentation each time to create a sensation.”“All dictators hate even the independence of nature. They can’t tolerate the slightest insubordination.” (So their governments are almost always characterized by gigantization, by creating the monumental - making spontaneity impossible.)“For the intellectual elite, words are meant, not to convey truth, but to distinguish one from the herd.”Now “Adolescents are precociously adult; adults are permanently adolescent.”“But if we cannot censor, we can censure.”This book gives the support and perspective to stand against the tide of cheapness, vulgarity, and cruelty.

Terrorizing and tracking people via the computer plays a significant role in the plot of this book. Since “Goodnight” was written in 1996, you have to cast yourself back a bit, to the state of computer technology then, to get in the spirit of the pursuit. Some of the references might seem creaky and antique to people who keep up on the advance of computers. You’ll find floppy discs and bulletin board postings here. The programmers “looked like workers tending a giant buzzing termite queen, down there in the basement.”But many of the techniques remain relevant, at least in principle. For example, both stalker and police make frequent use of proxy servers and APS (anonymous posting services) to misleadingly direct emails.However, you can still enjoy this psychological thriller even if you skip over the computer talk. The story at heart is about a woman who starts to receive messages on her computer screen from her murdered daughter. Who is this killer who’s adding torment to torment?My only objection to the author’s approach here is that she once again uses what has become the convention of ubiquitous hostility. Co-workers are hostile to each other; members of the police force are hostile to each other. A kind of low-level, pointless antagonism seems to form the main connection between people.But the writing here is generally perceptive and literate. Murphy paints a telling picture of what it’s like to live with an abusive husband, and she has a good descriptive command throughout. One character is described as being, not clever, but cunning. A house is described as having “the fossilized hush of habit.”The suspense mounts as killer and victim spiral towards a conclusion.

Before I read this book, I tended to think it was a good thing we continue to aggressively pursue war criminals until the ends of their lives. After reading this, while I still would like to prosecute such individuals in principle, I can see how prejudice and politics make such prosecutions, certainly in the case of World War II war criminals, almost impossible as a practical matter.You’ll learn a lot from this book besides the legal maneuvering that was involved in prosecuting Ivan Demjanyuk after he was accused of having been “Ivan the Terrible,” the sadistic guard of the Treblinka concentration camp. You’ll learn about the pitfalls of a system that doesn’t include trial-by-jury, but in which all cases are decided only by a panel of judges. You’ll find a graphic example of the many ways the truth can get distorted and buried during the ultra-adversarial process of prosecution vs. defense, and during the resultant clash of personalities between all the parties involved. You’ll learn how sustained grievance and prejudice can cloud judgment and even lead to mob action.More generally, you’ll learn a lot of telling details about the dynamics of the late-War and-post-War period in Europe, particularly about the politics of repatriation. Who went where after WW!!? How did so many higher-ups such as Mengele escape? What was the jockeying that took place among lesser functionaries to avoid going back into Russian territory and to establish revised identities? Why was the Russian KGB so intent on forging documents pertaining to so many of these individuals?My only complaint about the book is that it tends to be too much about the author, who was Demjanyuk’s Israeli defense attorney. Sheftel doesn’t come across as a very likeable person. He proudly tells how he impressed the U.S. defense attorney who arrived in Israel by driving up in his new Porsche. Similarly, Sheftel tends to judge others by the cars they drive and by initial appearances. This tendency might give the reader pause about the quality of his perceptions and reporting overall. Certainly the resultant falling-out he had with U.S. attorney O’Connor, which is so much of what the early part of this book is about, demonstrates how using such shallow means of appraisal can derail a project.Then Sheftel narrates how he gave up his “carefully guarded” bachelorhood to a long-time helpmate who stood by him during his medical crisis and who then told him, after he’d made a summary presentation in Court, that “It was simply amazing to see the power of your appearance.” He tells of the instances in which he feels humiliated by the judges and by others in the case, and of reverse instances when he purposefully does the nettling and humiliating. Also, Sheftel doesn’t seem to consider how his historic antagonism with one of the judges scheduled to preside over the case might have worked against Demjanyuk from the start and made Sheftel a poor choice of attorneys for the man.He doesn’t meet with Demjanyuk until he’s well into preparing his defense. Sheftel does give a thumbnail sketch of his client, but he doesn’t seem to consider it important to really get to know the man. So the book is a frustrating blank when it comes to acquainting readers with Demjanyuk’s personality. Nevertheless, you get a fascinating panorama of information in the course of learning about Demjanyuk’s particular case.I suggest you read this book in tandem with one of Helen Loftus’ books on the problems of eye-witness identification – a book such as “Witness for the Defense.” Loftus ended up not actually testifying here. But since so much of the case against Demjanyuk centered around survivors’ identification of him from photo arrays that included a suspect picture of him as a trainee at a camp for concentration camp guards – Loftus’ research into the proper protocol for witness identification could be of key value in helping you form your own opinions about these proceedings.

This movie is a pretentious mish-mash. It pertains to the story of the Amanda Knox trial in Italy, but names have been changed - I'm not sure why. The core of the action here is supposed to be a photojournalist's endeavor to bring a different angle to the proceedings. So many people have commented on how the accused Knox deceptively has "the face of an angel." The photojournalist however thinks perhaps that appellation might be better applied to the murder victim herself - or perhaps to the bartending woman who acts as his guide and muse through the streets of Sienna, the Italian town where this transposed version of the murder takes place.In the course of these ruminations, the photojournalist tries to draw a parallel with Dante and his beloved Beatrice. There doesn't seem to be any basis at all for making such an analogy, other than to drag in some literary reference by the ears.Everyone talks very fast. Some dream sequences are interjected to add to the confusion. The result is a real pointless mess of a movie. I would give it only one star, except some lovely photography of the Tuscan region of Italy redeems the film a little.

I just have a basic textbook knowledge of ohms and oh-ohs. I was able to follow along in this book for about the first 75 pages describing tools and precautions. But then I found myself in deep waters when Geier got into the details of using an oscilloscope and I came upon passages such as:“In a non-complementary design, the amplifier has to be biased to set its output halfway between ground and the power supply voltage when no signal is applied…”However, Geier tries to take as avuncular, helpful a tone as possible. He interjects memorably humorous advice such as “they don’t call metal connect points “terminals” for nothing.” He also gives advice on what brands to buy and where to buy some parts and products at discount prices.There were a few points in this generally sound book that I felt were misleading or insufficient. For example, early on, Geier says that electricity has always been considered running off the negative terminal of a battery. He says that’s been the conventional usage since the days of Ben Franklin. Well, that’s not quite true. Actually, until the mid-1950’s, electricity was generally taken to be running from the positive post of a battery.I have several reasons for wishing Geier had addressed this re-orientation. What little electrical troubleshooting I’ve done has often involved work on antique cars, most of which operated with a POSITIVE ground (the opposite of almost all modern cars). In all my probings in this regard, I remained largely in the dark because I have yet to come across a really lucid explanation of the implications of this difference. Various guides point out that older cars rusted faster because of their positive ground. Why would that be? The old cars would basically function even if you hooked them up the wrong way, but you would almost certainly blow their radios, lights, and turn signals.It’s true that an account of these effects would be more in the realm of electricity than electronics. But I think an explanation in the lucid style Geier is capable of, would have been really helpful in grounding (pardon the pun) readers, especially beginners in the field, in some essential points about the ways of electricity in general.Then Geier made a basic omission when he failed to tell readers how to check the viability of batteries. That’s almost always the first thing a beginner tries to check with a DMM. Geier devotes a chapter to the functions performed by various circuit components such as capacitors and transistors, and he tells how to go about checking for breaches in each of these.First of all, it might have been helpful if he had put this chapter BEFORE the very challenging one on how to operate an oscilloscope. Most important though, he ought to have included the basic information that batteries need to be tested under load in order to get reliable readings. I have met even some presumably practiced electricians who weren’t aware of this point.The section devoted to tackling the repair of specific items is very brief. There are only a couple of pages devoted to diagnosing computers. This might seem to contradict the title and premise of this whole book. But Geier has scattered some information on diagnostics throughout other chapters, such as that chapter on what individual components do and how to tell if they have gone bad.These little kvetches aside – this book can be a solid help, if you already have some understanding of electrical workings and terminology. In order to gain that understanding, there are a few preliminary readings I can heartily recommend, some of which are older or less obvious books – but helpful nonetheless. These include:“There Are No Electrons” by Amdahl - (Looks at electrons as party animals, and in so doing, memorably impresses beginners and professionals alike with an understanding of why electricity takes the paths it does.)“Electricity and Electronics Basic” Third Edition, by Steinberg/Ford – (An old book, but one of the best basics I’ve ever found.)“Electricity and Electronics,” the textbook, not the lab book, by Gerrish, Dugger, Roberts.“Understanding Solid-State Electronics,” the Texas Instruments Understanding Series from its Learning Center. - (This really makes it clear what’s happening inside diodes, transistors, MOSFETs, and the like.)“Automotive Electricity and Electronics” by Santini - (In telling exactly where you put probes to analyze a car’s circuity, you are able to extrapolate to all kinds of circuits.)“How to Keep Your VCR Alive” by Steve Thomas – (Again, an older book that might seem an odd choice. But it really tells how to open up the compartments of a device, how to look at how wheels and cams interlock, and how to get past them into the electrical components – information that can give you a feel for prying and unscrewing panels that can be extrapolated to more modern devices.)

This film seems to have started life as a Canadian made-for-TV movie with the title “The Husband She Met Online.” It has the low-budget, interior-setting feel of a soap opera. The pared-down pacing and rhythm of conversation also brands the film with a kind of soap opera quality.But that’s not a bad thing in this era of too many over-the-top special effects extravaganzas. What was a little more difficult for me to overcome before I could get involved with this film, was the casting of the lead actor. I initially kept thinking of Jason Gray-Stanford as the bumbling, too-eager-to-please side-kick detective in TV’s “Monk” series. However, once I got beyond stereotyping the actor that way, I could appreciate how he had morphed into a properly menacing presence for this role.There is nothing too memorable here, but the movie dramatizes what seems to be a common and perhaps growing problem in society – the problem of the controlling boyfriend/husband. While the character is this movie carries his need for control into shocking extremes, his early warning tendencies in that direction are not all that different from what myriad women are reporting in the media and to police.It might be possible to draw an important lesson from this film. If someone seems too good to be true – he probably is. So this likely wouldn't be a good choice for viewing with someone on a first date. It's bound to give a prospective partner pause.

I went from getting almost no channels with my indoor rabbit ears - to getting 57-60 clear broadcast channels with this outdoor unit. It is a great value. It’s hard to believe a person can get this much complex technology for so little money.The unit was also easy to install. For a pole (not provided in this kit), I used a length of plumbing pipe embedded in a bucket of cement.The remote control is working from a distance of about 70-feet for me, although I find I don’t need to use it much. Most of the stations in my area transmit from towers banked in one direction. Once I oriented the antenna for maximum reception, I’ve been pretty much able to leave it in place. But the remote does swivel the antenna this way and that responsively.The antenna beams a red light to show when the power box inside is on. So you can stand outside and see if anyone is inside your house watching TV.There are a few things to consider in connection with my 5-star review though. I live in Chicago and am only about 9 miles from the transmission towers downtown. So I can’t really speak to how much range this antenna has.Also, I had read in other reviews here that some buyers had doubts about the coaxial cable that comes with the unit. I happened to have 60-feet of sturdier coaxial cable handy, so I immediately used my own cable. Therefore, I can’t say how well the provided cable would have worked.But this was a good buy that has really worked for me.

I saw one of these wiggling, waving flowers on my bank teller’s counter. Its gyrations made me laugh. So for once, someone laughed IN the bank, rather than all the way TO the bank. I bought a set of these so I could also laugh at home.Three of the four flowers I bought danced immediately as I took them out of their cellophane packages. One of the flowers had to be gently secured in its track a little more firmly before it would animate a bit. (It’s never been as lively as the others, but 3 out of 4 strong dancers is not a bad success ratio at this price.) Be careful if you feel you need to do this. The flower stems are very fragile.These flowers do best in a window with good sun exposure, although they will also dance in a very bright room, especially if they are put under a goose-neck lamp. Either an incandescent bulb or one of the new energy-saving fluorescent bulbs will do the job in this case.There are a couple of things to be aware of when you buy any of these solar dancing ornaments. Most of these brands and sizes of trinkets do not store energy in the way larger outdoor solar lights do. With these, as soon as a sufficiently bright light source is removed, they stop dancing.Also most of these ornaments do not have any on/off buttons. When I took that one laggard flower out of its package, I wasted quite a bit of time looking for a button that I thought might be stuck in the “Off” position. But no – there are no such buttons on these flowers. Their cellophane wrap restrains them until you open the blister pack.

This is a good, absorbing account of the ultimately inexplicable murder of two children. It has more than a little suspense along the way, as for example when the author points out the possible “chilling” irony involved in the searchers’ pause in front of the family refrigerator.The book is co-authored by the man who became the chief prosecutor in the case. So there is necessarily a bit of awkwardness in the juggling of pronouns and referents, especially in the later chapters, when the case is taken to court. Don Weber narrates events from his point of view, but refers to himself in the third person. He alternately becomes “the prosecutor,” “Don,” and “Weber.” I don’t know if simply saying ”I” would have been an easier, more direct approach. But perhaps then the chronicle would have lacked the authoritative tone that its objective, reportorial style in fact gives to it.Since this account is written by a lawyer, it is naturally heavier on court room maneuvering than it is on psychological insights. But probably the latter would have been hard to come by, even in the hands of a psychologist. Paula Sims seems to have remained enigmatic and inarticulate about her motives. So instead of a look inside a killer’s mind, readers are given more of a legal procedural, at least once the suspect(s) are taken into custody.This approach has a fascination of its own. It’s like auditing a good class in criminal prosecution. You’ll learn phrases such as “writ of mandamus” and the legal meaning of “per se.” If you don’t get inside Paula Sims’ head so much, you do get inside the head of a good prosecutor as he prepares his case. Mostly, Don Weber provides a solid role model in this regard. However, there are a few instances in which his judgment about how to present a point to a jury ends in slightly humorous, off-kilter results.For example, he tells how in preparing a summary, he wanted to make sneering reference to Sims’ protestations that her babies were taken by one or more masked intruders. Weber initially thought that in order to underscore the patently fictive nature of any such invader, he’d call him “the bogeyman.” But then Weber had second thoughts. He felt that the term “bogeyman” might have a negative, personal connotation for any African-American jurors on the panel. So Weber instead used the character of “Rumpelstiltskin.”I’m not sure that reference was apt. That odd name from Grimm’s Fairy Tales has surely stuck in many people’s minds. But it’s unlikely that most people recall who Rumpelstiltskin was – whether he was hero or villain. If they do recall the story more exactly, they would know that Rumpelstiltskin did NOT steal children. He was NOT an improbable kidnapper. His bargaining with the miller’s daughter much more complicated than that.Weber also chooses to accept as a key element of his case the rather dubious testimony of one doctor regarding the effect of a head injury on a person’s memory. As Weber himself later admits, his doctor’s conclusions would tend to be contradicted by the experience of many prizefighters.Another slight problem with this book is a problem that it has in common with most true crime accounts. There are so many detectives, superintendents, sheriffs, lawyers, and others, involved in the investigation, that in places, these pages become like a telephone directory. In real life, crime investigation hardly ever seems to have the coherence of a Columbo story, with one brilliant mind pursuing the investigation through all its phases. So most true crimes books such as these could use an initial rundown of names, with thumbnail reminders of their roles attached - or at least an inclusive index. This book (or at least this paperback edition) has neither.Despite these few drawbacks, this book is a good insider’s account of a strange crime and its resultant punishment. It’s worth a place on any true crime buff’s shelves.

This is a well-researched account of a strange, seemingly unmotivated 1969 murder at Penn State. Author DeKok puts the reader back in that time and place by including reminders of the campus revolts prevalent then, the Viet Nam War protests, the manners and mores of a generation seeking liberation from all sorts of old restrictions and prejudices.It’s interesting to be recalled to a time when the victim had a strict curfew at the more conservative Michigan College where she did her undergraduate work. In spite of this guarded atmosphere, the Co-Ed Murders rocked that academic community in the 60’s, as briefly recounted by DeKok.
