(For a fuller account, see "The Michigan Murders" by Keyes) It’s a ghastly irony that part of the reason Betsy Aardsma moved to Pennsylvania for her graduate work was to get away from the killing fields that Ann Arbor had become in the 60’s due to the depredations of that serial killer.In the course of recounting Betsy’s earlier years, the author also provides a fascinating history of some of southwestern Michigan, especially towns such as Holland. I live not far from there, but had never realized the place’s rich ethnic, religious history.The only reason I give this book 4-stars instead of 5 is because of the absolute certitude with which DeKok names Betsy’s killer. Well yes, his candidate is indeed a likely suspect, but I don’t feel quite certain enough to consider the case closed. I have read enough true crime accounts to know how often the presence of a murder victim draws awareness to a veritable host of sociopaths and psychopaths who had been surrounding that individual. A case in point is the Peggy Hettrick murder. (See "Drawn to Injustice.")It seems that, on a somewhat lesser scale, this could be the same situation in this case too. Quite a few people with aberrations emerge from the shadows and are seen to have been circling in Betsy’s life. Some of these other suspects who were considered by police and whom you can read about here include:Betsy’s boyfriend, a pre-med student who really did NOT want to go through with marrying her, but whose alibi seemed air-tight;A man whom Betsy briefly dated, who carried a knife, who was in the library stacks at the time of the murder, and who was only eliminated as a suspect because he passed a polygraph test, a test which we now know can produce misleading results;An associate professor with whom Betsy might have had some contact, who philosophically modeled himself after Dostoevsky's killers-with-impunity as they were written about in “Crime and Punishment” and “Notes from the Underground – a man who shortly thereafter fell into depression and possibly committed suicide by crashing his car;An ostensibly homeless man who’d been sleeping in the stacks at the time of the murder and who wandered off without having had his presence reported until days later;A rapist who’d been terrorizing women in the nearby Mall;Betsy’s classmate who discovered the body and who had a very odd reaction to this discovery, going into convulsions at the sight, when at first it only looked as if Betsy had fainted there in the stacks.Then there are several other individuals who were never fully considered by police but who might creep off these pages as likely suspects in readers’ eyes - individuals such as:The prime suspect’s adviser, who seemed to have something of his own to hide in that he didn’t push forward a report of the suspect’s revelations on the night of the murder until years later;A relative of Betsy’s who went into over-the-top, life-long grief at her death, even though he was not a member of her immediate family;And finally, someone else – an unidentified person whose possible presence in the stacks by Betsy is suggested by an odd detail that neither the police nor author DeKok noted until I sent an email. To consider this clue yourself, see Page 55 of the 2014 paperback edition - the paragraph mentioning the scattering of books found around Betsy’s body.In short, this is an excellent summary of the case and the trajectory of the likeliest suspect. But it leaves latitude for you, the reader, to be an armchair detective, and to perhaps see things that have been overlooked through the decades.

I was motivated to buy this book after I watched the “American Masters” series entry featuring tennis star Billie Jean King. King is a champion whose achievements deserve to be recognized. However, I was disturbed by the documentary’s suggestion that King put women’s tennis on the map. I had gotten the impression from my parents’ involvement with the sport in the 1920’s, that a previous generation of women had fought for, and largely achieved, equality for women in tennis.I bought this book to see if that was true. Engelmann confirms here that not only did the female stars of the 1920’s put women’s tennis on an equal footing with men’s – their competitions by far surpassed the men’s as box office draws and as sheer sensation. That these women have been so largely forgotten, and that most current documentaries fail to credit them or even make passing mention of them, is one of the oddest mysteries of the sports’ world.Engelmann concentrates on recounting the exploits of French/European star Suzanne Lenglen (pronounced like a nasalized long-glen) and her arch rival, Californian Helen Wills. He tells how these women fought their way to preeminence, thrilling crowds of admirers with their power and grace. One of the rare modern commentators familiar with those stars has said that Lenglen was the Michael Jordan of that era, making seemingly impossible jumps and pirouettes across the court, at times, almost giving the impression of levitating.The face-off between Lenglen and Wills attracted more attention in its day than the King/Riggs competition did in 1973. While the King/Riggs tournament was merely a “Battle of the Sexes” – the game between Lenglen and Wills became “The Battle of the Nations,” or, even more dramatically, “The War of the Worlds.” It was viewed as pitting Old World traditionalism against the innovative vibrancy of America. People who had villas anywhere within eye-shot of the tennis court in the south of France where the game between the two women took place, often removed the entire tile roofs of their homes so that spill-over spectators could pop up their heads between the beams, like gophers, to catch a glimpse of the action. Other people climbed surrounding palm trees and resisted all the efforts of gendarmes to bring them down with grappling hooks. The outcome of the match made front page headlines around the world.So this book makes it clear that before King and before the Williams sisters, there were dazzling female tennis stars who broke barriers. Engelmann also tells about Ora Washington, who broke the race barrier, becoming the “black Helen Wills.” He tells how many of these women routinely practiced with and played against top-ranking men in preliminary matches leading up to the final Forest Hills, Wimbledon, and Olympic matches. (Tennis was dropped as an Olympic sport in the late 20’s because of controversy surrounding amateur versus professional status, and was only reinstated decades later.) Women tended to win at least half of these matches with men, making the novelty attributed to the King/Riggs match another example of our national amnesia.In a larger sense, Engelmann demonstrates in this book how the female tennis stars of the 20's became trailblazers and trend-setters. They made it fashionable for all women to be toned, tanned, and athletic. They brought women out of the pallor of Victorian parlors.This book can be a little boring if you aren’t a real tennis enthusiast. A large part of it consists of point-by-point accounts of various key matches. I wished Engelmann would have included an introductory chapter for novices such as myself, telling more about how the game is scored and including a glossary. (What's the difference between a lob and a slam?) I also would have liked somewhat more time spent on the women’s personal histories. I don’t mean any tabloid low-down on their romances, but something to bring them off the page as more than just point-scoring machines.However, I’m still giving this book 5-stars because it provides such an amazing and well-researched corrective to the amnesia we are suffering when it comes to women’s athletic achievements. Almost everyone is familiar with the male athletes of the early part of the 20th century – with the likes of Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey. Our modern disregard of women who generated as much hero(ine) worship in their day as Ruth – makes it clear that each new generation of women might have to be prepared to renew the fight for equality. This book does a good job of bringing earlier female athletes out of the eclipse into which they so undeservedly have fallen.

This is an intelligent, brilliantly acted true story of the meetings of two men - one a journalist, the other an imprisoned murderer. Each, in his own way, is shown seeking redemption and exoneration by using the other. Journalist Finkel hopes that by getting the scoop on the murderer’s life and thoughts, he can get his writing career back on track. Murderer Longo hopes that by talking to the journalist, he can get his deeds slanted and projected with a different spin, so that his lies will be believed and so that he’s projected in a sympathetic, exculpating light.The suspense in the movie often comes from the very smallest gestures and details. There’s that habit Longo is represented as having – the habit of ever so slightly cricking his neck when a particularly malignant thought is passing through his mind. One can see that habit becoming chillingly infectious. Then there are details such as the soiled leg of a teddy bear protruding from a satchel.This movie has inspired me to order Finkel’s book on the subject, to learn more about the people involved, and to learn more fully about their circling of ambition.

The main movie on this DVD is good enough. Its plot and philosophy are predictable. But the acting is engrossing. The photography sets an eerie tone, keeping things indistinct and fleeting enough to be frightening. Some of the actors are photographed from behind as they jostle along the path from the main house to the removed guest house where their strange fate awaits them. That technique was used to good effect in the movie “The Black Swan.” Here too, that kind of trailing view is arresting. It turns us, the viewers, into the stalkers, coming up from behind for a surprise attack.The producers of this film made the most of their low-budget independence. I didn’t miss the special effects or expensive production values.However, though the movie itself is worth watching, I found the bonus extras to be the real reason for getting this disc. The director/actor commentary is average. But there are two long trailers (over 20 minutes each) of other films Senese made starring Jeremy Childs. These films are not readily available, but the samplings of them presented here are almost enough to constitute satisfying one-act plays in and of themselves, even if we never get to view the full movies.Jeremy Childs shows amazing versatility as he stars in the trailer for “The Intruder.” The full-length version of this film promises to challenge us to consider who might be the real intruder on the scene. There’s a wounded war veteran who perhaps can get out of his wheelchair after all. There’s the wife who has been so bold as to report the strange noises coming from her neighbor’s apartment. There is the neighbor himself, played by an ominously transformed Childs, who might be trying to break into the woman’s house in retaliation – or who might be trying to break out of the predatory clutches of the woman and/or her wounded husband. Inside/outside, insider/outsider flip - with frightening effect. If this isn’t in fact the theme of the full movie – it should be.But the true gem here is the trailer for Senese’s film called “Suicide Tapes.” Even just this partial view breaks new ground in surreal suspense. Childs is transformed again as a psychiatric patient who might have attempted suicide. The action consists of only the claustrophobic dialogue between him and his psychiatrist. I promise you will uneasily watch for something strange to appear in the mirror in which the two are reflected in their verbal danse macabre. But then comes a real shocker…There’s a lot to this disc. If the main film doesn’t get you – the trailers will.

At first, I was a little dubious about the usefulness of these sheets. They seemed large and unwieldy for the original use I wanted to put them to - which was to clean the lenses on my camera and my microscope. I didn't need a 15-inch x 17-inch sheet to clean such small areas.However, then I realized I could use these sheets for other than the small "delicate" purposes mentioned on their dispenser box. I started to use them to clean fingerprint smudges off my rented DVDs and off my vinyl record collection. They do a good job ridding these surfaces of any oily residue without scratching. They are also good for cleaning eyeglasses, and come in handy since most opticians have stopped handing out complimentary cleaning tissues. You can moisten these sheets if you wish, but they will do a good enough job cleaning all such surfaces even when they are used dry.I'm sure the longer I have these sheets available, the more uses I will find for them.

These pads do seem to stay bacteria-free and stain-free, and they do a good job making plates and glassware sparkling clean. However, they have a few limitations that have caused me to subtract a star from their rating.The instructions accompanying these pads say not to put the pads in a microwave, and not to use them on stainless steel pans. I would be wary about using the pads on the non-stick surfaces of any pots and pans. They have a tendency to scratch if used somewhat vigorously.So taking these provisos into account, it might ultimately be more economical to buy the regular, less expensive Scotch scrub pads. The standard pads can be used on all surfaces, and they can be put in the microwave to rid them of bacteria.

The actors in this film absorb the viewer into their terse, tense face-offs. Some decades ago, popular British author V. C. Clinton-Baddeley wrote a mystery story entitled “To Study a Long Silence.” That title refers to a technique that acting students learn in order to hold an audience’s attention. But it can be used to summarize how the characters in this movie approach each other. Despite the close physical contact that their wrestling jousts entail, they still essentially keep each other at a distance with the long breaches of silence between them.The tension in the film comes from the enmity and imbalance that creeps into these caesuras. The caesuras become gaps - and then chasms.But we never really get to know what might have caused this estrangement between the real-life millionaire du Pont and his protégé Mark Schultz, whom these movie characters are roughly meant to represent.  Well, perhaps in the case of du Pont, there can be no satisfactory explanation for his ultimately shocking action - other than pure craziness.  But I was left wanting to know more about the transformation that overtook wrestling champion Mark Schultz. What caused his disaffection, which seems to come on suddenly? What changed him from viewing du Pont as his sponsor, mentor, friend – into viewing him as a stymieing foe? There is one scene that suggests the turning point, but it provides an insufficient answer.So we’re left with no real reason for having watched this film other than to have experienced an engrossing but finally frustrating involvement in profoundly inarticulate lives. Rather than getting a hammerlock on the people and their personalities, we’re left with at best a half-Nelson grasp.

Lee starts out as you might expect here, explaining the process of DNA analysis as it existed in 2003 when this book was written. Some of his account resembles an alphabet soup, with RFLP, SNPs, VNTRs, etc., all mixed a little confusingly into the broth. All these letters refer to different parts and lengths of the genome that can be analyzed in order to arrive at a statistical assessment of the likelihood that X done it.Elsewhere, I had read that RFLPs for example (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), simply refer to sequences of DNA bases that repeat a different number of times in different individuals. Scientists zero in on these repeating sequences of GATC bases that are found in what was termed the “junk” DNA between actual genes. Some people might have three repeats of a sequence at a site: AGAGAG. Some might have four repeats: AGAGAGAG. Five percent of a given population might have 3 such repeats at a given site: 20% might have ten repeats, etc. Scientists look at a number of these sites (or loci). They then multiply the odds of there being a certain number of repeats at locus A by the odds of there being a certain number of repeats of another sequence at locus B, etc., and thereby arrive at the usually rather slim chance of anyone other than a given suspect having that profile of repeats.Nowhere in this book does Lee ever explain the process of this kind of DNA analysis as simply as I’ve summarized above. You’ll have to work a little to make it all clear. But if you persevere – if you keep reading and take some notes – you’ll probably come away with a fairly complete picture of how DNA analysis works. If you are an aspiring mystery story writer, a lawyer, or just an interested reader, having this book will probably obviate the need of plowing through any expensive, technical textbook on the subject. You’ll get most of what you need to know here.Lee also sprinkles these chapters with thumbnail sketches of the cases of suspects who’ve been convicted and suspects who’ve been exonerated by DNA. Meanwhile, you’ll learn how complicated the process of DNA analysis actually is – how many steps are involved, opening the door to the possibility of cross-contamination and delay. You’ll come to understand how, at least until the recent past, DNA analysis took a lot of time and couldn’t be accomplished in the span of a half-hour TV show.But then in these densely packed pages, you’ll go beyond the boundaries of DNA analyses and get what is essentially several other whole different books. If you don’t mind digressions from anything strictly pertaining to DNA, you’ll find extended sections about:1. The Holocaust. In connection with determining if a certain set of buried remains were in fact those of Josef Mengele, the author goes into some detail recounting Mengele’s biography, and the motive and means behind his ghastly experiments, with twins and others, at Auschwitz. This includes a general look at conditions inside Auschwitz.2. The O. J Simpson Murder Case. The author here gives one of the clearest timelines I’ve read, recounting which detectives arrived on the scene, when they arrived, what evidence they found, where they transported it, and whether or not there could in fact have been any breaks in the chain of custody.3. Tabloid History. This is a clever term Lee coins as he recounts the results of a number of DNA analyses that have been aimed at revealing intimate secrets about historical figures. You might be surprised to learn here that, contrary to what you might have read elsewhere, President Jefferson probably did not father any children with slave Sally Hemmings. You’ll learn the results of other titillating disinterments.  Many of these researches have incidentally revealed whether or not certain notable figures had diseases such as syphilis. This gives Lee a chance to once again interject some of the sly humor that is scattered through these pages. He tells about attempts to confirm whether some tissue remains were in fact those of the Dauphin, son of Marie Antoinette. Lee winks that incidentally, the analysis can be expected to reveal whether or not the little boy had syphilis.There is also considerable information about non-human DNA and the developing science that distinguishes different strains of anthrax and the different strains of all sorts of bacterial/viral infections.All-in-all, these pages are jam-packed full of interesting information that’s fairly well presented. However, the lead summary of this book is misleading. You won’t find anything here about either Chandra Levy or Albert de Salvo.

This is a treasure trove of tidbits about how the development of the laws of probabilities have, or should have, informed the way we lead our daily lives.In the first part of the book, the author tackles such puzzlers of probability as the Monty Hall Dilemma and the chance of having at least one girl if you have two children. In some ways, the counter-intuitive answers to these questions have been better explained by any number of other authors such as Marilyn vos Savant in her collection of articles entitled “The Power of Logical Thinking.”But there’s still a great deal of new, arresting information here, including a lot of the history of mathematics. It’s fascinating to be reminded how the ancient Greeks pursued truth without a consistent way of representing numbers – without a decimal system, without the concept of zero. It’s also interesting to learn how the laws of chance were eventually developed, not as a purely scientific endeavor, but more often by gamblers interested in finding winning strategies.You might encounter a few little stumbling blocks along the way. There’s a bit of sexism, as when the author uses Oprah’s fluctuating weight to demonstrate the principle of “sample space.” Then, since the author is British, he might occasionally be using terms in somewhat different ways than you’d find in a typical American classroom. For example, he doesn’t make clear the same distinction between the “average” and the “mean” that I learned in school.However, this book really swings into delivering useful information in its last third. It helps rationalize the seeming portents and patterns behind Ouija boards, séances, and a host of what many persist in interpreting as “signs.” You’ll garner sound advice on topics such as the efficacy of hiring a financial manager with a winning track record. You’ll learn whether or not you get your money’s worth by buying the most expensive vodka and wine – whether or not you need to be wary of moving into an area that has been labeled as having a “cancer cluster” – whether you should judge team coaches or corporate executives (or anyone) by the last four or five years of results that their institutions realized during their leadership.All-in-all, this book is fun, informative, and provides valuable tips on how to rationally judge whether or not the odds are really in your favor.

Some of this book reads like an old time radio mystery drama. But here the lead character isn't a private eye. He's a Chicago-area newspaper reporter, waltzing through the twilight of the age of newsprint, knowing that his days on the job are likely numbered. What's more, the murders in this story aren't the relatively quick, bloodless affairs of old-time radio. Here the reporter is on the trail of a savage serial killer.But the dialogue has some of the lean, detached tone of the old-time private eye. After he's been knifed and beaten, reporter Alex Chapa wryly remarks that yeah, "I feel like a million bucks - give or take a million."The old-time sexism is here too. There's a kind of Velma-counterpart in the story, a woman who presses close to Chapa, making him feel her warmth through her form-fitting top. However, she's doing it, not out of love, but with an agenda of her own. Meanwhile, Chapa has a girlfriend back home, whose only role is to worry over him and to be there, as long as Chapa doesn't abuse the relationship too much by entangling himself in deadly danger. We read that this girlfriend smiled, "and in the glow of a night-light, Chapa saw a look of surrender and unguarded passion in her eyes…" These are the kind of women who were confined to the black-bordered panels of a comic book strip back in the 40's.But this book ultimately has more sensitivity than a standard Mickey Spillane. I usually like the cozies, the more literary English who-dunits. Nevertheless, this more action-oriented book kept me reading. Its 100 short, footprint chapters paced me quickly on the heels of the killer. Then it has at least a couple of really chilling, memorable scenes wrought by that psychopath.I got this book out of the remainder pile at a dollar store. Even though it has too many suspects too poorly delineated, it deserves a better fate. It's as good as many of the more critically acclaimed mystery stories out there, without having the miring pretensions often found in those books. Plus, you get some good Chicago-area backdrops. Where better for a hard-boiled kind of guy to pound the pavements?

The title of my review (borrowed from a bonus feature interview on the disc) - in fact sums up the action in this movie brilliantly. The monster starts as something definitely apart - something that might creep out of a closet, or rap under the floorboards. But then its spirit seems to inhabit the mother and turn her into the beast itself.This movie becomes a tour de force performance illustrating a descent into madness. In that respect, it might remind viewers of such cult classics as Roman Polanski's "Repulsion." But is that what this movie is really about? Or is there perhaps a real monster who haunts the premises?The people who produced this movie don't spoon feed any answer to viewers. We are left to decide for ourselves. The plot does provide some clues though. Where did that pop-up book that introduces the progressively more menacing Mr. Babadook come from? Why can Mr. Babadook penetrate into some rooms, yet be confined in others? Is the Babadook real, with an independent existence, or is he in the mind - or both? While the movie draws us into that question, it delivers some very scary moments and that chilling central performance by Essie Davis.The interview bonus features on the disc are also more absorbing than what's usually found on disc "extras." It seems it was primarily women who were involved in the making of this movie, and in telling about their journey getting this film as a realized project on screen, they weave a quiet, focused narrative that, in its way, is as atmospheric and intelligent as the movie itself.

So many true crime TV programs such as "48 Hours" have dealt with the gruesome murders in the Novack family, the Miami royalty who founded the Fontainebleau Hotel - that I was reluctant to get this video. I thought there could be little more to add to the already numerous accounts.But this movie does have a freshness about it, despite how well the ground has already been covered. The life leading up to these murders is recounted in a wry narrative style. This narration is done by the already dead Ben Novack, Jr., heir to the family's fortune. This puts the proceedings in a strange, out-of-body perspective from the start. It also allows Novack to be more of an appealing character than the straightforward TV documentaries made of him. Despite his addiction to porn, drugs, and Batman memorabilia, his postmortem account makes him seem almost angelic, a personage who hovers over the scene - enthusing in the excesses he enjoyed in life, and accepting with a sort of resigned twinkle the fate that these excesses ultimately dealt him.Overall, this "based in fact" movie reminded me of the purely fictional movie "Sexy Beast." Both movies are unusual in that they feature characters who enjoy their wealth to the hilt. They are not depressed by their over-the-top lifestyles. They revel in all the excesses that their wealth affords them. So this is a departure from the usual code that even most modern movies adhere to - the code that dictates that the rich must be demonstrably miserable and undeserving at all times.But then, this movie also swings along with the sort of syncopated beat that made "Sexy Beast" dance. In "Sexy Beast," Ray Winstone's character revels in his good fortune by pronouncing it fabulicious, or literally, "fan-dabby-dozy-tastic." In this movie, Rob Lowe never quite utters any such catchy scat phrases. But the spirit of riffing through the music of our existence that way permeates this movie, right through the brutal killings.It tends to give the viewer a new way of looking at life - and death. Isn't it all, in the end - Wow! Isn't it all fan-dabby-dozy-tastic?

Stephen King has produced so many works in the last decade or so that have been mishmashes of supernatural special effects (a la "Rose Red"), that this return to realistic human storytelling is a welcome relief. We have here the subtleties of a marriage that appears to be a good and loving one on the outside, but that even from the beginning has the tension and suspense of something sinisterly rotten at its core.There is even here though some departure from strict realism. Sometimes we can't be sure when we have crossed the line from reality into one of the spouse's imaginings. So, while I was 99% sure I knew what had happened and why at the end of the story - King leaves us that niggling 1% that might cast the story in a completely different light. The self-satisfied, triumphant way in which someone at the end pops open what had previously been a forbidden candy - might make you think - and wonder.

This is a small gem of a book written by a Swiss psychologist who offers some valuable advice to parents and partners who want to do the best for the people they love. Tournier writes about the necessity of having secrets, and about the subtle timing involved in ripening, then revealing secrets. He defines healthy relationships as this ebb and flow of restraint and confiding.The word "secret" is too often preceded by the adjective "dirty" in this culture. We often fail to appreciate the degree to which having a secret promotes independence in children and gives marriages their emotive force. In our tell-all, let-it-all-hang-out world, it's easy to become emotionally flat. We lack the inner spark that a delightful secret can give us.Tournier is one of the few psychologists to point out this positive aspect of secrets. You don't hear much about this from Dr. Phil or any of the other talk-show counselors as they deal with parents with wayward teens or wayward spouses. Having a secret and allowing others to time the keeping of their secrets can indeed be the "secret" to having a harmonious household.This book was written in the 1960's and does contain a couple of outdated references, as for example when Tournier refers to the extreme fear with which people often hide a family member's homosexuality. But for the most part, this wise little volume carries forward into the modern world with some remarkable insights that have been overlooked for too long.

In this book, Loftus recounts some fascinating true crime cases in which she was called to give testimony regarding the unreliability of eyewitness identifications. Loftus is a research psychologist who participated in a lot of studies demonstrating how easily people's memories can be influenced. She also is known for the work she has done demonstrating how memories can be implanted wholesale in adults or children, as happened in the McMartin pre-school case.Loftus does give some illustrations of how police can contaminate witness accounts, but I wish she had gone into even more detail about the studies she has conducted showing how this can happen, and about the advice she gives to police officers on how to avoid such undue influence. Perhaps though more detail on this score would have made the book too long. There is a bibliography provided to fill in some of these gaps.Here the author concentrates more on the circumstances of the crimes themselves. As it turned out, she didn't always work on the side of the "good guys." She tells about testifying for Ted Bundy's defense. Thinking back, she remembers disliking how Bundy smiled at the prosecutor, something an innocent man doesn't ordinarily do. A few scattered comments such as that might make the reader wonder if Loftus' memory might itself be showing the kind of after-the-fact malleability that she saw it as her role to remind juries to take into consideration. Did she really suspect Bundy at the time?In several of the cases Loftus recounts, there have been interesting reversals since this 1991 book was published. Some of the other individuals for whose defense she testified, also later appeared to be guilty. She writes about the part she likely played in exonerating Timothy Hennis, accused of killing a mother and two of her children. More recently, a DNA analysis of semen found in the dead woman matched Hennis' DNA. But this case cries out for an updated, full-length account. Hennis' three trials raise the issue of how prosecution can circumvent double jeopardy laws, and might even call into question the reliability of some DNA analysis, since so much of the other evidence seemed to unequivocally point to Hennis' innocence.There were other reversals, going in the opposite direction from guilty to innocent, after Loftus' book came out. Loftus was asked to testify for the defense team of Ivan Demjanyuk, accused of being a sadistic Treblinka concentration camp guard. Loftus recounts  how she agonized over her decision. Should she testify and appear to be betraying her Jewish ancestry by calling into question the memories of the survivors who identified Demjanyuk as being their tormentor? You can read the book to find out what Loftus ultimately decided.Other cases dealt with in this book include that of: Tony Herrerez, a camp counselor accused of child abuse; Howard Haupt, accused of child abduction and murder; Von Williams, accused of rape; and Tyrone Biggs, accused of assault and attempted rape.You'll find a number of insights into court procedure here that you won't find in most other true crime books. This book will also probably inspire you to read more about many of the cases mentioned, and to probe more deeply into the whole question of how accurate anyone's memory is, including your own.

A number of plots revolving around frighteningly disturbed people get woven together here. There's a young woman impelled by an increasing conviction that she was abused as a youngster, who is now seeking to get revenge on those who would deny it. There's a street tough who has lost all touch with his humanity. Most central to the book though is the boy found lost and wandering, fallen mute in the wake of some mysterious trauma his caretakers suspect he might have suffered. The cause of his unnerving silence has to be solved before many of the other people's disorders can be unraveled. Is the boy an innocent victim? If so, of what?The subplot that I found to be most interesting was the one involving the battle that a couple of the lead characters make against created or "implanted" memories of abuse. These psychologists draw an unreasoning amount of hostility from individuals committed to the life stories they might have structured for themselves as props, and from counselors who have dedicated themselves to helping people unearth these presumed causative factors. I hadn't realized the extent of the controversy surrounding this issue.This fiction led me to read some of the true crime accounts of psychologists who have been in the forefront of exposing techniques of implanting false memories. This included some of the work of Elizabeth Loftus who has frequently testified in court, making juries aware of how readily eye witnesses to a crime can be misled into identifying the wrong person as perpetrator.The writing in this novel is fairly lucid, although sometimes the point of view shifts and the story is told from the perspective of some unidentified person. These interjections appear in slightly different type faces. This is occasionally a little confusing. But generally, you can skim along if you want, just getting the gist of the action. Or you can pause over slightly more complicated, literary sentences, such as the one describing the street thug's girlfriend. "She stared up…, unable to convey so dignified a sentiment as disdain, and resorting instead to hostility."The novel is set in England and contains some English slang. That girlfriend is reluctant to "grass" on anyone. But anyone who has seen any British-produced crime dramas on TV should have no trouble understanding these occasional colloquialisms.The pace picks up and the suspense builds, particularly in the last quarter of the book. So if the going seems a little slow through some sections - hang in there.

This book has a grabber of a premise. It seems possible that an ingenious serial killer is eliminating all the people who were on the psychiatric staff of a hospital years previous. The murderer (if indeed there is one) has made each death look like an accident that meshes perfectly with some risk the victim was accustomed to taking in pursuit of a hobby. A mountain climber falls off his ledge, a pilot's plane crashes, etc.The two surviving members of that psychiatric ward have to figure out who, what, and why, before they might be the next to fall prey. Their task is made all the more difficult because most of the regular police have taken the long span of deaths to indeed be nothing more than perfectly explainable accidents. Even if the authorities could be induced to entertain some suspicion, the surviving doctors are bound by their professional ethics not to divulge the names of any of their patients from those days.There are some subplots here that might appeal to readers with special niche interests. The question of the identity and fate of D. B. Cooper, the real-life hijacker who became a folk hero in the 1970's after he parachuted out of a 727 with the ransom money he'd demanded, is once again considered. There is also some space given to the problems of living with a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.Author Stephen White writes in a straightforward way that will move you quickly through the pages. There are just a couple of gaffs that might trip you and amuse you for a second.  When the two doctors first seem close to renewing their torrid romance of years before, they stand face-to-face to embrace. At this point, White writes that the male protagonist feels his ex-lover's bosom rub against his abdomen. Well, that would be anatomically difficult unless the woman was a Little Person, which she was not - or unless she had extraordinarily droopy breasts, which she did not.White doesn't use a poetic or prepossessing vocabulary. The book's ending is rather lame. But I liked the level of detail White applies to describe people and places. For example, when Dr. Gregory spreads a blueprint for his house renovation out on his kitchen table, White tells us that he held down the curling ends of the paper with a brass pepper mill and an unopened jar of peanut butter. It's details such as this that really put you in the scene, and that make you feel put at risk along with the lead characters in the story.

This is not a who-done-it. And contrary to its jacket blurb, it's not very suspenseful either. It gets off to an odd start. It presents an obvious problem in the first pages. But in the 1960's world in which this book was written, the problematic action comes out of the blue and really isn't given any context. So it's more puzzling than mysterious, more frustrating than nefarious. The book occasionally feels as if some pages, some passages are missing. It lacks a certain narrative flow.It's altogether a little odd and off-kilter and antique. It presents a world of rented rooms where both a Doctor and a transient might stay, using a common phone that's down the hall. It presents a world in which a woman's character might be besmirched by almost any sexual liaison. When the villain or villains do swing into action, they appear a bit Victorian, with a stereotypical Dickensian cast.However the book generally held my interest, if for no other reason than that it is so unlike most more recent novels that involve malicious intent. There are also passages of exceptionally good writing. Armstrong really makes the reader feel what a trip on LSD might be like. She also paints some characters very well, giving them touching human motives. For example, she has the protagonist's mother-in-law clutching onto her husband, as if she were making a justifying clutch at all the bad decisions she's ever made in her life.So in general, I can recommend "Balloon Man" if you like a gentler, lower-key book that's well off the beaten path of our current serial killers and psychopaths. But don't expect to meet a balloon man any too soon on these pages. He appears late and very briefly. And along with his wares, this story might leave you feeling a bit up in the air.

This book consists of short, bite-size chapters describing a wide variety of analyses the author made regarding the implications, reliability, or source, of words presented to him. He did this as a leading authority in the relatively new field of "forensic linguistics" that he has been a pioneer in formalizing.This isn't handwriting analysis. Nor is it exactly like the kinds of attribution studies that scholars have been doing for a long time in order to determine such questions as "Did Shakespeare really write all those plays?" Rather, Olsson's work is geared strictly toward giving impartial testimony in court, so it calls for both legal and linguistic knowledge.I had my attention called to this new discipline in an episode of TV's "Forensic Files." It seemed like a fascinating subject for anyone interested in writing, or in the meaning and nuances of words. As a result, I immediately bought this book, as well as Olson's textbook on the subject. Of the two books, "Word Crime" is aimed more at a general audience. Each chapter is a case study that describes some of the principles Olsson used in reaching a conclusion about certain contested statements.The chapters cover an amazingly wide range of topics. They include Olsson's analysis of both written and audio sources. Had a "suicide" note found beside a woman's body really been written by that woman - or did her husband write it to disguise a murder? Was a witness' statement spontaneous - or did his account have the earmarks of having been fed to him by police questioners? Were the charges of genocide made by two Rwandan women against one of their countrymen firsthand accounts - or were they based on hearsay? Was bestseller "The DaVinci Code" plagiarized by author Dan Brown - or is it original work? (In this last particularly interesting case, Olsson refrains from spelling out what opinion he rendered, leaving readers to form their own conclusion.)In general, this book didn't dampen my enthusiasm for pursuing the subject matter further. However sometimes Olsson's writing is a bit stuffy and uninspired. Some of the conclusions he rather laboriously arrives at seem obvious. Also, some of the cases he cites don't seem to warrant the analytic lengths he went to in order to render an opinion. For example, there's the case of the airplane pilot who had his flyers' Club privileges revoked and his plane and hangar confiscated when his fellow plane enthusiasts thought he was the author of some bitingly satirical articles about the Club in the local newspaper.Olsson also sometimes contradicts himself from one study to the next. In one place he warns that it's now deemed to be unproductive to use concordances in which you total up the number of times a word appears in a contested document as compared to a known document. However, then Olsson tells how he used various corpuses (similar to concordances) and also just simple Google searches to see how often a particular phrase appears in general usage. It's the same when it comes to considering the average length of sentences and the richness of the vocabulary used in two documents up for comparison. At first Olsson says such factors are "not indicative" of authorship, but in subsequent case studies he uses those very factors to help him reach an opinion.In other cases, Olsson appears to be somewhat biased, contrary to the strict code of conduct that any forensic scientist is supposed to follow. He reports the cases in which the courts or judges rendered decisions contrary to his recommendations, and in some of these cases, the reader might feel the courts were in the right. Also, many of these studies were conducted in England and so are based on questions of jurisprudence and police procedure that might be foreign to many American readers.But on the whole, this material is a real find. It opens a door to a whole new field of study. Better yet, it will likely sensitize readers to phrasing and nuance. Did the witness say, "I saw 'the' cut on his arm" - or "I saw 'a' cut on his arm"? That difference can make all the difference.Be sure to take advantage of the glossary at the end of the book that explains the more technical meaning of many of the terms that Olsson uses.

Like so many authors who write about relativity and quantum physics for the layman, Brian Clegg explains some aspects of the science well, and skips over other aspects of the field. There are very few books out there that satisfactorily explain every one of the facets of quantum physics that is explainable.What's good about this book:It starts out on an interesting note, providing some of Einstein's arguments against quantum physics in his original German. Those original words, along with the more exact translations provided, give readers a better feel for Einstein's real objection to quantum weirdness, rather than just compressing his views into the usual quote about God playing dice;It contains some interesting descriptions of the art of encryption and what quantum science might eventually contribute to sending secured messages;It includes a better-than-average description of the set-up of Alain Aspect's experiments, the experiments that finally seemed to demonstrate the existence of quantum entanglement and therefore of "spooky action at a distance."How author Brian Clegg could have made this book better:He doesn't devote enough time to giving the exact results of Aspect's experiments and to explaining their significance. That's really what I read this book in order to discover;Although this book is largely about the phenomenon of particle "entanglement," Clegg never fully defines what constitutes entanglement. I'd have liked more hand-holding paragraphs devoted to that basic idea;I would also have liked fuller definitions of basic concepts such as "solid state," and "qubit."Clegg says qubits (when these theoretical entities could be harnessed) would be capable of carrying such a wide range of informational values all at once in a superimposed state, that their use would greatly increase the processing capacity of computers and would essentially return us to the days of analog rather than digital mechanisms. In that regard, I would like to have read about the use of "fuzzy logic" that was all the rage in the '80's, and that still is the basis for a lot of computer operations. Since fuzzy logic also returns users to the broad range of capacity that characterized the analog age, it might have been interesting to learn how fuzzy logic would compare to the use of qubits.Finally, both the title and the jacket of this book are misleading. Clegg doesn't make it clear until the last few pages that, by the "God Effect," he in fact is referring to "entanglement." He also doesn't mention the "God Particle," the Higgs boson, (another strictly theoretical particle when this book was written in 2006) until those last few pages. So we don't know the reason for the book's title until the very end. Since this isn't a mystery thriller, in which the skillful author doesn't reveal the killer's identity until the last page, this delay in clarifying the book's subject matter might be a little frustrating.Then the book carries a second subtitle of "Time Travel, Teleportation, and the Ultimate Computer." Again, two of these topics aren't broached until the last chapters, and then only to be either effectively dismissed or misrepresented. Clegg tells about the invention of the telegraph and how that enabled savvy horse race bettors to learn which horse won a particular London race, and then to bet on that horse while bets were still being accepted in England's smaller, outlying towns. Clegg characterizes this advantage given by telegraph transmissions as "traveling back in time." That kind of loose, possibly metaphorical reference, once again muddies the concepts of "time" and "time travel."As for teleportation - Clegg says it won't be possible in any literal sense for the foreseeable future (or likely ever). So if you are tempted to get this book based on its jacket's promise of presenting Star Trek in action, you'll be disappointed.Finally, Clegg is quick to dismiss entanglement as a factor in producing consciousness. He says that consciousness is more robust and more easily explained than through the vagaries of entanglement. I think most scientists would object to this opinion that consciousness can ever be "easily" explained..However, this book is good enough to keep you reading, and will inspire you to go on to read other books on the subject in order to fill in more of the missing pieces of the puzzle of quantum physics.

The jacket blurb advertises this book as "Three on a Match." That's a good way to characterize these three stories featuring detective Poirot. Some say it's likely that the phrase "three on a match" came to signify bad luck as a result of men's wartime experience. Using one match to light three cigarettes kept the flame burning long enough for an enemy to get a precise reading on your location. That's what happens in this triad of tales written in the 1930's, the heyday of dead bodies in the library. The stories get progressively more dangerous from first to last, as they home in on the heart of malice.The first story, "Dead Man's Mirror," does indeed present the classic puzzle of an eccentric, blunderbuss of a Lord found dead in his den, an apparent suicide.  Poirot immediately thinks he sees beyond that easy assumption though. This story is fairly good. It has appeared in several collections of Christie's short stories, sometimes I think in slightly abbreviated form. But in the course of arriving at the truth, Poirot has to pick his way through quite a mesh of confounding circumstance. This is more a story of logistics than emotion, and some of the logistics become a little implausible.The second story, "Murder in the Mews" also involves an apparent suicide. A young woman finds her flat-mate dead in her bedroom. This story involves a clever twist, but the twist is telegraphed, perhaps a bit too broadly. For once, I tumbled to a part of the truth early on. Perhaps you will too.The third story, "Triangle at Rhodes" is the most dangerous one of the three though. It involves some subtle psychological interplay which can be more chilling than lots of legerdemain in the course of effecting either suicide or murder. This last story about a mismatched group of people on vacation in sunny Rhodes is quite short - something you can read almost in the flick of a match.All-in-all, this small book, like so many of  Christie's books, is ideal for the bedside or for plane trips. A study once showed that a large percentage of travelers have taken a Christie mystery with them on at least one of their trips. An interviewer once asked Christie herself - "What do you take along for light reading when you travel?" What could she say? When you ARE Agatha Christie - there's nothing left.Aren't we lucky that we aren't Agatha Christie, so we can enjoy books like this on our travels?

There's that old saying - "When all you have is a hammer, the whole world is a nail." Since the author has made the study of Tourette's such a large part of his life's work, and since his son was diagnosed with the Syndrome - he sees it everywhere. He genetically associates the Syndrome with just about every other kind of dysfunction you can imagine, from all forms of OCD - to autism - to alcoholism - to depression - to schizophrenia - to hyper-sexuality, hypo-sexuality, and homosexuality - and the list goes on. In the end, he even says that he can see himself as being likely responsible for passing at least some part of the Tourette's gene complex onto his son, because he has been a workaholic all his life. Thus even working hard at a career gets labeled as a form of Tourette's.So Comings does tend to cast his net too wide, dragging in every kind of fishy malady that's out there as a result. This far-flung association might tend to make the reader skeptical about the whole body of his work. This approach also obviously will make it difficult for future researchers to focus down on any real remedies.What's more, it becomes difficult to see why Comings specifically chose Tourette's as the fulcrum of this whole gamut of disorders. Couldn't he just as easily have made something like compulsive hand-washing or any other OCD behavior as the centerpiece of his researches, and hung every other disorder, including Tourette's, on that hook?However, Comings researches, as reported here, still make a valuable contribution to the understanding of Tourette's and all compulsive behaviors. Comings was a pioneer in this field, and he hauled the Syndrome out of the Dark Ages when it was blamed on a mother's aloofness or on some other parenting failure (usually of course on the mother's part). He moved it from the sphere of vague Freudian accusation onto the firmer ground of genetics.His extensive observations also served to raise awareness of the Syndrome in the medical community and relieved many parents of their struggle to get a diagnosis for their child's troubling behavior. Comings took complaints seriously and took the time to observe over the long haul. He came to understand that someone with Tourette's could suppress symptoms for a while and appear to be trouble-free when sitting in a Doctor's office, again causing the Doctor to accuse the mother of being overly protective and of imagining symptoms, or even of imputing symptoms to her child.Comings also has assembled a huge number of family histories, charting what he found to be the increased incidence of OCD, alcoholism, and other troubling symptoms in the family trees of Tourette's sufferers. These records can serve as a valuable data bank for all kinds of researchers, although again, the readiness with which an uncle of a proband Tourette's sufferer gets labeled as an alcoholic with a habit of flashing school girls might be called into question. Comings does tell what standardized personality tests he used to label individuals with the variety of associated problems he finds. However, readers might still find these histories to be a bit random. Comings himself admits that other researchers have looked at his data and found NO linkages to Tourette's.The records might also be of minimal value in differentiating the families of sufferers from non-suffering families. Almost every family, even those without any Tourette's complaints, can probably find any number of uncles, great-uncles, and cousins, who were alcoholic flashers in their family trees. Nevertheless, Comings' records still stand as an impressive repository of suggestive data, and if nothing else, make for interesting reading.So all-in-all, I can recommend reading Comings if you have any interest at all in the subject of compulsive disorders or in genetics in general. In this later book, he traces how his thinking developed from the assumption that Tourette's might be linked to one specific gene or to a small number of interacting genes - to his current opinion that it could be the result of a complex multitude of interacting genes and their triggers, even including what we'd currently call "epigenetic" factors.However, if you keep in mind that Comings' ideas have developed away from any single-gene theory, you might still find his earlier book, "Tourette Syndrome and Human Behavior," more informative. That earlier, longer book serves as a lucid primer in genetics and includes many diagrams that clearly illustrate the principles of heredity involved. That 1990 book also includes more detailed family histories. These accounts of dysfunction are forensically fascinating and make you feel as if you're a detective following a familial trail of clues to solve the great mystery of Tourette's Syndrome.

This is the chronicle of what we'd call "besties" taking the grand tour after their graduation in the 1920's. They travel with an enthusiasm and innocence that would be rare today.Skinner and Kimbrough describe their adventures sailing from Canada and then taking in the highlights of England and France. Since Skinner was the child of a famed theatrical family, the two young women were able to stay longer and see more on their travels than the average tourist. Readers get a hilarious view of the Seinfeld-esque contretemps they experience.One of them gets "attacked in bed." The two learn about sex from "Leda and the Swan" at the Cluny Museum. Emily gets to flaunt the command of the French language she has acquired from road signs as she drops phrases such as "safety valve" and "No spitting" into sophisticated continental conversation with H. G. Wells and Margaret Sanger.But there are some serious lessons to be drawn from this book, written about twenty years after the fact. It's good to see how society has progressed in some of its attitudes. Cornelia's mother explains homosexuality as an unfortunate affliction that, in spite of being involuntary, can't be condoned. The girls aren't allowed to meet one actor because he was divorced. As far as the status of women goes, the girls realize that "A woman alone, or with another woman (which counts as the same thing)" is completely discounted in France. Finally, one of the girls sees something in a wedding picture that a veteran shows her - something that we've probably all seen in such old pictures, but whose implications we didn't interpret so keenly. She sees the groom standing behind the seated bride, his hand firmly clamped on her shoulder, "as if holding her down."There are also references to some of the fashions and famous people of the 20's that most readers will probably find too distant to remember.But for the most part, this book will make you laugh and will lighten your heart. It will enable you to face life with a new joie de vivre.

This book is disappointing.  Mr. Tompkins, the intrepid adventurer in the realm of physics, doesn't really play any part in it. Outside of a few interest anecdotes, It becomes just a straightforward overview of the development of ideas in the field of physics, including the more baffling field of quantum physics.Some of these concepts aren't even very well explained. For example, early on, there are confusing references to anodes and cathodes - first one, then the other being cited as the negative electrode in a cell. I was hoping Gamov would make the differential use of the terms clear with some of the quixotic clarity he mustered in the actual Mr. Tompkins books. However he doesn't. He lets the reader flounder with these terms, and with only partial explanations of many other principles.He goes on to recount some of Faraday's experiments, but doesn't explain them or their significance as well as a reader might find in other books on the subject. And so these pages proceed, basically as a rehash of information available in many other places. The first pages do include some interesting history, such as how the "Milky Way" got its name. But then, it just devolves into routine definitions (what's a millimeter - how many grams in an ounce, etc.) and routine reviews of basic information in the field.In summary, I couldn't see any real need for this book. You can probably find most of these concepts better explained in any decent high school physics book, and certainly in many of the hundreds of "Physics for the Layman" and "Quantum Physics for the Layman" books out there. Many of these other sources also would likely include more vivid, clarifying illustrations, which are very sparse here. It seems as if Gamov might just have written this book under contract to produce something, anything - in the wake of his popular Mr. Tompkins' series. Gamov didn't seem to bother to exercise his genius for explanation here.In order to find that, you need to go back to the original Mr. Tompkins books which take you, along with Mr. Tompkins, on wild rides into the fascinating realms of the very big and the very tiny.

Rothbotham writes this psychological thriller in the first person. The narrator/protagonist is a psychologist who is found to have incriminating links to several murder victims. At first I somewhat missed having the multi-layered perspective that's available to the omniscient observer used in many novels. But this book's approach gives the reader an urgent sense of running along with Joseph O'Loughlin as he races to clear himself from suspicion and to catch the person he believes to be the real killer before he strikes again.There are a few fault-lines here that might cause readers to stub their toes as they follow along. For example, the first murder victim is found after having been buried for ten days by a canal. The psychologist immediately recognizes the body as being that of a woman who'd been his patient some time before. In reality, it seems unlikely that anyone buried by water for ten days would remain so easily recognizable. Therefore, this book probably would not be a good choice if you're looking for realistic autopsy examinations and forensic analysis.Then there are occasional usages that might bring American readers in particular up short. There are some very British references that I had to research in order to understand. One character is referred to as having "a Scorse accent, such as you might find in a Ken Loach film."Another factor that might dampen a reader's enthusiasm a little is that Joseph is often not a very sympathetic character. He never refers to his father except as "God's personal physician-in-waiting." About the sixth time he thinks of his father in these terms, the snide sarcasm has definitely gotten tedious and intrusive. What's more, it makes it look as if Joseph has such an axe to grind, that the reader, along with the police, might begin to suspect that he really IS the brutal serial killer.Joseph also has had major failings as a husband, and he has not come all that far in reforming. In addition, he exhibits some minor, but just as annoying, sexist attitudes. He refers to Welsh weddings and funerals as being routinely officiated over by "women in support hose." He describes some elderly waitresses as being of the type who "should be home putting curlers in their hair." This is the kind of routine condescension one finds when actors dismissively talk about their matinees as being predictably stocked with "blue-haired old ladies." Such a tone would not be tolerated if the standard activities of different ethnic groups were being described. So if you are looking for a novel that features a thoroughly decent and heroic lead character - again, this might not be the book for you.However, "Suspect" is very well-written. It's full of apt, evocative figures of speech. One character, who might be the killer, ominously announces, "I was once a pawn, but I reached the end of the board. I can be anything now." When Joseph speculates that his counsel might be making an impression, albeit an unwelcome one, on a patient, he says, "My words are leaking through and expanding the cracks & crevices of his mind like water turned to ice."There are other good points about this book. As Joseph deals with his recent diagnosis of Parkinson's, he conveys some good information about the prognosis and treatment of his form of the disease. You'll also read something about the symptoms of schizophrenia. Finally, the motive for the killings turns out to be something different from the standard love or money or madness. It's a motive that might call all those in the counseling professions to take stock and think twice.The book slips into being a bit like an over-the-top action movie at the end. But it's a good, taut read most of the way.

The first part of this book didn't convince me that Patton was assassinated, especially that he was assassinated with a one-two punch. It just seemed too difficult and unlikely that Patton could purposely have been involved in a car collision, then when that only paralyzed but didn't kill him, that a stealthy agent could have finished him off in the hospital by some exotic means such as cyanide spray.As if this "how" weren't improbable enough, the "who" seemed even more unbelievable. Wilcox initially advances a dodgy individual involved in all sorts of OSS and other spy operations as the main claimant to have done the deed. However this man's information wavers with each re-telling. What's more he seems to be a blowhard whose facts don't jibe. For example, he claimed to have had one of his hands permanently mangled in a torture episode, but at least one later picture of him that's included in this book shows him with two perfectly shaped hands.But then Wilcox's claims about who might have been involved in the assassination branch out from there to become a hodgepodge of implication and innuendo reminiscent of Oliver North's view of the Kennedy assassination. Everyone from FDR and Stalin, down through Eisenhower and Donovan (head of the OSS), and then through a host of Russian and Ukrainian functionaries, are implicated in intimating a desire to get rid of Patton - a desire that might have gotten translated into action without anyone's ever having issued a specific order.Wilcox obviously did a huge amount of research for this book. He minutely went through everything available in all sorts of national document repositories (making note of what was suspiciously NOT available along the way). He examined the car which Patton's Ft. Knox Museum staff purports to be the one in which Patton's crash occurred. He even had old car buffs and car crash reconstructionists examine the Cadillac (along with accident scene photos) to confirm that the car now on display is likely not the car in which Patton was jolted to his ultimate demise. Wilcox interviewed countless people involved in the crash and their relatives, noting how their stories suspiciously shape-shifted over the years.However, it's plain that Wilcox pursues all these leads from a strong anti-Communist, pro-Patton stand, and therefore is likely looking only for evidence that would support his view of Patton as heroic victim. He definitely labels Robert Oppenheimer, Alger Hiss, the Rosenbergs, and others, as Communist spies rather than recognizing that the status of many of these individuals has been a contested, murky issue to this day. So Wilcox comes to the case with a Patton-could-do-no-wrong bias.Wilcox even leaves out details that might vaguely mesh with his conspiracy claims, but that would put Patton in a bad light. For example, Wilcox doesn't mention that Patton had a mistress and that she seemingly committed suicide not long after Patton's death.However, all this bias and these likely fabricated or exaggerated memories notwithstanding, I did end up feeling Wilcox might be onto something after all. In the later part of his book, he does a good job of recounting the chronology of Patton's campaigns and of the ill-will he generated along the way. Wilcox points out the urgency U.S. officials felt to cozen the Russians and to maintain our friendship with them - and how dangerously disruptive Patton was to these delicate diplomatic relations. With all the other anti-Russian information that was suppressed (violently if necessary) at the time - it begins to be more and more logical that Patton might have been suppressed too.Wilcox demonstrates how cheap all life was in the espionage entanglements of post-War Europe. It was a world of betrayal. There were proven assassinations galore. What's more, the lives of American and British POWs, German refugees (and virtually all other refugees), agents and double agents, were all so easily sacrificed in order to prevent any news of Stalin's massacres and of Russia's overall killing bleakness from leaking out. Wilcox does an excellent job of putting the reader back into that grim and mercenary reality, and in so doing, makes his case at least plausible.You might want to check out the movie "Patton" to view in conjunction with reading this book. The movie amazingly manages to capture so much of the waxing and waning of relationships between Patton, Eisenhower, Bradley, and others, through the series of  campaigns Patton led and the campaigns from which he was so pointedly sidelined. It dramatically summarizes the dangerous liaisons that Wilcox finally so ably expands upon in "Target Patton."

This inside look at a real jury's deliberations does very much parallel some of the dynamics shown in the classic movie "12 Angry Men." The actual jurors here were perhaps not as dramatically angry or impatient as some of Henry Fonda's co-jurors, but they did have to work their way through a variety of personality conflicts. As in the movie, some of these real-life jurors also were swayed back and forth between "Guilty" and "Not Guilty" as first one juror, then another held the floor with an opinion. These individuals also paralleled the fictional jurors in that they extrapolated from the evidence presented during the trial, supplying from their own experience some of the missing links left when defense attorney Hawk simply rested  his case without calling any witnesses.In his introduction to this book, author Villasenor says that he interviewed all the jurors several times on each point in order to arrive at an accurate composite recollection of every aspect of their debate during sequestration. However, it seems impossible for him to be exactly recreating every word, every gesture in the way he recounts here. It's more likely that he had to resort to some of the techniques that an author of historical novels uses. He likely recaptured the gist of the progression of the jurors' decision-making process - but necessarily had to imaginatively fill in the specifics of their conversation.There are a few points about this book that readers might find a little frustrating. First of all, it can be difficult to get to know all the jurors and to keep their differing views straight. However, Villasenor provides a list of jurors and attorneys at the beginning of the book, with thumbnail identifiers you can refer back to as you read.Second, you might initially find it a little frustrating to be thrown into deliberations about the crimes Juan Corona was accused of, without knowing what those crimes were. I hadn't been very familiar with the 1970's serial killings of migrant workers that Corona was charged with having committed. But it was amazing how soon a reader is brought up to speed on the facts of the crimes just by eavesdropping on the jurors' debate. Ultimately, this turned out to be an excellent way of learning the details of the crimes themselves - better than any simple chronological narrative could probably have provided.All in all, this stands as a rare look into what goes on behind the closed doors of a jury room.

This book contains snippets of science. Each interesting scientific fact is presented in a bite-size page accompanied by a cartoon drawing. So this makes for ideal bedside reading. You can learn a little something each night before dozing off.A lot of the facts are of the myth-breaking, believe-it-or-not variety. The author says that the "melt-down" of the 3-Mile Island nuclear plant hardly raised surrounding levels of radiation at all. Hurricanes are not stronger or more frequent now than in other eras. Wine and liquor sold in the U.S. must, by law, be radioactive. Most organically grown produce is vastly more toxic than produce grown with conventional large-scale spraying/fertilizing techniques.Muller explains all the above surprising assertions. However, some of the facts are presented all too briefly. The information is given in a hit-and-run form that cries out for a little more elaboration. For example, Muller points out that the Earth's magnetic poles flip every 800,000 years or so. The switch takes a couple hundred years, during which time, he says the Earth has so magnetic field at all. Can this be true? How did birds migrate during these magnetic black-outs? How did the hundreds of other organic and geologic processes that depend on the presence of some magnetic field push through so that the continuity of life was preserved on Earth during these periods?Well, such quick peeks into scientific phenomena can inspire a reader to research the topics more fully. These pages make you realize a lot of what you don't know - and that's really what learning is all about.

This book has all the elements of a classic thriller. It has a stalking killer and a series of vulnerable women. It also gives the reader a clue to the killer's identity which I didn't catch, but which, like all good hints, makes the answer seem so obvious - once you know.Tom Savage takes the time to give his characters some individuality, even repeating a religious joke that circulated in the family of one victim. But happily, none of his victims have quagmire back-stories of drug addiction, alcoholism, or other such "human failings" which so often seem to be mandatory in modern mystery stories.The writing here is generally quite good. Savage knows how to make the most of that pivotal moment in all good thrillers when the killer reveals himself/herself with a terrifying turn of expression. The killer "continued to smile at her, but she noticed the subtle change that crept into it. The gleam, the sudden look of triumph…"Savage goes beyond what many  thriller writers offer in that he also humanizes the killer. He allows that individual to have a say, so that the reader can feel the sense of humiliation and anger that has become a goad to action.Finally, you'll find real New York settings and some apt quotes from Shakespeare here, allowing you to consider your time spent reading this book as being "educational," rather than simply an indulgence in sensationalism.

This book captures a lot of the details of the debate between two giants of 20th century economic theory - but it is a bit dry in that it doesn't quite capture whatever spirit or essential genius either man might have brought to the match. It portrays two men confined in a ring roped off by presumptive concerns over the need to balance unemployment, inflation, interest rates, etc. The larger philosophical genius that Hayek especially showed in his "Road to Serfdom" largely gets lost in this more technical exchange.In the first half of the book, Hayek and Keynes are shown sparring over what was basically a form of the more modern debate between supply-side economics and demand-side economics. Hayek fought for the former, generally settling into a pattern that emphasized the necessity of keeping economies vital and growing by encouraging measures that led to more production. Keynes fought more on the demand-side by encouraging housewives to "Spend, spend, spend!"In the course of this exposition, the author sometimes explains easy terms at great length - terms such as "inflation." However when he comes to more difficult concepts, such as whether or not to peg currencies to the gold standard - he breezes right by, leaving less technically trained readers puzzling over why either Keynes or Hayek would have taken the stand he did on the question. Well, I suppose if the author had gone into a detailed explanation of these more complicated subjects, he would have turned the book into a lengthy text on economics. Still, it's frustrating not to be able to fit the positions the economists took on these matters into their larger philosophies.Wapshott might also be a bit too breezy in some of his chapter titles. He repeatedly uses a Wild West analogy. We have: "Pistols at Dawn," "Return Fire," "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence," etc. Again, some readers might feel there has been a slight bias against Hayek in this shoot-out. One chapter title is "Keynes Takes America." However, two principal chapters focusing on Hayek are entitled "Hopelessly Stuck" and "The Road to Nowhere." In the text itself, Keynes' opinions are often stated as given facts - "It was." But Hayek's opinions usually are labeled as just that - "He believed…"However, the latter half of the book becomes a valuable lesson in recent history. Starting with FDR and going through some of the second Bush administration, Wapshott summarizes the Presidents' economic policies, and in so doing provides a valuable recap of the times. These chapters illustrate how much the Presidents have been like Supreme Court appointees in that their earlier stated views and party affiliations were often no predictor of what economic tack they would take in office. Republicans often ended up promoting Keynesian policy; and Democrats often ended up instituting Hayek's programs.Through all their vacillations though, the officials rarely seem to think beyond the limited alternatives and definitions set by the Keynes/Hayek debate. It was always a see-saw of "spur demand" - no, "spur production." That surprised me in reading these chapters, because there were some other economic thinkers who had presented possibilities outside this clinch.For example, an American economist, Henry George, who was hugely popular in the early 20th century, had spoken to the anomaly of there being so much want in times of depression - so much work to be done, but so little employment. George still has followers today who run schools teaching his philosophy in most major cities. His solution of a single tax on land might seem to be a little creakily Victorian now in that he presented it with such gung-ho assurance as a panacea for all economic/social ills. However, George's insights into how speculative bubbles repeatedly arise and how they repeatedly lead to depressions/recessions should have informed the Keynes/Hayek debate.Then there are books written about "Unjobbing." These books are often written by and for back-to-the land environmentalists, but they contain more general insights into how people might think outside of the same old categories of "supply, demand, and full employment."Finally, writers such as Jane Jacobs discuss how to achieve vital economies without any reference at all to that endless teeter-tottering between unemployment and inflation, between inflation and interest rates, between supply and demand. She takes a personal, on-the-ground approach that informs about which kinds of industry ramify to create more and more vigorous economic activity - activity that satisfies actual needs rather than artificially manufactured needs goaded by a Keynesian command to "Spend, spend, spend."So in summary, this book presents interesting history, but I'm not sure you can come away from it with any net gain in insight into economics. For that, you might want to look into writers who have thought outside the box. You might want to read: "Progress and Poverty" by Henry George, "Unjobbing" by Michael Fogler, and "The Economy of Cities" by Jane Jacobs.

This true crime account would be of special interest to Midwesterners who were alive in the 1960's and who might be ripe to have their memories jogged about the people and circumstances surrounding the brutal slaying of Valerie Percy, daughter of Charles Percy. "Charles Percy" was a household name throughout Illinois for decades. He had been President of Bell & Howell, and then had gone on to be elected Senator from Illinois. He became a national figure with Presidential aspirations.Considering the fame of the people involved and the fact that the victim was a beautiful young girl, it's odd that more books haven't been written about the crime.
