This one seems to be the only book devoted solely to the case. Perhaps the reason more authors haven't tackled the subject is that the Percy family has so consistently asked for privacy and has not cooperated with outside attempts to re-examine the tragedy. A member of the family had the case re-investigated a few years ago and reportedly came up with a suspect, but the name of that individual has not been released.So in 2013, when this book was written, author Glenn Wall did as much as he could on his own, with somewhat limited access to the evidence. He advances the name of the man he thinks responsible for the murder in the first few pages of the book, not keeping readers in suspense. His candidate does indeed seem likely, although I have read enough true crime books to be aware how often there are a remarkably high number of off-balance, potentially homicidal individuals living in the area of any crime scene. This case was no exception.In addition to the candidate Wall names, there had been a young man with a history of some mental stress problems living in the Percy guesthouse. Then, although Valerie had a steady boyfriend (who was in England at the time), there were other young men who dined at the Percy home (including on the night of the murder), at least one of whom thought HE and Valerie were a couple. There was also a home invasion gang that had been operating in the area. There was an asylum near Percy's mansion. And on it goes.You will find a few points against Wall's candidate being the perpetrator. For example, many who investigated the crime concluded that it must have been committed by someone with extensive knowledge of the Percy home, something Wall's suspect probably didn't have. Then here too, as famously figured in a Sherlock Holmes story, there was a dog who did NOT bark. So readers are given a lot of possibilities to consider.The book also serves to take the reader back to the early 60's in Chicago - to the retaliatory marches against Martin Luther King, to the Speck murders, to the case of Judith Mae Andersen whose body was found floating in a tin drum, and to the many misdeeds of Chicago politicians, one of whom was found to have hundreds of thousands of dollars, bilked from the public, in shoeboxes. (Wall, wrongly I think, attributes the shoebox stash to Illinois Secretary of State Carpentier, when in reality it was Carpentier's successor, Paul Powell, who siphoned off the money.) But Wall otherwise seems to be a reliable reporter.If nothing else, this book serves to remind us that the "good old days" could be as deadly and depraved as the modern times we are always lamenting.

This truly is "something different," to use Monty Python's segue. It's witty, bizarre, enthralling - and features a real individualist as its lead character. You won't have met anyone like Gabriela before. As one co-worker says of her, she is sort of oddly “child-like.” But while she has maintained a child's capacity to become utterly fascinated by some seemingly incidental question, the particular subject of her fascination reflects anything but what we regard as childish innocence.Her fascination results in an unusual scene of dueling obsessions that will keep you guessing. Can this unlikely young woman hold her own against the most ruthless of homicidal maniacs? Who will win, and what will be the prize for winning - besides life itself?The answer might not be strictly anatomically correct, but it's gory good fun.What's more, this movie made me aware of a lucrative job opportunity. I've recommended "Curdled" to out-of-work acquaintances seeking extremely high-paying jobs that don't require much specific training. Although a few later movies, such as "Sunshine Cleaning," featured  crime scene clean-up as a career path - this is the original and best training film on the subject. So if you aren't a “gore-hound,” but can stand the gore, this is the film to get you started.

This review is for the more casual movie-goer who doesn't necessarily want to make a study of a film or fit it into a director's larger oeuvre, but who wants entertainment and an emotional experience. As hard to figure out as "Mulholland Drive" is sometimes, it really delivers on that score.I'm grateful to other reviewers who have lived with this film for a while and have sorted out what might be its its dream inclusions, its chronology, the identity of its characters, and its overall plot and meaning. Many of those who have analyzed this film in that way have found it to be a masterpiece. However, even if you are like me and generally don't want to exert yourself making sense of a movie, you're still likely to find this one's scenes individually memorable and mesmerizing.Just to cite a few scenes that I found unforgettable: There's Naomi Watts' character's two renditions of her audition reading. Her first practice reading in her apartment is well-done and engaging, but it's a rather straightforward reading of rather banal material. However, her second, presumably at-the-casting-offices reading with Chad Everett, adds a breath-taking erotic twist of interpretation to the words. There was a hint of interpreting such a conventionally scripted scene in that way in the 1940's movie “Gilda.” But this more sustained reading gives the viewer time to be drawn into such a possibility of meaning the opposite of what you say. This scene should be required viewing in every acting class. It will open aspiring actors up to the possibility of new levels of meaning in any script.The scene in the all-night vaudeville theater is heart-breaking, and offers a telling philosophical view of the nature of life and illusion.Virtually every scene is a glittering gem in its own way, so you don't need to care exactly why they are strung together the way they are to make this a worthwhile experience. Even the more prosaic scenes, such as the early one showing two men chatting in a diner, the one man narrating his frightening dream to the other – are so steeped in some larger atmosphere of menace and amazement, that they are riveting. They give the initial impression of being set in the real, everyday world, but as you get into them, you are overcome with a sense of being in some bizarro, mirror-image reflection of everyday life.It amazingly captures the fear many of us might have of that cheery, apple-dumpling, seemingly encouraging grandmotherly figure in our lives. It intimates we might have reason to suspect that behind that facade, there's a character of ghastly malevolence.Hardly anything could be more menacing than the soft-spoken, matter-of-fact cowboy who arranges a meeting at night in an old corral outside of town with its guttering light bulb over the ranch gate. You are left with an inner quaking apprehension that no mere gun threats could effect when the cowboy says, “If you do good, you will see me one more time. If you do bad, you will see me two more times.”If any movie could convert me from being a casual movie-goer to a student of film, this would be the one to do it. It inspires me to want to see it over and over and more deeply each time. It is magnificent.

Unless you really have an intense interest in this case about three youths accused of Satanic cult killings - you might find there's a little TMI included here. There are actually four discs in this "Trilogy."The first disc contains an account of the crime and the initial investigation. It's essential and interesting. The directors do a good job of recording the reactions of townspeople in the aftermath of the crime. You feel you really get to know some of these people. However sometimes a viewer might wish the reporters would have injected themselves in the inquiry more. There were questions that needed to have been asked. For example, many felt that the victims could not have been killed by the riverbed where their bodies were found because there was virtually no trace of blood around the scene. The water could have washed a lot of blood away, but if the theory about the killing having taken place elsewhere was correct, there must have been a blood-spattered room somewhere nearby. However we don't see any such search being made.The second disc is largely superfluous. Unless you have a lot of extra time, you can probably skip it. It summarizes the crime and its prosecutions and does follow-up interviews, but most of it is repetitious.You can move right on to the third disc. That includes the results of the prosecution of the three youths (now turned into young men) who had been presumed to have been acting in the throes of Satanic worship. It also includes the results of the activism on their behalf. Most interesting though is the follow-up interviews of some of the leading townspeople, showing how they and their attitudes have changed over the years. I found that one of the least likeable of the rabble rousers in town had actually turned into one of the most likeable and self-aware of individuals. These discs end on the optimism of how people can perhaps change for the better.There isn't much on the bonus fourth disc. Its brief content could have been included on one of the other discs. However its main feature, an interview with Jason Baldwin, again leaves the viewer with a more optimistic view of the human race. What comes across as the young man's essential kindness and persistent humanity in the face of all the trials he'd been through, sets an example for all of us.If you are not interested in the kind of in-depth and often repetitious view of the case that this Trilogy offers, you might check out the movie "Devil's Knot" starring Colin Firth and Reese Witherspoon. The movie gives a fairly good thumbnail look at the personalities and the issues involved in the crime.But don't expect any case-closed resolution with the documentary Trilogy, the slightly fictionalized "Devil's Knot," or Mara Leveritt's book dealing with the case. That's not what these accounts are about. They are more a representation of how hysteria and even something akin to mob rule can carry proceedings away from justice. In that sense, they are reminiscent of the title of another, earlier movie - "A Town Without Pity."

This account of Joseph Kallinger’s fetishes, obsessions, and hallucinations probably describes the objective facts of his progression into murderous madness adequately enough. However, I’m not sure that the coloration that author Schreiber puts on those facts can be completely trusted.First of all, Flora Schreiber was the author of “Sybil,” an account of multiple personalities that has been widely discredited. The charge has been made that Schreiber got too close to the subject of that book and ended up eliciting or imputing the many personalities that individual eventually manifested. It’s possible that happened again in this case. Schreiber tells how she finally won the right to interview Kallinger in prison, and that he came to enjoy and rely on their association. She said he remembered more about his actions and motives as their interview sessions progressed. Some readers might suspect that Kallinger was becoming a sort of Scheherazade, “remembering” more and more in order to keep a good story going and to insure Schreiber’s continued visits.The possibility that Kallinger might to some degree have been leading Schreiber on is reinforced by contradictions that emerge in his narrative of himself. On the one hand, he says he believed his parents were omniscient, able to see through walls, able to divine all his intentions and deeds. But then shortly after that, he says he realized his parents were afraid of him, but he didn’t know why. He was sure they couldn’t know that he had lured a little boy into the woods.Then Schreiber sprinkles the account with some rather rickety Freudian analysis. There’s some questionable dream interpretation and some intrusive reference to Jung’s theory of “racially inherited psychic materials.”This is a fairly exhaustive, depressing account. Despite its length though, there were areas I wish Schreiber would have explored further. While some mention is made of the physical problems Kallinger might have been suffering from, she attributes most of his aberrant behavior to the misdeeds of his adoptive parents. I wish Schreiber might have considered the possibility that he was suffering from some form of Tourette’s Syndrome - and various physical imbalances resulting from the glue fumes he inhaled in connection with his cobbler’s trade. I also wish Schreiber would have gone into more detail about Kallinger’s trials. Why was he given such mild punishment for the fires he set in order to collect insurance? Finally, I wish Schreiber would have more fully examined the relationship between Kallinger and his son Michael. The latter is represented as being even more vicious and depraved than his father, so the reader is left wondering why his complicity in the crimes was so largely ignored.I’m not really sure I learned anything about the psychology of deranged killers in general from this book, but then that behavior remains a mystery through all analyses and accounts. Bill James, the author of “Popular Crime,” a compendium of accounts of notorious crimes and books written about them – says this was the most terrifying of all the true crime books he’d ever read. With the several detours “Shoemaker” takes into pop psychology, it didn’t quite strike me that way. However, the chapter describing Kallinger’s most inexplicable murder does brand a truly sad, searing image in the reader’s mind.

This makes for an attractive, eye-catching little piece of jewelry. It's a good conversation piece, and is especially fun for creating a campy, retro look. It keeps good time, even including a second hand. It's easy to set, using just a single, old-fashioned pull-out knob. There are no complicated series of buttons you have to push to set the time, like opening a top-level security vault. What a relief!The back of the watch face itself seems to be the button battery that operates the watch. It uses one of the larger, 3/4-inch button batteries, but the battery's number doesn't appear here.There are two barely discernible brazed-down sections on the battery that can possibly serve as places to wedge the battery out when it needs replacing. I'm not sure that this will be possible though. I haven't tried removing the battery for changing yet, and my unit didn't come with any instructions. However, it looks as if it will be a long time before the battery will run down, so it's likely I won't be facing the problem any time soon.The watch band is expandable, designed to fit a wide range of finger sizes, although it looks as if this style ring I bought might fall off the fingers of very thin people.The only down-side to this finger-style of watch is that it is not quite as comfortable as I thought it would be. You more often apply pressure to your fingers than you do to your wrist. For example, when driving, I find I'm applying continuous pressure to that finger, so the watch begins to cut into my flesh and feel a bit of a nuisance. Therefore, I don't use it when I know I'll be driving a lot, or doing any sort of manual labor, or when I'm traveling and know I'll have occasion to wash my hands frequently.The ring is most suitable as a cute novelty accessory for a night on the town.

I’d hate to turn this very interesting book into a chore, but, like me, you might find it useful to take notes as you read. There’s so much packed in here that I found I hadn’t appreciated on the first read-through, but that I was able to think about more when I reviewed my notes. (What was it again that James said about the significance of the proximity of several intersecting public transit lines to the series of “Boston Strangler” murders?)The book’s title is a little misleading in that it tries to provide a sociological justification for people’s interest in the topic of popular crime. But that needlessly inflates the subject. The real heart of this book is simply author Bill James’ perceptive account of crimes that have made the news over the centuries. Most of the crimes are presented in chronological order, starting with the presumed abduction of Elizabeth Canning in 1753, and going through the more recent O.J. Simpson and Scott Peterson cases.The author gives just a thumbnail account of some crimes. But he really excels when he pauses to analyze a crime and express his opinion on the probability of different people’s guilt. His chatty, avuncular style draws you in around the fireside to consider who really “done it.” He demonstrates how far common sense and observation can take a person in solving a puzzle.The Sam Shepherd case is a prime example of his ability to analytically re-enact. He puts readers in the shoes of any likely perpetrator as that individual would have had to navigate right past the couch where Sam Shepherd was presumably sleeping, and make his way up the stairs to Mrs. Shepherd’s bedroom in the dark.Moving on to the Kennedy assassination, James has become convinced of the correctness of a novel interpretation of the crime – one that posits neither a conspiracy nor Lee Harvey Oswald’s exclusive responsibility. How can it be neither one nor the other? James thinks he knows.The one analysis of his that didn’t much convince me was the one dealing with the Lizzie Borden case. James says the solution proposed in the Elizabeth Montgomery movie would have been too unthinkably shocking for the day. Well, I don’t know about that. Shocking, yes – but perhaps not unthinkable. Still, his examination of the different possibilities is enlightening.By reviewing all these crimes of the centuries, the reader will learn a lot of history. Just as you learn more in a museum if you go there with some focusing questions rather than with only an intention of wandering aimlessly through the thousands of artifacts – so you can learn more about history by examining these key crime questions than you can by simply attacking an exhaustive narrative of names, dates, and events. James’ analysis of the kind of crimes characteristic of the Civil War is especially telling. He puts our current presumably “high” crime rate in perspective.He also paints an engrossing picture of the early part of the 20th century, the rise of the labor movement, the rise of the anarchist and Communist movements, and the consequent epidemic fear of certain kinds of “terrorist” crimes. He cites the strict immigration laws that followed in the wake of the Sacco and Vanzetti trial. These restrictions led to a sudden, severe contraction of the labor pool and, in James’ view, contributed to the Depression.That the Depression might, in part, have been caused by too few available laborers, is a unique historical view. But it’s characteristic of James’ often offbeat, but compelling homespun wisdom about causes and effects.His delineation of the likely biography of “The Killer of Kingsbury Row” in Cleveland in the 1930’s is a stunning model of profiling. James is truly Sherlockian in his projection of the killer’s probable military career (right down to what unit he might have served in), his prison record, marital status, and neighborhood of residence. Any reader willing to spend a little time on “Ancestry.com” should be able to come up with a name. James is similarly keenly perceptive as he walks us through some aspects of the Zodiac and the Jon-Benet Ramsey cases.The book includes a very helpful bibliography and filmography, with James’ rating of the usefulness of the various treatments.Overall, this book proved to be a real find - an outstanding addition to my true crime collection.

This pendant is pretty, but very delicate in every way. Its chain and clasp have not broken, however, I have difficulty trusting them. I think I will buy a new chain for it - one that's sturdier and a little longer.Also, the pendant itself is so slender that it's difficult to tell it has a Mobius strip twist in it. You have to come up close and examine the pendant in order to appreciate that it's really a topological oddity. For all intents and purposes, people looking at me think I'm just wearing a ring on a chain.If I had it to do over, I think I would buy a Mobius pendant that's a little thicker and wider - so that its twist would be evident from more of a distance. But this item is shiny and pretty, and looks expensive.

This couch exactly filled the bill for me. It is very comfortable, exactly the right firmness for my taste. I like the pillow arms-rests. They allow a person to stretch out and use the couch to sleep on without getting a sore neck.The couch was easy to assemble. You just slide the back cushions into their tracks. No nails or screws required. It took less than 30 seconds for me to complete the assembly. This couch is exactly the same size and style as the couch I'm replacing it with - except for the fact of those back cushions being separate. That's a good idea because if they should ever rip (as they are likely to do eventually with the heavy use I give my couch) - they can be re-upholstered individually, without the entire couch always having to be transported to an upholstery shop.The two ends of the couch do double duty as recliners. I find that I can pretty much bank the couch up to my wall, and still use the recliner feature. When you pull a recliner lever, the cushioning slides forward, away from the wall. So you don't have to use up a lot of room in your living quarters keeping the couch away from the wall.Note though that these end recliners do NOT have a vibrating massage feature, as many similarly designed couches do. You're getting a basic couch/recliner here without any needless frills. After shopping around for similarly designed couches - I decided on buying this one because it seemed by far the best value for the money. That has turned out to be correct.The delivery people were right on time, arriving exactly when they said they would.

This stand-up comedian paints pictures on larger canvasses, rather than just delivering a splash of one-liners. He really lets you live his trials and tribulations, for example on his farm – a deer-hunting poseur – a tractor-riding dandy. He’s a raffish version of the sort of storyteller that Woody Allen started his stand-up career as, on venues such as “The Ed Sullivan Show.”Hastings has a compelling genius for the art of stand-up comedy, and I hope he makes more DVD’s. The only reason I’m giving this performance 4-stars rather than 5 is that there’s a certain mean-spiritedness that runs through Hastings’ narratives that damped my enthusiasm for him just a little. He’s especially derogatory about his girlfriends. However, he does sort of soften that attack persona with moments of sly, self-deprecating self-awareness. He mentions the string of problematic girlfriends he’s had – virtually a dozen whackos in succession - and in mock beleaguerment he asks the audience, “What are the odds?”On the whole though, you’ll find a transport of hilarity here. But with Hastings’ graphic examination of topics such as the effects of Viagra and certain love-making techniques – this is not necessarily for the whole family.

This is a well-researched, temperate account of how various modern fundamentalist Islamic movements coalesced under different leaders and became juggernauts moving toward various bombing attacks and finally – 9/11.If you often just listen to the news casually, as background “Newsack,” you might not really understand the difference between such groups as Hamas, al Jihad, al-Qaeda, and the Taliban. This book distinguishes those groups by region, history, and leadership so that readers can approach currently unfolding news stories more intelligently.“Looming Tower” starts in the early1950’s with Egyptian Sayyid Qutb, telling how his ultimate martyrdom gave impetus to much of modern terrorist activity. Wright proceeds through the formation of the Taliban in the wake of the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, and on to bin Laden’s activities under the al-Qaeda banner. He tells how the latter became in effect, “a death-cult.” Enough biographical information is given about each of these leaders to convey a sense of who they were in their personal lives – of the frequent disjunction between what they did publicly and how they lived privately. There isn’t a huge amount of psychological analysis of how presumably religious people arrived at the point of justifying mass murder and suicide, but Wright does provide some insights into the process of transformation away from simple, often happy childhood days.This book is written in straight-forward reportorial style. But it includes enough telling metaphor to graphically illustrate many points. For example, Wright tells how some factions fell away from having a centralized leadership and instead organized themselves into cells. This gave them a “spongy quality, clandestine, hard to combat.” With that one word “spongy,” Wright conveys the difficulty that U.S. and allied military forces have been up against.The narrative includes some really surprising details about how Western and Middle Eastern cultures can differ in their interpretation of events. I had no idea how the Monica Lewinsky/President Clinton scandal was interpreted by many in the Middle East – and how it served to fuel further terrorist activity. Wright also tells of other instances where our failure to speak the language and realize cultural differences led to serious diplomatic and military miscalculations.The last third of the book moves quickly, almost too quickly, towards 9/11. A lot of it is told from the perspective of FBI investigator John O’Neill. There isn’t quite the measured detail here that there is the first part of the book. I felt a little hurried along. Of course, events themselves were rapidly sweeping towards the terrorists’ fearful culmination. But I would have liked to have known somewhat more about how vital information that might have forewarned us got lost in the jostling egos of FBI and CIA operatives. Well, more detail on that score might have made this book too long and was perhaps better saved for separate books.“Looming Tower” was first published in 2006, and includes an “Afterword” written in 2011. In that afterword, Wright expresses some optimism that a partial, peaceful resolution might be possible – an optimism that unfortunately doesn’t seem justified in light of recent developments.There’s a map at the front of the book showing Middle East countries’ relationships to each other, and the location of key bases of activity. Wright also provides a list of “Principal Characters” at the back of the book, reminding the reader who’s who. Despite the many names in this book, I found that I didn’t often have to refer back to that reference section. Wright provides such a clear, chronological account, it was easy to keep track of the key players.

This is a mean macho-man’s fantasy of the world. The villain is the ultimate misogynist as he goes about his savage, twisted killings. But the people who track him are also, in their way, misogynists. The person who comes closest to being the hero of this novel says he wanted to be around power. And women, being powerless, “held little interest for him – beyond momentary pleasure.”Women hardly play any part in the proceedings, except as the victims of brutal dismemberment or as mistresses expected to be endlessly inventive in bed. They aren’t even granted the status that Mickey Spillane gave his women as “babes” and “dolls.”So this novel wouldn’t ordinarily have been the kind of fiction I’d gravitate to, since I’m usually more drawn to the Miss Marple genre. However, this book initially attracted my attention, and then held it, for several reasons.First and foremost, it presents an excellent account of the Caryl Chessman case, which came to a head in 1960 when Chessman was executed after twelve years of fighting his conviction on kidnapping/robbery charges. As a child, I had gotten swept up in the mania to “Save Caryl Chessman.” After reading Chessman’s book “Cell 2455, Death Row,” I’d been fairly sure, despite his protestations, that he was in fact guilty of being the Red Light Bandit. But I thought the invocation of the technicality that made him subject to the death penalty was highly unjust, harkening back, as it did, to fears that had been generated by the Lindbergh baby kidnapping. In its early sections, this book reads almost like a “Frontline” documentary, as the circumstances of Chessman’s life, crimes, and conviction, are reviewed. I learned things about the case I’d never known, despite all the follow-up reading I’d done over the years.Author Stevens imaginatively weaves the real-life details of the Chessman case into the fictional lives of his characters. He starts with a compelling premise. Indeed, what might the lives and psychologies of the children of rape be like? You hardly ever see that question treated in fact or fiction.Second, this book held my interest with enough interesting turns-of-phrase. The writing isn’t fancy, but it definitely rises above the level of pulp fiction’s usual reliance on naked verbs and interjections. The author has his killer reflecting how “with invisibility would come invincibility.” In describing the kind of physical abuse the killer had suffered as a child at the hands of his mother, the author refers to “frenzy-flushed, pain-pleased bodies.” There’s insight into the kind of pathology that abuse breeds there. There are also thrusts of sly humor here and there. “I have lots of opinions, but I don’t necessarily agree with them.”Third, after the more expository nature of the first part of the book, the author falls into a rhythm of quick-cut narrative. We get a paragraph describing what the completely self-involved politician does – then a paragraph describing the killer’s plans – then a paragraph about the journalist’s latest surmise. At first I thought this technique was sort of distracting and fragmenting. But after a short time, I began to appreciate the quick slicing movement. This approach produced a tightly-woven tapestry of evil intent, with something immanent and dreadful catching the eye at every turn.Stevens does strike a few false notes along the way. For one thing, I didn’t find the killer’s psychology or his fantasies completely convincing. Then there were a few technical errors, which probably weren’t actual errors at all back in the 1970’s when this book was written. For example, Stevens repeatedly describes his killer as being a “mass murderer.” Actually, modern nomenclature would insist that he was a “serial killer.” The former, like Richard Speck, kill a number of people all at once, while serial killers, like John Wayne Gacy, kill sequentially over a period of months or years.Overall, this book will likely hold your interest, even if your taste generally runs to the cozies. You get some good, solid historical accounts of crime – plus action, gore, and finally, even a touching moment of humanity.

I’d always been a Christie fan, but this book made me even more of an admirer. I’d thought that Christie was good for clever plot twists, but not really a very good writer in general. This book of short stories changed my mind. I was amazed at how creatively Christie limns the characters in her stories in just a few short sentences – how she involves you in their fates from the first page.For example in her Miss Marple story entitled “Sanctuary,” readers are immediately able to picture the vicar’s wife as Christie describes her coming “round the corner of the Vicarage with her arms full of chrysanthemums. A good deal of rich garden soil was attached to her strong brogue shoes and a few fragments were adhering to her nose, but of that fact she was perfectly unconscious. Christened by her optimistic parents Diana, (she) had become Bunch at an early age for somewhat obvious reasons and the name had stuck to her ever since.”Such telling detail allows readers to effortlessly know and identify with so many of Christie’s characters. The only minor splinter in this capacity to evoke person and place is Christie’s slight tendency to the anti-feminism, and in some cases, to the racial stereotypes of her time. Her depiction of Bunch aside, so many of Christie’s female characters are judged solely for their ability to fight the good fight against aging. They are appraised and praised for maintaining an elegant handsomeness by dint of obvious special effort. When they finally slip over the dividing line into agedness (which is often considered to be past 50 in those years when Christie was writing, before 70 became the new 50), the women are often likened to elder cats in one form or another, inauspiciously curled in coziness before their fireplaces.But that sort of occasional indifference aside, Christie usually proves herself to be a keen observer of human character, and to appreciate characters who are themselves observers of the human pageant. The four protagonists of the four sections of this book are all successful because of their ability to sit back and creatively let the hurly-burly of other lives pass them by. The four non-movers and non-shakers presented here are Parker Pyne, Mr Satterthwaite (whose observations are catalyzed by the mysterious Harley Quin), Hercule Poirot, and Miss Marple.Parker Pyne was fairly new to me as one of Christie’s continuing featured characters. He is not so much a crime-solver as a life-solver. He is a mild-mannered actuarial who uses his knowledge of probabilities to bring happiness to people. His clients come to him as a result of his newspaper ads promising to lift people out of their dilemmas and doldrums. He has a few key operatives who do this by bringing romance and adventure to the clients in a way that is not always completely manufactured. I couldn’t help but think as I read this large section of stories that they might make a good basis for a TV series. The idea might also inspire readers interested in starting their own businesses. Mr. Pyne’s methods of bringing some measure of happiness to people could be replicated by ambitious and caring entrepreneurs.Overall, there is a compelling realism to the solutions wrought by all of Christie’s slightly surreal characters. Every character and almost every story presented here will draw you into the picture from the start. These interesting bystanders draw their powers from being so engagingly disengaged. They might encourage all of us to step back sometimes and become quiet observers.

The good premise that this movie starts with gets buried by pretentious surrealism. The actors move wordlessly through the vaguely futuristic suburbs of Toronto, estranged from their landscape and from each other. I kept wanting to yell at them, "Say something! Don't Act! Interact!" But it doesn't happen.In the bonus "Making of" feature on this DVD, the movie's director said that, like all good directors, he completely disregarded the book that this material was based on. He made it anew. In a way, I understand what he meant. Material has to be completely re-imagined to work in another medium. But although I haven't read the award-winning book this film was based on, I believe it has to be better than what got translated onto the screen.I also objected to the roles played by the three women here. Again in that "Making of" bonus feature, the actresses playing these roles praised their characters as being strong, determined women. I couldn't see that at all. Each of these women was given only a handful of words to say. Other than that, they were generally just left to themselves float in worried, estranged silence through their scenes. Most of the time, they were mannequins in service to whatever was the tacit need of the men in their lives.There is some puzzlement here that challenges the viewer, as all surrealistic images tend to do. But I would have liked more of the artful, less of the artsy. Unless you are a fan of art-house film, you might not want to gamble on this. You might not want to double-down - but simply fold.

This collection of Skinner’s essays was published in England during WWII. The person writing its forward defends its seeming frivolity by pointing out that such humor about our everyday frustrations could not have found an audience in Germany at the time – that the author of any such material centered on gentle bemusement would have been considered a dangerous defector from rigid, purposeful adherence to The Cause. That is true. This kind of humor would be considered an alien insurgent by any tyranny.But this Seinfeld-esque humor about nothing really needs no defense.  All these little bafflements are the stuff of our human condition, and Skinner writes about them with rare wit and with an antic, acrobatic vocabulary. We can all identify with her hilarious discomfitures over everyday nothings such as finding a vase for some cut flowers, making a trip to the bank, or trying to find floor space to exercise in a hotel room. But along the way, Skinner punctures pomposity and pretense. She notes how media ads selling soap always refer to how the product will “cleanse” –not simply to the fact that it will “clean.”There’s also more serious social commentary that runs as undertow through her observations. An example of the way Skinner combines the trifle and the insightful can be found in her essay on “The Business Party.” She tells what a chore it is for everyone concerned when it becomes necessary to entertain her husband’s out-of-town business associates. They take the couple dining, dancing, and then to a nightclub. A disaffected, hectic waiter sets up an extra table for them at the last stop of the evening. As a result, the visiting couple partially jut out onto the dance floor and fall prey to “every passing fanny.” But on the serious side of this picture-painting word-play, readers come to understand how empty this whole exercise is, and how we all repeatedly get roped into doing things that we don’t enjoy and that have no real meaning.There are facets of Skinner’s comments that will strike readers as being very antique. She makes references to personalities whose names were bruited about in the 1920-1940’s, but whom hardly anyone knows today. In addition, she makes any number of references to Greek Gods and movers-and-shakers in ancient history. This reflects the classical education that school children got in Skinner’s time. But hardly anyone today will readily be able to grasp her allusion to the “Gracchi” movement of ancient Rome.Some of Skinner’s opinions also fly in the face of our modern views. For example, Skinner says she does NOT regard herself as the equal of men, does not want to do men’s work, and in fact would just as soon not have been granted the vote. But then in the next sentence, her comments fall right in step with discussions on today’s talk show. For example, she says how books on “How To Be Happy” always make her feel sad, with their fatuous enjoinments to repeat some simple sentences such as “I am happy today; I am getting better in every way.”The illustrations in this slim volume are by both Alajalov and Soglow. Their subjects’ looks of baffled surmise add comic chirps to the proceedings.However be aware – most of the essays included here are also included in other Skinner collections. On the whole, I found this “Popcorn” to be the most inclusive collection of her articles, so if you plan to get just one of her volumes – this might be the one.For reference, these are the essays included here:The Defense of Long island; Excuse It, Please; The Body Beautiful; The Skin-Game; This Up-Lift Stuff; Yoga Attempted; The Paintable Type; Breaking the Ice; Horse Shows; Hoo-Rah; On Riding; On Skating; On Dancing; Floral Piece; Vaulting ambition; Municipal Efficiency; Med to Mum; It’s a Wise parent; Youth’s Furnishings; God Rest You Merry; Business Party; The Captain’s Table; The Importance of cocktails; The Wrong Party; Room Service; In Quest of Tea; Seeing Stars; Auld Acquaintances; Allow Me, Madame; Pour le Sport; Bonny Boating Weather; Great guns; Wednesday Matinee; I Saw Your Father in Kismet.

Author/cat-woman Alex Matthews presents a decent murder mystery in these pages. But the book is primarily interesting because of its Chicagoland settings and because of the way it shows its heroine psychologist/social worker dealing with the problem of feral cats. The Chicagoland settings include a peek inside the process of visiting a prisoner inside the County’s main jail on the South Side of Chicago.The theme of feral cats has the series’ ongoing protagonist Cassidy McCabe having to relocate a colony of outdoor cats after their guardian is murdered and a neighborhood resident threatens to shoot the animals. Had the presence of the cats made the man angry enough to commit murder?This topic drew me into the story right away because I was at that moment myself in the throes of having to get a colony of feral cats off the streets after a neighbor’s complaints. “Cat’s Claw” was written in 2000, before Chicago’s official catch-and-release program was in place, authorizing guardian individuals to trap alley cats - spay/neuter them – then release them back into their old neighborhoods to go on rat patrol. So Cassidy doesn’t specifically go through those steps. But she deals with the problem in parallel ways.Matthews uses the same italics technique here that she uses in other books in her Cassidy McCabe series. Most of the book describes Cassidy’s actions from an objective, non-italicized point of view. But then when the reader is allowed to eavesdrop on Cassidy’s brain chatter, the text switches into italics. I usually found this to be a good technique. It eliminates the author’s having to repeatedly write, “Cassidy thought…” or “I thought…” However, this volume might contain a little too much of that offset interior monologue, and, in any case, Cassidy’s thoughts usually aren’t very interesting.Another possibly distracting/detracting element in this story is its subplot involving Cassidy’s husband and the strain his undercover reporting work puts on their marriage. The personality transformation that Zach goes through as a result of his work, and Cassidy’s concerns about this estrangement, might strike some readers as being a little unrealistic.But with the Chicagoland settings, the problem of dealing with feral cats, and the problem of angry neighbors – most readers will probably find something they can identify with on these pages.

This book might almost have been written as an entry in the “For Dummies” series. It approaches the subjects of music notation, music terminology, instrumentation, and the overall way in which music produces its effects, on a very basic level. It consists of easy sentences step-laddered to painlessly raise you up to a better understanding. The author peppers the book with snappy humor. His wry word play makes what can be an esoteric subject to those without any training enjoyably accessible. He starts by saying, “Enough of the preamble, let’s get on with the amble.” And so it goes.Powell uses a number of apt analogies to illustrate some general ideas about the nature of scales and keys. For example, he likens a scale to the whole group of players a coach might have available to play football. But the key that a composer selects for a piece is like the specific team that a coach fields for a game. The captain of that team can be changed in the middle of the game, or players can be fielded in different positions, resulting in different styles of play during the game.I still found myself occasionally confusing scales, octaves, and keys, as I read along. And Powell’s explanation of “equal temperament” as the best method of tuning instruments remained a little obscure to me. But for the most part, I was amazed at how much information was packed into his simple sentences – and how many of my questions about the ways in which music is constructed got answered.Powell also shatters a few myths along the way. He challenges the general feeling that vinyl sounds better, warmer than music reproduced on CD’s – and the feeling that music written in a major key is always cheerful and confident sounding, while music written in a minor key must always be sad and pensive.This book comes with a bonus. There’s a 35-minute CD tucked onto its back cover. This CD presents an audio illustration of some of the points Powell makes in the text. For example, he shows how you can vary the timbre of your guitar-playing by varying where you pluck the strings of the guitar – nearer the neck or nearer the bridge.Finally, this book might inspire a reader to become more actively involved in producing music herself or himself. Powell says that anyone can write a pop tune, a process that’s always been a mystery to me. He tells how to sit yourself down in front of a piano – and do it.

This large sign really gets the message across. I've seen people walking their dogs past my property - ready to make a drop-off. But then the sign's big, bold message hits them - and they move sheepishly on or else do the right thing with pooper scoopers.The sign is strong and weather-resistant. It also comes with pre-punched holes so you can easily tie it to a chain link fence or any other upright.

This is an eye-opening, saddening account of the plight of orcas kept in captivity primarily to serve as circus-like performers in various marine worlds. These creatures are made to suffer merely to supply us with casual entertainment.This documentary does a good job of waking us up to the pointless cruelty we’re inflicting, and the waste of life entailed. Some of the commentators on the film are former marine world trainers who quit their jobs in order to be free to speak out publicly against the abuses they now regret being party to.However, the film could have been even better. It’s a little disjointed, recounting cases here/there, then/now, in which both humans and orcas have been injured or killed as a result of the animals’ unnatural confinement.Then it misses a few chances to give viewers further insights into the nature of these “black fish.” The writers could have included some more of the kinds of details that I learned when I went whale-watching off the coast of Vancouver. For example, this documentary doesn’t explain that orcas aren’t really “whales” at all – killer or otherwise. They are actually dolphins whose current name might have been an early transposition of the term “whale killer.”Also, this documentary states that orcas have never been known to kill humans in the wild. According to the whale-watching boat captains, that’s true – but not for this documentary’s implied reason that orcas might find some intellectual sympathy with humans and recognize us as kindred spirits. Rather the boating captains believed there were no attacks in the wild because humans are simply viewed as being relatively bony slim pickings for the orcas when they have larger prey available. The whale-watching crew said that one of a wild orca’s favorite repasts would be a moose.This conjured an eerie picture in my mind. I imagined an orca slithering out of its natural watery medium, through the Canadian forests at night, sneaking up on unsuspecting ungulates. How could that happen? But no, the crew member explained that moose like to swim between the many islands off the coasts of Vancouver and Seattle – and the orcas pick them off then.Despite the fact that “Black Fish” could have included more such choice details and been a little better organized, it remains a brave and awakening must-see documentary.

I went on a chocolate-tasting tour of Switzerland and adjoining countries once, but nothing I tasted there was as good as these Lindt Truffles. These chocolates are very finely spun confections, making them ultra creamy and tasty.These are the dark chocolate truffles, but Lindt also produces regular, extra dark, and other flavors. There are 12 truffles in a bag. I wish there were more, but that limited amount helps me ration myself so I don't go hog-wild downing these delicious treats.

This book reads like a novel, but is a true story of the man who is possibly the worst serial killer you’ve never heard about. You might not have heard of Charles Cullen because he operated subtly, in medical settings where deaths are common anyway.However, so much of the tragedy of this story lies in the fact that Cullen’s sly but deadly injections WERE noticed or at least strongly suspected. However, the fear of lawsuits and the very nature of corporate medical administration prevented his killings from being reported. This is a chronicle of how he was passed along from hospital to hospital with “neutral” or even praising recommendations. He was the proverbial hot potato being tossed from hand to hand. You might find it interesting to read a book such as “Criminal Investigative Failures” by D. Kim Rossmo in conjunction with this book, in order to get a clearer idea of how group dynamics often lead to perpetrators and their crimes being obscured or outright ignored.But any thumbnail summary of “The Good Nurse” can hardly do justice to the book. Graeber is an excellent writer who is able to suffuse his report with a dark poetry. He has a knack for the apt metaphor that puts you there, at the scene. For example, he tells how Cullen actually enjoyed the tension after each kill, how he keenly anticipated being arrested. “He enjoyed the waiting, the little death of that caesura.” That special tension made coffee taste better; gave every snap of a glove extra portent & meaning.What’s more, Graeber writes in short chapters, each one a needle injection of further derangement. Be forewarned though. The first chapters are very graphic. They deal with conditions in a burn unit where Cullen served early in his career as a nurse. While you might have known how life-threatening burns can be, you probably didn’t fully realize the sort of trauma inflicted on the body by fire.Graeber doesn’t involve himself in too much psychological speculation about Cullen’s motives. In the course of outlining Cullen’s biography, Graeber does suggest certain influences that might have been at work. Graeber also suggests that Cullen might have been killing himself by proxy. Since he was personally afraid to die, all his suicide “attempts” notwithstanding – he might have been keeping death as his familiar by killing others.All around, this is a fascinating portrait of the man who is perhaps America’s most prolific serial killer, but who fit no known psychological profiles. He was neither a classic “Angel of Mercy” nor a standard sexual sadist. His evil could not be categorized or fathomed – as is ultimately the case with most evil.

Wright offers a daring look inside Scientology – as far inside as it is generally possible for someone not in its upper echelons to penetrate. Along the way, he provides a biography of L. Ron Hubbard which diverges significantly from the biographical history that most followers of Scientology are given to understand. He also provides a more graphic picture of the punishments that Scientology metes out to people who are perceived as having transgressed some aspect of its disciplines. Most followers though are reportedly willing to submit to these “corrections” – in order to get back into Scientology’s good graces and in order not to be a disappointment to the Hubbard role model.In footnotes that appear throughout the book, Wright indicates instances in which Scientology leaders have disagreed with or outright refuted various aspects of his reporting. In a few cases, the footnotes even go on to provide refutations of the refutations by other Scientologists. So readers don’t just get a one-sided view of what has become The Church.Much of the development of Scientology, from Hubbard’s early conception of it as a program for right-living and then on into its apotheosis as a full-blown religion, is traced through the progress through its ranks of Paul Haggis, an early convert. Haggis is introduced on the first page of the book, and this is where Wright might have made his one notable misstep in reporting. He recounts how Haggis was recruited on the streets of London, Ontario, Canada. But in recounting this initiation, Wright describes that London as being a rather bleak manufacturing town with a dying downtown. As someone who has toured London, Ontario, on several occasions – I could hardly reconcile my view of it and Wright’s description. A friend of mine who lives there also confirms that the place is actually known to be a sort of boutique tourist destination, famous for its gingerbread Victorian houses and the central park that enlivens its downtown district.I was almost put off of this whole book right at the start by this contrary view of London that Wright provides. It was a minor point, but it made me wonder if Wright wrongly characterized London to such an extent – how he might be wrongly characterizing whatever descriptions of Scientology were to follow. I’m glad I persevered though and went on to read the rest of the book. Wright’s depth of research into Scientology and his grounded, unemotional approach, convinced me of the general validity of his reporting.Wright doesn’t offer a lot of psychological analysis of how and why people become so committed to the often very illogical principles of Scientology. In one exceptional sentence he does make reference to the human need for “transcendence and submission.” He also points out that illogical doctrines are to be found at the base of almost all religions.Overall, this is an amazing view into what strange lengths people are willing to go to gain that sense of transcendence and submission.

Saks takes us along on her odyssey through schizophrenia in search of some mental equilibrium. She describes the negative thoughts that assailed her, giving her what could perhaps be termed a case of “scruples,” the diffuse feeling of being guilty of anything and everything. This guilt at times made her anorexic as she felt unworthy of even the food she might consume. She felt she could kill with her thoughts. This leads readers to the novel realization of how much these various mental conditions might be related.Saks tells how she resisted medication for a long time, feeling that she should be able to lift herself up by the bootstraps with will power alone. Finally though, she found a combination of medication and talk therapy that has generally been successful at holding her demons at bay.Her preferred form of talk therapy has been psychoanalysis, often of the Kleinian variety. She says that the ongoing insights she has garnered from the psychotherapy have been invaluable. Some of the analytical insights do seem to hit home. For example, one of her analysts pointed out that it’s often easier to feel attacked than to feel grief or envy. So we can be complicit in creating demons to wage war against us.Some readers might doubt the ability of such therapy to produce new insights almost daily over a period of decades though. But then Saks does say that the heart of her talk therapy was in the relationship with the therapist, in the routine and security of having a professional there for her through thick and thin. I would have liked her to elaborate a little more on why the close friends she had, friends whom she could call day or night, couldn’t adequately fill that role, especially since strict psychotherapists avoid encouraging any personal relationship with their clients. They remain seated behind their analysands, maintaining inscrutable poker positions. As Saks briefly explains – this is the recommended stance, in part so that the therapist can be like a screen onto which the patient projects all her own impressions. These then become the substance of what the therapist has to analyze.I would also have liked Saks to elaborate a little more on the reasons for some of the decisions she made. For example, after attending school in her native U.S., why did she decide to go to Oxford, with all the upheaval and frightening novelty that entailed? Saks doesn’t say a word on that subject, just as she doesn’t make too many outreaching observations in general. Well, that is part of the condition of schizophrenia. A schizophrenic, of necessity, is preoccupied with inner turmoil.Then just one other minor mote of dissatisfaction crossed my mind as I read this book. How could Saks have remembered so exactly the nature and chronology of all her hallucinations over the decades? I couldn’t help but think there might perhaps have been some creative reconstruction going on here.But overall, this is a valuable testament to what goes on in the mind of someone suffering from schizophrenia or related psychoses. Such testaments, as Saks herself points out, are few and far between. While individuals with other challenges, such as bi-polar disorder or even Asperger’s Syndrome, have been writing about what the world is like for them - few schizophrenics have been able to organize and exteriorize sufficiently to give others a real feel for what they are suffering. Since so many of us likely know someone who is struggling with schizophrenia, this book is relevant to just about everyone. A list of resources is included at the end.

This is a long book, and unlike many of Ann Rule’s other books, it deals with only one main perpetrator. This individual is shown wreaking havoc over a period of decades, throughout an extended family. Despite the length and spread of the narrative, it held my interest. It's very well-written, putting the reader right there in the midst of this dysfunctional family dynamic.While keeping to the chronology of the family history, Rule doesn’t immediately reveal who the trouble-maker is. Also, the extent of this individual’s insidious influence only gradually unfolds. This individual’s long reach into the lives of everyone in the vicinity often isn’t made apparent until years after the fact.Rule doesn’t offer a lot of psychological analysis of the perpetrator. A sort of Munchhausen’s compulsion to garner attention at any cost is likely in play. But it’s difficult to understand other family members’ willingness to lend themselves so extensively to remedying and covering up the ensuing chaos. Perhaps it’s a personal re-enactment of the Viet Nam syndrome. Once people have invested a good deal of time and energy in a project, it’s difficult to abandon it. People become all the more committed to their efforts to bring a project or a person to some sort of fulfillment. In fact they can become all the more fond of that person for so thoroughly engaging them.So this book might serve as another warning against throwing good money after bad. Or it might more specifically serve to warn against pouring all one’s human resources into efforts to detoxify an essentially toxic person.

This is like a less fictional version of the 1980’s Masterpiece Theater Classic series “Brideshead Revisited.” As in that series, we have a young innocent coming onto campus and soon being captivated by a handsome, epicene upper classman. In this case, the young innocent is the real-life poet-to-be Allen Ginsberg, and the upperclassman is Lucien Carr. Like Brideshead’s Sebastian before him, Lucien Carr is shown here inciting those in his circle to exotic sensualities and sexual experimentation. Like a King Cobra, his gaze has hypnotized others before Ginsberg. But when he is through with them, they are not always ready to be through with him. That’s where the tragedy of this association of Burroughs/Kerouac/Ginsberg/Carr germinates.Some of the descendents of these founders of the Beat Generation have challenged the truthfulness of this film’s depiction. I had other problems with the movie, besides the dubious nature of some of its biography. The other problem with this film for me was that it was too fragmented and episodic. I never felt I got a chance to know or care about any of these proto-Beats. I found I was finishing watching the movie as I myself might finish a school assignment, coerced by Lucien’s magnetism into doing his homework for him. It was a bit of a chore, but I watched the film to the end in order to acquaint myself with some of the early history of this influential clique of poets, rebels, and easy riders.Flawed as it might be, this film provides a valuable clue to the lives of these creative individuals – a clue that most modern readers of their work probably never suspected existed.

There are a number of improbabilities and gaps in this plot. For one thing, I don’t think forensic voice recognition programs are nearly as precise and targeting as they are represented as being in this drama. What’s more, the ending is likely to strike viewers as being too generic and unlikely.Nevertheless, the plot set-up is gripping. I identified with the District Attorney’s dilemma from the start. In a bonus feature interview, co-star Samuel L. Jackson says that this movie project interested him because it promised to be everything he seeks when he himself goes to the movies. It promised to be entertaining, to take you out of yourself and put you directly in the plight of the characters in the movie, to challenge you afterwards to consider what YOU would have done in the same set of circumstances, and, as a bonus, to provide a sort of moral. The movie delivered for me on all those points.What’s more, there’s the added attraction of Gloria Reuben’s outstanding performance as a police detective. She does a wonderful job of showing the guarded suspicions her character has about what’s really going on. If I were guilty, I’d get chills from just her look. Her piercing gaze suggests to me that she knows – and that she knows I know she knows… Who’s going to make the next move?

The opening chapters of this book are almost too intense. They are an account of Russell Williams’ escalating crimes, one after the other. Offense piles on offense, fetish on fetish. As he creeps from sinister panty raids to murder, you might feel yourself being violated just reading this. But I believed it was important to finish the book in order to get some understanding of how such aberrations develop in people.The author of this book was a process=server who had occasion to deliver notice of a civil law suit to Williams after the Colonel had been imprisoned for the criminal aspect of his actions. So David Gibb was in a good position to assess and write about the sequence of Williams’ crimes and conviction. Unfortunately, the Canadian system of justice and Government allows numerous gag orders to persist, hindering journalists from gaining access to criminals after the fact. So Gibb wasn’t able to personally interview Williams. (However a tape of the police interrogation that led to Williams’ confession is considered a model of interview technique and is widely available, even having aired on several true crime TV shows.)The author of “Camouflaged” was also stone-walled by most of Williams’ relatives and acquaintances. Neither Williams’ wife nor his school-days girlfriends were available to be interviewed. But some summaries of the extensive photo record Williams kept of his crimes, and the journals he wrote detailing his actions, were available. However, much of Gibb’s final analysis of Williams’ devolution from respected Air Force Colonel to sexual sadist is based on FBI profiling generalizations. Gibb extensively quotes Stone’s “Anatomy of Evil,” a book I personally hadn’t found to be too enlightening in its classification of criminal types.Williams doesn’t easily fit into any of the FBI categories of types of sexual predators. But “Camouflaged” does at least offer some brief insights into how such extreme fetishes as his might develop, insights I hadn’t found in other books. Gibb also suggests how medication, mid-life crisis, and Williams’ inflating ego might have all contributed to his crossing the line from fantasy into practice. Finally, the author considers such issues as what role viewing pornography might play in such criminals behavior.Overall, this is a valuable record of the etiology of a dangerous perversity. It can also serve as a cautionary tale – warning how little we might actually know about the people we think we know – and how little we might actually know even about ourselves and our own potential for evil.

This story has some of the qualities of a classic Russian novel, except it is shorter, more accessible, and is hardly like a school assignment. But it does have the imaginative, intricate plotting of one of those novels. We get into the minds of three of the main characters as they observe the other people around them and as they lay their plans.At first it seems as if these three lives constitute three different plots - running parallel in that their protagonists all find themselves in precarious desperation, but being otherwise essentially unrelated. However, as the story gets under way, these three lives often begin to insect in surprising ways. We begin to see the fatefulness of it all.With Rendell, the characters and the movement of the plot are primary. She writes without pretension or elaboration, except possibly when it comes to describing her characters’ clothes. Here again, as in some of her other books, she perhaps goes into a little too much detail, describing toggle buttons, Black Watch tartan skirts, polo collars, etc. These paragraphs begin to read like one of J. Peterman’s catalogues as portrayed in “Seinfeld.” But for the most part, Rendell writes fluidly.There are complex insights embedded in the simplicity of her style though. For example, she tells that Benet stuck a pin in herself in order to have “a different focus of pain.” With those few words, she gives us as good a grasp of the motive behind the practice of self-mutilation as I’ve ever read.She quotes another character’s dislike of looking in the surrounding bedroom mirrors when he makes love. She explains that “his love was here and now.” Oh, to have a partner like that!Rendell’s characters come from different strata of society, and talk differently. Each one is unique, and Rendell writes them all so believably, rather than making them all reflections of herself. In this way, she is unlike, for example Dorothy Sayers, most of whose mystery novel characters strike the same note of detached urbanity.Rendell, especially in this novel, is real, gripping, and intense.

There’s more science than strict autobiography here. Oliver Sacks tells how all the magical certainties of science were his refuge throughout his early years when WWII and so much else was quaking the human world around him. He relished the odd smells and the fiery globules he could send rushing through the house as a result of various chemical combinations he contrived in his laundry room-become-laboratory.In the process of learning about his youthful enthusiasms, you’ll get an almost complete overview of chemistry and physics in these pages. But it won’t be the abstract, cold study you might have encountered in school. Sacks’ introduction to these disciplines is filled with his personal noticing of the little things – the way a piece of tungsten hefted in his hand, the luster on a chunk of wolframite, the way sparks could be made to arc between different metals.He includes some telling details from the biographies of various scientists he admired, ones who led the way in the experiments he was so joyously duplicating. You’ll be introduced to Hooke, Boyle, Lavoisier, Davy, and the Curies. Many of these individuals took the same kind of sensual delight in their materials that he took. Reading this made me wish I could have had a similar field of dreams, full of enchantment with the elemental things of this earth.The book isn’t all science though. Sacks does provide some intimate detail. Among his most telling reflections is his account of the cruelty he encountered in the school he was removed to in order to keep him safe from the bombings centered on London during the War. Although brief, his reflections on these experiences provide some of the best insights available into the effects of corporal punishment and bullying. He tells how he became in some ways cruel (such as to his dog) when he came home, in hopes of drawing his parents’ attention to the cruelties he himself had been suffering.This would be a good book to pass along to a young person in order to awaken them to the wonders all around them. Although the evolution of Sacks’ interests has a somewhat sad ending, any young person reading this account would be hard pressed to ever again take a bored attitude of “whatever.”
These Valentine hearts have made a beautiful red glow. I especially appreciated the fact that they came with their own suction cup hangers, so mounting them on my windows was a snap.

“Jumped” was published by Reader’s Digest United Kingdom branch, and at first I thought it was going to be too brief and basic an overview, popularized for mass consumption. But as I got further into the book, I found I was really learning new things about forensic science, and having old information clarified. What’s more, the book, with its glossy page format and color pictures, is a pleasure to read.It would be ideal for a student considering a career in forensic science or any area of crime detection. However, anyone who wants an easy overview of the field would likely enjoy reading “Jumped.” While some more professional studies such as Saferstein’s standard texts, go into a lot more detail, this book summarizes topics in a few sentences and so it lets you see the forest for the trees. I finally got a quick grasp on the difference between chromatography and spectrometry, and succinctly learned how to use toner powder to bring up underlying impressions on a piece of paper.Each chapter considers a different kind of evidence and the techniques used to analyze those clues. There are chapters on tool impressions, DNA, blood spatter, ballistics, poisons and drugs, and handwriting and voice analysis. Each chapter includes a “Day in the Life” page that tells what an expert in that specific branch of evidentiary information does on a typical day. Many of the experts who are followed here are British. There might not be quite the same categories of investigators in the U.S., but readers can still get a good idea of what assignments each kind of specialist faces on a typical day.Finally, each chapter recounts cases that were “cracked” by examining the kinds of evidence featured in that chapter. There are 50 of these cases, some all-but-forgotten ones dating back as far as the early 1800’s, but illustrative of some pioneering investigative technique. Other crimes cited are more recent and famous. Each case is dealt with in a “Just the facts, Ma’am” thumbnail of a sketch. There are no Anne Rule-style elaborations of character or motive here. But again, the paired down descriptions often allow readers to get a clearer picture of the crimes than any long drawn-out debates about them have afforded.In the ballistics chapter, the book clears away a lot of the smoke surrounding the Kennedy assassination in a few sentences. It tells what neutron activation analysis revealed about the trajectories of the two wounding bullets and about their source. It brings readers up to date on the resolution of other famous cases. What finally happened in the “Dingo Ate Your Baby” case in which the parents were charged with killing their daughter? What led the jury to their conviction of Jean Harris for killing Herman Tarnower, the Scarsdale Diet doctor? Who were Sacco and Vanzetti and what crime were they really charged with committing? What led detectives to Timothy McVeigh in the bombing of Oklahoma City’s Federal building, or to a Libyan agent in the bombing of a PanAm plane over Lockerbie, Scotland? How closely does Bruno Hauptmann’s handwriting match that of the handwriting on the ransom notes sent to Charles Lindbergh? You get to judge.Overall, this book is a keeper for anyone interested in forensics, crime detection, or a thumbnail history of some famous and some not-so-famous dastardly deeds.

This is essentially a silent film. Robert Redford is alone against the sea. He proves that he has been more than just a pretty face, delivering a tour de force performance.The film works on several levels. It can be viewed as a realistic story of the struggle to survive, teaching us how to condense potable water at sea and how to launch a life boat. But it can also be viewed as an allegory of our journey through life. There are big breaches in our days that we have to use all our ingenuity to patch. There are a few moments of breathtaking beauty, but hardly enough time to enjoy them before another huge challenge presents itself. This is a profoundly moving story on whatever level it's viewed.There are a lot of extras on this DVD, including a director/producer commentary. These commentaries are OK, but they don't really add anything to the experience of the movie. Unless you have a lot of time on your hands, you can probably skip these extras, and not dilute the impact of the movie itself.

If this plot seems a bit familiar to you, it might be that you’re recalling the movie “Whatever Happened to Aunt Alice." That movie was based on this book. Also, several Alfred Hitchcock TV hours and other mystery episodes have used elements of this plot in their own story lines. But even if your earlier exposure to those other thrillers gives you an early sense of which way things might go here, this book is still very worth reading. It’s downright chilling. The printed paragraphs, in Curtiss’ hands, turn out to be more graphically frightening than any number of pictures.Revelations made on the first page might lead you to believe that this is going to proceed in the light-hearted way of “Arsenic and Old Lace.” But things get serious fast. The plot becomes a matter of dueling suspicions. The suspense builds and some of the chapters end with real shockers.What’s that scratching, scratching sound at the door? Is it the big stray dog that’s been so unshakably nosing around the property? Or is it something else?

This book consists of short, memorable vignettes recounting the author’s life as a nurse on a sparsely populated island in the Hebrides in the 1970’s. MacLeod doesn’t have quite the same wry observational style that James Herriot had in his classic “Creatures Great and Small” series. But her writing is nonetheless excellent and evocative.Be forewarned though. These aren’t all sentimental, nostalgic pieces. There are some real shockers here. Although in one later chapter, MacLeod says there was no child abuse on these islands - that contradicts at least one or two of her earlier accounts of some terrible behavior born of superstition, a compulsive adherence to notions of propriety, and ingrown anger. These accounts, that MacLeod either witnessed herself or heard about having taken place in the not-too-distant past, recalled some paragraphs of a Sherlock Holmes tale. As Holmes and Watson are riding by train out to the countryside, Holmes reflects that big cities don’t deserve their reputation as being the exclusive breeding grounds of evil deeds. He says that there are as many, or more, heinous acts committed in remote rural areas. There in the dank isolation, people’s worst impulses can mushroom, with no one to check the growth.But for the most part, these reminiscences tell of kindness and resourcefulness. The people of MacLeod’s island (re-named in order to protect the inhabitants’ privacy) have a knack of making parties out of adversity. Inclement weather, fire, rain, and the need to transport the sick, all become occasions for rallying community spirit.After reading this, you’ll likely want to be one of the tourists who have been increasingly coming to these islands during their three short months of passable weather. But you might be disabused of any romantic notion of coming to live here to finish writing your Nobel Prize-winning novel. There were real hardships to be endured here in the 70’s, and probably there still are. The windswept beauty that Macleod describes might come to strike you as barrenness after a while.But at least for the stretch of these pages, you can warm to the malapropisms, the misdeeds, and the heartiness of these very individual inhabitants. In this place where almost everyone is “wee” and at least a little “daft,” MacLeod’s writing invites you to sit down and have a “cuppie and a clootie” (tea and a dumpling) by the fireside. (A brief glossary of Scottish colloquialisms is included at the back of the book.)Best of all, MacLeod promises more to come. She explains that she has many more reminisces of her time on the Island, and is now working on a sequel. Like me, after reading “Call the Nurse,” you’ll probably want to be in line for this second book as soon as it appears.

This slim book contains 8 practice tests, consisting of 40 questions each, with answers included. You are asked to allot yourself 90 minutes per test. The questions are difficult. You’ll have to immerse yourself in the problems in order to finish each test on time. The book will likely leave you with a feeling of having stretched your mind, and it will give you an impetus to really concentrate on something while you try to figure out what figure comes next in a series, or what letters have to go in the blanks to form a synonym for “autochthonous.” So taking these tests can provide a refreshing relief from distraction.But I’m not sure that these tests are really representative of what you’ll find, for example, on the actual I.Q. test used to qualify you to join MENSA. I paid for and took the practice MENSA test online, and it tended to present much less knotty, obscure posers than you’ll find here. The MENSA pre-test was weighted more towards requiring an ability to recognize the orientation of simple shapes.The brief introduction to this book does acknowledge that there are different versions of standard I.Q. tests. The Stanford-Binet emphasizes verbal ability; the Wechsler has separate sections for verbal and spatial abilities. The tests in this book intersperse vocabulary questions with numeric and spatial progressions. The latter tend to be frustratingly elaborate, while the vocabulary questions seem to have a definite cultural bias. You’ll do well on the vocabulary questions if you’re an educated Victorian English gentleman. Do you know the definitions of such arcana as barouche, farandole, jabot, pomander? If not, like so many of the immigrants coming through Ellis Island in the early 1900’s, you might find yourself being falsely classified as an idiot.Nevertheless, your score will likely improve dramatically as you move through these tests and learn the little tricks of approach to the problems. Your score will likely increase more than the 6 points the authors think that you’ll be able to eke out with practice. But even if the 8th test finds you as puzzled by it all as when you started – you’ll probably enjoy the challenge.

This is a good novel, but it doesn’t quite sustain suspense in the same way some of Rendell’s other psychological novels do. There are a few stretches where it might be easy to lose interest here. It was only my trust in Rendell’s ability to track her characters through to the poignancy of their perverse dreams that kept me reading through these somewhat flat sections.Things do pick up, and by the book's end, you can appreciate how well-woven the fates of these characters are. But if you aren’t already a fan of Rendell’s, this might not be the book to launch you into enthusiasm.
