If you thought the authors of STL were brilliant, Boost is another level beyond. This is the go to reference book on the subject, at least at this time. Do shop around though, the pricing varies quite a bit.

Red Pocket is an MVNO for AT&T. You get the same AT&T network. I had an activation problem that was poorly handled by their customer service. It took multiple phone calls to sort out.I used the service with my iPhone 5 in South Florida. I consistently got 1mbps downloads. That's ok but when TMobile refarmed my area for iPhone compatibility, I switched to PlantinumTel which is an MVNO for TMobile. My iPhone always got 3mbps downloads and sometimes > 12mbps. PlantinumTel was easy to activate over the Internet, cheaper, essentially unlimited everything and is considerably faster. YMMV.

Rockland Melbourne luggage is bi-polar. It's both voluminous and light, also cheaply made with worryingly thin casing and bears a carcinogen warning. I have similar hard-sided luggage that you can party on. Not so with this set. If you are looking for infrequent used but voluminous and light, definitely go with this set. If you want durability, look elsewhere. It can't compare with the durability of some other brands.Scary, Scary: The luggage comes with a scary warranty card. It says "This product contains chemicals known to the state of California to cause cancer or birth defects or other ...". That sticker is prominently placed over the warranty card obscuring the warranty return information. I've unsuccessfully tried to remove the sticker so I could read the warranty return info (just in case).

Dishwasher failed after two years. Too expensive to repair. Wish I had read the leading consumer magazine before buying. LG has the worst repair record. I'm going with Maytag for a replacement. Lesson learned.

Didn't work out for my situation. I bought the Meade TE346W to replace a competitor's product. The competitor's exterior temperature sensor stopped working after three years. All the functions of the Meade work as expected but the display isn't as contrasty. While I can read the competitor's display at 10 feet, it's hard to make out the Meade's numbers.
Tripp Lite TLP604 is a well engineered surge protector. They don't cut corners for the money. I tend to buy Tripp Lite because their products are well engineered and are good values.

I'll always remember this product. It made a great way to connect with my buddy's 10 year old son. I showed the kid how water was being wasted by toilet run-on. Over the course of a year, it was 1000s of gallons. He needed a bit of advice on how to remove the old flapper, count the old chain's links (between hook and float) and use that number to cut the new flapper's chain. He had to puzzle through how to remove the thin plastic disks on either side of the float. Finally, we inspected all the other toilets in the house for run-on. He now knows to check for the problem by watching the water's movement and listening for unattended flushes.
I concur with other reviewers. The MiniSuit 360 is a great valued product; flexible design, good protection, well executed. Feels good in hand. Easy to recommend.

Auto sleep doesn't work on my iPad 3. The case is not a perfect fit and requires high force to insert. The case might have been an acceptable value if sleep worked. Both problems might not exist on iPad 2. The merchant is advertising a product that doesn't match the description.
Impressive tolerances. Looks good. Feels good in hand. Seems durable. Just keep in mind it's a bumper and not a shock absorber type

Pretty easy to install. Replaced original part at a much lower price than Kohler's. Run-on stopped.Takes an extra couple minutes to completely shut-off but then it does. I'm not sure if that's due to this part or something else.

Part of the function of Amazon user reviews, besides qualitative ratings, is to supplement and refine information about a product. One wonders how so many good products, such as this tiny wireless router, become under-described and thus under-purchased. Let me do this router justice by filling in some significant details.1. It's a travel router, the size of a jigger, light as a feather.2. It has two Ethernet ports -- one more than the competition. The additional port is an extremely useful and unique feature. It enables use as a transparent wired-to-wireless bridge. To do so, plug Ethernet into the LAN port, leaving the WAN port unconnected. It will broadcast WiFi using the same subnet (same IP range, you must disable DHCP server) as its Ethernet connection. You can give it the same/different WiFi password as the other access point. I'm not aware of any other travel router that can use an existing subnet. The others create a new subnet.3. It works everywhere in the world. A dual voltage (100-240v) US adapter is supplied, but it also works off of any USB connection such as on a notebook computer. A USB cable is also supplied.4. The WAN port, in addition to dynamic DHCP, also offers static DHCP, PPTP and L2TP modes. PPTP and L2TP are required for setting up the router as direct to VPN. I use this feature (not yet tested on this router), to connect to the popular HideMyAss VPN service to impersonate an IP address from another location, useful for receiving NetFlix while traveling abroad.5. I can confirm this device can WiFi broadcast Internet to at least 15Mbps, probably somewhat higher. I haven't benchmarked an all wired scenario.6. I'd like to highlight that this router is ipv6 compatible. That's a bit rare for travel routers. I haven't tested this feature.A minor con is the device does not come with a travel bag. I keep it in a Ziploc bag.Update: 9-Nov-2012: I'm unable to get the VPN feature (PPTP or L2TP) to work with HideMyAss VPN service.

Impressed. I find the ZONET zsr4174we router quite easy to work with and surprisingly flexible. In particular, it's PPTP VPN feature is compatible with the popular HideMyAss VPN service to enable NetFlix access outside of the USA. It WiFi connects to my Apple TV 2012. Here's how.Plug a live Ethernet cable from your router into the ZONET. Use the ZONET's hardware mode switch to select Wireless Router. Pause for the reboot. Use the ZONET's web page (Wireless N SSID, 192.168.2.1, admin/admin) setup to specify the following along with the usual router setups (change admin/admin password, provide a WiFi passwod, change SSID, whatever). For Apple TV 2012 device, use "WPA2 - Personal" security mode with AES encryption algorithm. If you screw up the Zonet's settings, you can reset the router by holding down the mode/reset button for 30 seconds.1. PPTP Server: <some HMA PPTP ip server address>2. User Name: <your HMA username>3. Password: <your HMA PPTP password (not your web login password)>4. MTU: <use the default>5. Address Mode: <select Dynamic>6. MPPE: <must be checked>7. It should automatically connect to the HMA server. Check the Status page to verify.8. The ZONET is now a VPN connected wireless router. Just point your device at the SSID.I haven't found any firmware updates but then I don't have any issues.

The first tale, Confederacy in Blue, takes a look at the legends -- and the modern, historical perspective -- of the anti-abolitionist movement in Columbia County, the hatred for Lincoln and distrust of the Union army, and racist perspectives that linger to today. Writing from points of view set in 1864, when the killing of a bounty hunter looking for draft dodgers set off harsh reprisals by the Union, and 2013, when a modern scholar wrestles with the contemporary perception of those events, Laubach links the racism of the Civil War era with the racism of the Obama presidency.It ends a little too abruptly, though, leaving the reader to wonder what happened next in both eras.Season of the Witch explores a very different place in history, the 1928 slaying of a powwow doctor in York County by a man who believed he was "hexed." The story pulls together the paths of John Blymire, who believes his own healing powers have been snatched away by a more established practitioner, Nelson Rehmeyer, and is led to murder by the advice of Nellie Noll, the River Witch of Marietta.The stories place the reader in the moment of both events, rounding out the facts as they are known with well-reasoned fiction.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

I love the concept, but it doesn't quite work out right. For me, at least, but maybe I'm just clumsy.The idea is to get perfectly spherical ice balls, which look cool in a drink, last longer and melt more slowly than conventional ice cubes. I get it. But what I get from this product is roughly roundish ice shapes that have roundish parts but aren't really round.The problems are, they design doesn't really keep water from seeping between the four ice chambers, so when you open this up you have a sheet of ice connecting the balls, and it's impossible -- unless maybe you're using a funnel of some kind -- to fill the spherical chambers properly without overflowing and getting a slab of ice on top.So it's a good idea but the design isn't perfect. I'll still use it, but that's because I don't really care too much what my ice looks like.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

This item was sent to me free of charge in exchange for an honest review. It sat untouched for a while -- to be honest, I just don't like coffee, and the process for making tea with it seemed needlessly complicated when compared to, well, any other way of making tea.But recently my 17-year-old daughter moved back in with me, and SHE is a coffee drinker. I gave this to her on her first morning back, and her eyes lit right up. She's been using it pretty much every day since.She loves it. She says it's easy to use, fairly easy to clean and it makes a good cup of coffee. It's also pretty durable, she says, and she thinks it will last a good long time. Really, I'm not sure what more you could ask for from a coffeemaker! If my daughter is happy with it, I'm happy. (And, since it's fairly compact and doesn't have a power cord like most coffeemakers, it's far more convenient to store in our cramped kitchen!)

I enjoy some young-adult novels, but it’s rare that I -- my youngest child is 17 -- will go out and buy an illustrated children’s book. An exception to that statement is any book penned by Jane Yolen, who has written so many good books for adults, young adults and children that I would never hesitate to curl up with her latest to read.This one is special, because it deals with one of my favorite topics: whales. And, as Yolen is an honest sort, she doesn’t sugarcoat the reality of the central leviathan in this tale.“Stranded Whale” is obliquely about a massive sperm whale that beaches itself on a remote Maine beach in 1971. It is more directly about the three school-age siblings who find the helpless animal and do what they can -- all well-intentioned but ultimately fruitless efforts -- to save it.This story is not a feel-good yarn, nor should you expect a happy ending. It touches briefly but deeply on the emotional impact a creature in peril can have on a person, no matter how fleeting their interaction.Illustrations by Melanie Cataldo suit the story neatly, with muted colors and a slight graininess to the art that reminds me of classic children’s books from my youth.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

I received this item free in exchange for an honest review. I had previously received an ice-ball mold that produced four balls in one, and I had less than stellar results. This product is far better.For one thing, the four molds are not attached to one another, so you don't have that pesky overflow of water that freezes and bonds them together. These molds hold their shape better, without leakage, so you actually get ice balls that are ROUND. The holes at the top are easy to fill, and the molds are easy to separate once the water has frozen. You're left with large, almost perfectly round balls of ice that melt slowly in your drink and look cool all the while.I'm a fan!

I very much like the look of these mugs, and they do a pretty good job of retaining the temperature of whatever drink you put in them. At the same time, they're not something I'd use very often and I can't really see the point of them. I mean, they look like copper, but it's only copper plating, so you're getting the look without the benefits. And, as plated mugs rather than solid copper, I think the price is a little high.But I received these for free in exchange for an honest review, so let me say they are DEFINITELY worth what I paid for them ... and yes, more. These are a nice set, but I'm just not blown away by them.

This statue is the perfect size for my garden, and its coloring is subdued enough not to overshadow the flowers while still being artful enough to draw the eye. I particularly like the subtle touch of blue in Mary's outer garment, which is reminiscent of more garish representations without being so bright as to stand out overmuch. The serenity of her expression and pose is exactly what I was looking for!

This statue is the perfect size for my garden, and its coloring is subdued enough not to overshadow the flowers while still being artful enough to draw the eye. I chose a St. Francis statue for the saint's associations with gardens and wildlife, and it looks very appropriate in my yard. The basin he holds is too small for most uses, but I find it's handy for a small amount of water to satisfy passing bees and butterflies. Very nice piece!

I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review. And, I suppose, because I'm a notorious tippler who would appreciate products made for the discerning drinker of alcoholic refreshments. Which I am.The glasses are plain but stylish even so, with the double-walled glass adding a classy-looking thickness to the set. The gap between walls means your glasses shouldn't sweat, and temperatures should not transfer as much between the drink (hot or cold) and your hands. In my experience so far, this would be true.The whiskey stones are great for anyone who wants to chill a beverage without the dilution that comes with melting ice. They are sturdy and attractive, and they hold a chill for a good long while. I'd be careful about dropping them into a glass from any great height, but overall they're a nice touch to the experience.I'm not sure I'd sell these products together; although related, they seem more like accessories to one another, rather than a matched set. But they are of good quality and they are useful, so I have no hesitation in recommending both parts of this set.

This fountain water dish and feeder, which I received free in exchange for an honest review, is pretty cool. I like the pump, which keeps the water moving and seems to please my dog, too. It holds lots of water. The little nightlight, which also makes it easy to see how fool the tank is, is also a good idea.There are a few minor issues that I hope they fix if they redesign this product. They're not deal-breakers, but they could make it even better.- White isn't a great choice when you're dealing with dog food. It looks dirty almost immediately after you begin using it.- The fountain turns on when you plug it in. A switch would be nice; I don't like to leave it running constantly, and I don't like having to reach around to plug or unplug it every time I want to flip the switch.- When it's off, the water drains into the reservoir. It would be nice if some water remained up top so my dog could get water even when it's off. As it is, I either have to keep it on constantly or I need a second water dish.- The food bowl is right beside the water dish. If your dog is a sloppy eater -- and mine is -- that means you'll get food in the water, sometimes even in the hole where the water percolates up from the reservoir.Like I said, these aren't big flaws but they are small annoyances. I hope they take another look at the design and make this product even better.

OK, I'll be honest ... my dog is a vigorous chewer, so the squeaky noise can drive me crazy sometimes. But Charley LOVES these balls, and that's what matters most. We can play endless games a fetch with these and, while not indestructible, they last a good long time -- much longer than regular tennis balls. The size is perfect for his powerful jaws!
My dog loves the flavor, and they're small enough that I don't feel guilty about giving him a few extra snacks. What more do you want from dog treats?!

I bought these as a surprise gift for my son (who fancies himself a ninja) and, what can I say? He LOVES them! It's a great set. The blades look great, and they feel good in the hand. Would I trust them in an actual battle? Probably not. But I have high hopes that my son won't ever actually need to fight someone with these, so they serve their purpose of being basically just cool things to have.

It'd be great if our problems could be solved with a pill. I am, I confess, a skeptic, and I approached this supplement -- which I received for free in exchange for an honest review -- with low expectations.While I am pleased to see so many other reviews from folks who have had great success with this product, I can only report that I noticed to effects while taking this, even at an increased dose. No benefits, no problematic side effects either. Just a normal day. Perhaps it's because I like to consider myself happy, calm and focused by nature -- maybe I simply didn't need the extra boost.

My dog absolutely DESTROYS most toys in a matter of hours or days, or maybe sometimes weeks if I'm lucky. This ball has survived Charley's teeth for MONTHS, and he still enjoys chasing it as well as chewing it. Better still, it doesn't squeak -- Charley loves squeaky toys so I try to indulge him sometimes, but MAN they drive you crazy after a while! This ball may just be indestructible AND it's quiet. Win-win!

Like some others who have reviewed this item, I purchased it as an accessory to a steampunk costume. Attached, along with other ocular accoutrements, to a hat-and-goggles ensemble, these small lenses are visually appealing and have earned a lot of favorable comments from people who saw the finished piece.

I saw this and immediately thought it would look perfect on my teenage daughter's wrist. I bought it on a whim -- you can't beat the price -- and I was right. It looks great, and she loves it. This is a very nice, eccentric-looking piece and a real good buy.

I got this for my teenage daughter, who of course has plenty of books and other items to lug around school each day. She really likes this, both for its look and its spaciousness!When it first arrived, I started to fumble with the buckles and worried that they were too inefficient. It took me a moment to realize they're just for show -- the bag's compartments are held closed with magnetized snaps. Very nice! All in all, it's a nice looking item and it seems durable, too. (With a more masculine pattern, I might consider using one myself!)I received this product for free in exchange for a review.

I received a free sample for review. I was ready to love this item, and was already preparing a glowing review when it arrived. Unfortunately, this ball has not performed up to expectations.It hangs in a very sunny spot near my house, receiving far more than the minimum required amount of daylight. The "on" switch is properly toggled. But all I get at night is, at best, a pale, weak glow and, at worst, nothing at all.Based on the many positive reviews for this product, I am willing to believe I received a faulty sample. Most of the customers seem more than happy with this sparkling glow-ball, which makes me all the more disappointed in mine!UPDATE: The seller immediately offered to replace the faulty product, and the new one works perfectly. It looks every bit as good as I hoped it would. It's already earned favorable comments from friends who saw it hanging on my side porch!! A nice item ... and very good customer service!

This solar light is bright and long-lasting. I positioned it in a sunny spot in my yard, pointed at a landscaping feature I thought would look attractive at night, and I have been more than pleased with the results. I recommend this light and would gladly put a few more to use around my house!I received a sample product for review.

It has a soothing, friendly cover. It's sturdy. The monthly calendar pages are spacious and neatly organized. If all you want is a planner, it's up to the task.But this planner has ulterior motives. It's designed not just for organization but for soul-searching as well. It asks you to outline your goals, in both your personal and your professional lives, and make a plan for achieving them.This planner is perfect for someone who wants to make changes in his or her life, someone who likes to be organized and who likes to have a strategy for accomplishing goals. Other folks might find this a waste of pages, or might simply ignore the parts that they don't need. In other words, it has a targeted audience, but folks in that audience should love it.I received this calendar/planner for free in exchange for a review.

Valerie Estelle Frankel is far more invested in the Holmesian tradition than I. In fact, one might assume she has studied the great detective's many lives under a magnifying glass, deerstalker cap firmly planted on her head.Her book is an exhaustive bit of research. She examines the particulars of the BBC series starring Benedict Cumberbatch as Holmes and Martin Freeman as his erstwhile companion, Dr. John Watson, and she relates every plot twist, every minor character, every tiny clue and textual reference to Doyle's original work, as well as the various classic screen portrayals. I suspect the reading would be a little dry if you saw down and read the book through -- unless, I suppose, you are a true Holmes fanatic. I instead kept the book handy, and each day I read one or two chapters, most connected to a single episode and its many references.Frankel examines each episode's title, its story, connections to canon, locations, innuendo (are Holmes and Watson more than friends?), ties to the actors' outside work and references to pop and British culture, such as the closely connected series Doctor Who and The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy and the protagonists' work on The Hobbit.It's a little daunting to see how much work the show's makers put into these little Easter eggs for fans, and it's even more so to imagine how much time Frankel spent finding them all.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

As dog poop bags, I have no complaints about this product, which I received for free in exchange for a review. They seem like durable bags and they do the job for which they were intended without muss or fuss.I suppose my biggest question is WHY. Why make perfumed bags for feces? The bags' aroma is a little strong, more chemical than herbal. However, the bags are no match for the strong scent of poo; walking to the garbage can with a neon-green bag in my hand, I smell poop, not lavender. It's not like they turn my garbage into a bouquet of flowers, either -- I took a big, deep sniff and it still smelled like trash. Personally, I'd prefer to use biodegradable bags that don't introduce extra chemicals into whatever landfill these end up in.The bags are great. The chemical smell, not so much.

I think this is the first time a dog treat smelled so good I wanted to eat it myself! (I've resisted the urge, but still....) The pumpkin and blueberry scent is bakery-fresh, and my dog enjoys them immensely. They're small, so they're great for times when I want to give him a treat without packing on the calories.

These is a fairly cheap pennywhistle ... but hey, that's what you expect when you buy a CHEAP pennywhistle!! I purchased a bunch of these to hand out to students at a Celtic whistle workshop, and they were perfect for the occasion. Certainly this isn't a performance-quality instrument, but if you want to learn the basics of the whistle before investing in something better, it's a good enough place to start.

Worried about the various issues with rawhides but not wanting to deprive my dog of the pleasure of them, I was happy to find this beneficial alternative. Charley LOVES these treats, and they seem to be keeping his teeth clean and his breath -- well, it's still doggie breath, but it seems a little better than it used to be!

This harness is well made and seems durable. It's easy enough to get on and off a wriggling dog, which is a great plus! It does seem to run small ... but otherwise I have no complaints about the product itself. Unfortunately, my dog doesn't like wearing it and fusses when I put it on him.I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

Annually, some of the best musicians from Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, throw a week-long party -- the Celtic Colours International Festival -- and they invite a bunch of friends from nations and musical styles around the world. It's an experience not to be missed, in part because of the musical friendships and collaborations that form during that week of music.In 2011, the Barra MacNeils -- a talented musical family from Sydney Mines -- were artists in residence for the festival. They closeted themselves in the studio with some of the guests that year, producing 10 tracks that blend voices and techniques in combinations that will likely never again be repeated.The result is amazing. Sure, I'd rather go to Celtic Colours myself. Barring that, this is a great taste of the kind of musical expression that grows from its creative melting pot.And you can listen to it year-round.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

I had high hopes for this album, solely because I have had exceptional luck with music from the Nova Scotia region, which boasts some of the finest Celtic performers on the market, whether playing purely traditional music or taking it in new directions. At the same time, I was wary, because the name "Celtic Angel" and the title "Celtic Hits" sound like gimmicks meant to snare tourists, rather than appeal to true fans of Irish, Scottish and Maritime culture. The selection of songs -- chestnuts including "Wild Mountain Thyme," "Danny Boy," "Scotland the Brave," "Skye Boat Song," "Amazing Grace" and "Loch Lomond" -- also had me worried, since Fraser obviously is treading well-worn paths with her choices.My fears were justified, while my hopes were not. Unfortunately, the album sounds like something you'd hear in a cheap Celtic knick-knack shop; Fraser's sopranos are quavery, and the treacly arrangements are overly synthesized.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

"Kama Sutra: Connect the Dots" by Eland Sparklers (a pseudonym, obviously) is exactly what it says it is -- a copy of portions of the Hindu sex manual with numbered dots replacing some of the more intimate bits. The reader -- or readers, if you choose to do this with a partner -- takes pencil in hand and, yes, connects the dots to get a glimpse of what passes for ancient Hindu pornography.Clever idea, I suppose. Question is ... why? What is the target audience here? Face it, connect the dots is a child's pastime, something that hones artistic skills and fosters creativity at an early age. Are there really adults out there who are so hard up for a glimpse of entwined limbs and sketchy nudity that they'll connect the dots to get it? Have those people never heard of the Internet?Like I said, clever idea, but I don't see the point. I do not feel compelled to sharpen up my pencil for this one.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

This leash is strong, comfortable in the hand and has a very durable feel to it. It looks great, and my pup seems a little prouder when we use it for walks! I'm worried that it might prove an irresistible temptation, since Charley likes to chew, so I keep it out of his reach when it's not in use.I've only had it for a week, but I love it. Great accessory!

Taped live in 2007 at the Millburn Stone Memorial Theater at Cecil Community College in Northeast, Md., this concert recording features singer Charlie Zahm at his vocal best.The CD is dominated by Scottish and Irish songs, including "Westering Home," "Follow Me Up to Carlow," "Mairi's Wedding," "Minstrel Boy" and "Scotland the Brave." Other songs range from Nova Scotia ("Out on the Mira," "Farewell to Nova Scotia") to Broadway ("Memory") and include a handful of Zahm originals: "Summer Rains," "Sweet Virginia," "Lighthouse on the Shore").All combined, it's an excellent concert experience, proof that Zahm sings equally well in the studio or on the stage.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Collections of quotations are by their nature hit and miss affairs. Any good collection, on any topic, will provide pearls of wisdom or wit that the reader has never before seen or heard. At the same time, every collection at some point lets the reader down, omitting some key phrase or source that absolutely MUST be included.“The Quotable Sailor” draws its quotations from varied sources: authors, poets, philosophers, sailors, political figures and more. Topics include sailing, the sea, sailors, boats, weather, engines, racing and philosophy.Those who appear in these pages range from singer Jimmy Buffett to naturalist Rachel Carson, from President John F. Kennedy to authors Joseph Conrad, Jack London and Herman Melville, from philosophers Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau to the poet Homer.I was vaguely disappointed not to see anything from the likes of Forester, O’Brian or Pope, although Douglas Reeman (aka Alexander Kent) makes one appearance.But, all in all, it’s a nice collection to keep handy, to browse when you have a few moments to kill. There are words of praise and loathing for the sea, but all are heartfelt.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Ever since people first took to the sea in boats, there have been accidents and disasters large and small. Many of these were unavoidable collisions with the forces of nature -- unpredictable and uncontrollable movements of storm or sea that led ships to their destruction.Many also were caused by simple human error -- "blunders," as author David Blackmore describes them, in his book Blunders & Disasters at Sea.The book begins in the Nile Delta in 1176 BCE, when the "Sea Peoples" were routed in a naval encounter with Egyptian forces. It ends in December 2002 and a series of collisions with the wrecked vessel Tricolor in the English Channel.And between the two, more than 100 separate incidents, each with one or more wrecked ships and great loss of life.It's interesting reading. Blackmore doesn't spend much time on each, but presents the facts concisely before moving on to the next. As novelist Wilbur Smith notes in a quote on the back cover, "There is material for a hundred or more novels in these pages." I'd probably enjoy reading those novels, too -- but in the meantime, I thoroughly enjoyed Blackmore's brief, more anecdotal versions.Wooden sailing ships, steamships, cruise ships and massive World War II battleships all have their place here, and many still rest at the bottom of the ocean because, ultimately, someone goofed. My only complaint? Too few pictures. There's a nice collection in the middle of the book, but the book screams out for more.All in all, though, this is a good collection for anyone who's fascinated by tales of the sea.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

The title of Robert Elias Cahill's "New England's Naughty Navy" was apparently chosen more for alliteration's sake and less for the actual meaning of the words. The phrase "naughty navy" conjures images of sailors engaging in shenanigans on shore leave. This book is nothing like that.For the most part, the book is a perfectly serviceable text on the formation of the first American navy during the Revolutionary War. It's intestesting enough stuff, too -- it's a fascinating period of history, and those upstart Colonials were pretty plucky to take on the mighty British navy in their whaleboats and converted merchant vessels.But it doesn't deliver on the promise of its title, or even of chapter headings such as "Washington's Wet and Wild Warriors" -- which might lead one to assume the soldiers competed against the British in wet T-shirt contests or something.This book obviously was titled solely with the notion of attracting the eye of New England tourists in gift shops, who would pick up the slim volume in hopes of alluring anecdotes of salacious seamen. (See, I can alliterate, too!) And hey, it worked, since it succeeded in getting me to buy a copy during a visit to Massachusetts.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Richard Woodman likes yanking his readers right out of the action in order to lay a little exposition on them.Believe me, as an avid fan of nautical fiction, I enjoy learning the details of history from the Age of Sail as much as the next person. But Woodman, who in An Eye of the Fleet has crafted an otherwise excellent start to his Nathaniel Drinkwater series of novels, seldom bothers to work facts seamlessly into the story; instead, he just plops a few paragraphs of textbook narrative into the tale wherever he deems appropriate.Worse, Woodman often throws in historical trivia that had not, as of the time of this novel's setting, occurred. It throws off the mood of a period novel when the reader is abruptly thrust into some other era, with details that could not be known to the characters in this story.That complaint aside, the novel is an entertaining introduction to Drinkwater, who would go on to be the protagonist of 14 novels by Woodman. He begins the novel young and unsure of himself, low in confidence and even a bit cowardly in the face of danger. He grows rapidly in the role, however, exceeding his peers and gaining the attention of his superiors in short order. Without knowing what lies waiting for him in the series ahead, I can suppose he has a promising career in store.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Beginning a new nautical series is usually a treat, and one from McBooks -- a careful and quality publisher of historical fiction -- is most often an auspicious occasion. So I was delighted to start The Valiant Sailors, the first volume in V.A. Stuart's Phillip Hazard series.Unlike the majority of books in the genre, Valiant Sailors is not set against the backdrop of Britain's wars with France, but rather is launched at the onset of hostilities between Turkey and Russia.Phillip Hazard is a likable and capable man, first lieutenant on the steam frigate Trojan. Both ship and crew are far better than the Trojan's mean-spirited and heavy-handed captain should warrant; much of their success is accomplished in spite of, rather than because of, Captain North's cruel leadership.The greatest failing here is Stuart's lack of detail regarding the ship itself. Steam-driven ships were a far cry from the previous generation's fleet, which had only wind and tide to drive it, and many of the officers during the Crimean War were slow to grasp the possibilities of a steamship's maneuverability. Stuart touches only lightly on the subject, however, and the dangers inherent in the new technology are ignored completely.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

I had heard whales "sing" before. It was at one time in vogue for musicians to slap a humpback whale or two in the background for atmosphere. But Paul Winter has gone a step further, treating recorded whalesong as the melody and the human musicians as harmonists. The result is surprisingly good, even to someone who has long been a fan of humpback whale recordings.Whales Alive! is, oddly enough, a byproduct of Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home. The movie, directed by "Spock" star Leonard Nimoy, featured two Earth-saving humpback whales, and Nimoy approached cetacean biologist Roger Payne -- best known for his recordings of humpback whales -- for the necessary sound effects. Payne introduced Nimoy to his friend, Winter ... and somehow that meeting led to this recording.To make the album, Payne sat in the organ loft of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, playing his recorded whalesongs on a tape player. Organist Paul Halley, a long-time collaborator and friend of Winter's, improvised organ harmonies to mesh with the whale melodies. Winter, sitting down in the cathedral nave, listened to both organ and whales and wove his own melody and harmony lines into the sound on his soprano saxophone. It is an incredible example of improvisational recording, and Winter was careful to give the whales equal credit for the tunes' composition. (Winter, writing in the liner notes, said the whales are "such inventive melodists, always taking us in new and unexpected musical directions.") Nimoy later added passionate recitations of old and new literature about whales, and additional members of Winter's consort added extra layers of harmony and rhythm to complete the recording.The outcome of this unusual collaboration is amazing. The whalesong sweeps and swells in patterns no human throat could duplicate, wrenching emotion from the soul of anyone with an appreciation for the beauty of nature in all its myriad manifestations. The instrumentations successfully match the melody in quality, emotion and pure musicianship. The whales, I think, would be pleased.And let's talk about Leonard Nimoy. Love or hate Star Trek, there's no denying that Nimoy has a deep, resonant voice very appropriate for this sort of emotive, dramatic reading. The words of poetry and prose -- chosen from a broad range of whale-related literature -- roll from his tongue like honey from a worn wooden spoon. It's possible to get lost in those words, to close your eyes, push the distractions of your world into a corner for a while and just soak in the beauty of language.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

This beautiful painting makes for a great night light, and the presentation here is attractive in a dark room. By and large, a night light is a night light, but this one looks good, is solidly constructed and has a handy swivel plug so you can use it in vertical and horizontal sockets. Nice!

John Braginton-Smith and Duncan Oliver detail those early “fishermen” who first harvested the oil and bone from drift whales, or those who beached themselves on their shores, and later set out for short distances from the coast in small whaling vessels, usually oar-driven and carrying only a handful of men. These vessels would usually “gang up” on the whales, attacking from several sides until the whales died and could be towed back to shore, or until the whales sank and, the men hoped, washed ashore within the next few days.Their story is interesting, as they devised ways to defeat creatures many times their size with only rudimentary weapons. Men, too, died on those expeditions.That said, the authors here have presented the meat of their story in a bland sauce. The text here is dryly written, poorly organized and often-times repetitive. (I lost count, for instance, of the number of times I read that Jacobus Loper was invited to Nantucket to teach them how to hunt whales, but he didn’t go.)And, at less than 100 pages of text, it still feels like Braginton-Smith and Oliver were scrambling to find enough to fill a book. They present a great amount of dull, unnecessary detail that really doesn’t further our understanding of early whaling, and they use a large number of very similar photographs of dead whales on the beach -- in fact, they use the same photo twice -- and of illegibly scribbled documents.This book bored me.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Based on the other reviews, I'd say a lot of folks bought this for its intended purpose: magnification. Not me! I got this as an accessory to a steampunk tophat I was designing, it was proved to be an inexpensive touch that was perfect for the look I was going for!
This is exactly what I needed to store an assortment of teas in an easy-to-organize, easy-to-access location. Plenty of room for lots of tea, and it's easy to find the type I want.
It's a great phrase for you and your special someone to post in a prominent spot in your home. The text is attractively presented, and the decal itself holds up well -- no bubbles, no peeling.
This is a great gift for the Doctor Who fan in your life -- or to accent your own car, too. It catches the eye AND it has held up well through all kinds of weather.
This case is the perfect size for a good-sized selection of CDs, and it's nice and compact and durable for use in the car. I'm well pleased with this purchase!

Jacky Faber's waters never run smooth, and this time the calm is disturbed by the arrival of a pirate ship carrying a grudge and a British naval warship with orders to capture the fierce pirate that is 16-year-old Jacky Faber and return her to England for trial and hanging.But, while we might expect the winsome lass to wrap the crew of HMS Dauntless around her small finger, her plans for escape run aground when a French naval fleet sails into view with its eyes on a ripe British prize. Before you know it, Jacky and her shipmates are imprisoned and bound for the guillotine.I'm sure it gives nothing away to assure you Jacky does not have her head chopped off. Instead, the book takes her in entirely new directions, from the British Secret Service to a Parisian brothel and to the elite conquering army of Napoleon Bonaparte himself.Louis A. Meyer, the Maine writer and artist responsible for the Bloody Jack series, has once again raised the bar with this latest installment. The irrepressible Jacky is a darling character who will make you laugh, sigh, shed a tear and loudly cheer at every turn of her misadventures.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Cracking open a Jacky Faber novel is like taking that first breath of sea air after a long, stuffy car ride. There's a hint of fish and tar on the wind, a fiddle tune in your ear and you can almost feel the deck rocking beneath your feet. It's refreshing, and it fills you with excitement for what's to come.In the Belly of the Bloodhound is no exception. Our young heroine, Mary "Jacky" Faber, late of London, Boston and the high seas, continues to prove that no dreary episode can stifle her general good cheer and optimism for long. And believe me, that's a quality she'll need in spades in this latest installment from Maine-based author L.A. Meyer.Jacky, freshly escaped from British naval justice (over a little thing having to do with piracy on the high seas) in the confusion that was the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805, has made her way back to Boston, where she was last seen fleeing after her questionable involvement in the setting of a really big fire. The Lawson Peabody School for Young Girls was left in ashes, but the unflappable Mistress Pimm has rebuilt from the ground up, and she calmly welcomes Jacky back into the fold of high-society ladies-in-the-making. For Jacky, it's a way to hide out in good company while avoiding those seeking the price on her head, but even a quiet sojourn at an elegant school can't keep her contained for long.An innocent trip with her classmates onto the briny sea leads to their capture and confinement on a slaver bound for North Africa. And, while Jacky has proven herself resourceful in countless grim situations, the other 31 girls in her company are prone to panic at the sight of a broken nail, much less the dank, rat-filled hold of the slaveship.Fans of Meyer's series so far will delight in the fourth installment. In the Belly of the Bloodhound takes Jacky and other familiar characters into new places, fresh dangers and entirely new limits of excitement. Whether faced with a cat-o'-nine-tails or freshly cooked rat, our heroine provides an entertaining read.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Jacky Faber is back at sea. Under the Jolly Roger begins with Jacky's arrival back in London, having crossed the Atlantic in service to a whaling vessel of some renown. After a clever wink and nod to Moby Dick, author L.A. Meyer begins to unfold the next tumultuous chapter in Jacky's topsy-turvy life.A misguided attempt to surprise her long-lost love leads to a serious misunderstanding, and Jacky -- disguised once again as a boy -- is pressed into service on another British vessel. This time she's sent to a ship blockading French ports, and the vile British captain -- who proves to be greedy, lustful and in ill health -- refuses to send her ashore. But Jacky is nothing if not resourceful, and she has a knack for making the right friends in the right places, and -- well, let's not spoil the surprise. The title of the book is enough to tell you she doesn't remain under proper British rule for long.Under the Jolly Roger includes plenty of action at sea and intrigue on board, as well as the kind of heady, high-spirited character development that has proved a hallmark of Meyer's work.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

One would never expect the challenges of a respected Boston finishing school to equal the dangers of a life at sea. But Jacky Faber is no ordinary young lady.Jacky, who survived a childhood on the streets of London and more than a year at sea in the service of the British navy (disguised as a boy), was revealed as a girl at the close of Bloody Jack and left to the tender mercies of Mistress Pimm at the Lawson Peabody School for Young Girls, where she must learn to be a proper lady. Her midshipman's share of HMS Dolphin's prize money stands her in good stead for an education, but her disposition may be unequal to the task.While used to a life of discipline, Jacky is not accustomed to the many limitations of her sex -- and Boston, circa 1800, has a lot of them. Jacky is free-spirited and direct, gregarious and full of zest. She loves music and dancing, and she enjoys the rough company of a seaside tavern more than the refined air of an afternoon tea. She is neither modest nor circumspect. Fortunately, Jacky is resourceful.Author L.A. Meyer continues Jacky's story in fine form in this second novel in the series. This novel is very different than its predecessor -- trading a nautical setting for Colonial New England -- but maintains the flavor that made the first book such a joy.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Dudley Pope lays bare the details of Trafalagar -- Horatio Nelson's greatest and final naval victory -- in a brilliantly clear and highly detailed narrative that almost reads like a novel.Decision at Trafalgar begins very nearly at the end. Nelson is dead, the battle is over and a heavy gale is fast approaching, and the wee ship Pickle is sent 1,000 miles home to England -- followed by many rough miles over land to London -- with the news. The frantic pace of that journey sets the tone for the book, which soon pulls back in time to set the stage for the conflict to come.You'll get to know Nelson, as well as other great figures in this drama from their respective English, French or Spanish stages. You'll learn a great deal about the state of England as the threat of French invasion drew ever nearer, and you'll discover a lot about the movements of British politics as well as the actions of British sailors.The amount of detail packed into this book is astonishing, but it never reads like a textbook. One can easily see why C.S. Forester, author of the enduring Horatio Hornblower novels, urged Pope to write fiction.Without ever letting his prose become tedious, Pope introduces us to officers and men throughout both fleets and, through his painstaking research and fluid way with a pen, we come to know them, what they were thinking and feeling preceding and in some cases during the battle, and what their fates were by battle's end. By God, we know Nelson, and we understand what he was thinking and why his men, from senior captains to the lowest tar, loved and respected him.And Pope, who knows a thing or two about seamanship, makes sure the reader smells the smoke, feels the wind fill the sails and suffers the impact as cannonballs slam into wooden ships and fragile men.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Captain William Proby sounds like a likable enough man. As described here by Dudley Pope, he seems a fair and competent leader who did good service for his ship and her crew, as well as Britain's ongoing war with France.Why, then, was Proby labeled "the devil himself" by the men who mutinied against him? We may never know the full story behind the insurrection onboard the former French corvette, now serving in the British fleet as HMS Danae. A careful read of The Devil Himself: The Mutinty of 1800 makes it plain that there were several bad seeds among the crew -- men who would always be unhappy at sea, men who had mutinied before.Pope, who has often demonstrated his excellent grasp of naval history and tactics in his fictional adventures of Nicholas Ramage, here goes into thorough detail as he explores the background of the ship, her men and the political climate surrounding them. With facts culled from British and French naval archives, he paints a clear picture of the situation and follows it through Proby and his men's captivity, parole and eventual court martial. His narrative style of writing makes the history a pleasure to read.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

A whole lot happens in Ramage & the Rebels, not the least of which involves a ship full of slaughtered civilians and an island -- yes, an entire island -- that wishes to surrender to a lone British frigate.The frigate Calypso is, of course, commanded by Capt. Nicholas Ramage, one of the youngest rising stars in the British navy. Ordered to patrol for privateers -- and, consequently, fatten his admiral's purse with prize money -- Ramage is not quite prepared for the responsibility for a whole Dutch island. The Dutch, of course, are allied with the enemy French, but in this case the colony is more immediately threatened by a large body of revolution-hungry rebels and bloodthirsty privateers.One privateer in particular is responsible for the aforementioned slaughter -- it's a subplot that seems underused and largely unfulfilled here. And author Dudley Pope -- who is among my very favorite nautical writers -- uses a technique here that I don't like; he slips into the present tense, usually when some third party is observing Ramage and admiring his looks, bearing or skill in some way. It's a distracting style that interrupts the flow; if he's done this in previous books, I managed to overlook it.Otherwise, Ramage & the Rebels is full of thrilling action and the usual amount of Ramage luck. Sure, no real person could ever hope to conjure the amount of lucky breaks that Ramage gets, but I can't help enjoying his unending succession of victories.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Nicholas Ramage, beloved leader of men, the target of a ship's mutiny?Or is Ramage, ever the obedient officer of the King's Navy, himself the leader of an uprising against his immediate commander?The title of this volume of the Dudley Pope series, Ramage's Mutiny, raises a few questions, the answers of which may well surprise you.The book begins with Ramage still riding high after his many successes off French-held Martinique. His admiral, who should by all rights be doting on his daring and astonishingly profitable junior captain, instead sends him off on what should by all rights be a suicide mission: bring back the Jocasta, a British frigate whose crew mutinied more than a year prior, murdering the captain and officers before sailing into a Spanish port and turning over the ship in exchange for their freedom.It doesn't seem to matter to the admiralty that the task appears to be a suicide mission. This ship, fully crewed and manned with a detachment of some 300 soldiers, is moored in a harbor protected by a narrow channel and three heavily armed forts. Another British naval captain has already fled from the assignment, deeming it impossible.Of course, he was no Nicholas Ramage.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

This time, Ramage is serving as lieutenant in command of the brig Triton and is part of a British navy escort of a massive convoy of merchant ships bound for Jamaica. One ship in particular is carrying especially valuable cargo -- important and secretive passengers, actually -- who must not fall into enemy hands. It's a given privateers will make an attempt at some point during the voyage -- and that Ramage will be on hand to deflect it.The mission is complicated by Ramage's own lack of favor with superior officers in the fleet. One in particular will do anything to disgrace the young lieutenant, and the voyage will offer plenty of opportunities for a fatal misstep.A massive hurricane is another hitch -- and here in particular, Pope excels with fine storytelling that puts the reader on deck as the winds howl and waves surge over the scuppers. There's also a little time spent on a tropical island, of sorts -- and a treasure hunt that is perhaps just a trifle silly and too easily resolved -- and a tense, high-stakes court-martial proceeding on charges of cowardice that could ruin Ramage's career, or end his life.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

It's a simple enough mission, transporting a pair of Italian dignitaries to Gibraltar. Even the fact that Lt. Nicholas Ramage, captain of the cutter Kathleen, is madly in love with one of them shouldn't interfere too much with the easy cruise. But when he stumbles upon a drifting and defenseless Spanish frigate, Ramage's sense of duty leaves him no choice but to capture it -- even though doing so is a direct violation of orders.The capture is simple enough, but towing the large, disabled vessel makes Kathleen herself an easy target -- and all too soon, Ramage and his crew are captives themselves. But, resourceful as ever, Ramage manages to put his time in Spain to good use as a spy. Then, with priceless information in his grasp, he makes his way back to the British fleet -- and soon finds himself, once more in command of little Kathleen, sailing into battle against a massive Spanish armada on Feb. 14, 1797.Historians will thrill at Dudley Pope's in-the-thick-of-it retelling of the Battle of Cape St. Vincent. And, while the actions of Kathleen and her crew aren't part of the official record, they certainly could help to explain the outcome. ... When Valentine's Day dawns and the British fleet sails into battle, you will read one of the most extraordinary naval narratives yet published.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Dudley Pope doesn't waste any time getting into the action.Ramage, the first book in a series, begins with the frigate Sibella already sinking after a brutal attack from a French ship of the line. Sibella's captain and senior officers are dead; the only surviving officer is junior lieutenant Nicholas Ramage, himself badly wounded. With only a small portion of the crew still alive and able and the ship sinking fast, Ramage comes up with a plan to escape the scene, leaving only the wounded behind to be captured and, he hopes, treated for their injuries by French doctors.Once free of the ship, Ramage decides to complete his late captain's mission to rescue a group of influential Italian aristocrats from Napoleon's advancing army. But there are other issues that face this young officer, from the inevitable court-martial for surrendering a British vessel to unexpected charges of cowardice in the face of the enemy. Somehow, in the midst of all that, Ramage finds time to fall in love -- and then there's another rescue to effect, when a British ship runs aground under the guns of the French invaders.There are weaknesses here. One is Ramage's habit of day-dreaming when his attention really should be focused elsewhere; this is obviously a tool Pope uses to bring readers up to speed on important information, but it strains believability to have a man of Ramage's station drift off during combat, for instance, or while being interviewed by the esteemed Commodore Nelson. Ramage's endless stream of good luck and happy coincidences also tests the reader's credulity.But there is plenty to like here, and I like Ramage a great deal. This is only the first book in an 18-book series, and I know already I'd love to read the lot. Ramage is a promising character with boatloads of growth potential, an interesting set of character flaws and a personal history that could stand in his way. Pope, meanwhile, has an obvious knowledge of and love for the sea, and it shines through in his writing.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

In a desperate age of battles at land and sea to prevent the further spread of the Corsican, Napoleon Bonaparte, across Europe, one would hardly expect the Royal Post Office to serve as the basis of a dramatic novel.In the hands of Dudley Pope, however, the mail service is perfect grist for the mill. Ramage's Prize takes Pope's eponymous hero, Lt. Lord Nicholas Ramage, from the sunny Caribbean back to England aboard a mail packet; his mission, based on true events, is to discover why so many ships bearing royal mail have vanished on the high seas, falling prey to French privateers in unprecedented numbers.Before he and his crew see England again, there will be poor seamanship, a lukewarm sea battle, wood rot, treason, murder, kidnapping and more, all wrapped up and delivered in a neat parcel befitting Pope's skill at naval wordsmithery.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

It begins with a hearty breakfast, as all good adventures should, of cold tongue and oysters.Then there's a grand ball, and an urgent message to Lord St. Vincent and Lord Nelson, and before you know it, Lt. Nicholas Ramage has been assigned to penetrate revolutionary France and determine whether Bonaparte's Army of England, which has been massing along the French coastline, has much chance of crossing the English Channel. The mission requires the aid of smugglers, including a navy deserter whom Ramage has had flogged, and a great deal of intrigue in France to avoid the highly suspicious officials of Napoleon's government.Ramage & the Guillotine lacks the action at sea that is a hallmark of this series, and it once again counts on the protagonist's amazing good luck to see him through. I look forward to seeing Lt. Ramage back at sea, where he belongs, in his next adventure.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

Ramage's Diamond, the seventh book in the Dudley Pope series, finds Nicholas Ramage newly made post-captain and assigned to the Juno, a frigate whose previous captain was drummed out of the service in disgrace. Ramage reports to find the first lieutenant drunk, the crew unruly and the ship in disarray, but with a few new officers, his longtime sailing master Southwick and a handful of men from his previous command, he manages to get the ship in good order en route to his new assignment in the West Indies.There, Ramage is given the unglamorous assignment of blockading a French port in Martinique. Fortunately, Ramage is not one to sit idly by, tacking back and forth and waiting for something to happen. There is, very quickly, a lot of ship-to-ship action, including a dramatic cutting-out action involving an enemy frigate, a bit of cat-and-mouse with a pair of privateer sloops and the interception of a well-defended merchant convoy.Ramage, as always, relies heavily on good luck to see his way through a series of potential misadventures. But he also knows his way around a plan, too, and this one involves Diamond Rock, an otherwise useless lump in the water that he puts to clever use.Luck aside, Ramage's adventures are a pleasure to read because of Pope's enthusiasm for and thorough knowledge of his subject. In fact, perhaps because his protagonist has finally ascended to captain's rank, Pope here takes more time than before to educate readers about the ways and means of preparing and sailing a ship. It's never a dull textbook, though; I, at least, enjoyed the education immensely.by Tom Knapp, the Rambles.NET guy

This is a stylish, nice-looking scale that is an attractive addition to our bathroom. However, I rank accuracy above appearance when it comes to a utilitarian object such as this, and this scale is not as smart as its name suggests. Usually, the numbers fluctuate, running through a repeating series of numbers nowhere near my actual weight, never settling down on just one. When it does stop on a number, it's far from accurate -- I know what I weigh, and this scale has never once come within 20 pounds of the correct answer.An attractive design just doesn't cut it when the product itself is flawed.

This sweater took forever to receive (since it came from China).  It's one size too small and it's itchy.  If I ever plan on wearing this in the future, I'll have to wear a button-up collared shirt under it.  Not a good buy.  And I can't send it back unless I want to pay a fortune in return shipping.  Save yourself the grief and buy something else from somebody else.  I recently bought a sweater nearly like this one (except in pink) from Venus that is dreamingly SOFT.  So, Venus has these sweaters for about the same price that are actually as soft as this one kind of looks in the picture.  So, go to Venus.  Avoid this sweater.

This is the worst chair mat ever.  First of all, it has no "cleats" on the bottom so there's nothing holding the mat in place.  It constantly has to be dragged back in place every 5 minutes or so.  And that totally sucks.  So, if you move AT ALL when you're sitting at your desk, you'll find that this mat is climbing up either side of your desk and then you have to bend it back down into place, usually with a heavy box or something.  The bottom of this mat is super smooth so there's absolutely no friction to hold it in place.  Stupidest design for a mat ever!  I bought 4 of these and, after only one week, the one that's under my chair is going in the trash.  It's way too much work to have to straighten this mat out every 5 to 10 minutes or face the consequences of leaving it to have to rebend the plastic down if left sliding up the side of the desk.

I'm very unhappy with this product.  Not only did it NOT kill the grubs and my raccoons are still digging up my grass to get to them BUT it killed my honey bees.  Yes, I have a hive of honey bees that I DID NOT want to kill off.  We as a DYING PLANET need these honey bees to keep our food growing and I had a hive that moved into this old abandoned ventilation cylinder that's in my yard.  I never bothered them and over the years their hive grew and grew bigger.  I sprayed this in the yard last week and inadvertently sprayed the lower branches of one of the trees that they gather pollen from.  I noticed today, less than a week later, that ALL of my bees are gone.  I was absolutely devastated as I feel like I lost a family.  Again, these honey bees are VERY IMPORTANT to our environment and this product killed them all.  If I would have know this, I would have NEVER purchased this product to begin with, as it's VERY harmful to our environment yet it does nothing to get rid of the problem they're advertising which is to rid the grubs.

This is a total waste of money.  It doesn't work.  I have raccoons who have dug up my entire front yard.  I spread this around my front and back yard.  It did NOTHING to stop them.  They've kept digging and now they're moving to the back.  Total waste of money.  Plus is stinks worse than powdered horse manure.  If you get it on your clothes and shoes (which is easy to do), it will upset your pets and cause them to urinate on your stuff in the house.

This is the best cleanser on the market, in my opinion.The biggest issue that I have with other cleansers out there is that they are much like a lotion or they are a hard sticky soap that takes forever to wash off just to have that coating of "film" on my face.  And I absolutely hate that.Further, I don't like spending a lot of time washing my face so there's nothing worse than standing in front of the sink for 20 minutes trying to get all the soap off.And this is why I love this Simple Cleanser so much.  It's foamy so no sticky heavy-residue soap here.  It washes and rinse quickly and in its entirety so there's no film feeling.  And my face feels squeaky clean and SUPER SOFT!I'm sold for life on this cleanser and I'll never consider trying anything else ever again.  If I could give this 10 stars, I would.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for those of you with sensitive skin, as I do.  This doesn't cause break-outs or redness or anything.  It's VERY gentle on the skin.

This is really an awesome buy!  If you want to save money and get the best possible bang for your buck for a cheapy set of headphones, there's nothing else you should consider buying other than this pair.  I have all kinds of headphones ranging from Bose to Beats.  While this doesn't compare to a headphone set that's several hundred dollars, this pair definitely ranks pretty high in comparison to any set that's $100 or less.  You can't go wrong with these.  You'll be happy with your purchase.

This was recommended to me by someone I know.  She raves about this product.  So, being the stress case that I am, I decided to try it to mellow me out.  Yes, it works.  It does mellow me out.  However, even though I'll take one or two of these in the morning, by the time I go to sleep, I notice that my heart is racing and beating out of my chest!!  I can't sleep!!  I've experimented with different dosages and the same thing happens every time.  So, I had to discontinue taking the product because it makes me feel like I've taken a Pep pill or caffeine tablet.  Too bad.  I really wanted to continue taking this.  I also noticed that it gives me a vice-grip type headache at night.  Not good.  Not good at all!!

I took a recent cruise.  I always use the Sea-Band Adult Wristband, Color May Vary, 1-Pair with the acupressure bead on it which work VERY WELL, by the way.  However, as a back-up, I decided to get this Dramamine just in case.  I'm VERY glad I did.  We did an outing on a Catamaran on rough waters then returned to the ship where there was a lot more in the way of rough waters for several hours thereafter.  My daughter (age 7) got really sea sick so, as per the instructions, I gave her 1 of these.  Within 20 minutes she was out like a light.  (This makes you tired much like Benadryl does.)  Two nights later I got sea sick, took one of these, and although I was tired (it was in the evening), it knocked the sea sickness out in 15 minutes.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.  This really works.

Hands down, this is the best sleep mask ever.  I've tried MANY TYPES of sleep masks and none are as light as this one while creating COMPLETE coverage so there isn't any light leakage around the nose that you'll find with just about every other mask out there.  I can't sleep without these, seriously.  I have a myriad of different colors and patterns.  Please note that if you're like me (who wears these EVERY NIGHT), you'll need a new one every couple of months.  You'll notice that the part that wraps around your head starts to stretch out a little.  For the price, it's definitely doable to replace this every couple of months.

I was pleasantly surprised at how well this worked on my recent Caribbean cruise vacation.  I used it in the ocean in the Bahamas as well as climbing Dunn's River Falls in Jamaica.  It allows for easy phone access and it isn't difficult to take pics or to text when the phone is in the bag/cover.  You can also put other things in the bag/cover including money, your ID, credit cards, etc. and not worry that anything will get lost or wet.  Awesome product and you can't beat the price.  Highly recommended!

Very classy!  I love this!I'm not big on decals since many look too shiny or cheesy but not this one.  I have a small travel HP that's blue.  I wasn't sure if I should go with the white or black decal.  I settled on black and it looks amazing.  Very easy to apply.  I'm super happy.  You can't go wrong with choosing this one.

I was overjoyed after blowing this up because this slide is freaking HUGE!  It's MUCH BIGGER than others like it.But...a couple of issues:1) There is NO bottom anchor to keep it from not moving.  Other slides like this will have a bottom part that you fill with water to keep the slide from going anywhere.  Not this one!  There is NOTHING to keep this in place, making it move all over the place including it escaping into the middle of the pool.  That sucks!2) Because you constantly have to keep pulling the slide BACK in place over and over again, it split the seam at the very top to where it was a gaping hole large enough to put a child's fist in it.  In other words, it can't be repaired, especially with that useless patch they give you for "repairs."The good news, the company I bought it from (VM INNOVATIONS) had me send in a piece of the slide to them so they could replace it.  This is their policy provided that it's within 60 days.  So I have a second one coming to me as a replacement.Still, if I would have known that there is no way to weight this down to keep it in place, I wouldn't have bought it in the first place, as I'm predicting that the next slide I get will also last a single weekend before ripping apart.  Totally flawed design.  Don't bother!UPDATE:  Received the 2nd slide (for free) from the vendor BUT it also lasted 2 days and then the seam split in the EXACT same location as the prior slide we had.  I reduced my review from 3 stars to 1 star.  DO NOT BUY unless you're looking for something that will only last a weekend...perhaps for a BBQ pool party or something.

My daughter loves this go cart.  It goes much faster than I thought and it is pretty well-built.  I couldn't believe that the same model was selling at Toys R Us for $400.  I got it here for much less!Yes, it states its for kids 8 and up but it seems to be okay for kids 6 and up.  I have a 5 year old neighbor boy and he's a tad too young to ride this.  He maneuvers it well at his age BUT has a tendency to run over other kids with it.For kids 6-9...awesome go cart.  It may be a little too small for kids over 10 or 11, especially if they are big for their age.

Not comfortable to wear AT ALL!  There is no support and I had to wear thicker socks to make them tolerable to wear.  Wearing hose or thin socks with these will give you a blister.  Even though they are cute, I wouldn't buy these again.

These cups are awesome.  They are HUGE!  Perfect for soup, very large cups of coffee, or even a small meal.  They are thick and heavy weight so they are made to last.  The color is a rich deep blue, making them classy looking.I used these as a gift.  I put a bag of ground coffee made in Hawaii then wrapped it up in clear cellophane tied with colorful curly ribbon.  I gave them as gifts to my daughter's teachers and other school faculty members.  They were a big hit!I bought more of these (but in white) for myself to use at home.  Even though the white ones look slightly larger (perhaps because of the color) but they don't seem as well-made or as thick as these blue ones.You won't be disappointed with your purchase, as you can't go wrong with these cups!

The picture makes this shirt look beige but it's more of a light olive color.  It didn't match my suit so I couldn't wear it.  When trying it on the material seems flimsy and the buttons are so cheap that they won't stay on long.  Not happy.

I have a daughter who refuses to eat any other cereal except for Cocoa Pebbles.  I bought this to see if she'd try something else.  She refused...at first.  Then was intrigued by the little shapes that look exactly like pieces of bread.  Once she tried them, she was hooked and couldn't believe that they taste just like French toast.  She likes eating them as a snack without milk.  Great for kids and small enough for even toddlers to eat as a dry snack.

I'm in love with all these Method foaming hand soaps.  After trying them, I now refuse to go back to regular sticky Soft Soap and other hand soaps that don't foam.  Method foaming hand soaps will make your hands feel extra clean and super soft.  Highly recommended.

Total POS!  Okay, so I've run the gamut with these blow-up pool slides and this is my 4th one in the past 3 years of having a pool.  This was, hands down, the WORST ONE I've bought (and the most expensive).  It lasted for a week and...that was it!  Already had a hole in the seam.  And for these stupid pool toy companies that provide those lame clear patches for a "repair," those are 100% useless since 99% of the holes you'll get in ANY pool toy or a slide like this is IN THE SEAM.  So, the patch doesn't do anything!!  Don't get this suck-fest slide.  It's expensive and lasted the LEAST AMOUNT OF TIME out of ALL the blow-up slides I've purchased.

I love, love, LOVE this earring tree.  It's MUCH LARGER than anticipated.  The picture doesn't do it justice so hopefully you have a place on your dresser or vanity that can allow for room for this large tree.  I got so tired of digging through this jewelry box drawer that I have to find earrings.  Now all of my earrings are in perfect order.  What's nice is that you can hang loop or dangling earrings on the lower part of the leaves and affix the stud earrings onto the higher part of the leaves.  Great buy.  This is much nicer than I could have possibly dreamed it would be.

These are dreamy sandals.  I have a pair of Nike that I bought a couple of years ago.  I bought a pair that were my exact size except that they seemed to fit my foot perfectly.  I hate it when sandals fit perfectly without having at least a 1/4 or 1/2 inch extra.  Unfortunately Nike didn't have 1/2 sizes and I wasn't going to size up a whole size on the sandals.  So, when I decided to buy different pair for my recent spring break trip to Hawaii, I bought these.I love, love, LOVE these soooooo much.  In fact, they're 100x more comfortable than the comparable Nike sandals and they fit great (with that extra 1/2 inch) without me having to size up on the shoe.  I decided that I'll be retiring my comparable Nike sandals (that look almost like these except they're all black) and I'll be getting more colors of this brand for sure.  They cost less, are a high quality sandal, and are super comfortable.  If you're sitting on the fence between these and the Nike ones like these, GET THESE INSTEAD!  Nike's suck compared to these and they're more expensive too with few color selections.

Unfortunately I had to send this back.  The plate that you see affixed to the tree at the bottom comes separate when receiving it in the box.  I tried screwing it onto the bottom of the tree but either the screw was too large or the hole was stripped.  I couldn't get the plate affixed onto the bottom of the tree and therefore had to send it back.  I've since purchased a different earring tree because I didn't want a repeat of the same experience.  It's too bad because this is a nice-size tree that would have looked nice on my vanity.

I'm in love with these Method foaming hand wash soaps to where I'm replacing all my Soft Soap dispensers in the house.  The smells are awesome, no matter which one you pick but I like how clean my hands feel.  Other soaps leave a "sticky" residue, making me feel like I have to rinse my hands forever to get it all off.  Not these.  Great buy!

This is an amazing bargain for all these sponges.  I get so sick of getting ripped off on sponges, paying a fortune for only 1 or 2 in a package.  This is the first time I've seen these many sponges for such a small price!  I love the texture of these, as they make applying liquid or whipped foundations a breeze without "dragging" on the face like some latex sponges will do.  Another reviewer said these are small.  I disagree.  How large does a sponge have to be to apply foundation without it being awkward or too big?  These are the perfect size without being too big or too small.  You really can't go wrong with this purchase.

Really nice.  I used this to put something on top of my kitchen cabinets since it was barren and plain up there.  This ivy looks really nice and adds a lot to the kitchen without looking gaudy or lame.  However, there is a strong smell when you first open up the bags.  (I received 4 bags.  Each bag contains 72 feet, I imagine.  And then in each bag, 2 strands are tied together.  Therefore, each strand is actually only 36 feet long.)  It smells like bacon or something...but it airs out after a day or so.  Probably contains some heavy cancer-causing chemicals that don't legally have to be disclosed due to this product coming from China.  And it did take about 2 to 3 weeks to receive so if you're in a hurry, you're not going to get it in a realistic time frame.

These really last a long time and I love that they have the glass protector over the top unlike other models.  I bought the Triangle bulbs and was disappointed that they didn't have the glass cover of top which is why I went through an entire 10-pack within only weeks of getting them.  These last a long time, several months.  And these lights are still on a darker schedule meaning that they are on about 12 hours a day (from 6pm to 6am).  I'm sure that when I change my timers to 8 hours a day, these will last even longer.  Great buy.  Can't go wrong with these!

My daughter loves this backpack.  Decent quality.  I can understand why people think it's small.  It's mostly for kids in early grade school years.  Probably won't work for someone in junior high or high school since it won't fit larger books or 3-ring binders.  My daughter is in the 1st grade so it works fine for her.  Great buy!
This is stunning.  The picture doesn't do it justice.  It's sparkly and very pretty looking.  It's larger than I expected.  Thanks a lot.

Years ago I paid for this joker's video set which ran about $500 at the time.  I followed everything he advised and ended up losing thousands of dollars.  First of all, he suggests that you have customers call you on a toll-free number that you have on the postcard.  Then you have people listed to some 2 minute sales pitch.  At the end of the sales pitch, customers are supposed to fork over their credit card info and then end up on some monthly payment plan for whatever home-business system or health supplement you're selling to people.  I wanted to test out whether this all worked or not and ended up losing just under $10,000.I actually do make money using postcards but it's not AT ALL how this joker suggests to do it.  First of all, why the toll-free number?  They are EXPENSIVE and a lot of people just don't want to call a number.  They'd rather look at a website.  So, I send out postcards with a website address and NOT with a phone number.  Then your website does all the work, takes the order, and allows for your customer to download a virtual product (of course, you have to ship a product if you're selling health supplements or something shippable).  If you do it this guy's way, you have to pay for a toll-free number, pay for a special type of voice mail that's attached to a live order-taking service (which is VERY EXPENSIVE) and then manually input the credit card orders into the system (requiring MORE admin work) or have the order taking service do it for you, requiring an extra fee.  His way: EXPENSIVE and OUTDATED.I like reading other reviews because it's clear that they just read this hack's book but never actually put any time, effort or cash into their postcard enterprise otherwise, like me, they'd quickly realize that this guy's stuff MAY have worked 20 years ago before the Internet became hot and heavy but it's just not realistic to do it his way now.  Pass on this book.  I recommend The Ultimate Postcard Marketing Success Manual: Increase Sales & Boost Branding - All for the Price of a Stamp! instead.
