These pillows totally suck.  I'm used to sleeping on a Tempurpedic pillow but I have had insomnia lately so I figured I'd try these.  I ordered directly off the infomercial on the MyPillow website.First of all, unlike what they claim, these pillows DO GET HOT!  Yes, they get hot.  No, they DO NOT stay cool.  NOT BY A LONG SHOT!  I can't stand sleeping on a hot pillow, especially one that seems to get HOTTER than other pillows I've had.  Yes, it cools off quickly when you get up, use the restroom, and come back but...who wants to do that every 30 minutes?  I found myself having to flip the pillow all night because of this.Second, these pillows have some kind of foam cubes or chunks in them.  You can feel them.  They should have ground them down further and not kept them in such a large size.  This makes the pillow uncomfortable, cumbersome, and hard to sleep on.  The foam itself is a medium-density.  Not soft and not super hard.  But not comfortable either.Third, yes, you DO have to fluff this pillow CONSTANTLY in order for your head to not "sink in" like it would in a feather down pillow.  It actually reminded me of a down pillow because it kept sinking in the middle, pushing all the foam pieces out to the sides.  I kept having to fluff it up ALL NIGHT LONG.  I personally can't deal with feather down pillows BECAUSE they part in the middle and because of those pokey feathers.  I've tried down alternatives which have helped alleviate the feather "poke" problem but I still can't deal with having to fluff a pillow all night or sleeping in a "crater."  And this is exactly what I had to do with these MyPillows...fluff them ALL NIGHT.I'll be going back to my Tempurpedic pillows and these will be getting shipped back as soon as I submit this review.  Total disappointment.  Don't even think about buying these piece of crap pillows.

I got this to help digging into a clay/rocky hillside. It worked great with my demolition hammer, but will not cut through any root larger than 1/2" so that made it somewhat inconvenient. Overall happy with it as it has saved me lots of digging time.
I couldn't fine this size at the local store so I ordered if from Amazon. Works just fine, as expected.

It is hard to image all these great works of art history residing in one place. It makes you wonder what is was like to wander the halls and passageways of the house gazing as these masterpieces. No collection such as this could likely ever be accumulated again outside of a museum so to go through the pages of the book seeing all the different works of art is a feast for the eyes. The quality of the images is excellent and the book is quite extensive in both its photography and its history of the works. I don't think I would ever be able to find the time to read all the text that goes along with the artworks but just flipping through the book is a pleasure in itself. Would recommend for the art history fan.

Interesting book on a very curious subject. The concept of hiring someone to live you your garden, in a hovel of a hut or cave, remain unclean and unshaven for years on end, is certainly a things of the past. It is neat to read about these niche subjects of the great landscape gardens in history. The author lays out this history of the hermit and ultimately his demise quite well in the book. I don't imagine there are many other sources of info on the subject that you will find that aren't referenced here in some way. I would recommend for a garden/history enthusiast.
Thicker sock than other brands but somewhat tighter also. Would not recommend for people with wide feet. Mine are pretty normal width but these are quite snug. The length is fine.
Great for uniform shirts. much better than the style that clips to the top of your socks. Highly recommend.

The book is good for a quick browsing. The first section gives an intro to all the various garden buildings types that came to be in the lands of the large country houses. The remainder of the book covers individual buildings and structures, most have 1 photo and a short paragraph of text, so you don't really get much info on their history. More photos would have been nice. Wouldn't recommend it as a purchase, so find it in a library if you can.

Love it, love it, love it. My 3 year old can not get enough of this. I mounted it on the front of his push bike and the kid is on cloud 9. Super loud siren sounds, like ridiculously loud so put a piece of tape over the speaker part to muffle it a bit. And the blue led does look green, but kids wont care. Easy install, batteries have not run out after a few week and many hours of being on.

Great deal for a 10 pack of glasses. Between my son, his friends, the garage, the garden and the tool shed I always have a need for extra eye protection and these glasses work out great. Different colors to please all, fits both my 3 year old and my big head just fine.

As an avid gardener I enjoy identifying the creatures, big and small, that I see in the garden. I mainly used this guide to look at the photos and drawings to identify the bees I was seeing. It was easy to use and had lots of interesting information about each of the different species of bees described.

Just give it 2 days and you will be happy.When the ants come up, especially during the rainy season I just put one of these baits down along their path. They all congregate like crazy around it but then after a day and a half or two days they are all gone. It's not like a spray and does not work immediately but seems to get the whole nest.

I like this for use on dry hands and feet but probably wont buy it again because the ingredients all seem to be synthetic or chemical based. I would much prefer a more natural hand cream so I will keep looking. The product does work well though.
My 2 year old loves these. Quality organic ingredients and a great price when bought in bulk. The only downside is there is a lot of garbage created with all the individual packets.
Cheap batteries that worked for me. You can buy a 10 pack on Amazon for the price of 1 at the local grocery stores.
Small quiet fan for our guest room. Simple as that.

These work as well as any dishwasher tabs I have tried. I like other method products and will keep using these until something changes. No complaints. Good deal if you buy in bulk. We probably run one dish load per day and have not noticed any scratching or whitening like some types.
Great for Thomas fans, like my son, for some wintertime stories. These are the older Thomas programs that use the models not the newer animated videos.

I use these as uniform shirts and Amazon ended up having the best price for these. I have used many of these shirts for year and they have held up great. I would love if they offered slim or tall sizes in these as they can be a bit wide.
Lots of baking cups for a good price. Just what I needed. Worked great for a kids birthday. Many different styles as shown.
To say my 3 year old loves these is to understate the situation. The kid would wear these to bed if he could. Easy for him to pull on by himself, easy to clean if they get muddy too.

Worked better than I expected to make huge bubbles for a kids party. I made these the day before in a 5 gallon bucket like the directions said that had no problem making huge bubbles. The mix lasted several days and still worked out great. I made bubbles for 30+ minutes and still had more left over, so you won't run out quickly.
Works great, starts bubbling after about 2 minutes. My 3 year old is fascinated by them. Fairly short strand, maybe 6 feet or so. Seems like it will hold up for a few years.
Just what I needed for the guest room. Lightweight, easy to fold away, quite sturdy.

I needed a 20 amp cord for a concrete saw and found this to have the best reviews at the best price. Works great. As it is a heavy gauge cord, it does not loop easily but I assume overtime it will loosed up a bit.
Like most Thomas videos, my son loves these. Pretty standard episodes.

My 3 year old loved this, granted I did most of the construction. The only problem is the hitch between the trailer and the truck comes out really easily. I would have thought Lego could have used other pieces to make something that doesn't just pop right out if you move it a quarter inch. Otherwise it was easy to build and a fun toy

This worked perfectly for a kids birthday party, in combination with the beeboo bubble mix which I let sit overnight. It took just one or two practice bubbles to get the hang of it and then it was toddler pandemonium when the bubbles started. Looking forward to more kids parties with this.

Good indoor broom but I would have liked it all the same without the adjustable broom head as I haven't found much use for that feature. The bristles have much more spring than my last broom so as first I was flinging crap all over the floor but I have the hang of it now.
Quality jammies for kids. I have purchased several pairs of Leveret pajamas as they have the styles and shapes that my son like. Sizes are true and they hold up well.
My son loves it, of course. I sure wish it was easier to just get to the video selections instead of the endless preview and startup screen that you can't always fast forward through.
Lots of silly straws as expected. Btw, don't put them in the dishwasher as they don't hold up well. Great as party favors.

Worked out great for a 3 year old party. Best deal I found and the quality was good. Would buy again if the situation arises. Plus I appreciated the fact it was not like Fort Knox to get into this thing. The kids hit it a bunch without success but one good whack by an adult and it was raining candy.

Good general guide book to houses and structures owned by the National Trust. The big sites get up to 3 pages, the smaller ones get half a page. Some have no photos and others may have 2 or 3. Very interesting to flip through and get a short history of the houses and help guide to you the places you want to be explore more. A good companion book for the book, Gardens of the National Trust, which I found more interesting.

I thought the book was fine. As I read through it I just did not find all the stories very intetesting. It seemed like the beginning of the book was better put together with the choices of trees to focus on and toward the end the author was choosing less remarkable trees for the book to appear more well rounded. In any event it is a fun book to flip through but not one I would buy.

I had a chance to go through this book and it just did not appeal to me. Many type of gardens appeal to me from classical to country cottage, but most of the gardens in this book seemed to have no soul. I like a garden with a story and something I would enjoy walking through. Seemed like many of these gardens were just owned by wealthy people who did not have much of a connection to them. Too bad, as I would have expected better choice of gardens for this book.

Great book about a fascinating house. In the grand scheme of things there is nothing that makes the house special historically other than it is extremely large and built by a very rich family. Not many homes like this still survive in the Bay Area. It has the look of the grand houses of Europe but without much of a social history. The house sat vacant and was nearly torn down in the latter part of the 1900's but has been beautifully restored. It was pretty interesting to see all of the architectural plans that have been reproduced for this book.

An essential reference for anyone wanting in depth information about Ham House. Much more than photos and stories, much of the information presented is from years of research on all aspects of the house, the people who lived there and the history of contents of the house. It would be hard to sit down and read from front to back as this is more of a reference book in some aspects, but I found as I went through I would read certain sections and flip through the photos in others. A neat coffee table book, not sure I would drop $100 for it unless you are a collector or scholar.
My 2 year old loves this book, we read it nearly every day. I remember this from 30 years ago when I was a child too.

As a fan of English country houses and gardens I found this book to be a very enjoyable read. The author travels through several centuries of private houses that are palaces unto themselves. The history behind each house is long enough to be very interesting but well short of being long winded. I enjoyed all of the photos of the houses, many of which I had not heard of before despite being keen to the subject matter. Many of the photos show how truly amazing these houses were and still are, albeit all the photos are black and white. I would definitely recommend this book to anyone interested in architecture, design, or just a fan of great English houses. I enjoyed this book much more than many of the more recent books on the subject, even with the fancy new color photos.

Got this to check and reset my check engine light when comes on and off every now and then in my Chevy truck. Used it with the Torque app. Was pretty easy to get set up and check the codes and reset the light. Haven't gotten into all the other features with Torque but the unit itself works great.

So I just finished building the bed and it worked out pretty well. Even being very careful with all the directions it did not fit together perfectly, but I would call it a B+. Obviously, the reason you buy this set is to save the $1000 extra a pre-made bed would cost. Don't even attempt this unless you have all the tools called for because you have to make a lot of very precise cuts and drill holes. I used prefinished maple plywood and it turned out pretty good.

Not very useful to someone looking for building plans for coops. Only a few pages of color photos stuck at the end of the book. The different coops just have a few illustrations but no photos or plans. I ended up having better luck with internet searches.

It could have been better but it got the job done. I had three 4.5" holes to bore through 6" concrete foundations in order to install some PVC vent pipes, so this drill in combination with a MK diamond bit got it done. The "instructions" are useless, you are on your own. An email and call to the company were never returned for more info on set up, so don't expect additional help from them. Ideally you should install some anchor bolts and mount this in the drill spot so the base doesn't move which is safer and easier to get more downward force, but it can be used just by standing on it too because it is heavy. Only one speed and the bit can bind up if not perfectly straight, but even when the magic smokes comes out just turn it off and give her a minute to rest and it will work again. I used it for both wet and dry cuts and worked fine for both. For minimal (by comparison) cost, this is the best option I found when I just needed a few holes drilled.

While I was initially looking for a book more focused on designing gardens for chickens, I was still pleased with this book even though it ventured well into the topic of raising chickens. I already had a few books on raising chickens so while I still browsed through a lot of this book, much of the info was not new to me. I liked all the photos of the coops and small garden areas as they gave me lots of idea to go out an implement.

Read the book in about two hours as it is a fairly quick read. I skipped 6 or 7 of the sections that did not appeal to my interests but most of the other ones were both interesting and inspiring. Many of the were from folks local to me so that was neat. Nothing too in depth, each story gets 6-7 pages with plenty of photos. Chickens, bees, urban farms, rooftop gardens, mushrooms, aquaponics, permaculture and similar topics. Time to get out and do some more gardening.

Today is my first day wearing these and they are great. Fit true out of the box, easy on and off. Much more comfortable to walk in than my many other pairs of boots I have worn over the years. The cushioning is more than I expected and I am quite pleased. They appear to be very well constructed and should last me a while.

As an avid gardener I enjoyed this book as it touched on many aspects of vegetable gardening that appealed to me. It also ventured beyond into the bees, chickens, small livestock and other aspects of your own mini farm in your backyard. While some of the sections a fairly small, you can't expect it to be a jack of all trades. I took plenty of ideas from this book I plan on implementing in my own garden.

Bought this for my wife as she had wanted on for a while. I thought it was just a gimmicky blender until I tried it. Very easy to make fast drinks and the blender works amazingly well. All sorts of fruits, veggies and nuts will get ground up in just a few seconds. Clean up is easy too ask the blade contraption just pops right out, nothing else to clean up but the drinking cup.
Great dried fruit strips for on the go snacking with a good sour/tangy combination. My 2 year old loves these. Good value if bought with Subscribe and Save.

I like the idea and philosophy of permaculture as a practical gardening idea but not when it is presented in a preachy and very counter-culture type of way, but that's fine, different styles for different folks. The book itself is well put together, but I think most people who have read a few gardening books will already know most of what is in here.

These were easy enough to put on the bottles we bought last year.  They not only provide excellent grip for no slippage, but when they fall, they protect the bottle!  Real life situation, lol!.  I do not enjoy the hipster super bright colors at all.  I will experiment and spray paint one a beautiful metallic bronze and let you know how it worked.

Good arch support when I tried it on. I won't be able to wear these without a little tweaking because it rubbed the top of my toes raw. I only tried on one shoe.  :(  The shoe is not too tight, it's something sharp on the underside of the upper. I haven't investigated further, just tried it on, walked on the one shoe and took it off.  I'll update this later.
Ooh, this things is great! Not too stiff, but totally stiff enough to scrub stuff vigorously without losing bristles.
Great! We use these for both our Truth Cams and my digital camera.

SO happy to find this product for a sweet price! I cut them to fit our air conditioners - two little wall units and one behemoth of a portable.  The portable one offers precut filters for a price too high for me, so this is really a treat!  I cut what I need and then use my vacuum sealer to protect the rest. Honestly, it might be fine to use a large ziplock bag and squish the air out, but I love using the vacuum sealer  :D

What's not to like? They perform as intended, I use them not only for baking, but as bowls for small servings of stuff.  :)  Microwave safe, but I use these mainly in the regular oven.  I like them for puddings and ice cream, too.  :)

I like these very much. Sturdy, well made, no splintering or bending. Handy little design on the handle end deters slipping if you're poking into something pretty hard.  I'd buy them again in a heartbeat.z
Good stuff! I use it for all kinds of things as basecoat and sometimes instead of white paint itself. I love the consistency, not too thick, not too thin. Sounds corny, but works for me.

Ahh...super softness!  These are awesome for washes and covering large surface areas. They hold a lot of product/water.  HUGE difference from cheaper brushes. These are affordable, reusable and absolutely lovely to use  :D

These are great. Same old good, stout product.  I like the taller sides - less spillage.  Microwave safe, oven safe. I make individual Tamale Pie, Apple Pie, etc.  With the taller sides, I can use the same amount of filling as I do in wider, shallower version and when I put foil or plastic wrap (fridge) over the top, it doesn't touch the food itself. Yay!
I love using mason jars and the metal lids get rusty so quickly  :(  These are great!
Very useful size. I have two of these because I punch a lot for specific huge projects. I can use a die with multiple cuts, but for "fussy cutting" specific images, these are the way to go.

AWESOME!  I'll continue to buy these as long as the quality remains as spectacular as they are now!  DH likes them, I love them. Easy to clean, easy to dry, easy to iron, easy for him to look sharp at work!I buy them in different colors. I have backups in the closet in readiness for one gets worn our, torn or stained beyond repair.
These are great little flannels. Soft, small and useful. I don't have babies. I use them.You can fold in thirds and use as pantiliners.

I love the idea of using only 23 watts for a lightbulb, but there's now way the output looks like 100 watts to me. I just don't get it. How people can be satisfied replacing fabulous regular old lightbulb 100s for less light  :(

I know it's not good to be using these, but they're so good (other than the pesky killing-the-environment aspect) There's no freaking CFL bulb that comes close the light output of these no matter what's promised.  They do get hot, so I use them in cooler weather and switch to LED (CFL when I have to)  in hot weather. No kidding. The temperature output makes that much of an impact on my physical comfort.
These things are great! I use them for hanging crafty things to dry. I use a tension shower rod together with these and it's fantastically useful.
I wish everyone would use one of these.  They should be mandatory to use in every freaking office kitchen.Well made, sturdy, nothing cheapo about these simple little bits of brilliance.
I love it because I can use it during power outages. Grrr the outages that happen far too often for my comfort.
SO useful! I keep one in my office-to-go kit. If they could make a battery operated one this small, I'd buy it, but for now, my wrist and fingers can handle this guy just fine.
Mistakes, me? Never.  That's why I go through so many of these *cough* erasers.I make no mistakes. Ever.
These little workhorses are indispensable.  :D  I know there are other styles of staple removes out there, but this one beats the others.  Fits perfectly in my little office-to-go kit.
Memories....  Some aspects of school I miss and this is one of them.Can't go wrong with a Ticonderoga pencil. No. 1 in this case  :)  I like the softer leads for some things.

Man, I love this stuff and was clamhappy to see it in this huge bottle for a not-so-huge price.There are some projects that vinegar just doesn't work well enough on. Surprising, I know, but it's true.
Mey, they're okay for now. The quality of the silicone is such that it gets old and tacky/sticky quite quickly and it has nothing to do with use or washing.
It's a cutie, but it does the job AND it fits into my traveling office kit!  :D  Wheee!

Pretty pretty.  :)  I got this to go alone with a place setting of Fiestaware I gave as a gift. This is a slightly different color than the set, but it doesn't matter, it coordinates beautifully.  Recipient was delighted!Sturdy enough for his chile verde!

Good stuff Maynard.  I don't know why it's so difficult finding Orange Blossom Honey, and I was happy to find it here.The Clover I find everywhere is kind of an unpleasant musky flavor to me  :(  YAY or Orange Blossoms!It's so tasty, too!

This stuff is pretty neat. It's thicker and better quality than the usual strips on a roll. Nothing wrong with those, but this is very useful quality crafting.  I do wish there was a larger variety of colors, but with the white or cream, we can add paint and ink for some very kewl effects.
It is what it is and it's holding up just fine.  :DI use it to add a border on clothing that's too short. I wish they made a larger variety of colors, though.

Oh, my gosh - this thing is spectacular! Who knew I'd use that word to describe a utilitarian laundry drying rack?  DH said this item should win a design award for it's brilliance AND soundness.  There is nothing weak or wobbly about this.  It's incredibly sturdy for being so lightweight.  We have an electric dryer that's on casters. It was expensive, holds a third of wash load at a time, and takes so long to dry, but it's the only thing we could use in our rental and it had to move to be positioned in an outside doorway to vent outside. This rack holds an entire load of DH's size 2XLT shirts, socks and undies with room to spare due to the horizontal rack within the A-frame.  FREAKING AWESOME!  I just came back to leave my review and to buy a second rack. I enjoy doing laundry (yeah, I do!) and with a second rack, I can wash two loads back-to-back and have both loads dry outside. If I had more outdoor space, I'd buy a third.  It's SO lightweight and convenient, I just close it up and bring it back inside when done. There's is nothing cumbersome or difficult about using this. It's completely assembled; just remove it from the box and off you go. Super easy to set up and to close up and put away.The crossbars are tubes (not wires) and don't take regular clothespins, but you won't need clothespins as you drape the item over the bar itself.  If I have a smaller load, I drape across two more more bars for more airflow and a faster dry time.  Yesterday, I draped my quilted twin mattress protector over the entire thing with the "wings" out straight - boom!  The cover doesn't dry evenly in our little dryer even with multiple stops mid-cycle to rearrange it several times.  Absolutely no problem draping this or a bedspread or sheets over this.  If the item is longer, you can adjust the wings at a higher angle to prevent touching the ground.BOTTOM LINE: Buying another one!

I like and expect things to work as advertised. It doesn't even fit like the picture shows.I could like this if it fit.  The straps aren't long enough to deposit the velco on the sides of the fan - it would have to curve around onto the grate edge and that's not practical since it would be permanently glueing the grate to the frame and I'd not be able to remove the grating for cleaning like I do.  I'll be returning this.  :(ETA: NO WAY does this fit and you certainly won't be placing the receptor velcro where it's shown in the picture.  It should be just a shade larger towards each corner and the straps should definitely be longer. I'd keep this IF the straps were long enough to attach this, I'd live with some fan not being filtered, but at least it would mostly work.This is the fan I bought to put this on:  Lasko #3723 20-Inch Premium Box Fan 3-SPEED

They're definitely heavy duty and will staple a lot of pages together. My main problem is that after my huge project is finished, I won't have enough pages to staple together because these legs are very long. AWESOME for large projects!I bought these to use with Heavy-Duty Stapler - 100-Sheet Capacity and I'm delighted  :D
So cute! I'm having fun looking through this, but having a hard time trying to decide which project to do first!
Yep. They're good, strong and opaque for that garbage you don't want anybody to see  :D
Goooooood Stuff!  I use this for lots of applications. I prefer a matte finish on most of my projects, more than I use gloss, but the gloss is great, too.
Pretty pretty. DH very happy. I bought the single setting to see how he'd like it, before I got an entire set.
Man, I love a good, sharp knife!  This size is great for mincing garlic  and peeling apples.
Yeah, I own it. I use these. They work and they're not too bulky at all!
I LOVE having this super short cord!  Really useful for me, I've been looking for years for any cord shorter than 3 feet.
So far, so good!  Fun to use.

Variety pack of nail files. Mostly marked variety of: 1 for Normal nails, 1 for Fragile nails, 2 files Medium on one side, Fine on the other, 1 file unmarked grit, but says Elegant Emery Board/Colorful Nail File.Two of the files came with both ends cut off.  Odd, but I believe these are "seconds" where damaged goods are sold and bought more cheaply than usual, then resold. The ends were probably damaged, cut off and sold here.I wouldn't do this again, I'll just go back to Target for better price and first quality.

These just don't close well enough to actually grab hair to tweeze  :(  The metal is too flexible.  The flexibility makes it easy to pinch closed, but not firm enough to grasp hair, fine or coarse. I don't know if the tips are sharp enough or calibrated or if it's overall design.I feel like picky Goldilocks because some other tweezers can be too stiff and difficult to pinch closed.It's too bad because they do come with a nice little case for them and they're packaged with an offer to enter and win $50 and a 15% coupon - that I didn't do of course. It took very little time to see that these just don't work.  It may be that I got a bad pair or a cheap knock off, I don't know.  It's a cute presentation and I do love things like this, but only if the main purchase does what's supposed to.I don't mind paying $12 for tweezers and I'd rather have $12 worth of tool, than carrying case I wouldn't use because they go straight into my makeup bag.  I may go back to my old standby Revlon slant tips for $4 and pay for sharpening.  I just love the convenience of Amazon quick shipping, so I ordered these.I'm going to initiate a return as soon as I submit this review.  I will come back and update.

I loved this! I watched the entire 13 episodes back to back over two days and was so disappointed there were no more  :(  This was entertaining, delightful, the characters very distinct, likeable and unlikeable. Human beings. I thought it was a well-rounded storyline.Waaaah....I want more!  The main actress was good enough to prompt me to look for more with her acting.  :)

The only reason I sat through the whole thing was because of my crush on Ciaran Hinds  :)  This movie must have been heavily edited because it seemed as though there were numerous chunks missing. Distinct lack of continuity and in this case, nothing made sense. Ridiculous. No resolution regarding dreams, nightmares, suicide, deaths, rotting people appearing out of nowhere for no reason. I love a good horror movie, drama, psychological drama, or paranormal, but this was trying to be too many things at once and succeeding at nothing. Not a damn thing.It's a shame, CH is wonderful, the scenery and photography really well done, but nothing else.Bad movie. Bad, bad movie.

Love these cookies because they're not too sweet.  I like to dunk them in coffee  :D  Yum.I came back to order more, but found the price has just about tripled from 3.99 on July 14, to 9.99 today.Pass. I'll go back to buying at our local co-op.
Definitely not long on the leg as shown in the picture!  :(
I like it - it's bright like an incandescent but uses MUCH LESS electricity.Watch out, it gets very hot.
I like them fine. They are NOT as tall as shown on the model. Even taking account for body types, they just don't cover that much tummy as shown in the picture.  They do ride up.
I love it - super heavy duty is excellent for stapling together lots of sheets of paper and/or cardstock.

Not crazy about this brush. Bristles are too stiff, I could scrub the shower stall with them  :(  I don't like the super soft brushes because they feel like they don't do anything. I'd like something either in-between the normally too soft brushes and this too stiff brush for my body except it's okay for my feet. A little uncomfortable, but doable.One thing I don't like about this hard brush is that I can't get shower gel/ liquid soap to cling to the bristles to wash my back :(  or my feet!Although I did read the description of the brush being 14", it turns out to be too short for me.  That's not a complaint about this item because I knew the length when I bought it, I'm just mentioning it.  I'm 5' 8" and I need a longer handle to reach the middle of my back.This

So far, it's okay.  Super noisy high shrill sound, I'm considering ear plugs, seriously.  The concept is great - think Dustbuster on a stick with a mouth attachment for "rolling" across carpet.  The attached roller/mouthpiece gives the impression that the suction part is wide, but it's still the same little 3" or so opening.  The suction is okay, but it's basically a $50 dealy. I have to clear the filter every few minutes.  It's a bagless, and the filter has a velcroed wraparound paper filter surrounding it. That gets blocked pretty quickly.It's extremely lightweight, I laughed the first time I picked it up.  The on/off switch is on the vacuum part itself, none on the stick, but no problem.  It comes with a couple of attachments and an extra filter!Very handy for a quick grab, but for  *real* vacuuming, I'll continue to use my fabulous monster vacuum.
Timeless for the high school labels and relationships.  I'm almost 60 and I enjoyed watching it again.

Sharp little scanner for the price!  I don't use it for graphics, just office stuff and it's great!Updated: I did use it for some graphics and photos to experiment. Meh, but I never expected this to be for graphic design. Get a grip peeps, it's a cheapy scanner and it's fabulous for documents, but get a real grown up scanner if you want good quality graphics and photographs. I'll continue on with my big Epson scanner for designing.I love that there's no external power supply; one less cord to keep track of. This is lightweight so I take it with me when traveling.Super easy set up, I began scanning within minutes of plugging it into my Macbook - piece o' cake.

These work better for me than the stoppers that are supposed to fit snugly in the drain opening.The weight of the water keeps them secure and watertight.  I keep a finger on it until enough water fills up.

They're pretty thin  - ew.  I got them for FIL because he's old-school and they match his boxers - no kidding!  I'm going to use these for some sort of craft project and keep looking for a hardier handkerchief for him to blow his nose.I wish he'd use tissue like everybody else.
Good as always.

I liked it at first, I use it about three times weekly (use loofa-on-a-stick four days) and this unraveled after two months.  I tried fixing it using dental floss and hot glue, but I don't have the patience. It's been sitting in the REPAIR box at home since April.

THIS IS AWESOME!  I bought this for the sun; I live in very hot climate and sometimes it's too hot or bright to walk.THIS IS AWESOME!  I was hesitant to order another umbrella since I have more than one already, but I wanted a pretty, summery design instead of my usual basic black.  The black attracts and holds the heat, so that's no good on a hot, sunny day.THIS IS AWESOME! This umbrella is lighter weight fabric, but also the long stem with traditional curved handle and workings are lighter than the regular umbrellas, but sturdy for use.  I prefer a longer handle like this one, my arm gets tired and my hand gets cramped holding onto those short stemmed straight handles.  This Is Good Stuff here!  :DBottom line:  I'm buying another one in a different design - yippee!

Wow!  I love these - heavyweight, really soft and virtually no shrinkage - amazing!  I bought three for me even though I'm a woman, because I like the longer body of the Tall sizes that women's T-s don't offer.  I bought two different sizes, one to formfit my body and a larger size so that I can sew the bottom of the bigger one (gathered slightly) to the bodice of the formfitting one. Wonderful and feminine looking top.  :DBOTTOM LINE:  I'll be buying some more soon.  AND my DH loves his, too  :D

These are a lot like any other gummy vitamin. They taste great, and have a nice texture. The outside is coated with a sort of granulated sugar, so they don't stick together in the bottle, or leave the oil on your hands that lots of others do. The texture is more like a Dots candy, or the inside of a jelly bean than a gummy bear. I really liked them, and will likely be ordering more.

Overall, these are pretty nice shoes. They look good, and are reasonably comfortable for heavy boots. I only have a few small complaints. The shoes themselves run very large. I ordered two sizes smaller than I typically wear and I was still swimming in them. They also have a sort of odd foot shape. the sides of the shoe fit well, while there was still another two or three sizes worth of extra length. If you have longer thinner feet, these would probably fit you really well. Lastly, the upper portion of the boot is made from thinner leather than I would have expected. My guess is that it is for appearance, since it makes the boots look a little more worn in once they are tied down tight, but I'm not 100% sure what it would do to durability. Ultimately, the boots just weren't going to fit my foot shape, so I ended up returning them, but for the right person, they'd be very nice.

This is one of the better case humidifiers I've purchased. Thanks to the gel inside the tube, I'm confident that even if there were a leak, liquid wouldn't end up dripping on my bagpipes. The magnetic clips work well, and I trust them to keep the humidifier in place. It also seems to provide liquid at a pretty consistent rate, slightly faster than my other humidifiers, so if you are looking to up humidity, I think this is a great place to start.

I enjoy 5-HTP as a product in general, but I didn't really love these. They're on the chalky side, sort of like a softer tums. If you're looking for a dissolving tablet, these are probably as good as any others out there, but just not for me. Also, more than a few broke inside the bottle, so I think I lost a few tablets in transit. Not a huge deal, but it'd be cool to avoid it.
It fit perfectly, and was attractive inasmuch as a screw on cover can be i.e. no scratches, good polish.  Assuming this is the part you are looking for, it'll do it's job just fine.

Like a lot of other reviewers have pointed out, this perch isn't actual pumice stone, but plastic with a gritty coating (which could be made from pumice for all I know). That being said, for the price I like it. It seems sturdy and is reasonably attractive for the money. I do think it will accomplish its intended purpose of exercising my budgies' feet and wearing his nails down a bit. If the title said "Sand-coated plastic perch," this would be a five star item. As is, I'm taking one star off for the lack of clarity.

My little budgie loved it. I don't know how much use a larger bird would get out of it, but he's slowly taken the mat apart fiber by fiber, and it's time to order a replacement. None of the chain links actually open, which is a shame since it would be nice to be able to reattached them as the mat was whittled away. A great toy for the money, and likely an item I'll be buying every couple of months for the foreseeable future.

The budgie seems to like it, which is my major requirement in terms of birdseed. I can't really speak to whether a mostly millet food provides proper nutrition, but two bags in he seems to be just as healthy as ever (not exactly scientific, I know). I'll almost certainly be buying more.

These are a lot like most gummy vitamins. The texture is more like a Dots candy than a gummy bear, inasmuch as it matters. Assuming they contain what they claim, they seem to be one of the better Biotin deals on Amazon.

These picks look good, and while the hole in the center doesn't really seem to help me personally, others might really like it. My issue with them is that they are made of a very stiff/smooth plastic. I think it's delrin, but since I don't see that confirmed in the description, it's just my guess. The bee graphic (which is only on one side) is the only place that seems to grip for me. If you held your picks a little tighter than I do, so you could make more use of the hole in the middle, these might work really well. They just aren't for me. The delrin (assuming I'm right about that) is also much stiffer than a normal pick, so while these pics are .80 mil, they feel more like 1.00 or so. It's subtle, and probably not worth griping about, but they do feel different from typical picks.

In terms of their use as a pick, these are pretty close to any others, with the exception of the graphic, which I really like. Just for a reference he "mediums," seem to be somewhere around .80 mil.  I don't know if it's obvious in the pics, but the celluloid is more opaque than it is see through. I'll be grabbing more.

For the most part, these picks are just like any other standard celluloid picks, so there isn't really any point going into anything except for the star shaped punch out in the middle of the pick that is supposed to give you a better grip.I think the concept is probably sound, create a bit of skin to skin contact in the middle that keeps the pick from sliding around, make the edges of the hole jagged so it can't twist, and you'll end up with a better grip on your pick. The problem is that I don't grip the pick nearly hard enough to make the hole in the middle work for me. When I'm holding the pick naturally, my skin doesn't press into the cutout, so it slides around just as easily, if not more so than the rest of the pick. This might not be true of everyone. If you grip your picks significantly harder than I do (I have no idea where I am on the gripping spectrum, so I couldn't really tell you if I'm closer to tight or loose, though I suspect I'd be on the looser grip end) this might work great for you, so they are probably worth a try. For my money, they aren't really any different than a standard celluloid pick. If they were both sitting at my local music store counter, I'd literally just buy whichever was cheaper.Also, this doesn't really have anything to do with the product itself, but I received half .71 mil and half a lighter gauge. I don't have any handy, but I know it was less than .50 That's on the seller, not the product, but you might end up with an assortment, so just be aware of that.

I have a couple of these Biltwell shields, two tinted ones and a clear one for night riding, but I picked up this one because amber tint is legal after dark in my state (Colorado), and I was sick of switching back and forth.They all fit a standard five button really well (a Bell three quarter in my case), and are all reasonably scratch resistant. They let enough air through to keep from fogging without vibrating or getting that great wind tunnel sound. They're also easy to attach, less than ten seconds at most.As far as the nighttime riding is concerned, which is likely why you are looking at an amber shield, I find that this one works very well. Blocking out the harsher light does sort of mellow the glare at night and makes the shield very reasonable to ride with after dark. I see the most benefit in the twilight hours, where it gives things a sort of greenishy almost "tornado weather" appearance and really seems to up the visibility factor.Over all, I'd recommend any of the Biltwell shields. They are tough, easy to install, and very reasonably priced. And, I do think this amber is great for nighttime riding. If you are looking for this type of shield, this is definitely the one to get.

These earplugs are great, and I wholly recommend them.I'm just providing a few pros and cons for those who want them.Pros:- Solid volume reduction. Ultimately, that is what earplugs are meant to do, and these do it well. There is a tradeoff for the higher sound quality, and these don't reduce volume as much as the foam or wax ones, but the sound quality is much better. I think the balance is a good one for musicians or people who like to be up close at concerts.- Great sound quality. Things don't sound muffled, and I feel like I'm getting a much truer sense of the sound I'm producing with these than with the foam or wax ones.- The stem makes them less finicky to get seated properly in your ear. It's not a big deal, but I was surprised how nice having the little stem there is. With the foam ones, you have to compress and get them in place, then if they aren't in the right spot, you have to completely reinsert it again.- The little carry case is nice. It's not a big deal, but it's a kind of soft plastic, so much less annoying to have in my pocket if I'm out and I don't have a good place to put it.Cons:- Less sound reduction than foam or wax. If you need to shut down volume at the firing range, these aren't for you. They do most of what I need when I'm playing my bagpipes, but for anything louder, they really wouldn't work well.- The rubber has a little bit of memory. When I first got them, they were sort of smashed flat, and it's taking a little while for the rubber to spring back. It still makes a good seal with my ear, but I think it might be just a little harder to get seated.- I have bigger ear canals, and the tapered shape means that these insert farther than I'm in love with. I sort of wish there was a way to remove the smallest little dome. I got used to it fast, but it's annoying.- The little stem can get knocked around. It only happened once when I was moving my pipes on my shoulder, but it's not a pleasant sensation.- There are much much more expensive options, but there are also foam plugs that are like ten sets for three dollars, so I'm counting the price as kind of a con. You have to really want the higher fidelity, otherwise spending anything over a quarter on a pair of earplugs is pretty unnecessary.I still wear my foam plugs if I'm sleeping or using a saw or something, but for playing or listening to music, these are definitely the way to go. I will be buying more if I ever lose or need to replace these.

Walsh practice chanter reeds are my personal favorites. When I'm on my practice chanter, I'm working on fingerings, not lung strength, so I like that they don't seem to take nearly as much air pressure to get a sound out of, and seem to be very forgiving when you aren't focused on your breath. They seem to have a long life, and are easily adjusted with a piece of sandpaper, if need be. At the time of this review, this is the best price on Amazon for Walsh Standard Practice Chanter Reeds, and I definitely recommend them.Also, it's a silly thing, but the little plastic case is sort of nice. I have a bad habit of mistreating my practice chanter, and regularly have the reeds knocking around loose in the bag. I probably should have grabbed a plastic box like this years ago, but didn't. Not a reason to buy the reeds in and of itself, but a nice little bonus.

Like the title says, I think this is great shave soap. I get a very close shave, on par with any others I have tried, and I personally like the scent. To me, it smells more like chai tea than it does like bay rum, but it's not far enough off to be surprising when you first get it. I'll be getting more when I run out.That being said, I have two issues. First, it seems to be a little more finicky to lather than other soaps. It's fine, but it doesn't seem to get quite as thick as others, and takes longer to get to a good consistency. It's not a real issue, though I do use a cup. I don't know if it's going to be your best option if you like to do the lathering on your face. Second, it seems to dry out extremely fast. You need to apply the soap to your face, then immediately reach for the blade. If you wait a minute or so, it will already be starting to thicken back up. It's plenty of time to get a good clean shave, but you just can't goof around while it is on your face.Both issues seem to happen no matter how dry or wet I try to make the lather, and no matter how long I use the brush, but if you disagree and feel like it's a mistake I'm making, please do let me know. I'd hate to take off a star unfairly.

I'm not sure what this item was actually supposed to be. There is some sort of mounting hole in the bottom, and the shape reminds me more of a peg you might hang something off of than a true slide-bar shape. I still like it though. It's more than heavy enough to serve it's purpose, feels good in the hand, and so far the finish seems to be staying in place. Considering it was a third the cost of something made by Dunlop or Fender, I would highly recommend giving this a try first.One caveat. The thing is heavier than a lot of similar items I've used. If you aren't using it on a dedicated instrument, with a higher action, I might go with something a little lighter.

Like the title says, I love this little thing for the price. I'm just providing a few quick pieces of info.- As others have said, the item wouldn't trick you into believing it's a key. It's thicker than a normal key, and even when closed, the blade is clearly visible. If your keys were sitting on the table, I doubt someone would pick out that there was a knife on your keychain, but if someone takes the time to look, it's very clear that this isn't a key.- The mechanism is smooth for an eight dollar knife, but it's an eight dollar knife. Temper your expectations on that one. It feels like a lot of other cheap blades in that respect, not scratchy, but not buttery smooth like something pricey- This seems solidly built. I won't be prying with it any time soon, but it locks in place and i'm comfortable using it to open packages or cut cord, it's intended purposes for me.- All and all, I'd pick it up again. I have no real complaints, and it serves it's purpose, riding around unobtrusively on my keychain.

These fit great, and so far they are holding up quite nicely. If I had to come up with one criticism, I think the sleeves are a little short. Depending on whether you are wearing these as an undershirt or a normal shirt, that could be considered a positive or a negative, but if you want something with a longer/looser sleeve, grab the hanes. Otherwise, I couldn't recommend these more highly.

I couldn't decide what review to give this brush. So far, it's been great. It has a soft feel, lathers the soap quickly, and even though it's lost a hair or two, it's nothing extreme. My only complaint is that the one I received was black. I probably still would have ordered had I known that. The price was great and it gets great reviews, but I don't like receiving items that are different from what I ordered. On quality alone, I highly recommend this brush, but just be aware, you might end up with a black one.

Like the title says, I'm a new runner. I did plenty of running for football in high school and whatnot, but as far as just taking off to run a few miles, I'm very new. The being said, here's a few impressions I've had so far.These are impressively light. I imagine they are on par with most running shoes, but the last pair of shoes I ran in were cleats, so maybe I'm easily impressed.So far, they seem very comfortable. There are no seams in uncomfortable places, and the top material is flexible enough to allow for a good fit.They breathe very well. At the end of five miles, they are still dry and comfortable.The tread is solid. I live in Colorado, and almost certainly will be running in these when there are small patches of ice out, and I'm not worried.They seem to position you very close to the ground. I'm enjoying that feel. My normal shoes feel like platforms now.I personally like the position at which these allow my foot to strike the ground. I gather that is very specific to the gait and the foot, but I have higher arches, and tend to strike more towards the front of my foot. I imagine similar people would find these comfortable.All told, I'd buy these shoes again. They have been a great option for me getting started with running, and I'm excited to keep going.If you're a first timer with questions for another newb, feel free to ask and I'll try to answer.

I'm reviewing these right after receiving them, so I can't speak to any kind of longevity. I'll update my review if they fall apart early. If I haven't updated, you can assume that these are still going strong, or lasted as long as the shoes.I've noticed a few reviewers saying that these were difficult to get on without instructions. I have to say that wasn't my experience. You simply press the button then slide the laces through. It's a tight fit, and it did take a little bit of wiggling and finessing to get the laces through, but I didn't find them confusing or complicated.They seem sturdy. This is day one, but I'm happy with the weight and feel of the laces themselvesI got the package with the five different colors, and I don't think they are quite as bright as in the pictures. It's a tiny difference. I honestly might well be imagining it, but just so know.I put them in three different pairs of shoes, and they fit easily in every pair. The aglet is the same size as all the original shoelaces, so I can't see why they wouldn't work on any pair of shoes you own.When I tied off the laces and trimmed the excess, there was a bit of fluff from the sheath portion of the laces. Pro tip: a little heat from a lighter will shrink that fluff right up if it bothers you. Just be sure not to get too close; you could damage the elastic.The moose isn't as noticeable as it seems in the pictures. It may be stupid, but I don't like the moose. I was pleased to see it's not something you would notice if it wasn't pointed out.Be careful to get the shoelaces entirely in place before trimming the excess lace. Once the aglets are gone, it would be almost impossible to get these back through the push-button mechanism.

Overall, I like this shavette. Most of the attributes are just as easily pros as cons depending on your preference, so the list below is more just FYI than anything else.Pros:- The size is pretty comfortable. It's smaller than my other one, but not enough so as to cause trouble. It will accept both the shorter and longer blades- The system for holding the blade in place is pretty solid. I'm confident the blade won't shift or slide, and it's very easy to clean.- The lighter feel is a mixed blessing. On the plus side, it's easier to feel which areas are stubble free. There is sort of a . . . gritty sensation in the hand holding the shavette when it moves over an area that isn't completely smooth. It's hard to describe, but it's something that has been very helpful.- The plastic piece that holds the blade in place has a tiny protrusion that covers the corner of the blade. In my experience 95% of my nicks come from the corner of the blade scraping me, and that'd be almost impossible with this shavette. In my opinion, it's worth the price of the shavette alone to fix that problem, but if that doesn't happen to you, it's not going to be of major benefit.Cons:- The flip side of the lighter weight is that it doesn't have quite as solid a feel as some of the other shavettes out there. It's nothing horrible, but I could see someone complaining that it didn't have the premium sensation that some of the heavier ones had.- I could see someone not liking the smaller size. It doesn't bug me, but it would be understandable if it did.- The system that holds the blade in place, while really easy to clean, is a tiny bit harder to seat the blade into. It's a small thing, and only took a day or two of getting used to, but I thought I'd mention it.- If I were actually designing my own razor with the people from Dovo, I might let the blade hang out just a hair more. I'm probably just used to a little more blade hanging out because that is the way my last one was. It's by no means hard to work with.I'd definitely pick up this shavette again, but a ton of personal preference is going to play into your opinion on it. From a "just the facts" perspective, it seems well made and does a fine job holding a razor for a shave, which is it's real purpose.

These gloves are great in lots of ways. The pair I got seemed solidly built and were comfortable. The style is a tiny bit flashy, but it's nothing unforgivable. They aren't spectacularly warm, but I'd say for running around town on cold windy days they'll be just fine. I wouldn't use them as my only gloves in sub zero weather, or if I were headed out to shovel the walk, but for most days they should be great. They also fit mostly as I expected. Maybe the tiniest bit on the small side, but just barely.My issue with the gloves is that they didn't work for me. I was able to get my phone to broadly respond to them, but they didn't register lots of taps or almost any precision movements.I don't think it's entirely the fault of the gloves. I use one of the glass screen cover on my phone and I suspect that is the culprit. At dinner with some friends, we tried it with about a half dozen phones, and it worked just fine with everyone else's (both with no screen covers, and with the plastic variety). Since mine was the only one with that specific kind of screen cover, I'm thinking that's probably the issue.It's totally understandable that the gloves might not work great with every screen cover, but if that is the case, I'd really like to see it added to the description. These gloves would get five stars with any of my friends phones, or if the potential issue had been listed somewhere in the description. (Please correct me if anyone sees that listed somewhere in the description, I don't want to review down a product unfairly).If you aren't using a glass screen protector, I'd say give these gloves a try. For ten bucks you can easily pass them along to someone else if they don't feel responsive enough for you.

I have a newfoundland, and being built for the cold weather he tends to get cracked and chapped areas on his nose and paws during the summer. Using Bag Balm on his paws and nose during the warm months completely clears it up. He hates it, but it does the trick.I haven't noticed any stains anywhere (I believe someone had that question in another review), but the smell really leaves something to be desired. I wouldn't put it on him before people were coming over, that's for sure.As far as humans go, I use the stuff to help with cracks in the skin on the soles of my feet when I'm running too much. No matter what I tried in terms of pumice stones or lotion, I kept getting cracks anywhere the skin on the bottom of my feet was flexing when I ran. I put the stuff on more or less daily and it doesn't completely get rid of the cracks, but it keeps them from stiffening up and getting painful. I absolutely love it for that. Give it a try if you get that kind of repetitive damage.

This is a nice ice pack, but I probably wouldn't buy it again.Pros:- The two different cooling temperatures does work nicely, but you can get the same effect from a washcloth between the pack and your skin.- The wrap around strap for knees, elbows, ankles etc is solid and reasonably comfortable. I have no doubt it will last the life of the pack itself.- The gel material allows it to wrap the way it's supposed to, so all is well on that front.Cons:- The price. At Walmart, for five bucks less, you can get more solidly made/comfortable packs. I personally prefer my Thermipaq. They'll do hot/cold, and the "clay" type material seems to stay in better contact when wrapped. Again though, buy that type at Walmart, they are one third the cost.-  The double sided velcro (which is necessary to allow for the dual sided option) can be uncomfortable if it doesn't lay in the right position on your body. When I ice my knee, it sits towards the back and it's not as though it's painful or unbearable, but it'd be nice not to have.- It feels just a little cheaply made. It's a bag filled with gel, so it's not as though there is a huge range in quality of materials, but the bag is the more "plasticy" variety rather than the vinyl variety, and is just a bit thinner than my other packs.- There is no great way to clean the blue side of the pack. The blue half is sort of a felt material (not the best way to describe it, but the closest I can really think of). A decent number of my iceable injuries come with some breaking of the skin, and I'm not thrilled about the idea of having lingering blood stains. With the pure plastic kind you can just wipe clean, and with the cloth types with the removable cover you can just toss it in the laundry. Long term it'll be an issue, but it's a fifteen dollar item. If I have to toss it at the end of the year because it looks like a scene from Dexter, I'll have gotten my money's worth.- This is kind of a pro/con combo, but the gel seems to cool down and heat up faster than my other packs. Means you don't get as much time on the area you're icing, but also means you can repeat more often. It's up to you how you decide to view that attribute.All told, it's fine and I'll use it, but I think there are better options.

(Above the line is my review of the Phantom I&II, below the line are a few comparisons of the two ballasts for people who  have used the original Phantom.)In my opinion, if money isn't an issue, these are by far the best ballasts on the market.Most ballasts these days have a lot of the same features so I won't go into those (dimmable, HPS or Halide, 120/240, internal breakers and the ability to restart with a hot bulb in the event of a power outage etc...), but there are a few things that are worth mentioning as pros/cons.Pros:- Indestructible. I've never had one of these fail on me, and I've run enough ballasts to have one of most every kind give it up eventually. Also, the casing seems extremely sturdy. I have yet to drop one of these, but of my ballasts I'm willing to bet that this would be the one that would survive a fall the best- Cools itself without a fan. I think this might be part of why these last so long. There is no fan, so there are no moving parts, or open portions of the casing. You'd think this would make it run hot, but it doesn't in the slightest. This is among my coolest ballasts.- Comes with a power cord that is large enough for the thousand watt load. I bet half of my ballasts came with cords that I would consider unsafe under a thousand watt load, which I immediately replaced. The Phantoms both come with large gauge power cords completely suited to their task.- The Phantom II's wall mounting system is smooth, easy and stable. Great for wall mounting.Cons:- As far as I'm concerned, the only flaw with this ballast is the price, while not ridiculous, you can get very solid ballasts for almost half of what this one costs. I have bought ballasts all through that range, and this one is by far the nicest, but you will have to decide for yourself where the best value point is for you.- The original Phantom's wall mounting is clumsy and complicated. It can be wall mounted just fine, but the Phantom II is MUCH better if you are going to be wall mounting your ballast.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you have used a Phantom I, this should seem pretty familiar. It's an almost identical piece of equipment, and I've repeated a lot of the same things I said about the Phantom I. There are only two major changes, and they are both awesome.The first change is the size. This is just slightly smaller than the original Phantom. It's subtle, and not a monster difference, but it's always nice to save a little space.The second, and much more important change, is the wall mount system. The mounting system on the original Phantom was clunky and basically just pinned the handle on top to the wall. It stuck out, it had lots of moving parts to fail, and I was NOT a fan. It was my only complaint of the old unit. This model has completely changed that. Now, two large bolts go into the wall, and the ballast slips over them. It's simple, it's stable, and the packaging even comes with a handy little measuring template to get the position of the bolts right.  The Phantom went from having the most precarious wall mounts of my ballast to having the best.

From what I can tell, these things seem great, though thankfully I haven't had occasion to use them on a person. The few pieces of info below are based on as much info as I can get without actually shooting someone.- According to the instructions, you are supposed to test them when they arrive, and both cannisters worked smoothly.- The mechanism to fire is simple and well designed. I bought these for running in a somewhat nasty neighborhood, and I doubt they will accidentally go off in my pocket, or in my hand, due to motion. That being said, they are simple and I think I'll be able to fire them reasonably quickly.-The cannisters seem sturdy. I wouldn't want to drop anything on top of them, but they seem to be about on par with a can of shaving cream. I'd trust these in a bag or purse.- In as much as it matters, the split ring to attach these to a keychain is on the tough side, no worries about losing keys off of it.- The expiration dates on the cannisters are four years out, so there won't be any need to replace them for a good long while.Beyond that, I can't provide much information. When I tested these outside, the smell alone made me feel like they'd probably be very painful and effective. I couldn't speak to the effectiveness of the UV dye.

I don't think this is what I'd go with if I was honing an extremely expensive blade, but this is a fine sharpening stone for the four dollar price tag. The fine side on this is a bit rougher than some other stones I've seen, so again, probably not the worlds best bet for putting a razor edge on super high quality blades. The course side seems to be about the same as most of the stones I've seen. This is a great option if you want something to toss in a kitchen drawer to give knifes a quick pass if they are seeming a little dull. I'd definitely make this purchase again.

I really like this little TARDIS keychain, and I'd probably give it four and a half stars if Amazon would allow it. Below is just some extra info and a few pros/cons.I think a lot of people are disappointed because the white accents in the picture aren't present. If I hadn't read the reviews and known this ahead of time, I think I'd probably be a little bothered to. From what I can figure, the picture is of a different TARDIS keychain that can be found elsewhere on Amazon. This one is just blue, no accents except for the brand name on the bottom.People who say you can't fit bills in here are a little nuts; it's not a wallet, you are going to have to do some folding. I folded five twenties in half lengthwise then rolled them up, simple as that, and they fit great. One hundred bucks is plenty of emergency cash for me, but if you wanted you could always use hundreds and have half a grand in your keychain. As far as keeping enough cash inside, I think that's plenty, but that's just me.Pros:- I love the appearance. The white accents would have been cool, but the TARDIS is well cast and the paint is solid.- Fits enough bills to accomplish its purpose.- Is larger than I pictured (could be a pro or a con I suppose). Other reviewers gave dimensions I believe, but I'll just repeat. The base is an inch square, and the tardis stands just over two inches high (if you include the little peg the keyring goes through, just under two inches if you don't). 1 x 1 x ~2- Feels solidly made. I have no doubt that if I don't lose it, it will be hanging around in ten years.Cons:- The flip side of being solidly made is that this thing is heavy, weighing in at 86g. For reference purposes, that is the weight of about 15 quarters. Maybe not a big deal if you keep your keys in your purse or on a table, but mine are usually in my pocket. Lighter would have been nice, but it's a minor complaint, and the good news is that if a puma comes at me, I know I can always bludgeon him with my keys.- The logo on the bottom is huge. It's hidden from view if the TARDIS is upright, but I don't totally see why "WOW" needed to cover the entire bottom side of the keychain.- The rubber O-ring holding the internal piece in place seems to work pretty well, but I would prefer it were a tiny bit more snug. I'm probably just nervous because I'm not used to having 100 bucks on my keychain, and I think realistically it will stay put just fine, but a tiny bit thicker O-ring wouldn't have been the worst thing in the world.All in all, I'd definitely make this purchase again. If you are looking for a sleek way to keep a few extra bills, and you are a fan of The Doctor, it's a great choice.

I wanted to incorporate some Manga elements into some of my cartooning, so I picked up this book along with four others. This seems like one of the best. A few pros/consPros:- To start with, the book is gorgeous. There's tons of color and great illustrations. The physical quality of the paper and the printing is excellent as well. You could almost leave  it  out as a coffee table book.- Strikes a good balance between starting at the beginning and talking down to the reader. Some of the books I've found (even beginner ones) assume skills that aren't really universal. Others seem to want to start by explaining what a pencil is. This one started at the beginning but was challenging.- There is a nice progression. The book takes you through various aspects of a finished drawing piece by piece, breaking it down in a very logical way.- Includes some very cool topics not really approached in other books. Specifically, non humans. It's nice to see them tie some drawing basics into something a lot of other books handle as almost "mysterious."- The drawings in this book seemed much more polished than those in some of the other books. It's hard to describe exactly what i mean, but in some of the others, the end product is more "cartoony" than I would have liked. Sort of a silly criticism to make of a book about Manga, but it's the best way I can describe the difference. A lot of other books have artwork that just seems flat.Cons:- I say this about every single drawing book, so I don't  take stars off for  it, but why can't they make these coil/spiral binds? Every single person using this book is going to want to have it open while they have their hands busy with the lesson they are working on at the time, why not set it up to lie flat. Just a pet peeve, but I'm hoping someday a publisher might notice (Pro tip: you can get things coil bound at fed ex kinko's for five bucks or so, well worth the frustration you'll save).- There was a lot of included artwork that, while gorgeous and interesting, wasn't really helpful to actually learning anything. I really enjoyed it, so I'm not taking stars off for it, but I could see someone feeling like the book wanders from the point a little.If you are interested in learning some Manga techniques, this book is an excellent choice.

I really like this stuff; it's a great combo product:Pros:- The color seems about as natural as you can ask for, and goes on pretty smoothly. It did slightly darken a callus on my hand, but that was the only issue.- No issues with stinging in the eyes. Super important for this sort of item since if you can't go close to your eyes it is going to end up looking very strange.- The SPF seems to work as promised. I haven't seen any burning- Smells about as nice as you could ask given the combination of products here.Cons:- Super slight staining of a callus or two on my hands. Not noticeable, but it's there.I do worry about what this will end up doing to my undershirts over time. If it starts to stain them at all, I will update my review.

The bag is exactly as described, a bright pink cotton recorder bag. The size is spot on  2.5 x 14.5, and the fabric is reasonably heavyweight. Heavier than a t shirt, but lighter than a pair of jeans. It should hold it's shape well. I'd purchase again.

I really like this book as a concept for how to start drawing manga. The inclusions of tracings and times to copy along side the instructions is a really good idea. The downside, as far as I saw, was that the instruction itself wasn't quite as good as in some of the other books I've picked up on the topic. This is a really cool workbook, and worth checking out, but if you are going to have limited time, or going to start out by only grabbing one or two books, the Mark Crilley books are probably a better choice.

I'm almost entirely new to drawing, and completely new to drawing comics/manga, but I wanted to see i I could pick it up, and I couldn't be more pleased with this book. The instructions have been clear and easy to follow and I feel like I am progressing daily. I will be picking up all of the other Mark Crilley books in turn and I recommend them to anyone else wanting to try out manga.

Love D'Addario stuff. This is a lot like any other cable you might run across. Seems thick enough to last, and I've always liked the way they shape their jacks (it just seems durable). There isn't a lot else to add. If you're looking for a three foot cable with nineties on either end, this is the way to go.

The title says it all, these are nice erasers and the deal seems solid. They erase clean, and the paper around them is tough enough to stay on during use. They do leave a fair amount of dust, but it's an eraser, probably not fair to complain about that. I'll be buying more as I have need

D'Addario always makes great stuff, just some info below.- In my experience their strings tend to last longer and break less (though, most people aren't aggressive enough on a dulcimer to do much string breaking).- These don't come in the same sealed package as their guitar strings, though I'm not sure how necessary that actually is.-Thoughts on sound and tone tend to be pretty subjective, but I find these to be very bright and crisp.I'll definitely be buying more as I have need

I think there are probably better deals on Amazon (two or three bucks) for what amounts to the same thing. Mostly just writing to point out that this is the lighter aluminum variety, rather than the heavier ones that are a steel or iron, just in case you have a preference.
These are what they are. If you are looking for a very nice bronze six month chip, this is a good option. I've bought this same type in the past, and I'll buy more in the future.

This is a great little package. The vinyl eraser is pretty much standard size, so you can see from it that the kneaded and gum erasers are on the small side, but this is a cool way to have all three around if you like to use them for different purposes like I do. I'll probably grab this pack again in the future if I have need.

Like the other reviewer, I picked this bag up to house a dulcimer, which is probably very similar to his strumstick. I did throw one of my guitars in it, just to get a sense of how it would work for it's intended purpose, and it is very typical of an inexpensive gig bag. Here are a few things I've noticed just as FYI's.- The padding is on the thin side, but it's not just a bag. There is definitely some foam worked in there to cushion the instrument. I wouldn't trust it in a drop, but if I clipped it on a door as I turned or something along those lines, I think this would protect it.- The bag is SMALL. It is only going to fit electric guitars on the smaller/shorter end of the spectrum. If you are looking for something to house a dulcimer/strumstick/bass ukulele or something along those lines, this is an excellent choice.  If your instrument is much larger than an average stratocaster, I'd look elsewhere.- This is simple, but well made for the price. There are only two pockets (aside from the main one for the instrument), but they, as well as the handles and shoulder straps, seem to be well stitched and secure.- The outer material is tougher than I expected. Not the super rugged stuff you might get on a higher end bag, but not the windbreaker style material you'd often find on cheaper bags.All and all, for the ten to fifteen bucks these seem to be going for, I think they are probably one of the better deals on Amazon. As you head into the twenty dollar range and up, there are probably better options.

These are great, exactly what you'd expect. The only reason I'm reviewing is that sometimes these kinds of sharpeners are aluminum and sometimes they are a heavier metal (one would assume iron or steel). These are the heavier metal, in case you have a preference.

I think you'd be hard pressed to find someone who didn't use one of these at least occasionally during school, for standardized tests if nothing else, so there isn't a lot of shocking information to be provided. They sharpen well. The erasers aren't dried out. The graphite is thick enough to not break easily. I honestly feel sort of silly trying to come up with helpful info. If you are looking for good deal on yellow number two pencils, this is a good choice.

These are awesome. As far as removing marks on a page goes, they are as good as anything else I've tried. Unlike a kneaded eraser, they do leave dust, but not quite as much as a an art gum or something like that. The real benefit is the shape. A lot of other erasers come in a massive block form that I find hard to use for finer purposes like refining sketches, but this flattened oval is perfect. I'll definitely be buying more when I use these up.

This kit works exactly as described to make a Wacom drawing pad wireless. The parts (at least the ones on the tablet side) all fit into the device, so there is no visual evidence that anything has changed, and the battery isn't heavy enough to make much of a weight difference.The receiver that plugs into the PC side is small, unobtrusive and stores away cleanly inside the tablet.I'll definitely make sure i buy these kits with all of my future tablets. This is my first drawing pad, and I never realized how much I rotate and shift the "page" as I draw until the cord was getting in the way of that.High quality item overall.

These sketch pads are great. High quality paper, a good price and well made enough that it isn't falling apart by the time it's full. I really can't say enough good things about them. There is a reason they are a number one seller on Amazon. If you need this sort of sketch pad, then this is definitely the one to get.

This is a very nice little art set, especially for the price. All the included items seem to be of pretty high quality, at least to the extent an amateur like I can see. Only the pencil sharpener seems a bit flimsy, but that's an incredibly minor complaint. The pencils all feel good, and came in good shape. And nothing seems dried out or cheap. I would definitely buy this again.

The title says it all. Just providing some additional info.- This is really a decent sized bracelet. I got mine to use as a sort of mini mala, but I can get it over my hands, which are larger than average but not by much, and it doesn't look ridiculous (size wise at least) on my wrist. Based on the adjustments, I'd say it would fit the majority of people from child to adult.- The beads are well formed and polished. In the picture, it seems as though they taper as they head towards the adjustment (at least to me it does) but they are the same size the whole way around.- The cord seems very tough, and a kind of ornate slip not is used to adjust the size of the band. Solid workmanship in my opinion.All and all, a very nice little item.

I like these boards, and I'll be buying more as I lose these. This is just some info for potential buyers.- These are typical padded emery boards (the larger size, a little smaller than the width of my thumb)- The colors seem to be random, only one of the ones I got matches one in the picture.- For the most part, these are like the colorful ones you would find in a cup next to the register, but one of mine is labeled as "eco board" and has the brown color of recycled paper, or a paper shopping bag.
