I went back and did the activation through the website which worked fine, followed by half a dozen emails with my activation code.There's no way to move the app when it's running, forcing me to move my webcam out of the way as the sensor insists on sitting dead center.  The counter weight was very close to the sensor and didn't move easily.  I had to work out that I could move the weight so the sensor would drape over the screen properly.I had to swear that I was not using a hub and there was no ambient light falling on the screen.  I lied.  It works fine on a hub.  With that being said, if you have Win7/8, avoid using USB3 hubs which are problematic.  No issues on the Mac tho.  I had to wrestle with it as it kept telling my monitor was too dim.  Looks fine to me.  It was unclear if I won the argument but finally got it to calibrate, then reduced my backlighting to a comfortable level.After it completed, a yellow icon which looked like an ugly nose appeared on my Mac's toolbar.  I tried to remove it, but the only way it would go away was to quit the background program.  Apparently there's a background task which expects me to keep the sensor plugged in all the time to measure my ambient light.  I quit the task.  I don't need a fancy piece of software to tell me when my lights are on.Other than that... perfect color calibration.

Who wears a watch when the exact time is always displayed on your cell phone?  At some point, I decided that it was more convenient to use a watch rather than dig out my phone every time I wanted to tell the time.  I was really picky.  First, it must be a tritium watch so I can see the time in total darkness.  The second hand must be illuminated.  And, it needed to display the date.My next set of criteria was a sapphire crystal since I'm always scratching plastic watches.  Some reference to 24 hour time would be most welcome.  Dive watches were a possibility, aviator or chronometer styles were tempting, but dress watches were out.Then I found this unique looking fellow.  It's rugged looking, but without the unnecessary depth gauge and helium mixture calculator.  It has a sapphire crystal without being too expensive.  And, has an illuminated second hand and date display.I was originally sold on the Reactor watches with the Never Dark design.  But, let me tell you - this is plenty bright.  In a brightly lit room you'll barely see the hands glow.  As I move into an unlit room or outdoors at night, I can see the time clearly without waiting for my eyes to adjust.  The only situation in which I can't tell time is while driving at night with bright headlights all around me.  Then, my eyes never have time to adjust to the darkness - but, I've got that covered.From what I've read, Traser is the brand of mb-microtec, a Swiss company who makes Tritium tubes for other watch companies.  They diversified with their own brand of watches at an affordable price and have a good reputation.  While you can find cheaper watches, you probably won't find the same quality for the price.The watch is a little heavy but not too big, most definitely a man's watch.  Traser sells a healthy assortment of watchbands if you're not "feeling" the green.  I searched for years for a watch, knowing that most of the time it will sit on my desk while I type.  If you want to own only one watch, this one is a good choice.

This is a plastic plate cover, described as a microwave splatter shield.  A splatter shield brings to mind some type of microwave-safe netting to allow steam to release without the splatter.  This plastic plate cover is solid and allows steam and boil-over to escape through the 2 large holes in the top.  The photograph is a bit deceiving as well.It's a plastic plate cover.

This is similar to the Zojirushi mug Zojirushi SM-SA48-BA Stainless Steel Mug, Black, 16-Ounce, but for less money and not built as sturdy.  It does have the same great performance.  I was looking for something to keep my glass of water cold overnight on the bedstand.  With water at *room* temperature, I added 4 ice cubes which lasted 8 hours.  This gave me ice water for the entire night in a spill-proof container.  What they describe as "purple" is open for interpretation.  It's more of a pink / clay type of color.  I wanted something which would blend in with the bedroom colors.

I tried the Oregon Blueberry Sour Cream mix - just amazing flavour.  I was taken off guard that I needed to add egg and sour cream rather than just water, but slight inconvenience was well worth the result.  For making breakfast for one, I divided the package in half.  Makes (2) hearty breakfasts, superior to supermarket mixes.

They really should re-take the photograph which does not do it justice.  It's a shiny silver metal plaque connected to a sturdy chain and a flat, not round split ring which makes keys easier to add.  This quickly became my favorite keychain in my collection.  You probably won't get the humor unless you've watched the series Breaking Bad.  This keychain serves as a reminder that bad things happen to good people and that life is uncertain.

I was looking for a reliable splitter made from quality parts.  This one is is.  Some of good features include a solid built plug with a blade type 15A fuse cleverly built into the handle, heavy cord, 4-way rather than 3-way and that extra socket can actually accommodate a genuine lighter if you're so inclined.Mind you, cigarette plugs and sockets are a gimmick.  It was never designed for electronic gizmos and such.  If you have a device which has a plug which falls out of this, consider replacing the plug, not the socket.Anyway, I bought this for an "off the grid" 12v battery system for when the household AC goes out.  I wanted to charge my power-hungry smart phone - check; it has a nice 5v USB socket in the rear.  And, lots of juice available (10 amps) for lights and other gadgets.But, wow - that LED draws a lot of current.  I nearly returned it, but decided to void my warranty ;)  The front LED is connected via a 1k resistor to 12v.  That equates to a healthy 12ma just to keep an LED lit which I didn't really need.  There's an additional LED in the rear which tells you the status of the 5V USB port.  I think there are just way too many LED's in gizmos these days, so a simple wire cutter dropped the current draw to almost nothing.  If I wasn't lazy, I would replace the 1k resistor with a 10k easily to drop that blinding red light. - DIY'ers take note.

You just can't ask for a better 12v fan than this.  The cable is heavy, components are well made, and for about 1 amp of current this fan really moves the air.  I was a little apprehensive considering the price, but was pleasantly surprised how much air I could move on such little power.My only complaint is the cord a bit too short to be practical.

High quality components and heavy gauge wire.  I have one issue with them, the socket is just a tad too big and several mating plugs I have do not have enough friction to keep a good connection.  I swapped out the socket with a different one.

I'd never think that I would be writing a review about a toenail clipper.  But, here we are.  I've gone through many cheaper ones.  The last plastic clipper fell apart in my hands and I surfed around for a metal replacement.  I didn't know they came in stainless steel.  Bathrooms are damp and have caused many previous clippers to rust.  I'll bite and see how this stainless steel one works for me.It feels good in my hand.  The cut-outs allow a good grip, important when using sharp objects near my body.  There's an emery board built into the body, not a swing out type which I've always found annoying.  The action is smooth, like a precision instrument.The bad points?  It's a bit more expensive; but, you won't be disappointed with the quality.

A coffee drinker's coffee.  If you are the type to judge a restaurant by their coffee, this one is for you.  Rich, shiny black Arabica beans, full of flavor, strong taste and excellent body without bitterness.  And, as I found out, backed by excellent customer service who really takes pride in their coffee.  It is unlike the popular coffee shop chains, far superior to supermarket coffee.  This is honest gourmet coffee roasted by people who know their trade.If you are new to gourmet coffee, try the medium roast and use a bit less than what you are accustomed to.

I had a bedroom which smelled like a locker room.  The first step should always be to clean.  Don't take shortcuts.  Rent or buy a carpet steam cleaner, BISSELL ReadyClean PowerBrush Full Sized Carpet Cleaner, 47B2 which will take you 85% of the way there.  Once you're done cleaning, use this carpet fresh sparingly.  It's got a great, fresh scent although it doesn't seem to last too long - probably a good thing since no smell is the best smell.
This works fine with my Asus Transformer tablet.  I had first searched for an Asus car charger and was surprised that none exists.  Here's one at a great price and works well.

Just amazing reception, clear picture, and (fairly) easy interface.  I am 50 miles from the nearest transmitter and can still pick up a few stations with the whip antenna, but not very well.  This is for emergencies after the storm knocks out all the electricity, phone, internet, and cable television.  Here's the good and bad:Good:Runs on ordinary AA batteries.  No rechargeable built-in battery to run out during a power failure.Excellent sensitivity capable of picking up signals where I would never expect possible.Great color and picture.Easy controls - not the best, not the worst, I can kinda figure out what button to press.Cons:5v adapter input rather than what should have been a mini-USB.Really oddball external antenna input.Built-in antenna very delicate and I expect to break it in the near future.Here's how I overcame the reception problem.  I purchased an external flat digital TV antenna to put in the window, 1Byone 0.02" Paper Thin Digital Indoor TV Antenna Aerial Ultra Thin Lightweight Soft Design with High Gain and Low Noise Excellent Reception for Digital Freeview and Analog TV HDTV Digital Terrestrial Signals Type#0185  I chose the passive type rather than amplified because, again, it's for when the power goes out.  To connect it, you'll need one of these, RF Antenna Adapter for RCA Portable TVThe antenna says it's good for only 35 miles.  I'm picking up a signal from 50 miles away and get 3 or 4 stations, one of them being good for network news.This little TV is going into my "oh darn" box for when all else fails.

I felt the need to write a few words about this film after the feedback.  Ignore the negative comments.  Perhaps it's billed incorrectly as a sci-fi thriller where the operating system of a computer becomes a sentient being.  uhh, yea, kinda; but, not the reason to watch.  If you're expecting anything science-fiction-ie, you're going to have a bad time.What I see is a collection of metaphors, how we deal with technology, how we deal with people, how technology is becoming a part of our lives, how we see each other, our full-time connection to the Internet, what is to be human, what it is to be machine.  Then, the film takes some of these concepts and lets them run off the rails like an out of control game of The Sims to see how far the simulation can go until it becomes absurd.Perhaps those negative comments come from those too young, who not yet experienced a real human relationship, spending too much time in the basement playing video games.  This movie more for adults who can spot a relationship running amuck or those little clues that you need to put some space between you and the woman you're dating - immediately.Or, perhaps this illustrates what can happen when we don the video glasses and talk to our cell phones like they're human.It's a love story which has only one person in it.

It's a nice leather case with stitching and antique brass accents.  One thing, tho.  This case jams up against the control ring around the lens making it impossible to turn.  In 80% of the camera functions, you will never need to use the control ring.  If you don't use any of the manual functions and just use it for point-n-shoot then it's not too much of a problem.  Else, you're out of luck if you want to turn the control knob.

I originally had a pair of LLBean's, but they proved too difficult to slip in and out of.  I don't like laces.  Zipper boots have bad reviews.  Then, this BOA system closure caught my eye.  Some have had problems with cable failures.  Now that I own them, I see where they're going wrong.  It's very tempting to ratchet the cable very tight, which gives it no ability to bend or flex, so it breaks.  I just snug them down as tight as I would make lace boots.  I think it will last the life of the boot.  I took an extra precaution of buying spare parts.  The mechanism and lace appear easy to replace and BOA provides a warranty.  It's only a few bucks to replace and it's always nice to have a backup.  It's geared more towards ski boots, so I needed to send a few emails to find the correct replacement parts for these.Then, there are the replaceable soles.  It came with a snap-on set of ice spikes.  The non-metal spikes on the boots seem aggressive enough for most conditions.  I was tempted to swap them out, but they're really stiff and difficult to change i.e. I would only switch to metal spikes for actual walking on frozen ice all day, not for normal use.  Best, if the soles wear out, just snap on a set of new ones.Breaking in - the boots were very stiff and difficult to walk in at first.  I was surprised when after wearing them for just one day, the softened up enough to be easy to walk in and not a problem in the car to drive with them on.  Nice and water proof.  I had no problem walking around in a foot of snow.  I plan on wearing them through most of the Winter.

I have given up on all those sticky pads for eyeglasses which sit on the frame.  After a few days, the adhesive melts and I'm left with a gooey, sticky mess.  My latest frames for prescription eyeglasses fit great, but keep sliding down.  Sometimes this is a good thing, allowing me to peer over the top since I'm near-sighted.  I didn't want to have them tightened or adjusted to clamp tighter onto my face.This solution was cheap enough to try.  They're perfect.  My glasses no longer slip off.  I can look down and shake my head without them wiggling off, yet they don't feel tightened or clamped onto my face.  They are small enough to hide behind my ears, not really visible.  I've only had them for a few days, so assuming worst case I need to replace them for some reason, they are inexpensive enough and slip on without sticky adhesives.If I had to say one thing bad about them, when I slip my glasses on, I hear a noise as the foam moves past my ears; but, not while I'm wearing them.

I was doing research on alum and came across these solid blocks of salt for both deodorant as well as shaving.  It's Potassium Aluminum Sulfate, aka alum or potassium alum or barber's alum.  I gave it the acid test.  I shoveled the walk, worked up a good sweat and stench.  Just a few passes of this alum and the odor was gone.  It works by killing off bacteria which cause body order.Potassium Aluminum Sulfate is a very old substance, dating back to at least 200 B.C.  It's a deodorant, water purifier, after shave, makes a good fire extinguisher - it's just an amazing little molecule.  Many commercial deodorants contain aluminum chlorohydrate, which is a smaller molecule and more easily absorbed by the body - which is more unhealthy.Now, a word about aluminum.  There was a study done back in the 70's which remarked about the unusually high concentration of aluminum in the water supply of a patient with Alzheimer's.  As it turned out, there was no link to aluminum, but it was enough to cause everyone to throw out their aluminum cookware.  The fear and ignorance continues.Aluminum chlorohydrate is safe, but tends to be absorbed by the body whereas Potassium Aluminum Sulfate is a larger molecule and not as easily absorbed.  This makes Alum a preferred substance.But, to say that Aluminum Sulfate contains aluminum and is dangerous is just wrong on several levels.  It's like saying that H2O aka water aka dihydrogen monoxide is poisonous because it has (something) monoxide in it.  Or, saying that water is explosive because it has a very flammable substance, hydrogen coupled with an oxidizer, pure oxygen.  If you have never been exposed to chemistry, H2O aka water may seem like an extremely flammable substance.  Yet, in the real world, we extinguish fires with water.Such is the same with aluminum.  When atoms combine to form molecules, the new substance takes on entirely new properties.  Do not confuse Alum with aluminum.

I wear a medium hat and this fits perfectly.  The faux fur is warm and the ear flaps extend to the bottom of my ears.  They snap up out of the way and looks good either snapped up or hanging down.  Good price.  I'm thinking of buying a second one.

I purchased this to cut 4-40 screws which were poking too far out.  The right-angle cutter would not fit into the space.  This cut the screws easily with one hand, provided you've got a medium-strong grip.  I cut 8 screws in under 1 minute.

I bought this for my Pentax K-3 digital SLR.  The camera's built-in microphone picks up all the sound in the room and auto-levels everything for a flat response.  But, this becomes distracting for video where you want the subject's voice louder than the background noise.  For this, you need a directional microphone.This one works well and provides a really nice stereo separation.  The shoe mount is ok, but I would recommend a shock mount for better isolation against noise, Polaroid Microphone Shock Mount With Dual Mount design (Shoe Mount, 1/4 20, 5/8)

It does the job, includes 2 spare bands and held my microphone well.  My one complaint was the shoe mount for the camera, which I was unable to tighten.  This caused the whole thing flop around.  I resolved this by adding a small piece of rubber gasket under the screw.  This also served to protect the camera from damage from the lock nut.

I replaced an old, worn runner with this one and totally happy with it.  I was a bit put off by some negative reviews.  Is it thin?  No, it's exactly what I had expected.  It comes rolled, so I needed to place weights on the ends to give it a chance to straighten itself out, as expected.  Does it have a smell?  No, it smells like carpet.  I did not notice any strong or unusual odor.As for the picture, the color is slightly different than the photograph, which I am guessing is due to the warm lighting at home.  It's also has more fuzzy edges to the design, not the razor sharp lines you see.It feels great between my toes when I walk on it.  It's perfect and a nice replacement.  It does not have fringe tassels which you might think is nice to have, until you realize it easier to vacuum without them.

If you are considering this AT-214, compare also the AT-213.  It's the same tripod but folds into fewer, sections.  The trade-off is how short the tripod is when it's folded vs. how many sections you need to pull out when you setup.  I went for this model the smaller folded size.  Also watch the 22lb weight limit if you're shooting with a long lens.  Fear not, they make heavier models such as the 313 and 413.I've been a huge fan of Bogen tripods until discovering Induro.  Here are the things I love about this model:  It comes with a case which quickly and easily tosses over my shoulder.  I've never been able to carry a tripod using a strap or a sling before today.  It has nicely padded legs - no more foam covers which slip out of place.  When open, it's reasonably level and very sturdy, doesn't wiggle like others I've owned.  It has all the classic features, like a removable center column and clips for attaching a sandbag or accessories.  It also comes with a tool kit in a pouch which attaches to the tripod.Other nice things, the carry bag is large enough to carry the tripod attached to one of the largest heads Induro makes, the 5-way pan-head.  The twist legs are so nice, compared to clamps, but that's a matter of taste.  They work well with a smooth operation.To be fair, here's what I didn't like.  I didn't care for the "Made in China" stickers, but they're easily removed.  The country of manufacturer in no way distracts from the quality of construction.  Second, to switch between spikes or pads, one needs to use the tool kit to unscrew one and screw in the others.  I guess I'm a bit spoiled with other tripods which convert between spikes and pads with a twist.  This one, not so much.  So, once you've got your spikes on, it's a commitment.  I shot with spikes in soft sand and pads inside on a smooth floor.  Both worked well.Induro is more like a shooting assistant than dead weight to be lugged around.  Great product at a great price.

Technically speaking, yea, it fits both the Arca Swiss as well as Manfrotto quick release brackets.  On the Arca Swiss bracket, it is very narrow and does not have the ability to add stop screws which prevent the camera from sliding off.  On the Manfrotto, the bracket is so narrow that it sloshes around, not fitting properly.Good for amateur photography but professional photographers will not like this plate.
This is not a 5-mode flashlight as the description says.  It's on full bright or off.  No zoom, lightweight.  Takes two CR123A batteries.

This is the most versatile head I own.  I can quickly and easily pan, tilt, swivel all with precision.  Just a really well-built, sold, yet surprisingly compact head.  It's not lightweight, but lighter than you would think just by looking at it.  The best feature is the folding control arms - just really well thought-out by people who live on the tripod.There are just a couple of things you must be aware of.  First, bubble levels cover this thing - a bubble level for every axis you can imagine.  They are just not very accurate.  My Pentax has a 2-axis electronic level which made leveling the camera much easier than using the tiny bubble levels on the head.  ok, not a big issue and probably not unexpected.  btw - you can find hot shoe mounted bubble levels which do a better job for you.The second issue is the quick release.  Love 'em or hate 'em, we are treated to a universal Arca Swiss Style quick-release mount rather than a proprietary mounting plate.  As I fiddled with the knobs to setup the camera, I turned the quick-release knob which protrudes out further than the swivel knob.  Just a touch of this knob with the camera in a vertical position sent it accelerating towards the ground at a great acceleration.  Thankfully I had a hand on the camera at the time and felt it slip, grabbing it just in time.  whew.  Really close and enough to make me not so found of the quick release.I noticed some small text on the knob, telling me to hold my camera while turning this job.  yea, no kidding.  I put a rubber band around it, hoping that it will remind me to not grab that knob ever again.Still tho, I thought some more and realized I could reverse the quick release plate 180 degrees.  This puts the quick release knob in a very awkward position making it difficult to turn; perfect.  Depending on your setup, you may or may not have the room to face this knob forward, placing it under the lens.  But if you do, do it.  It's one less knob in your face, making operation easier.  You may never have to face that "ah ha" moment when you realize, Oh, wow, that's what that knob does!With the little "issues" behind me, this tripod head has become my favorite.Edit 12/2/13: I'm a bit more knowledgeable about the Arca Swiss Style quick-release plates.  The problem I was having was I had purchased the head used and the previous owner had apparently removed the two "safety screws" which prevent the QR plate from sliding sideways as I had described.  After some emails, the manufacturer understood the situation and resolved all my issues.  so, I'm adding another star if the system will let me.Great tripod.  Great customer service.

I wanted to replace my plain cheese grater for something a bit more useful.  This has a drawer to capture the cheese, rather than having me spill over the counter and floor.  Upon receiving it, I see now that this thing is really huge and could have been half the size.  The wood trim is wonderful and they even thought of adding a lip to it for leverage so it doesn't slide around.  But, aside from it taking up a lot of room, as I grate the cheese, the metal insert rocks back and forth producing a loud click-clack sound.  I eventually gave it away to someone else.

I have the Pentax K-5 and usually shoot with eyeglasses which are in the -3 to -4 range.  The K-5 viewfinder has a +/- adjustment but it has never worked for me.  The "M" adapter fits a wide variety of Pentax cameras, one of the great things about Pentax in general.  After I installed this -3 correction on the K-5, I can shoot with glasses or without glasses, sliding the +/- adjustment on the camera all the way to the left or right.  Highly recommended purchase.Now, I'm looking for rubber eyecup which fits over this adapter.  Still looking.

I bought these as spares to my genuine Apple cables.  They kinda/sorta work.  Once in a while I get a message pop-up on iPhone 4s which says this accessory may not be compatible.  If you're buying them as spares, they're ok.  But, I'd advise not making this your primary charging cable, especially if you're charging the device overnight.  The warning message appears about 10% of the time while plugged into a hub under WinXP.

Great quality sheets.  The color looks better than the photographs.  It's a bit darker, deeper color with a shiny appearance.  I would call it "slate blue" rather than flint blue.  In any event, you won't be disappointed.

You don't need to spend hundreds of dollars for a machine which steams milk.  I used an inexpensive espresso maker Vev Vigano 8194 Kontessa Inox 4-cup Coffee Pot to make a shot of espresso with this milk frother and produced a cappuccino (or is it a latte?) in less than 3 minutes. (see attached photo).  Didn't have any milk, so I used fat-free 1/2 and 1/2, put it on the stove for a minute to warm it up, pumped for a few seconds, and I'm done.  Creamy, smooth, dash of cinnamon.  yea, it doesn't make "the noise."  But, it works like a dream.

I needed something a bit more comfortable for my girlfriend when she's been bad.  The extra length fits the bill.  Peerless is made in the U.S., carries a lifetime warranty, and is built solid.  They're less expensive than S/W, although they lack their highly polished finish.  Can't beat the value tho.

I wanted to jazz up my carrots by making a honey-glaze.  I just put a pat of butter on ordinary frozen baby carrots, sprinkle this honey powder, and I have a super quick and easy side dish.  Much better than store-bought honey glazed carrots.

My girlfriend and I have a barter arrangement.  When she performs well, I buy her something from Amazon.  But, we usually wind up arguing over how many times she has done something special for me.So, now, she carries this punch card.  I use a heart shaped punch, Fiskars 23607097 Hand Punch, 1/4-Inch, Heart to record her progress (the heart shape punch discourages cheating) and when she finishes the agreed upon duties, she redeems her card for her reward.It's saved me a lot of money taking her out to dinner.

I've never had great luck with electric shavers, but recent experience with a competing brand convinced me that there may be some merit in their use. After looking at the feature set and construction of the Norelco, I was excited to try it out. Unfortunately, it did not live up to my expectations.Things started out well. I was impressed with the construction and look of the razor and love the fact that all three of the rotating heads pivoted independently of each other, something that my other three head razor does not do.I also thought that the combination charging and washing system was fantastic. I like the way it looked, and like the idea of having the entire razor cleaned and lubricated after each use. Sadly, it was in critical areas of actual use that this razor showed its weakness on my beard.In testing it I used it dry (which I found it fairly uncomfortable, not at all what I would think a razor for sensitive skin would feel like), wet with just water,  with gels, and with traditional shaving creams. I used it regularly for 3 weeks, to make sure that I gave my skin ample time to acclimate to the new razor.The results of all my testing were disappointing. I do have a fairly coarse beard, which has caused problems with electric razors in the past,  but I thought that a razor carying this price tag would be able to handle it. No dice.To get anywhere close to a reasonable shave, I had to apply more pressure than I found comfortable, and continue going over the same spots again and again and again; they felt irritated long before they were clean shaven. I tried it with less pressure to allow the blades time to conform to my face, but it made no difference at all and I was never able to get a suitably close shave with this razor.The rest of the system worked flawlessly though, and I found it easy to clean, easy to charge and easy to hold onto wet or dry. For these reasons, I very much wanted the razor to be functionally excellent. Instead, I'll be going back to my older rotary razor which actually does a fine job even on my course beard, and I'll be passing this one along to my son who has very fine whiskers that are removed easily with the Norelco.If this actually works on your beard, it's a wonderful razor with great construction look and feel. However if, like I, you have a course beard or simply one that just doesn't want to work with this guy, no amount of wonderful features will make up for the fact that you won't be clean shaven, and you'll be looking around for a traditional razor in no time.

Is it possible to make the perfect travel pack? I don't know, but this gets close.Honestly, if I were to design exactly what I wanted in a weekend travel pack, this would ALMOST be it. First of all, the pack itself is very well made, with nice materials, high quality SBS zippers, an strong stitching throughout. The handle on the top makes it simple to use as a carry-on bag for flights, while the well-padded shoulder and waist straps tuck away into a zippered panel in the back.There are plenty of pockets, including two mesh water bottle slots, and a nicely padded laptop pocket that had no problem swallowing a 15" computer. This is my only real complaint, as the pack itself is wide enough to handle a 17", but they've made the laptop slot a bit narrower.There's a lightweight aluminum and HDPE frame in the back that allows the bag to hold its shape while empty. And it's removable - sweet.Then there's the killer feature - the outer section of the pack zips off and can be used as a small day pack, complete with shoulder straps. What a great feature for travelers! Leave the bulk of your things in a hotel or tent, and head off for the day with your camera, wallet, pad and paper,... whatever you want close at hand is there, without the hassle of carrying everything everywhere.Bonus: behind the zip-off pack is a hidden zippered pocket, which makes it easy to keep important documents (passport, etc.) or extra cash in a more secure spot than a pocket open to the world.I can guarantee this: the next time I or a member of my family goes on a 3-4 day trip, this is going to be the one piece of luggage that is going for sure.

This is an awesome tomahawk. Period. Here's why:- Weight and size are perfect. Enough heft to add to a strike, but not too much so that it's a pain to carry.- The blade is beautifully made and razor sharp. This thing is totally ready to get to work.- The nail puller end is a great touch, and it can, of course, be used for piercing stuff.- The hammer head is a bit awkward, but a welcome addition.- The paracord-wrapped handle gives fine grip and is a genius idea.- The fire-starter in the handle is secured well (no worries about it dropping out) and, while not as fat as some, is more than enough to get a few fires started (practice before you need it though).- The included sheath is extremely well made and fits the 'hawk perfectly.You know that show "Naked and Afraid," where they drop two people off in some remote location with nothing but a single tool? If they were allowed to bring this one, they wouldn't be naked OR afraid for long (ok, MAYBE naked, but they'll be saving so much time on making shelter and fire that they'll have plenty left over to weave clothing).It'll do it all and is a fantastic work or survival tool.

There's a lot to lke here, not the least of which is the 300-400 bucks that stay in your pocket after purchasing it over one of the flagship devices offered by most carriers.First of all, it looks fantastic and feels like a premium device in the hand with nice fit and finish. It's very light and slim as well, which is great for those that like to keep their phones in their back pockets. How it would stand up to being sat on though, I do not know.It comes loaded with Kit Kat 4.4.4, and I've not heard about any upgrades to Lollipop, but that's not a huge issue to me. The version of Android is lightly skiined by Huawei which allows it to be very quick and responsive.Call quality is excellent, and the volume on the speakerphone is plenty loud and clear. This was a real treat, as most phones in this price range tend to sound pretty poor.The screen is one of the obvious cost-cutting decisions the company made - it's only 720 x 1280, which doesn't bother me as much as the fact that it's also not particularly great looking. Colors aren't quite right, and off-axis viewing isn't up to snuff. However, considering the price point here it's not a deal breaker at all.The camera software I found to be quite good, and photos and videos are better than I expected at this price point. If you're looking for a flagship--killer you might want to look elsewhere, but for basic snap shots and videos, though, it does a fine job.There were a couple of software issues I should mention. First, Auto Brightness on my review model was completely non-functional. Bummer. Also, I was excited to see that I could adjust color temp, as it is extremely cold from the factory, but that, too, didn't work. Weird, but I assume easily fixable in a patch.All in all, this is a fine effort from Huawei. I'm really glad that there are reasonably priced unlocked phones on the market now, as I really dislike the absurd pricing on cellular service and devices. More choices like this will hopefully get the big carriers to be more aggressive not only in device pricing, but airtime as well, which is a win for everyone.Faced with the choice today of buying my current phone, a Droid Turbo (which is my favorite phone I've ever owned) or the P8 lite, I'd have a tough time deciding. But I'm telling you right now: I suspect I'd be walking around with the extra money in my bank account and the P8 in my pocket.

Vacuums seem to be getting more and more gimmicky lately - not something I'm particularly a fan of. So when this one arrived on my doorstep, I was pretty excited to check it out.My first question was "what makes this a commercial vacuum?" I suppose in this case it's the lack of the gizmos and gadgets that so many vacuums come with. I've read that often the commercial models don't have rubber bumpers, but this does, or that they have bigger motors, but this is a 12 amp, just like my regular vacuum. So really, I suppose it's the utilitarian look and feel, along with the bright orange heavy duty cord.This assembles easily with a screwdriver and was ready to try out in no time. As I said, there are very few frills: it comes with one plastic tube extension for the hose, one crevice tool that can be attached to the extension, and one non-moving basic brush attachment. That's it. Happily, they all live on the vacuum so they're always handy. Construction is pretty good, though some of the plastics felt quite cheap. On the other hand, then weren't to rigid, so perhaps they'll last longer under stress and won't snap easily.As for functionality, I'm very happy. It has tremendous ability to pick up whatever I run it over, either on rug or bare floors. Rugs in particular get a fantastic cleaning, and I was able to get a ton of dirt up that my other vacuum had left behind. Bare floors suffer a tiny bit because you cannot turn the motorized brush off, so things can sometimes get flung backwards, but it happened rarely and the overall effectiveness made up for it.The hose attachment clicks into place on the body, which I really like, and is released with the push of a button. The hose is long, but not quite as long as I'd like. However, the suction it produces is epic. Seriously more powerful than any vacuum I've used in recent memory. The tools, basic as they are, do their jobs well and I don't find myself wishing for any additional attachments.Emptying the canister is extremely easy: take it to the garbage and open the bottom. One nice feature: the switch to pop open the bottom is on an extension, allowing it to be released from a ways up the canister. This makes it possible to push the canister farther into the garbage before opening it, and keep my hand from getting dirty or dusty.The top of the canister opens easily if you need to clear anything from the upper chamber, and the filters are easy to reach, remove and clean.Some reviewers have complained about the noise level, but it's quieter than my last upright, and WAY quieter than our Shark, which actually hurts my ears. So I'm extremely happy in that regard.Overall, it's become my go-to vacuum now. It's relatively light, it's powerful, and it's effective. If the hose were just a bit longer and I could turn off the motorized brushes, this would be a 5 star for sure. But even with the ding of a star, it's still my daily driver.

Yes, I'm an adult. Let's not make a big deal about it.The fact is, this thing is great for any age. It's really well constructed, has an excellent quality large-tooth zipper, and is stupidly cute. The concept is simple: write down your worries, and stick them in the mouth for Saggo to eat up.For children, this is a great exercise in identifying what worries them, and then writing them down can help make them far less scary than when they live inside their heads. If you have very young kids, you can tear them up and put them back for them to find later, which would further help them let go of their fears, while bringing a little bit of magic along for the ride.For adults, well, read the paragraph above. Except for the tearing up part. Though come to think of it, why not that too?My whole family actually loves this, and my daughter's 18-year-old boyfriend was the first to use it. That says a lot.A sweet, cute, and surprisingly therapeutic... thing?We love it!

Maybe it's because my wife's eyes are only 45 years old and not 65, but this product had limited appealApplication is lovely: it has a nice texture and smells nice as well. It feels great going on and remains comfortable. Makeup can be applied over the top of it if you wish, or you can go out with just the serum. Once applied, it does have a nice tightening effect that lasts for a few hours, though it has not, as of yet, provided any long term positive results.Again, this may be a function of my wife's eyes having only light lines so there's not much to fix, but for her, while it was a very pleasant experience with a nice temporary effect, there did not seem to be any permanent line reduction over time. Perhaps, as another reviewer pointed out, was the skin looser and/or creased with more lines, there would have been a lasting change.In the end, it's a lovely experience but has not (yet) shown us the kind of performance that would prompt my wife to purchase more.

I've had a juicer before. Sold it because it wasn't used enough. Why? It was a bit of a pain in the but to set it up, prep the fruit, then clean it up all for a limited amount of juice. This KitchenAid I'll be keeping though, even if it has one unbelievable design flaw.Out of the box it's great looking. Good quality, well-made components and an overall feeling of real quality. It assembles easily, too, with only a few main parts to assemble. The unit allows you to choose how much pulp you want as well, with three settings ranging from low to high. The instructions are a bit confusing as to which setting is which, but looking at the top of the screen while adjusting it makes things clear.The feed chute is quite wide, which allows for dropping whole (small) apples in at once, and minimizes how much you have to cut down items that don't quite fit. The chute is great when putting a big clump of kale or other greens in as well.The juicing process works just fine. Two speed allow you to use different types of fruits and vegetables, and as long as you keep the pitcher under the spout with the cover on it, there's no mess at all. However, something that I thought would be a great feature turns out to be the first minor problem: the spout is hinged, allowing you to flip it up a bit when you're done, ostensibly to keep any last bits of juice from pouring onto your counter after you remove the pitcher. A great idea in theory, but mine leaks a bit of juice each time you flip it up or down. It's not terrible, and not as bad as it pooling on a counter, but the front of the unit does get dirty.Another thing I noticed is that as you push the fruit or vegetable through, particularly in the case of soft fruits like pineapple, the last bit seems to get slung right into the waste bin, not quite fully extracting all the juice. I ended up with a lot of pulp in some instances that could have been better extracted. This may be just how they all work though {I can't remember how my last one did it} and it's not throwing entire chunks of fruit - just a large clump of pulp that looks like it had more to give.As the name implies, this is very easy to clean, with the one exception I alluded to in my opening paragraph. Each piece comes apart easily and I have, for the most part, made it to the sink without making any mess on my counters. Once in the sink, it cleans up well, and the included brush gets the juicer screen quite clean. Parts can be placed in the dishwasher if you wish, and I had no issues when I did so.The problem is that there is a section of the unit, just above the spout, that is completely inaccessible to anything except flying pulp. It's hard to explain, but there's a one-inch square slot that's open at the bottom but closed at the top into which various bits of pulp must ricochet, because when I go to clean up there's a bunch jammed in there. The problem is that the construction of the thing is such that it's impossible to get anything in there to clean it: it's completely blocked by the bottom of the bowl, and you really cant spray it out or anything. I had to find a pipe cleaner, bend it up, and wiggle it around in there and STILL couldn't get it clean. For the life of me, I cannot understand how this flaw was left in place: one use and it's obvious that the section has to be sealed up or users may well end up with rotting bits of fruit and vegetable up there. If you are extremely patient and let water wash in and out of the section, it will eventually get most of the pulp out - but without the ability to directly spray or clean it out, it's a total fail in the "Easy Clean" department. The irritating part is that it would have been incredibly simple to just close the slot at the bottom and avoid the whole issue.One final note regarding the pitcher: the cover on it is designed to supposedly keep foam from pouring into your glass. It doesn't work very well at all. I can see how the design SHOULD work, and perhaps it would in a perfect world, but my world is apparently not perfect.In the end though, I really like this juicer and have been using it quite a bit. With the exception I talked about above, it really is easy to clean, it works really well, and looks nice on my counter so I don't mind leaving it out. Considering getting them out and set up is half the battle with juicers, that's actually a bigger deal than it sounds like. Were it not for that one ridiculous design flaw, this would be a 5 star product. But those flecks of fruit and vegetable are really tough to deal with, and I don't want to ignore them and let them mold. I'll probably see if I can figure out a way to block it off {though as I said is so inaccessible it's tough to see how I could work on it}, but it's an amazingly dopey oversight and costs one star.

I've been looking for a nice drive to carry critical files around for a while, and I'm very happy with the P20.The drive has a metal back with a plastic front cover, and a plastic switch to retract and extend the USB plug. The construction is extremely solid and the device feels like a quality piece.Speed is excellent - by far the fastest flash drive I've tested thanks to the USB 3.0 capabilities, and I have had no issues with my computer detecting it as USB 3.0 vs USB 2.0.The encryption software is robust and simple. They've included EncryptStick Light, which provides a quick and easy way to create an encrypted vault on the stick. Basically, you run the program, it creates a "vault," you set a password and then open the vault and drag and drop files that you want to encrypt into the window. Close it up and you're encrypted. When you look at the stick, you can see the vault of course, but you cannot open it without opening the program and entering your password.This does NOT encrypt the entire stick, which is as it should be. As many other files as you wish can be kept on the stick in an unencrypted state as well - the vault essential acts like a folder on the drive that's encrypted. It's the easiest and most intuitive process I can think of to provide the service. You can also upgrade to the full version which includes syncing and auto-backup of your encrypted vault. A very nice simple program.Overall, I'm extremely pleased with the stick. My only complaints are that I wish it were smaller, and that the only way to put it on a keychain is using the super-thin lanyard that they enclose (which is a PITA to attach, actually). But those are small complaints. It's fast, roomy, and comes with free encryption software. I love it.

I've checked out a few routers in my day, and in many respects this is the top of the heap, with one annoying issue.Setup is easy, either wired or wireless. Login, follow the instructions for basic setup and you're good. If you want to get in and make changes to specific parts of the router, that's easy as well, as long as you understand the system of course. Every aspect of the router is fully configurable, as it should be at this level.This simultaneously runs a 2.4 GHz network and a 5 GHz network, as most good routers do now. The 5 GHz provides faster theoretical connections though range isn't as solid as the 2.4 GHz. However, running on 5 GHz, assuming your wireless device supports it, gets you off the crowded 2.4 GHz band, which may be an advantage for you. Both networks can have their own names and passwords, so it's easy to assign each to different people or networks if you wish.The router also offers a guest network as well, running on 2.4 GHz. This is where my one complaint with the AC 1200 lies. Rather that setting up an third network secured by a standard encrypted password, it's an unencrypted network that you must use a web page to enter the password in. So your guests select the network, then open up a web browser and try to go anywhere but are blocked until they enter the password into a web page. I find this system to be ridiculous, frankly. I don't want to have to explain to friends such a silly system - I'm not Starbucks or a hotel for goodness sake. I just want to say "log onto network a, use password b." That's how my Archer C5 works, and it's a great system and all of my kids' friends are able to connect to Wi-Fi easily, without me worrying about our network security.In range and signal strength tests against my Archer it's a toss up on the 2.4 range, with both having excellent coverage and range, though the Linksys does have a slight edge in 5 GHz network signal.Additional feature-wise, the Linksys is packed with goodies like the eSATA and USB 3.0 connection for external storage, and the ability to run OpenWRT, the open source Linux-based OS. That's a great feature if you are really going to geek out with this thing.So in the end its a super solid router with excellent range and signal strength, great build quality and a full suite of advanced features. If you're looking for a basic and fast router for your home network, you may be better off spending a bit less money on something comparable but with less features, but if you're looking for all the goodies and can excuse the guest network implementation, the AC1200 is definitely worth a look.5 stars - 1 for the guest network

I like bluffing games. I'm not great at them, because despite thinking I know when someone is lying, I'm not. But I still love bluffing games. Add in foam guns and being members of a gang that turn on each other and you've got my idea of fun.It's a simple set-up: you've just pulled off a robbery and you and your cohorts have all decided you want more than just  your share. Who gets shot and who gets away with the loot? It all comes down to bluffing and a bit of luck.Along the way, there's plenty of. opportunity for players to channel their inner De Niro, Buscemi, Madsen or Fiorentino.It's a fast play, fun and full of laughs. It's also best with more players. Yes, you do point guns at each other, but listening to your wife telling you not to "crack wise or you're gonna get it, see," pretty much dissolves any pretense of actual violence (the silly orange tips on the guns help, too).

They say if you build a better mousetrap the world will beat a path to your door. If that's true, it's going to get crowded outside this company's offices,  because this IS better.I've tried humane traps repeatedly to no avail, and needed to get serious about de-mousing my workshop, so I finally caved and went with the other option. However, I hated the idea of poisoning for a couple of reasons, and whatever method I chose had to be as humane as possible - I think this Victor is it.The bar has enough power to dispatch mice quickly and as humanely as I'd think possible under the circumstances, and the bait area is more than sufficient.But the reason I find this particular trap to be "better" is the way it's set: I used to hate setting the old style snap traps and haven't messed with one since, because I always thought I would end up snapping one on myself (ok  - I was a kid when I last set one, so maybe it's an unreasonable fear, but I still hate them). This trap doesn't require setting a trip bar across the open snapper: you just pull the bar back until it clicks, and never have to risk getting your fingers smacked. Fantastic.Disposal is equally easy as setting, and the thing is all plastic so it's easily washable if necessary.A great basic solution for mice that works, is humane, and is reasonably priced.

I've gone through a LOT of cases for all of my phones over the last few years, and this one ranks up near the top.First, it looks really nice (I have the clear-ish one), and is a great change from the typical cases most people have. It goes on and removes easily as well, but still holds the phone extremely securely.Construction is excellent, and protection is solid despite not adding an undue amount of bulk to the phone. All cutouts for the ports and IR lens are cleanly cut and perfectly positioned, There is no kickstand, but I've never used the ones I had, so that wasn't an issue for me at all.Yes, I dropped my phone while the UAG case was on. Twice. On tile floors. Both times accidentally (there's only so far I'll go to do a review, and purposely dropping a $600 phone is over my line). How did it do? No problems whatsoever, not a mark on the phone OR the case, and no issues cropped up whatsoever.Combined with the water resistance of the S5, the UAG gives me all the protection I can reasonably ask for and looks great doing it. A winner of a case

Here's the thing: I always approach headphones from a quality of sound angle. Maybe it's because I was a recording engineer, maybe because I listen to music almost constantly - it doesn't matter why though: sound comes first, everything else follows.And that explains my three star rating. The sound is just SO not up to par. The bass is fine, I'll give them that, but the midrange is missing and the high end is completely inaccurate. It was a rather bizarre experience actually: I put them on and they sounded really hollow making me feel like my ears were almost being sucked out into them.I compared them to a huge range of headphones and earbuds, and they came up way short of all of them. Which is too bad, because functionally they're really good. The built-in mic works really well, and the controls are easy to find and use. They've avoided the trap of putting the mic on the cable, and for gaming they're really great. They do come with cables that will allow them to be used with a phone as well as a computer, so they're really flexible, too.But, like I said, for me it's all about the sound and these don't make the grade in that regard. If I were only concerned with gaming I'd give them a four star rating for sure, but since I use headphones for games, phone calls and a ton of music, these just don't rate more than a three.

Fire pits are pretty basic affairs. Four legs, a bowl, a grate, a top, and a tool to lift the top when it's hot.What it comes down to in the end is how well it's built and how nice it looks, and in this case I think it rates above average on both counts.Assembly was simple: remove four nuts from each of the four leg positions, place the legs over the bolts, and replace the nuts to hold them in place. Flip the thing over, then drop the bowl into the middle of the circle of tiles, place the grate in the bowl, attach the handle to the top and you're done.The hardware is sturdy and heavy duty, as are the legs, so I have no issues there. Each leg has a foot screwed into the bottom which is an excellent touch: you can adjust them for height if you wish, but the major benefit is keeping any potential rust from the legs from staining brick or concrete. A nice touch.The grill is sturdy and sprayed black, as is the bowl, and the top is not nearly as flimsy as some I've seen. The tile work around the perimeter looks nice and has a suitable rustic feel to it, though for some bizarre reason the grout is tinted pink. Not a fan there - but at least it isn't a bright pink...NOTE: It is NOT rustproof, and the instructions recommend covering it with a vinyl cover when not in use. I suspect that other fire pits come with the same caveat though, so it's not a big deal.Pink grout aside, this is a well-made fire pit that is easy to assemble, looks good and works well. If you're looking for a nice fire pit and can live with pinkish grout, this makes a nice choice.

I had no idea of what to expect here, so I was extremely surprised to find out how much I enjoy this. In short, the point is to help you learn to calm your mind in the hope that the effects will carry through to one's day to day life, and in my experience that's what has happened.Setup is pretty simple: download the app, link it via Bluetooth, and follow the instructions that are clearly and calmly spoken via the app. They recommend using headphones, and I'd concur, though earbuds are a much better idea so that you don't jostle the headband.Getting the headband properly reading all five sensors is critical. Thankfully, I'm bald, and it was easy. However, it did appear that I was losing contact with a couple of them, but I wasn't - I was just moving around a bit (which defeats the idea of calming down, so my bad). Once I was still, all five sensors read clearly and solidly.Once the sensors are set, you go though a calibration process in which you think of as many things as you can in specific categories (the app suggests them), then you begin to work on calming yourself.The app indicates increased brain activity by using both auditory and visual cues. This can start a cycle of overthinking of course, but that's a good thing: once you get how to calm yourself back down those skills can be used any time at all. At the end of a pre-selected time (they suggest starting at 3 minutes), you see how much of the time your brain spent in various stages of activity. As you work with the device and software, you learn how to increase the amount of time you're calm and decrease needless activity.As for real-world results, I definitely find that I am less anxious and more content to move calmly through my day when I use the Muse regularly. My calm times have gone up, and with them the amount of balance I've found each day.Meditation is a proven way to help reduce anxiety and increase clarity, so it's no surprise that it works while using the Muse. The question is, can you get the same results without the Muse? I'd say certainly you can. But if you, like I, can get slightly obsessional (am I doing this right? Am I really calm or just thinking I'm calm?), or if you'd simply like actual data on how you're doing, Muse is a great tool. I love it.

I wanted to enjoy these fellows - I've reviewed some Jabra ear buds in the past and found them to be excellent: sadly, they were stolen (or lost) while I was in a hospital room in an induced coma (who does that?). Unfortunately, these don't come close in sound or comfort.First off, the manual is wrong: if you hold the multi function button down and wait for it to tell you it's pairing, you'll be waiting a long time. It simply lets you know it's on. Once you realize that, pairing is smooth and quick.They come mounted with the mid-sized ear cups mounted, and these were too small for me. Getting a good seal is absolutely essential to getting any bass response, so I swapped them out for the large. Things went better then, but I still had trouble getting a good seal (maybe my ears are wacky?) but was able to at last. It was during this process that the first negative popped up: they're kind of a pain to get on. I'm aware that the fact I wear glasses doesn't help, but I still found it uncomfortable to put these into my ears far enough to get a seal as the black plastic electronics section would irritate my outer ear.I did, however, get them on and sealed and get going with them. After all the work, I was disappointed in the sound. At first blush it seemed alright, but almost immediately the over-accentuated mids made their presence known, and I found the treble shrill and less than optimal. Those two things combined with a distinct lack of bass left me wanting my old Jabras back badly.I had a few ergonomic problems as well: while I was glad they put the controls on the cord and not an earpiece, and while it was easy to figure out what button was what, it hangs behind the ear and over the shoulder, making it a bit of an awkward reach. Worse, though, is the fact that since they are worn with the cable behind the neck, sitting in a chair can easily tug them and move the earphones irritatingly in the ears. Bummer.I had no problem with battery life or pairing, so functionally they worked as they should. But the ergonomic and audio issues let me down sufficiently that I don't think I'll be reaching for them any time soon, unless I'm running (which I rarely do any more due to an injury): getting rid of the cord in that case may make the other issues bearable for a bit.Perhaps there are better ears out there fitment wise, and perhaps some will enjoy the sound profile. For me though, they're a pass.

So first off, yay for more female heroes. It's refreshing to read a crime thriller in which the protagonist isn't a (usually) misogynistic egotistical superman with a heart. Alexandra Hemingway is a 6-foot tall, pregnant, highly educated and independently wealthy NYC cop on the hunt for a serial killer of children, partnered with a highly decorated veteran detective that has a bit of a father complex for Alex.Not the freshest idea on the block of course, but not so bad, either. The problem for me, character-wise, is that Pobi has chosen to make Alex a tough-talking chick "with balls" as her partner says. So we get the same tired tough-talking cop cliches but with less penis. And that's too bad: I'd have liked to have a female NYC detective that actually read like an Ivy League-educated trust fund recipient rather than a rich girl trying to act like Dirty Harry.There are problems with the mechanics here, too (warning: very minor early-pages spoiler coming). In the opening of the book, two young men try to carjack Alex on her way to work. She guns them both down, of course (with the requisite tough-guy lines spoken as she does so) then heads to work. Apparently, there was no need to say put and deal with the scene that she caused, nor was it necessary to file reports, turn in her gun after the shooting, sit down to explain it to her captain, meet with IAD etc. etc. In what version of New York do two young black men get gunned down in the street by a white cop without there being at least some investigation? Not the one I grew up with, notwithstanding the cell phone video tape shot by tourists (to whom Hemingway flipped the bird, to further establish her cliched tough-girl anti-authority street cred).There are many other less egregious examples, as when Hemingway meets a character that owns a Beretta handgun. She lets us know immediately that Berettas are useless unless you throw them at someone, and that the owner knew nothing about guns and bought the most expensive one thinking that would make it the best. Which is simply bizarre to anyone that has even a passing knowledge of guns.Odd things ranging from stupid (the Beretta commentary) to unbelievable (that opening scene - in fact the prologue contains even more bizarre leaps that didn't quite make sense)WTF? How did this get by? It make thoroughly pepper "American Woman" and, while some may not effect the overall story, they took me right out of the narrative while I thought "s no sense." Some sections bothered me enough that I reread them thinking I must have missed something or misread it. Nope - they were just... not great.That's too bad, too. Because Pobi has a good story here, and some of the characters are beautifully drawn. As others have said, it can be a tough read due to the tortures visited upon the 10-year-old victims, but I'd have liked to enjoy this book absent so many glaring oddities that took me out of the story.In the end, what started out with a nice premise devolved into what I've read too many times before and, while I was interested in the story and wanted to stay on board to the end, I don't think I'll remember the name or the plot of this book in a few months.

OK. Yes. The idea explained on the cover of a disease ravaging the world that causes people to forget things like how to breath sounds like a great setup for an apocalyptic thriller.  And no, the disease doesn't really matter at all here, which is a lost opportunity (it sets up a trip to a research center 8 miles under the sea - that's about it). But the question is, does the story that proceeds from there make the book a worth read?Well, yes and no. The first two thirds of the book I enjoyed. Not "oh man, this is incredible" enjoyed, but definitely "wonder what's going to happen next" enjoyed. I mean, it kept me in to the end, which is something a really poorly written book would not.While Cutter's descriptions of claustrophobia and the creeping horror under the sea were solid, the problem for me lay in the inclusion of too many cliches, combined with some logical leaps and behaviors that I didn't particularly go along with. As the book progresses, things devolve quite a bit for the characters, and there's a slide toward either insanity or the invasion of psyches by some external force (you'll have to read to find out which). But by the end of the book, things had unspooled to such an bizarre extent that it felt like the author was trying (and failing) to channel both Barker and King.I found myself just getting a bit exhausted, frankly. Cutter has a hell of an imagination, and he's quite good at laying out some fairly unpleasant imagery, but for The Deep it would have helped to get it all in check just a bit.

First important thing: despite it not being mentioned in the description, this IS a dual link DVI cable and has no problem giving me full 2560 x 1440 resolution on my 27" monitor.One of the things about a 27" monitor, by the way, is that they're 27". A monitor that large requires a fair amount of space, and the distance from it to my computer could barely be spanned my my standard cable - this almost absurdly long one solved that problem neatly.Construction is excellent. It's think and strong without giving up flexibility, and the connectors are solidly attached and feel extremely strong as well. The screws are well made and turn easily, and the pins were all aligned perfectly on my cable.All in all, a great value for a beautifully-made cable that gives me extra flexibility for monitor placement.I wouldn't hesitate to recommend these AmazonBasics cables, and they'll be the first brand I'll  be checking out when looking for cabling in the future.

You'd think there isn't much to say about memory cards, and you'd be right. But what little there is can be extremely relevant.Obviously you want a card that is well built so that it can stand up to being taken in and out of devices, dropped in bags, etc. The Samsung passes with flying colors, feeling a bit heavier and more substantial than other cards I have. The lock switch is smooth and easy to move as well. It looks nice, too, which may not matter when it's in a camera, but it's still a nice plus, and the white and orange color scheme make it easy to find in a bag.But where the rubber hits the road is in speed: can it keep up with shooting multiple stills as well as HD video? In the case of the Samsung, I found no problems at all and it was able to keep up with whatever I was doing, whether in my Canon EOS or my Sony HX300.However, as another reviewer said, when tested, the Samsung has a great read speed, but the write speed is  lower than some competing cards which may result in a slow down when the buffer on the camera is full. However, when I used the card that didn't hobble me - perhaps if I had the fastest shooting camera on the market it would, I don't know.A fast, sturdy, good looking card with a 32 GB capacity for under 20 bucks?  For consumers and those with anything outside of the cutting edge camera equipment, I'd call that a great deal.

There are two main aspects of this case that need to be looked at: protection and the claim that it makes your iPhone louder. Incredibly, Speck delivers in both areas.Why incredibly? Because people have been making claims like Speck's since health potions were sold from the backs of wagons, and they've rarely delivered. In the case of this Speck case though, there's been no false advertising claimes I've been able to see. Slapping an iPhone into this thing really DOES deliver a huge increase in volume. Is it double? I don't know - but I do know I have to ask my daughter to turn down the music despite the fact that the door is closed. That's impressive.As for protection, the Speck delivers here as well. My daughter has confessed to dropping her iPhone "a bunch of times" but there has been no damage whatsoever suffered. I consider that a huge win - she's killed more than her share of iProducts (both phones and pods).For me though, there's one fact that really closes the deal for me. Not only has it survived my daughter's less-than-optimum care, not only do I have to tell her to turn it down  through a closed door, there's this: she's been using it steadily since I put it on her iPhone over a month ago. Is there higher praise?

I've gone through a lot of cases in my day and frankly, I change it up a lot. I get bored, to be honest, and want to change the look and feel of my phone fairly often. But I'm never willing to forgo quality, and with the Otterbox there's absolutely no worries there.Keep in mind that the GS5 is pretty big to begin with. Not Galaxy Note big, but no lightweight, either. So by definition, you're going to be pushing the limits of your pockets (I don't do holsters) no matter what case you drop the phone into. And that being the case, if you're going to make the phone considerably bigger, you'd better at least be gaining a ton of protection. On this, the Otterbox delivers.Fit and finish are both excellent. The case goes on easily but holds the phone tightly. All cutouts are clean and perfectly positioned, and the button overlays are easy to use and positioned accurately. It's a two-part case, with an inner synthetic rubber sleeve (synthetic rubber?) and an outer polycarbonate shell. The Otterbox also includes an excellent screen protector that is cut accurately and, if applied correctly, is effectively un-noticable. The combined effect made me feel like my S5 was as indestructible as possible for a modern smart phone, and I was extremely impressed.However, I don't use it every day. As I said, the phone is big to start, and it's made bigger with the Otterbox. For my usage, I prefer a slimmer TPU case. BUT - were I out on the road more often, and certainly if I'm going on a trip, I think the Otterbox is unbeatable. It's tough, good looking, and adds as little bulk as possible to provide the level of protection it delivers.If you tend to drop your phone a fair amount and need a good, tough case - the Otterbox is a great choice.

This is my first stand-up paddleboard (SUP) and I love it. I have borrowed friends' before and enjoyed it, but I'm no expert at all. This thing suited me perfectly.First of all, it's inflatable, which means I can store it easily and don't need a roof rack to get it to the water. Great. It comes with a large backpack-style bag that holds the board, pump, fins and leash, making it relatively easy to lug to the water (it ain't light, I can tell you that). It inflates quickly and easily as well. So how does it work?Really, really well. It's extremely stable and neither I nor anyone else in my family had any problems getting on and paddling around. We tried it in the Intracoastal, which is calm and easy going, as well as the ocean - and it was equally at home in either. The stability does come at the price of speed, but that's a very fair trade off, and yes, you can catch waves with it.The downers? Well it's pretty spendy, but not having used any other inflatables I don't know if the extra money buys features or quality others don't have. Also, it does NOT come with a paddle. Not a deal-breaker of course, but something you may want to know.  Finally, it's not as easy getting it BACK in the back after deflating it as it was when it arrived all flat and nice. But it CAN be done.All in all it's a really nice board and I've had lots of fun with it. I expect to keep having tons of fun for quite a while.

Why surprisingly? Because the way they're marketed, I was expecting absurdly bass-boosted headphones that would wreck the balance of the music like some other brands do. Instead, I got a set that with some sources bested my Sennheiser HD 580s. Here are the relevant bits:Fist of all, construction is exceptional. They're heavy and well-built without being too much to bear on my head. They come with not one but TWO cords: a longer one with a coiled section perfect for use at home (or if you're a DJ), and a shorter straight cord for use with MP3 players and phones. Very thoughtful.The cords themselves are obviously removable (good) but they can be plugged into either ear cup (great). The plugs themselves are extremely high quality and attach by plugging in to the ear cup of choice and then rotating 90 degrees to lock them in (fantastic). No worries about the cord accidentally getting pulled out.Comfort is quite good. Not as plush as my 580s, but I had no problem using them for extended periods of time. Which is something I wanted to do because they sound really, really good.As I mentioned before, there is no absurd bass boost here, despite the marketing. What there is instead is a very smooth, very accurate representation of source material. If your material is bass-heavy, these can handle it no problem, but they aren't going to make The Beatles sound like P Funk - which is a good thing. The low to mid range were not muddy at all, with each instrument easily picked out and not getting lost. Mids were accurate and not accentuated, and the high end was sweet and clear without being harsh.As I said, on some source material I found these preferable to my HD580s which is high praise indeed. In fact, it was only when listening to older jazz material like the Ahmad Jamal Trio recorded live at the Pershing in 1959 where I found myself wanting to return to my Sennheisers, which delivered more air and a wider sound stage, feeling almost like I wasn't wearing headphones.But I was extremely impressed otherwise. These are beautifully built, well though-out, come with multiple cables and a nice carrying case, are efficient enough to be driven by an MP3 player but work great with a stereo (they come with a mini-to-1/4" adapter as well) and sound fantastic. If you had asked me if I thought Pioneer would pull of a trick like this I would have said "not a chance - they'll be bassy and muddy" - but I would have been very, very wrong.Great job Pioneer. Really.

So here's the deal: I've reviewed more than a few sets of headphones and earbuds. I was a recording engineer and record producer for a while and I'm pretty picky about sound, so I tend to check out new sets looking for a nice surprise sound quality-wise. Sadly, these did not deliver.Construction wise they're pretty alright. Seem well-made, fold up small, fit in the football-shaped case that's included. The cord is removable (good), but can only be plugged into the left ear (less good). The Star Wars branding is really nicely done, and the swag is ok I suppose, but none of that means a thing if you can't get good use out of the headphones, and there are two reasons that just wasn't happening for me.First, they just aren't very comfortable. The band over the top is thinly padded and the cups are on the small size, making the grippiness intrude on the listening experience.Second, the sound is just nowhere near where it should be for a set of headphones like this. The upper mids are strong, but bass and lower mids are muddy and lack definition. The high end is attenuated, making it sound like a cloth has been tossed between the cups and my ears when I compare it to other sets I have on hand (Sennheiser HD580s and Pioneer SE-MX9s which I'll be reviewing when I'm finished with this piece). The one nice thing I can say is they are extremely efficient, making it no problem to use a portable music device to drive them sufficiently.In the end though, as much as I'd like to love them, it looks like all the care went into making a package they could sell to Star Wars fans rather than important things like long-term comfort and sound quality.

I've used Movie Studio before and found it effective and rock steady - version 13 is no different, though the learning curve can be a bit steep.Installation was a breeze and went quickly. Startup is relatively fast, and once in the program you're presented with  multiple ways to get started, tutorials, etc. Help bubbles are on by default, which is helpful.As far as functionality, the program just works. Once you get your head around how to use it (there are plenty of tutorials out there to help) the workflow makes sense and things move along quickly. It handles all relevant formats, including 4K video, which is fantastic. The included filters and plugins are extensive and useful, and really I can't see most users outgrowing this software unless you're moving into a professional setting.Then you've got music - which is a huge bonus. In addition to Sound Forge, which is an incredibly solid and useful music editing program, Acid Music Studio is included, which makes it relatively easy and fun to create your own music for your video projects.Frankly, I'm blown away by how much value is in this package - great video editing, audio editing, audio recording/creation and dvd authoring that would destroy far more expensive programs that were out only a few years ago. To get this package at this price is a steal, and I can recommend it wholeheartedly.

Here's the deal: the period in McCartney's life from the Beatles break up to John's death has always had some mystery around it. I mean, we all know he was busted in Japan, we all know he was working on a record when he heard about John's death (and wrote one of his best pieces of music ever about his relationship with John - "Here Today" which is just heartbreaking), and we all know about the Wings mishegas. But beyond that, what was going on?This book provides the background that McCartney fans have been wondering about for years. Author Tom Doyle had conversations with McCartney for years in preparation for this book and it shows. He gained a level of trust from his subject that allowed him to provide an honest and revealing look at not only what happened, but what McCartney was feeling and thinking all those years.If you're a Beatles fan, particularly if you fall down on the McCartney side of thing, this book is fascinating. A great read!

I've had some poor luck with suction cup holders, and had pretty much given up on them. Then the Arkon arrived, and my opinion changed (and my mood improved).This thing just works - which is really all I was looking for: something that will work on the windshield or dash, is easy to position, and will hold whatever phone I happen to be using with no issues. I've used it with my Galaxy S3, which I've since changed to an S5, and it held both perfectly, even with a TPU case on my S5.Easy on, easy off, holds stuff steady. Excellent.

UPDATE: After less than a year, this thing completely fell apart. Started with leaks at the ends, then spread to leaks throughout so bad that it no longer worked at all. JUNK.Original Review: I've always thought these lightweight expanding hoses were a gimmick that preyed on people like my mother-in-law: she'll buy anything, really, and went through a couple of these things with horrible results. And while that may be true of many of the hoses in this class, that has NOT been my experience with the Rumford.This thing has been fantastic since the day I got it. There is a procedure to using it of course, which some may not like: close the valve on the delivery end (a really well-made brass valve, not a piece of crap), then turn on the water at the source - allow the hose to pressurize and expand.
