After use, shut off the water source and open the valve to allow it to empty and contract again.Since we've had it, this thing was worked flawlessly, expanding to its full length and allowing me to get where I need to, while contracting to a tight and easily hung up size when I'm done: at last, I could throw away that crappy crank on wheels contraption that I kept my old-school hose on.The only downside is that when you extend it fully, then use it, the decrease in pressure can cause it to contract (and therefore shorten)  a bit, so the actual useable length isn't quite it's fully extended size. But that's a small complaint, and overall I love this thing. If you like the idea of an expanding hose, stay away from the crappy ones you see in front of the supermarket or at big box stores and jump right into this one: it's great.

We have a new Samsung dishwasher that actually requires using a rinse agent, so getting my hands on Finish was great. It works as well or better than the other major player, allowing glasses and silverware to not only come out with greatly reduced spots, but lets us empty the dishwasher faster because things are dryer sooner.Some of the Circulon dishwasher-safe pots that I've cleaned still came out a bit spotty, but that's true of any rinse agent I've used. Definitely makes a huge difference when compared to no agent though. Highly recommended.

I received the wired version for review, so I cannot comment on the Bluetooth version, but the wired version is pretty good.While the trend these days is to overdrive bass (e.g. Beats by Dre), the Adaros for the most part avoid that trap. For me, that's a good thing; I was an engineer and producer and value flat and true to booming bass. This isn't to say the Adaros are totally flat, because they aren't: bass is boosted a bit and the mids and highs could be a bit smoother. But in today's market, these are among the best you can get in this price range.Comfort wasn't there for me though. I found the ear cups a bit small and hot, and the head band didn't have enough padding for me: it felt like something hard was pushing into the top of my head. A drag, because I'd love to use these when I go for a bike ride or long walk as they are easily efficient enough to be driven by an MP3 player or cell phone and blow away ear buds away.Which may well be why they get as many glowing reviews as they do: for people raised on those crappy ear buds, these things will be a revelation.Overall, they're fairly well built (though a replaceable cord would be nice) and sound pretty good for something in this price range. If comfort isn't an issue (I have a fairly large head) and you like the trend towards a fuller, accentuated bass sound but find Beats to be too much, give these a shot. However, if you want something that more accurately represents what the artist and producer intended and that are (in my opinion) more comfortable, check out the AKG K240s in the same price range.

Anyone that suffers heartburn even occasionally knows that fast relief is key - and these Zantac tablets deliver. I've been woken up in the middle of the night with heartburn and a Zantac clears it up in minutes, allowing me to get back to sleep. A great product.

It's not easy finding treats for our dog that aren't of questionable quality, so I was excited for her to try these; they're made with no artificial colors or preservatives, there's no sugar or grain in them, and they're made in the US, not in a questionable factory on the other side of the world.Of course, none of that means a thing if our dog dislikes them, but she LOVES them. They keep her busy for a while, too, though perhaps not as long as I would hope.She had no side effects other than blue-tinted poop, so she (and I) are really happy with them. The only downside is the price, which averages over $3.50 per treat and worth dinging a star for . Still, they may well be worth it for an occasional (the manufacturer - of course - recommends a bone a day, which would run $100 per month!) treat .

The first thing to keep in mind when you're looking at this monitor is that although it's a 27", the resolution, AT 1920 X 1080  isn't any better than on a good 24'. That's not a bad thing as long as you know it going in; you aren't going to be able to fit more information on the screen than any other (smaller physically) 1920 x 1080 screen. However, what you get is pretty darn nice.Clarity and color rendering are quite good. Not up to par for graphic design of course, but this wasn't built with that in mind. The screen is matte, not glossy, so it's resistant to reflections - I like this quite a bit. The screen tilts, but is NOT height adjustable, which is a bit of a drag, and the stand feels just a bit on the small side for the size of the monitor.Inputs are via VGA (a bit of a waste) and HDMI, which is the way I went and which netted a nice full HD picture. There is NO DVI in put, which can be an issue for some people and is a bit of a minus.If you need a super high-res monitor, or work with graphics and photos a lot, this isn't for you. But if you're looking for a nice, bright, clear 27" monitor that does every day jobs quite well and at a bargain price, this is worth a look.

This is my second Powerline adapter kit, and I love it. We have a house that doesn't particularly like passing WiFi signals so, for example, my daughter's room is left in the cold. I used this adapter to replace an older one that was in her room that served to feed a second WiFi router, allowing her to have a network for her phone, computer and Roku box.Setup is quick and easy: plug it in to the two outlets, wait for them to connect, and plug in your Ethernet cables. I've had a fast and dependable connection since setting them up and anticipate no problems. I've also used them to connect a PS3 to my router via Ethernet, as the WiFi always seemed slow to me - connection speed and dependability improved immediately and substantially.If you need to add a new or extend your existing network, or need to get an Ethernet port to an electronic device nowhere near your router, this is a great choice.

I'm not a huge chai tea drinker, but I've been known to tip a cup now and then. And really, this is a lot better than I expected I'd get from my Keurig.The flavor is pretty right on for chai - maybe a tiny bit weaker than I expected, though I do tend to brew the biggest size cup available, so that's really in my hands. The only real issue I have is the sweetness: it's conveniently already sweet, but it's a bit over the top for me. My daughter loves it, but I wish it were dialed back just a bit, allowing me the flexibility to get the sweetness where I want it.But other than that, it's really good and obviously extremely convenient. If you're looking for a nice chai tea to make in your Keurig and you like your chai sweet, I recommend giving the Lipton a shot.

Frankly, I can't believe the quality manufacturers are pulling off at a reasonable price point. I've gone through quite a few audio interfaces in my day, and this is up at the top of those in my home studio -- and I've honestly never been a big fan of M-Audio in the past.It's solidly built and flexible. All inputs sound dead quiet, and the mic pres are pretty darn good. I'm not retiring my Joe Meek outboard pre yet (a personal love affair of mine), but if I didn't have it handy I'd have no issues using these phantom powered-equipped ones. The four inputs make this a great box for doing scratch recordings home or on location with a band as well, so I'm really not complaining.Finally, latency is next to nothing, which is a big, big deal for me (as, I suppose, it is for everyone). The Avid software that comes with it is useful for basic recording, though not, obviously, on a par with the major players in the space.But for the price, I can't see doing better. Well built, plenty of inputs, transparent, phantom power, low latency... a great choice.

This is a wonderful DAC. I've used it both with a Marantz CD player's digital out and a MacMini playing HD audio files, and in both cases performance is stellar.Soundstage is full and deep, and imaging has been excellent across the board, particularly with some 3 piece jazz albums I've played. As another reviewer has said, it's fun to go back through my library and listen through the UD-501 - with some of the material it's like hearing it for the first time again.It handles a wide variety of formats, is well built, sounds amazing and looks beautiful on my shelf. Plus, it handles DSD files for under a grand. I'm not sure what more I could ask for. A huge win for Teac.

Bigger than the standard box of this class, these 12 x 25 boxes give plenty of room for extra files, paperwork, magazines, etc. I'm clearing all the papers out of my office but obviously can't toss them, and these are the perfect storage solution.Extra well built and reinforced, the string closure works great and avoids messy tape. There's an extra piece of cardboard in the bottom to provide extra strength as well, which is nice.Finally, the lift easy and stack perfectly. My new go-to box.

I've been spending quite a bit of time lately watching UK crime dramas. Sherlock, Luther, Broadchurch - all quite fantastic shows. So I was hoping for a bit more of the same with Jack Taylor. And it's good, but not quite as good as the others I've mentioned.Taylor is an ex-guard, fired for hitting a politician, with a drinking problem. While the cliches don't end with that initial premise, Iain Glen's portrayal of the flawed protagonist kept me watching through all three films, and I'm glad I did - the second and third installments were both better than the initial outing, which felt to be trying a bit to hard to define Taylor's character all at once, as opposed to letting it unfold naturally over time.But that's not too much to put up with for the payoff of a pretty good group of films. The settings are fantastic, it's well shot, and the I've always been a sucker for a characters that actually have human failings and struggles.In the end, Glen doesn't quite pull of amazing performance that David Tennants turned in as Alec Hardy, but Jack Taylor isn't Broadchurch either. But if you're looking for a gritty UK-based mystery series with fine acting and and an enjoyable group of stories (particularly the last two), this might just be your cuppa.

This is a pretty simple tool - a stick, six massage balls and some straps on the end - but its been really nice to have around.Construction is quite good, and it's easy to reconfigure the stick however you want it. The larger of the balls are a bit soft, while the small yellow ones are much firmer. I've found it's fantastic on by back, neck and thighs, as well as doing solid duty as a foot massage device.The handles are comfortable to hold, and the straps are high quality and well attached, allowing me to give myself a pretty great massage when I can't convince a family member to help me out.I've never used one of these, but I'm certainly glad I gave it a try (as is anyone nearby that gets a quick back massage courtesy of the SKLZ). I can't compare it to others in the market, but this one is well made, feels like it will last quite a while, and has done everything I've asked of it.

I'm going to say right out that unlike many people, I prefer the Playstation controller shape to that of the Xbox, so going into this the SC-1 was at a disadvantage.  That said though, this wasn't a bad bit of kit, but it's not a total winner either.Right off the bat, you'll be disappointed to know this requires a dongle. For those that don't want to give up a USB slot, or have their PS3 positioned where a permanent USB stick could cause problems, this can be a bad thing. One past that though, it works pretty much like any other controller.Charge time is relatively quick, and the battery seems to last plenty long - perhaps not as long as my PS3 controllers' but it's fine.Construction is ok - not amazing, but not junk. Buttons and switches have a firm, positive feel and are easily controlled. I personally do not like the shape of the R1 and L1 buttons, but that's a personal matter.Turbo mode works fine, as does the limited macro programming (chaining together multiple moves and assigning them to a single button). However for me, I prefer to just play using my (limited) skill sets; if I can't win on my own, I'm OK losing.In the end, it's not a bad option for people who want an Xbox controller on their PS3, particularly if they'd enjoy the turbo feature. For me though, it's not my first choice. Perhaps I'm just used to the PS3 shape, but the design coupled with the lack of Bluetooth connectivity have kept this one in the controller storage box more often than not.

I'm new to the projector world, so I have no real way to compare this bad boy to other models, but I can say this: it is great.I've used it in the two environments one might expect: work and home, and it performed beautifully in both.It's light and easy to carry from room to room (or to head outside to the yard), as well as from home to office. Once in your destination, it's also easy to set up and get running. Horizontal, vertical and focus adjustments are all manual, but extremely easy to execute, and once in place you'll be ready to start in no time.The projector provides a decent range of inputs, though it is missing DVI, so computers without an HDMI output won't be able to run in 720P. However, for DVD players and computers that have an HDMI out, you'll be treated to a really wonderful picture. I've used it in office environments that weren't exactly dark, and the Epson provided plenty of brightness to get the job done.But it really comes alive at home - in a dark room this thing looks just great. I've used it in the living room and finished basement with great results, and last weekend set up an outdoor movie viewing party for my kids, using a screen borrowed from my cousin. Extremely impressive performance at a 10' screen size. In fact, it's been fantastic in every environment.The only downside is the lack of an audio output. While the built-in speaker is ok for some uses, a real stereo pair (or more) is pretty much necessary for a movie, so you'll have to use an audio out from your source.But that's a small tradeoff when the picture is this good. I'd ding it a half star for no audio out, but the rest of the package is so impressive that this has certainly earned a solid five star ranking.

I've had a lot of Android phones, and while this isn't the very best, there are things about it I like more than any others I've had.To begin with, form factor is excellent. Compared to my Galaxy SIII, it's narrower - but that makes it far easier to hold and text one-handed - something I'm fond of doing. The back of the phone is also nicely textured, minimizing the chances I'll drop it (I've, um, dropped my GSIII due to it's slick and sexy back).Verizon bloatware is extreme though - and some of it caused a major problem for me until I updated it. One of the apps was failing and throwing error after error message (on screen, too - not some hidden file) that could not be cleared. Like I said, once I updated it, the problem stopped - but it should be noted that Verizon was NO HELP fixing this at all - they were utterly clueless about this phone. And once that was resolved, I was still stuck with a bunch of crappy software I didn't want and couldn't delete which is extremely irritating to me. Sadly, it's all too common these days.The screen is quite good when viewed head on, though it does lose some of it's color accuracy when viewed off-axis. Not a problem for me, but it may be an issue. It's quite bright though, and colors are strong, if a bit on the cool side. The high resolution in a smaller overall screen size may make for slightly smaller type, but it's also sharper than on my GSIII thanks to the smaller pixels. The glass is not up to the quality on my GSIII though - in what way is hard to explain, but it just never feels as smooth and clean. I had no overt issues with it however, and it cleaned up well and suffered no scratches during my time using it.Although the dual-core 1.5GHz Snapdragon chip is slightly underpowered compared to today's fastest phones, I found no issues starting up, opening apps, and running multiple apps. I had no problems with any of the apps I downloaded.Sound is better than I expected. Rather than using an open speaker port, the Hydro Elite transmits sound through the glass on the phone. I found no real downside here, and you actually CAN hear the thing if you're wearing a motorcycle helmet, or hat, or whatever. Very neat bit, that. External speakers for media are, of course, crap - but that's true of every phone I've ever heard, so take it with a grain of salt. Earphone volume, though, is extremely low. While not an issue with headphones, I can't come close to getting enough output for the Aux-in in my car (a total drag) to deliver music to my (admittedly on the loud side) liking.Kyocera runs a skinned version of Android (as almost ever phone on the market does), though I find it less intrusive than the interface on my GSIII. Odd, perhaps, as the GSIII has more bells and whistles, but then I don't really like gimicky features - I just want a phone that works and works well, which the Kyocera does (pretty much).Batter life, which I thought was a bit short, is actually longer than on my GSIII, so no complaints there. Finding spares is a bear though; I couldn't find any vendors that supplied them, so if you like to carry a spare, you're out of luck right now.The 8 MP camera is actually quite good - sometimes. Settings offerings are about average, with different focus, white balance and shooting modes (including color effect modes and HDR), and it often takes beautiful pictures. However, in tricky lighting situations (even mildly), it's totally hit and miss. While shooting a closeup of some soap I recently made, it kept adding an odd purple tinge in the middle of the shot (no, it wasn't a lens flare or smear). Irritating. The front-facing camera is fine - about average in class. One quick note here: you CAN turn off the camera click, which you can't (stock) on my GSIII. Yay Kyocera.Video quality is on par with stills, which is to say that sometimes it's quite good, but in any tricky lighting you're going to be gambling.Then there's the waterproof bit, which is really the meat and potatoes. In a work: excellent. I can't tell you how much I like not worrying about spilling a drink on the table, or leaving it out on a chair in the rain. Plus, it's fun to throw it in a sink of water in front of unsuspecting friends and family. I have submerged it, poured water all over it, even used it in the shower, and have had NO ill-effects. Plus, the chunkiness of the thing makes it feel sturdy enough that I feel far more secure carrying it than I do my GSIII.Frankly, the decision about which to carry is MUCH harder than I thought it would be. I really, really love a lot about this phone - in partiuclar, of course, it's ability to shower with me. But the occasional camera issues and low-level headphone output have me jumping back to my GSIII (particularly if I'm driving anywhere), which is where I'll probably stay. For now.A solid mid-range phone with a fantastic feature: it doubles as a shower buddy!Update 6/18/14 - This phone began having very strange issues after a while - wouldn't answer calls occasionally, odd software glitches, and the camera actually started to look worse. I've downgraded the rating accordingly and would recommend looking elsewhere.

I really like this drive despite having had a few issues getting my head around how, exactly it's set up. Before proceeding I should mention that I've been working on computers and setting up most operating systems (including FreeBSD!) for about 2 decades.Setup in its most basic format is simple as pie: plug it into the wall, plug it into your router, look for it under network on your Windows PC. Easy - acts exactly like another drive, and you can use it from any computer on the network to backup or store files with no hassle at all.However, once you log into the system to check out settings and update firmware, things can get a little confusing. You're asked to set up a username and password for every computer on the network to use. OK - fine. But a folder is created with that user name, which appears alongside a folder named public. And thenceforth, to log onto the drive AT ALL from a local computer, you need to use that username and password - what's odd about that at first is that Public isn't actually public, as you need to log onto the drive to see it.Shortly though, it became clearer: once you set up ANY user at all, the entire drive in not accessible on the network without a password, EXCEPT via DLNA (or anonymous FTP - more on that below). So, in effect, the entire Public folder becomes the main media serving folder for the network, and accessible via any DLNA client. Getting onto the drive itself anywhere including Public requires a username and password.This allows setting up all Public media in one space to stream to devices, while allowing the addition of multiple users with private folders - once logged into the drive using one set of credentials, all that are accessible are the public and individual user folders. It's actually a pretty good way to set it up: the problem was that those details are spelled out exactly nowhere in docs with the drive, or on the Seagate website.Remote access via the Seagate website worked flawlessly, which was nice. It's easy to access any folders from any computer anywhere, as long as you set up a remote user and run the service on the drive. I'm curious about the security here (didn't have time to research it), as you actually log in through Seagate's site - until I know how that works I've turned the service off. But assuming it's entirely secure, it's a neat and easy-to-use feature that does not require you remember your home IP address.Both SFTP and FTP are available as well; using anonymous and a blank password will allow you access to the Public folder only, while using a username and password will drop you into that private folder and allow you to back out to see the entire file structure (assuming that the user has admin privileges).Transfer speeds could be faster. I was getting 10 - 13 MB/s average using Windows transfer and my wireless router as a hub. Yes, it could well have been the router, but I don't have a spare GB hub here to test, sorry. Noise level was extremely low though and was never bothersome at all.All-in-all though, it's an excellent and fairly good looking box that does exactly what I want it to while having a ton of flexibility for people with deeper skill sets. A great buy.

I was hoping for a set of headphones that would be easy to pick up and use with my tablets and phone - perhaps a nice pair for in-bed movie viewing while my wife is asleep. Unfortunately, these ultimately missed the mark.Design is basic, with volume up/down, skip fwd/back and a Bluetooth button all on one side. Setup and connection were easy - I charged them quickly and paired them easily with three different phones and had no problems. Oddly, I could not find any indication of a right/left side on them though; I figured it out but when the skip buttons skipped in the wrong direction. Hint: controls go on the left.Sound quality is actually better than I was expecting - when these were in stock on Amazon I believe they were selling for only about $20. At that price, I was thinking they would be utter garbage, but to my surprise the sound wasn't torturous. My set did not have the buzz that others have complained about, and while the sound lacked detail and upper-mid to high-end clarity resulting in a bit of a boxy feel, overall it was better than I expected; I think that I'd have no problem using them for casual media usage. If I could stand to wear them for more than 10 minutes that is.They're just incredibly uncomfortable to me. While they're fully adjustable, the bar over the top of the head is incredibly under-padded, making it feel as if there's a hard piece of plastic pushing down on top of my head. Loosen them up so the bar doesn't touch and they just sag, of course. I simply could not find a position in which I could stand wearing them for more than 10 minutes, which was an extreme disappointment to me. It's worth mentioning that the ear cups were also made with low-quality padding and a cheap covering material, resulting in no joy for my ears, either - this, though, was a far less egregious ergonomic error, particularly at the price point I noted.In the end, while they certainly aren't studio-quality, the acceptable sound and Bluetooth would make them a steal at only $20. If only they were comfortable...

There's not a lot to say in describing this: it's a thick, squishy rubber mat. But it really does make life easier when I'm standing in one position for an extended period of time.I have bad knees and a bad back (genetics can be pesky, can't they?), and find standing in place for too long can cause a fair amount of pain in those areas. But using this mat actually helps; and I was a real skeptic about it.I use it in the kitchen when cooking or doing dishes, but the real benefit comes in my work studio where I make soap. Soaping requires long periods of time blending, as well as lifting and pouring large quantities of oil. I've found that I have less general aches and pains in my back and knees after a long time at work while standing on this.Really, there's not much more to say: it's a simple tool that does a basic job, and it actually works for me. I've noticed absolutely no changes in thickness or springiness since I started using it either - in fact the ONLY issue I've had is that the "Y" in Stanley came off (they're actually thin black rubber stickers on top of raised yellow letters), but that certainly doesn't effect it's usefulness.A winner.

I had no idea what to expect with this light, but I was hoping for something that would be a nice addition to the house (for me or my kids). However, between the build quality and the feature set, this has made its way into the pile of unused stuff in the garage.To begin with, it feels and looks cheap. That may not be an issue for some, but at this price I can't imagine anyone opening the box and feeling particularly good about the purchase. It's clearly a cheap Chinese import that's being re-sold as a supposedly high-end device. And looks are not entirely deceiving. The buttons have bad tactile feedback, and sometimes it's unclear if they've been pushed or not. While the menu system is pretty simple and easy to set up, the overall usage experience does not build much confidence.In actual use, I was not very impressed either. The gradual increase in light does work as advertised, starting dim and getting brighter, until it's at full brightness at your alarm time, at which point the alarm sounds begin. Theoretically, this would be the way to make it work, but the actual experience isn't great.To begin with, the selection of nature alarm sounds is terrible. You get a choice of three birds, all of which sound fake and distorted - they're annoying scrapey-scratchy-squeaky noises that make my skin crawl in the morning (and bum my dog out). Then, once the unpleasant noises wake you up, you're treated to the fun of looking into the sun while trying to find the button to turn the alarm off, thanks to having the membrane buttons directly above the blinding light. And if you're looking for a snooze feature, don't bother - there isn't one.The kicker is that I could tell no difference in how I felt after getting up using this alarm clock save one: I was irritated from dealing with the thing. I suppose it may have some value as a "light therapy" device, and perhaps some may find the limiting features, annoying design and poor construction worth it for an improvement in their wake-up routine, but I found no such value.

This is about my tenth laptop, but my first 17", and I'm very happy. Before I go on with why, I just want to make one point about the size - it's big. Not heavy and fat (see below) but just... big. As in: I have three different backpacks designed to carry a laptop, and this won't fit in ANY of them. If you're looking for easily portable, look at 15" and smaller. If you're looking for a great desktop replacement and don't mind using a briefcase-style laptop case (or larger than standard laptop backpack) to transport it, read on.First of all, despite my comment above, it's lighter than I thought: under 6 pounds with the battery, which is surprising indeed, and it's fairly thin, at about an inch. The charger is also reasonably-sized, which makes the entire package easy (relative to other 17" units of course) to travel with.The case itself is great - I love the textured finish on it, and it feels extremely sturdy and well-built. There is no latch to keep the laptop closed, instead relying on a hinge that requires both hands to open it. I prefer this setup: I like just popping it open. The finish continues on the inside on the palm rest, and I really like it; it's very comfortable and stays cool.In fact, the whole thing stays cool - quiet too. I truly dislike loud fans spinning up and making a racket almost as much as I dislike burning my lap with computer/heater. But despite having a sufficiently fast chip, this laptop never gets irritating in either department.The screen is quite good, or at least as good as you're going to get without going to an IPS or equivalent screen. I'm usually unhappy with most laptop screens, but this ranks at or near the top of the class.Keyboard quality is excellent: keys have good action and are generously spaced, making typing or using the number pad easy and comfortable. There's a full compliment of media control keys as well (start/pause, skip fwd, skip back, vol up/down) which I appreciate - I hate having to go to a mouse or touchpad to skip tracks.The touchpad is average, with the usual compliments of multitouch, including two-finger scrolling up/down and right/left, plus gestures designed to mimic the gestures one would use on a Windows 8 touchscreen laptop: swipe all the way right to left, the charms pop up, left to right switches between running programs, top to bottom is like a right click, giving the menu and options for the program you're in. For the most part, it accurately reads touches and swipes, though it's not quite as consistent as the best I've used.Battery life was sufficient for me, but not stellar: maybe 3-4 hours. This isn't such a bad thing though: as it's a 17" screen, it's really not the unit I'd choose to run around with all day - it's really more of a desktop replacement that you can cart from home to work, or set up at your hotel when you're on the road. Thus, I have it plugged in as often as not.On-board audio is OK, but not great. No matter what these manufacturers claim, laptops are never going to sound great. I use Bluetooth to connect to an external rig, or headphones if I'm away from my desk.An full set of modern ports is included: 2 USB 3.0 and 2 USB 2.0 ports, an Ethernet port, HDMI out, an 8-in-1 card slot and a headset port in which either a combined mic/headphone or headphone-only rig will work. Of course there's also a DVD reader/writer for installing software and burning DVDs or CDs.I've touched on performance, but want to expound just a bit. I find performance excellent, as long as I'm not asking it to do what it really isn't meant to do. Booting is reasonably fast (it's only got a 5400 RPM drive), and restore from sleep is quick.Program performance as well as base operating system performance are both snappy - I can switch between multiple programs with no lag, and Office 2013 loads fast and runs flawlessly. So for an office desktop that you can move from place to place, this is great (and, in fact, what I've been using it for as I've been starting a new business across town). However, this is no gaming computer, and certainly not designed for things like digital audio (where the slower hard drive would hobble it anyway).Of course this comes loaded with Windows 8, which I'm not totally sold on, and there's no easy way to "downgrade" to Windows 7 - one of my only complaints here. I am getting used to it though, and wouldn't ding my review because Microsoft's latest OS is a bit of a let-down.So, bottom line, what we have here is a very fast (for its intended use), light and thin (for a 17" screen) laptop that has great build quality and makes a fantastic office desktop replacement - and the entire package comes in at under $550. It's an excellent value that would have been unheard of not so long ago, and a laptop that I can easily recommend.
