Then I flicked the “On” switch and recorded my wife and I having a normal conversation in our living room. The device was across the room from us about 12 feet away. It picked up every word clearly and distinctly.It does not have its own speaker, and so you can only play back recordings on your computer. It’s simple to do. When plugged in, a window should pop up showing you the folder of the device, and any recordings you have made.If the window does not pop up automatically (which it always should) just go to your “devices and drives” (I’m using Windows 8) and the recorder will appear as “Removable Disk D:” Click on this icon and your recorded file will appear.I chose to open the recorded item using Windows Media Player. The window popped up and my recording was right there ready to play. Easy as pie.Again, you can also use this device like a normal flash drive to store other files, such as texts or pictures, etc.The range is not super great – for example – if you want to record a lecture in a classroom, you best be seated near the front of the class. However, if you want to record any normal conversation or sound in any normal sized room, such as your office, at a meeting in a conference room, or your living room – this will work in terrific fashion.I’m a journalist so I often interview people face to face. For this, it’s absolutely excellent. In fact, I love it for this task. For covering meetings, such as a City Council meeting or School Board – it will work if you place the device up close to where the board members are seated – but don’t expect it to catch everything from the back of the room, especially when there is a lot of ambient noise also present.To start recording, you just flip the “On” switch. To stop recording – well, go right ahead and flip it back to “Off.” You’re done! Files saved!Will last 4 to 5 hours on a charge.Love it. Absolutely great product. Simple, powerful and it works.Please note, I received this item free in exchange for an unbiased, honest and objective review.

Before I say anything else, I must echo what other reviewers have said about the leaky bottle problem. This bottle arrived with traces of oil outside the bottle and inside the package. I immediately detract one star because the seller must solve this problem and find a better way to contain and ship this product; several others have rightfully complained of the same issue.Beyond that, I find this product, by all outward appearances, to be a high quality product – but I have several qualifications about this statement. Please read the entirety of my comments to follow:First, I will say this oil has a 100% neutral taste – not sweet, nor bitter – and it feels wonderfully pleasant on your tongue if you care to try a tablespoon straight up.I was highly skeptical of the suggestion to dose my morning cup of coffee with this oil – GAK! Oil in coffee? – but I was amazed at how well it just blended in, did not affect the taste, and yes, I think it gave me an energy boost … well, I think … maybe.Was my energy boost all in my head, as in, the placebo effect?My wife has also been using this oil in a variety of ways, mostly in smoothies, and she reports no noticeable energy boost.Personally, I don’t think the science itself is complete or accurate enough for the manufacturer to make the claim that this product can give you a feeling of boosted energy – but maybe it does. I just don’t know.If the other claims about its benefits are true – help with weight management, aiding digestion, enhanced athletic performance – then it might be a marvelous product indeed.However – and I must emphasize this – my understanding of the science is that the data is simply not complete or accurate enough to truly verify any of these claims. I know lot of individual people claim they get these benefits from MCT oil – but that is anecdotal evidence, not rigorous scientific data.I know I’m being something of a stickler, but so much of nutritional science is junk science. Consider the recent revelation that everything we thought we knew about cholesterol for the past 40 years is wrong.Consider this quote from the June 24, 2015, issue of Time Magazine:“The war against fat was started by one man: Much of what we think we know about the supposed dangers of high fat intake comes from a single research project by a charismatic Minnesota pathologist named Ancel Keys. His Seven Countries Study compared the health and diet of nearly 13,000 middle-aged men in the U.S., Japan and Europe, and ostensibly found that populations that consumed large amounts of saturated fats in meat and dairy had high levels of heart disease, while those who eat more grains, fish, nuts and vegetables did not. The influential Keys relentlessly advocated the theory that fat caused heart disease, persuading the AHA in 1961 to issue the country’s first-ever guidelines targeting saturated fat—and he wasn’t shy about shouting down any researcher who questioned his data.Yet it turns out there was a lot to question. Keys chose the countries most likely to confirm his hypothesis, while excluding nations like France—where the diet is rich in fat but heart disease is rare—that might have challenged it."(End Time quote)For me – and I admit I’m no expert – everything we read, hear and think we know about nutritional science is questionable. That would have to include the claims for the benefits of this kind of MCT oil.While I don’t believe this oil can do you any harm if taken in very small amounts, I have no way of knowing if it can do you any good. Even our best science can’t answer that question at this time.Please note that I received this product free in exchange for my objective review.

There exists in America a special place where you'll find a transition zone between two distinct cultures.It's a mixture of the staid, straightforward practically of Midwesterners with the wild, mysterious blend of the Deep South as shaped by the edge of the Appalachian wilderness. That location is southeast Ohio.If a writer could capture the flavor of that unique mixture of Americana by telling the stories of ordinary people with a collection of short stories - anyone reading it would gain a certain deeper understanding of the American experience.It would also be incredibly entertaining!I'm delighted to report that Ohio author and film-maker STEVE ANDERSON has accomplished this subtle task with this collection of short stories titled: 1979.On the outside these tales would seem to be a series of coming of age "booze and boobs" vignettes featuring hormone-driven pre-adolescents and teenagers who are just waking up into a world where temptations abound - cheap wine, beer, sexy young girls, (and a few lusty older women), fast junky cars, cheap dope and the delicious discovery of that first kiss coupled with a daring grope of breast.However, by design or accident, these stories deliver more than just surface-level entertainment. Let's face it; each offering here is a little work of art. The writing often transcends the quality of being merely entertaining yarns to delivering that sense of:"There is something real here that strikes a chord. I'm not sure what it is, but I can feel it."I can't decide if Steve Anderson is one of those natural writer who is able to make stories like these just flow off his fingertips, or if he is one of those dogged writers, rewriters and revisers - but who cares? He writes extremely well.Reader will quickly forget that some guy is trying to enthrall them with words because we're swept away by each of these stories right from the first sentences, and before you know it, the story is done. Then you realize you have just forgotten that you were sitting in an uncomfortable chair squinting at words on a page because you were magically transported 35 years into the past to a small town in Ohio- it's as if you lived a few visceral hours through the eyes and feelings of the characters.I like writers who understand that if you just tell a story, everything else will take care of itself - and also comprehend the importance of character. Anderson's characters pop off the page, alive, fresh and vivid, almost certainly because he based his creations on real people he knew while growing up in the 1970s.I don't want you to think what you're going to get here is a lot of bland "Happy Days" nostalgia ala an idealized version of what life might have been like in 70s-era small town America. Anderson shows that, like the mean streets of Detroit, the tough hoods of New York or the gang infested barrios of Los Angeles - small towns can incubate their own festering brand of mean street cruelty.With the cool gaze of an unflinching observer, Anderson regales us with sweat-inducing scenes, such as a man getting brutally whip-beaten with a metal car antenna; a tornado breaking the back of cow; wild-eyed southern boys pulling off the pants of a young boy in an alley and then meting out a tooth-knocking thrashing before they nearly cut off his testicles with a dirty pocket knife.Yes, you'll find sweetness and sentiment here, good times and laughs, but there's also loneliness and boredom, betrayal and alienation, lust and violence - all part of an unvarnished look at the basic reality of life -- delivered to your doorstep courtesy the pen of ... one ... savvy ... wordsmith!

I live in northern Minnesota where winters are long and frigid, sunlight is scant for months on end – and that means people living here may become Vitamin D deficient.In general, I have a dim view of taking any kind of supplement because I firmly believe eating a well-balanced diet (the way nature intended) will supply all the vitamin the human body needs to function normally.However, a good case can be made for using Vitamin D in supplement form.If I have to take any supplement. Vitamin D is found in only a few foods in small amounts – including herring, tuna, mackerel and sardines.But the bottom line is that you will never get enough Vitamin D from food.What you really need is adequate exposure to sunlight. This ignites a biochemical process in your body, causing it to manufacture its own Vitamin D.The problem: Getting enough sunlight is difficult in many northern parts of the world, and also, too much sunlight is damaging to the skin.Thus, taking a Vitamin D supplement is almost certainly an excellent idea. Again, this is the ONLY supplement I would ever take myself. Based on my understanding of the science, there is absolutely no proof that taking a multivitamin or any other kind of supplement will do anyone a lick of good – as long as you have a healthy well-balanced diet high in fruits and vegetables, with an absolute minimum of junk food, and stuff like white refined sugar, etc.So if I have to take a Vitamin D supplement, I trust this company, Viva Labs, to supply me with a high quality product. I say this based on my experience using a variety of other products from Viva Labs, from their Quinoa and raw chocolate, to their chia seeds and cacao powder. Everything I have purchased from them has been absolutely of superior quality.Please note that, in this case, I received this bottle of Vitamin D3 free in exchange for my honest and objective review.

The mask promises to give a sexy edge to a Halloween costume, and it does that. I think it would make anyone look more alluring, mysterious and sensual in a dress-up/costume situation.I received this mask free in exchange for my honest review. I asked my beautiful wife to model it for me. She is already incredibly lovely, and when she strapped on this black lacy mask, it added an element of sizzle to her already powerfully attractive look. It helps that my wife is a tall blonde of Norwegian extraction -- the luxurious blackness of this lace played off her fair skin and blue-green eyes in a marvelous way.This is a simple, low cost way to have more fun dressing up while helping women feel pretty, adventurous and fun. That's why it earns five stars from me.

I was first diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis about 25 years ago. Over the years my condition has smoldered and slowly grown worse -- although I have long since come to accept my condition as the "New Normal."Many times well-meaning friends and relatives have suggested I take this supplement, glucosamine chondroitin MSM, which is available in several brands.I have always resisted because:* My doctors put me on raft of prescription drugs to control my condition and relieve pain.* Over the years, these prescriptions have changed from one drug to another.* At any given time, I might be using two to four different prescriptions medications.Thus, I reasoned that taking adding glucosamine chondroitin on top of everything else I was taking just seemed like overkill, and also, I was uncertain about how it would interact with my other drugs.It's common for people with arthritis to take medicines that thin the blood, and according to Web MD, glucosamine chondroitin can also add to the blood-thinning effect, so it may not not a good idea to add this supplement to other blood thinners, in my opinion.However, now I take just one drug that controls all my symptoms beautifully -- an injectable "biologic" drug called Humira.I asked my doctor if I could take glucosamine chondroitin, with Humira, and he said "Yes," but that he also doubted it would help.Thus, after receiving this bottle free from the seller in exchange for my objective review, I thought it was finally time to try this product after all these years.DID IT HELP?I really can't say. You must keep in mind that my arthritis has been progressing for 25 years -- that means a lot of irreversible damage done -- so it may be that any new treatment at this point might be difficult to notice at this stage in my life and condition.I have only used the product for a month, so my test period may not be long enough to notice a real effect.I should also note that I think this product is indicated to be more helpful with other types of conditions than the one I suffer from, such as osteoarthritis. I can't attest to the effectiveness of this product in the case of other conditions.I do know that this supplement did me no harm -- and that's the first rule of medicine. "Do no harm."The fact is, in terms of medical science, the jury is still out on the value of this supplement for people like me who endure arthritis and similar conditions. There's plenty of studies out there, but I don't think the mainstream scientific/medical community has ever given this product an official "okay" as an effective treatment.Thus, I give this product three stars -- this indicates that I simply can't say with authority -- both from my personal experience and based on my research of the science -- if this supplement truly provides the results which many sellers claim it does. I just don't know.I know that many people swear by it, and claim it had helped them a great deal. But this is what medical researchers call "anecdotal evidence" -- which is not the same as controlled scientific studies in double-blind protocol situations -- and only the latter is a true indication of the efficacy of any kind of treatment.It didn't help me or hurt me -- but your experience may be entirely different. Also keep in mind: Any of us can be swayed by the placebo effect -- but sometimes, the "placebo treatment" is the best treatment of all.I must add that I have sampled almost 10 other products of Viva Labs and I consider this company to be of extremely high value and trustworthiness -- so if you want to try this product -- I can't think of a better supplier to buy from than Viva Labs. They're good people.

I’m writing this right in the middle of outdoor BBQ season, mid-June in Minnesota. Let me tell you, when you have a big-ol’ chunk of meat you want to shred up fast, these meat claws are a tool that will get the job done for you – and fast!I’ve long known about meat claws, but I have never had a notion to buy a pair for myself. These were sent to be for free by the seller in exchange for my honest and objective review.I struggle with whether to give these tools a top 5-star mark, or detract a star. I settle on four because I must say, even though I got them free, I was hoping they would be made of metal – mostly for aesthetic reasons.After using these claws make of hardened plastic, I realize there are some advantages to plastic – they are lighter, they are probably just as sharp as metal, and they clean-up remarkably easy. They may even be easier to clean than metal tools.For me, they fit okay in my hands, but perhaps not perfectly. They felt just a tad clumsy or awkward in my hands as I grappled with a large roast. Part of reason is that I think you have to learn how to use them – getting that right motion down – which means holding down the meat with one hand while you do most of the shredding with your dominant hand, depending on whether you are left or right handed.The price is reasonable, they are a handy tool that deliver on what they promise to do – so I can recommend these claws. I would have preferred metal – just because I think that would have been cool and would have made me feel like Wolverine from the X-man – but the reality is that plastic is probably just as good or even better than metal.Do you really absolutely need these? Perhaps. I’ll let you decide. Your level of needs depends on how often you have large chunks of meat to shred up fast – it should be mentioned also that you can use these in other kitchen situations, such as grasping and holding watermelons.

I’ll be honest, this is probably the best cacao powder I have ever tried. It’s a bag of silky chocolate pleasure with a rich flavor that is quite unlike any other form of chocolate you can bake with, or with to make a cup of hot coco. Easily beats chocolate chips or various off-the-shelf store brand of coco powder sold by the major labels.My first recipe was a simple chocolate cake made from scratch. I have a recipe that calls for buttermilk, three eggs, some vanilla, walnuts etc. I added about a half-cup of this cacao powder and was rewarded with a rich, moist chocolate cake that is to die for.Since this is a raw, organic and unsweetened, you control the sugar or other sweetener amount you want to have in your food.  All this and it delivers high nutritional value, including high fiber content, magnesium, antioxidants and amino acids.The array of different chocolaty recipes you can make is limited only by how many volumes of cookbooks you own, or how many recipes you can find on the Internet. I would say this is a must-have product for any kitchen pantry.Please note I received this 1 lb bag free in exchange for my honest, objective review.

I received this wig free in exchange for my objective review just in time to give it to my niece for her 16th Birthday!Here is what my niece said when she opened the package and found this pink wig:“YEAAHH!  I LOVE IT!”As it happens, my niece and here parents were planning a trip to the Canadian city of Winnipeg for the next day, and my niece said:“I’M GOING TO WEAR THIS WIG ALL DAY WHILE HOBNOBBING AROUND WINNIPEG!”I asked my niece what she thought about the quality of the wig. She said:“I JUST LOVE IT! I THINK IT IS EXACTLY WHAT IT IS SUPPOSED TO BE. IT CAN GIVE YOU AND AMAZINGLY DIFFERENT LOOK. IT LOOKS BOTH REAL AND UNREAL AT THE SAME TIME.”I asked my niece if she was into cosplay role playing activities.“NO, NOBODY I KNOW AROUND HERE DOES THAT KIND OF THING. I GUESS WE LIVE IN A TOWN THAT IS TOO SMALL AND RURALI asked my niece: How else might you be using this wig? She said:“I THINK ONLY YOUR IMAGINATION CAN LIMIT YOU ON HOW TO HAVE FUN WITH THIS. IT WILL BE GREAT FOR HALLOWEEN, BUT ALSO, I DON’T THINK IT’S JUST A COSTUME. IF YOU WANT A RADICAL NEW LOOK ON ANY DAY, THIS IS TERRIFIC.”So there you go.I think for the price, the quality is adequate and for the joy it brings to young people, this item fulfills its function, and therefore, deserves my top 5-star rating.

The goji berry – also known around the world as the “wolf berry” – is simply a fantastic nosh when eaten  as a dried fruit. Just slightly sweet, chewy, no added sugar needed, not bitter – it would be difficult to think of a better healthy, refined-sugar-free snack that one can enjoy without an ounce of guilt.I just eat them right out of the bag, but you can put them in tea, sprinkle them on salads, mix them with nuts and your other favorite snack-bowl items.This is a healthy snack that delivers phenomenal nutrition: A 1 oz serving has 140% of daily Vitamin A, 13% calcium, 8% Vitamin C and 3% calcium. Also has 2 grams of fiber and 8 grams of natural sugars. The supplier says they contain 20 trace minerals, including zinc and selenium.My wife and I both absolutely love these berries. A simple, healthy snack packed with nutrition – and they taste great. What’s not to love?I received a 1 lb bag free in exchange for my honest, objective review, and I am glad to recommend this product without reservation. It’s a no-brainer that this product deserves 5 stars.

Hey, if you are like me and love to cook – but also like to be adventurous and try all-new recipes to make unique culinary creations – these raw cacao nibs offer an opportunity to expand your tasty horizons.Yes, this is chocolate, but it’s raw and unsweetened. No, these don’t taste like your average chocolate chip. They have just a slight bitterness, the pleasant kind of bitterness that you like in black coffee, for example. Yes, the “chocolaty” flavor is present, but this is perhaps a different kind of chocolate vibe than most of us are accustomed to.The first thing I tried was to bake one of my favorite buttermilk, white-cake-from-scratch recipes – and I put in a cup of these raw nibs. I wanted to start out with one of my reliable recipes, and one I am well-familiar with, to see if the unique taste of this product could change things up in a significant way. I was pleasantly surprised.I really like the way the slight bitter-yet-chocolaty taste of these nibs enhances, complements and “plays off” the otherwise sweet flavor of the rest of my cake. I truly felt like I had transformed one of my oldest and most familiar recipes into something entirely new.And I think that’s the main benefit and appeal of this product for me – it gives me an opportunity to make “all that is old new again” – and in a simple way. A basic white cake now becomes an exotic, sort of foreign treat – it’s like you are visiting a country you have never been to before, and you are experiencing new flavors and sensations for the first time.Another terrific aspect of these raw cacao nibs is the vast array of possibilities – the number of different recipes, ways and the alternate-interpretation spins you can put on foods is all but endless. You can enhance both sweet and savory dishes – and you control the sweetness from the outside.Have you ever tried to enhance chili with chocolate? A bit of chocolate flavor in chili is actually an incredibly good twist for a hot and spicy recipe –these nibs don’t overpower a savory dish with sweetness while adding a hint of bitter chocolate taste that would be difficult to get otherwise.All this and you’re getting an excellent nutritional boost – these nibs are high in essential fatty acids, vitamins, deliver some iron and calcium to your diet, not to mention dietary fiber.It’s no wonder the ancient Maya and other civilization of Central and South America highly prized this product as a “Food of the Gods.” And what else can an ordinary mortal like me give the nosh of deities but a 5-star rating? I do!Please note: I received this 1-lb bag free in exchange for my honest and objective review. My honest opinion is that this is definitely a superior product which I am glad to recommend to all my readers here.

I think everyone who owns some kind of computer tablet has, at times, come up with creative ways to prop up their device in various situations. Sometimes you lean it against a book, roll up a towel or some piece of cloth - you just want to view comfortably while your hands are free.Well, wherever there is a problem - no matter how small or trivial - someone is striving to solve that problem and make a buck marketing a product.This item certainly does provide a solution - although perhaps not perfectly. For example, where I find myself wanting to prop up my Kindle Fire most is at the dinner table when I am at home alone having lunch. I usually lean my device against a cup, or put a cloth napkin underneath it so it tilts forward for easy viewing while I dine.For me, this 18-inch pillow is just a tad too big for use at my kitchen table, but it can suffice for that. There is just something about the kitchen table that makes me feel this item does not belong there, however.But in many other home venues - while reading or viewing in bed, sitting in the living room, lounging on the floor, or outside in our gazebo, this pillow with rubber iPad/Kindle holder is nice to have. It's a comfortable lap pillow, and I can rest my hands on either side while reading or watching, hands free.I don't travel much, but this cushion would probably be ideal for use on an airplane or while riding in a car. But then again, I'm not sure if you would want to carry this 18-inch long pillow around with you while traveling, and especially flying. It's light-weight and all - but it's still another thing to carry on a plane, and airlines are getting so restrictive about what you carry on.There is a small zippered pocket on the side opposite the holder. That, I assume, is for convenient storage of a cable for your device. The holder itself also has a hole at the bottom so that you can charge your device while you are using the pillow.You might get some extra use out of this nice soft cushion using it as a neck rest, or support for your lower back while sitting - again, that would be great in a cramped airline seat, or bus seat.It's filled with buckwheat hulls and microbeads, I guess, so it's a very cozy beanbag type of thingy.  It does feel pleasant and comfortable.It attracts pet hair like a powerful magnet! So watch out for that. (I have three cats).All in all, I have to give this at least 4 stars because this is a product that delivers on its primary promise. It's a comfortable way to prop up your iPad or Kindle while freeing your hands from holding it in a variety of situations. But do you really, really need it? I'll let you decide.Please note: I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review.

This is not so much a book using Minnesota as a backdrop, but a novel that creates a kind mythological Minnesota that does not exist in reality - unfortunately, the mythical Minnesota elements are largely gleaned from Hollywood movie clichés and bland, surface-level stereotypes.Yes, this is fiction so anything goes and I believe in granting any writer all the poetic license they want to  make up a story in an imaginary world - but for me, this novel comes off as a clumsy mish-mash of standard fictional props, well-worn plot gimmicks and jarring inconsistencies.The setting is present-day Minnesota where people carry smartphones, yet there are beads-and-sandals wearing hippies that seem to have time-traveled from 1960s California to reappear as "tree huggers" in the Boundary Waters; there's a Minnesota cop who is essentially a Clint Eastwood cowboy from a 1970s spaghetti western; there are Native Americans who are still using bows and arrows and painting their faces (that's right) and journalists, doctors, loggers and country attorneys who never seem to have progressed out of the 1940s.It's also breathtaking how much the author gets wrong about Minnesota - I kept asking myself throughout this book: "Where was this guy's editor?"For example, take this sentence:"The ice melted and filled the thousand lakes of Minnesota and then the trees grew on top of the rock."Say what? A thousand lakes? Or course, Minnesota is the "Land of 10,000 Lakes." It's on our license plates. Technically, Minnesota has 11,842 lakes if you want to Google it.Or this sentence:"Diane had the frankness that comes from watching a father die of black lung disease and going to work full time when she was just sixteen."There is no black lung disease found in Minnesota miners. We have taconite mines and black lung disease is not associated with taconite mining, but rather, coal mining. Black lung disease is something you find in West Virginia or Kentucky - true, Minnesota miners have higher incidence of lung disease, but this is associated with asbestos and/or silica dust in mines. This produces a condition called mesothelioma, a disease of the outer lining of the lungs. To invoke black lung disease in a Minnesota story is simply culturally and scientifically ridiculous.Or this sentence:"Thought maybe it was the girl who was in the shed, but she didn't sound like she was from the lower forty-eight."Again I have to ask in utter perplexity: Say what? I mean: "The lower forty-eight"?What on earth is he talking about? Again and again, the characters use the term "lower forty-eight" to refer to anyone from outside of Minnesota - except that Minnesota IS ONE OF THE LOWER FORTY-EIGHT!No one that I know of here my home state of Minnesota refers to outsiders as being from the lower forty-eight, and why should we? We are among the lower forty-eight, we all know we are among the lower forty-eight, and so why refer to someone from, say, Illinois, as being from the lower forty-eight?It's just inexplicable! Again, where was this guy's editor?Speaking of bad editing, the books is loaded with clumsy sentences, downright grammatically incorrect constructions and confusing elements of time. As an example of a bad sentence, try this one:"Tom Jorde stabbed a computer resembling a large egg in a green T-shirt of white lettering--SAVE THE SPOTTED OWL FROM EXTINCTION."Did the author really mean to suggest that an egg-shaped computer was wearing a t-shirt?Throughout reading this novel, I found myself literally gasping and searching with frustration for the best superlatives to describe what I was reading: absurd, ridiculous, painfully wrong ... even though this is merely fiction. But even when writing fiction, there should be some adherence to plausible reality unless you're writing out-and-out fantasy, not a mainstream novel.Much of my exasperation is with the way the author tries to handle "Minnesota Speak," - his effort is clumsy and just beyond absurd (there's that word again.) I mean, whether the character is a doctor from Minneapolis, a lawyer, a redneck logger, a Native American or resort owner - they all talk like 100% Norsky-hillbilly hicks who just fell off the boat from Norway, smelling of pickled herring and lutefisk.Oh ya, you betcha, everyone talks like this here, you know ... ya, oh ya, fer sure, that's right there then what do yer think of that there here?Even Minnesota's Native Americans are portrayed to speak this way - and if you grew up with and have known Minnesota Natives for your entire life like I have - then you would understand how just exasperatingly ludicrous it is to make a Minnesota Indian sound like Sven Swenson from the old country, even in a work of fiction.Take it from me. I was born in Roseau, a small hockey-power town where the snowmobile was invented, and where the Polaris factory is still the primary employer. I also have worked as a newspaper reporter and Minnesota state government official - I have lived in a remote corner of Minnesota all my life -- but I have traveled all 87 counties of our state interviewing thousands of Minnesotans while writing about Main Street Minnesota over the past 30 years.So you can believe it when I say the only place in Minnesota where people speak like Ole and Lena is in Hollywood movies - such as Fargo -- and the occasional sketch on Minnesota icon Garrison Keillor's Prairie Home Companion radio show.It's not that I am insulted by the way Mr. Hazelgrove or any fictional media like to play up the mythical Norsky-Hillbilly Minnesota speak - far from it - I think it's fun. I love it. I was delighted by the movie Fargo (one scene was filmed practically right in my back yard) - I loved police chief Marge Gunderson and auto dealer Jerry Lundegaard - and the way Frances McDormand and William H. Macy mastered and really nailed the faux-Minnesota accent - except this movie was CLEARLY PLAYING IT FOR LAUGHS.In JACK PINE, a serious murder mystery, we are expected to believe that regular, everyday Minnesotans from all professions and all walks of life, young and old, all talk like Ole Olson - he was a guy from my home town of Greenbush. Ole owned a Swedish potato sausage business in the 40s, 50s and 60s, died at the age of 97, born in 1905 - so yes, sure, he had that distinctive Scandinavian sing-song gate to his speech - but his generation are largely gone from our state and culture now.To be clear: My low rating of this novel goes well beyond my problems with the portrayal of the language - the writing is frequently muddy and unclear, the time sequencing of key events is confusing to say the least, the characters are cookie-cutter cliché props borrowed from Hollywood movies, the metaphors are strained, the descriptions of the Minnesota wilderness misfire ... and on and on.All this and I'm a big WILLIAM HAZELGROVE fan - this is the fourth of his novels I have read, and I have reviewed all here and given all my top rating. Hazelgrove is a fiercely talented novelist who is one our finest modern American novelists working today - but nobody is perfect - and Jack Pine is a certified bust.As penance for penning this disaster, I hereby sentence William Hazelgrove to read five JON HASSLER novels, two Sinclair Lewis novels, say three Hail Marys, strive to amend his life, and go in peace.IMPORTANT FINAL NOTE:Despite filling every page with characters aping the Hollywood faux-Minnesota Speak, the author fails to use even once the most genuine, ingrained and ubiquitous Minnesota idiom of them all, the one word that all Minnesotans actually and truly do use: UFF DA!That's right - not once! Minnesota! Home of the uff da taco! (A taco made with lefse for a wrap).Not one use of uff da! within a 300-page novel set in the culture of Minnesota.That is absolutely ridiculous.Please note: I received a free copy of this book in exchange for my honest and objective review.

The first thing I did when I got this bag of chia seeds is whip up my favorite from-scratch buttermilk muffin recipe.I dumped in a half-cup of these chia seeds into my mixture and put them into the oven to bake. The result: Absolutely excellent muffins peppered with the wonderful look of these dark seeds throughout the yellow cake. They added just a tiny sense of crunch – they add no bitter taste or anything else unpleasant – just some extra good.Can you really taste chia seeds in bread and muffins? I don’t think so, but you can be certain that you are adding something important to these foods you will east anyway: protein, fiber, omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants.One of my other favorite things to bake are Kaiser rolls. Before baking, you apply a brushing of egg wash on top the dough and then sprinkle with sesame seeds – but you can just as well sue these chia seeds. My Kaiser rolls turned out terrific.If you like a good, crunchy sesame seed roll, then you’ll love the same made with chia seeds.This is a remarkable food. Put a teaspoon in a smoothie, and you instantly supercharge your drink with loads of protein, fiber, omega-3 and antioxidants.If you let these seeds steep in some plain water for about 15-20 minutes, they turn into a gel. Here’s how to do it:Take about 2 tablespoons of chia seeds and put them in one cup of water. Whisk them around real good to make sure the seeds don’t clump up. Let it stand for about 15 minutes – and you have a very thick gel.There is all kinds of things you can do with chia-seed gel – such as eat it directly like a bowl of oatmeal or pudding. I like to put a little cream and brown sugar in it – and yum!  A super healthy, nutrition packed meal! And it’s extremely simple and idiot proof – thankfully for me.I received this 1-pound bag of chia seeds free from the supplier in exchange for my honest and objective review.This sample is as good or better than any brand of chia seeds I have used from other source – so it’s a no brainer to give this my top 5-Star review. I would heartily recommend chia seeds, and this brand to anyone, and I feel good about doing so.

I always like to convey my very first impression of a new product I am reviewing --- that means my immediate impression when taking the item out of the box - and so taking these Soundpeats A1 out of its shelf package made me think:"Ah, I like the look and feel of these headphones. At first glance they seem like a high quality product."And after some days testing these headphones, I find that my first impression was mostly right once again.The short version of my review will tell you this: For the price, these are an above-average deal on a set of headphones that may not be "high end," but they are definitely a big step up from any of those standard basic headphones we all tend to buy at Wal-Mart or Target for $10 to $15. At the same time, they may be just as good as perhaps $50 to $100 set.For a long time I have been getting by on the cheap with headphones and ear buds. The last set I bought were some of those regular kind of headphones with that black plasti-foam covering that do not cover the entire ear. I think I paid $8 for them, on sale.But using this A1 set from Soundpeat is a whole other experience. It makes a difference when you have headphones that cover the entire ear. It's been a long time since I had a set like this, and I forgot what I was missing. When you cover the entire ear, you not only focus all the sound inside and into your ear - but you block out unwanted sounds coming from outside.I was pleased that I could easily make these headphones pair with my Kindle Fire tablet. All I had to do was go in and turn on the Bluetooth button on the Kindle - and I was immediately getting sound into the earphone (this was after I charged them for about an hour using the provided UBS cable connected to my laptop).The sound quality itself it darned good - perhaps a perfect balance between bass tones and those higher tones that I like to be clear and distinct. I won't say the treble tones are especially high, scintillating and distinct as maybe I would like - but still, hard to complain.One of the primary things I use any set of headphones for is to listen to hemi-synch meditation tones - binaural beats consisting of alpha, theta or delta wave - and for that situation you want really good balance between right and left, and very clear sound transmission. For that purpose, these headphones perform extremely well.Positioned on the outside of the ear cups are variety of buttons, including volume control, power switch, "previous" and "next" buttons, a "pause play" button and jacks for both "line in" and USB port.These are difficult to find while you are wearing the headphones - until you get used to using them for a certain amount of time. You can "teach your fingers" where to reach the buttons easily after a bit of time and use.You get both a regular line-in jack for non-bluetooth direct usage with any device, a USB cable and a very nice soft black felt bag to carry everything in. Also - these headphones fold down flat, making them easy to fit in a suitcase or carrying bag.These headphones also have a built in microphone which makes it easy to use with your smartphone - the mic pics up your voice well - so you can enjoy hands free communication while using this product.The only slight drawback for me - both my wife and I find these headphones just a tad uncomfortable to wear, especially over long periods. They never seem to fit just quite right for my size and shape of head. You may have a different experience - I think it depends in your head/hat size and the shape for your head.The top headband is well-padded, but for me, still does not provide total comfort for where the top part touches the top of my head. I think people with more hair (yes, I'm rather thin on top) will not find this to be a problem.THE BOTTOM LINEFor the price, these are ALMOST a high-end class of headphones for a much lower price - great sound, very high quality construction, feel and function - I can recommend them without reservation. I detract one star only because the fit was not one of total comfort for me - but they be more comfortable for you.Please be aware that I received these headphones free in exchange for my honest, objective review.

I've been a regular user of Quinoa (pronounced KEEN-WAH) for about two years. Back then I read about this Andean "super grain" in the food section of the Minneapolis StarTribune, jumped on the Quinoa bandwagon, and I have never gotten off since.That's because there is so much you can do with this incredibly versatile natural food.The first thing I did when I received this one-pound sample bag from Viva is dumb a cup of it into my Vita-Mix to grind it into a fine flour. It takes just about 90 seconds. I used this to bake bread using one of my favorite made-from-scratch recipes. I just add about a half cup of floured Quinoa to a one pound loaf mixture made from organic wheat berries, which I also grind to flour with my Vita-Mix.The result, of course, was a terrific, rich bread with just a hint of "other" flavor from the Quinoa - which I admit is difficult to describe. But I like adding Quinoa to a lot of my bread creations because I know I am getting a terrific nutrition boost, especially protein, iron, fiber - and also magnesium, folate B9 and B6.One of my favorite ways to use Quinoa is to prepare it as a breakfast cereal, similar to the way you would make milled or rolled oats.It's best to place Quinoa in a fine mesh and give it a rinse. Then just boil the grain for perhaps 20 minutes until soft. A little brown sugar and half-n-half or almond milk - just a fantastic, energizing breakfast.This Quinoa from Viva Labs is as good or better than any other I have purchased from other sources.  It is sourced directly from high plains regions of the Andes Mountains in Bolivia, so says the supplier. It's organically produced and they use a non-mechanical method to remove something called "saponins" from the grain - rather than removing this naturally bitter substance using a chemical process.I received this 1-pound bag of Quinoa free in exchange for my honest and objective review. I see no reason to give it anything other than my top 5-star rating because this is obviously a high quality product that's just as good, and probably better, than any other quinoa source. The grain is bright, clean, has very little dust or residue of any kind, tastes great and performs well in all my recipes.

This is a solidly-built, well designed clothing maintenance tool that fits well in the hand - the ergonomics are darned good. It's easy to grasp, point and move around as you steam wrinkles out of your clothing.So there is more than a little to like about this item -- but it will fall well short of my top recommendation for a number of reasons. But first a few more bright spots.WHAT'S GOODThe compact size of this steamer makes it good for traveling. At just 8 inches high and a maximum 5-inches wide it will fit well into a suitcase or traveling bag. It's light weight, about one pound. It has a generous 6-foot cord, and you want a long cord as you move around and steam articles of clothing.As I said, the handle is comfortable and the on-off switch is positioned just right to very conveniently click on or off.It heat up and starts producing steam amazingly fast. A jet of steam starts coming out strong in about 45 seconds; within 60 seconds, it's ready to go.WHERE I HAVE CONCERNSThe manufacturer says this hand-held steamer will get out "even the toughest wrinkles." I have my doubts about that statement after spending a lot of time steaming wrinkles on a variety of different shirts and slacks, made of a variety of materials, from 100% cotton to various synthetics and blends.It will definitely relax most of the wrinkles in most fabrics I found - but it has a tough time getting out ALL the wrinkles and some of the more pronounced ones. The instructions says that you have to steam BOTH THE INSIDE AND OUTSIDE of the fabric to truly nail the wrinkles.  My experience is that this might be true - but I just don't think so for the "wrinkliest" wrinkles.A REAL POTENTIAL PROBLEM:As I was really getting into my steaming test, once or twice I waved the steamer around just a tad too vigorously - and some drops came splashing out the front spouts, getting wet spots on the clothing!If you splashed some of this water on your hands, you might get a burn. I'm not sure if this should be faulted to the manufacturer, or consider it a "common sense" issue - I mean, I suppose it should be obvious that one should take precaution when handling an item that is generating boiling hot water and steam.THE BOTTOM LINEIn my view, one should not expect a small unit like this to produce results that are similar to a professional dry cleaning service, wherein your clothing are made super wrinkle-free and perfect.This is more of a tool that you are using "in a pinch" while traveling on the road. It will allow you to make your clothing look better than it otherwise would have without having another, convenient way to iron out wrinkles. Most hotels and motels I know will lend you an iron if you ask for one at the desk - I don't think this steamer is an absolute substitute for an iron.For a guy like me who is not super fussy about eliminating every wrinkle, this steamer goes far enough to get my shirts into acceptably less wrinkled condition. It will get out most of your wrinkles - yes for sure. But in my view it doesn't produce professional results, or even match how good my mother was at getting our clothing wrinkle-free with her old-fashioned iron and ironing board.Please note that I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review.

If a pitcher or carafe is not made of glass or porcelain, it should be made with some kind of high quality material that is not “plastic-like.” The aesthetics and “quality feel” in a serving implement just makes it more pleasant for you and your guests.Thus, my first impression about the aesthetics of this infusion pitcher was a good one.  It’s made of a heavy, clear acrylic that gives the impression of a high quality product that is strong and functional, while looking good on your table. I think this item is especially nice for less formal gatherings, like outdoor picnics and barbecues. It sits pretty on a wooden picnic table, or your outdoor patio tables.The central idea behind the function of this item is also excellent: It’s healthy to drink a lot of fresh water every day, and if you can infuse that water with the flavor, vitamins and nutrients of fresh fruits – well, that’s simply a fantastic idea.As it happens, just as I took this pitcher out of its box, my wife came home from work, and she had stopped off to buy some lovely organic strawberries. We immediately washed the pitcher, sliced up some strawberries and filled the central tube with beautiful red berries and filled the jar with cold water from our 400-foot-deep Minnesota artesian well.Of course, common sense made me realize that the infusion process would not be immediate. After filling the tube with strawberries and cold water, we put the pitcher in the refrigerator to steep or “infuse” for a couple of hours. After about two hours, we could already taste just the very slightest hint of strawberry flavor.WIt was best, however, to let the pitcher infuse overnight. The next day, the result was absolutely excellent: We had cold water with a delicate, yet definite hint of strawberry flavor – not overpowering, no aftertaste – just fresh, light, delicate and delicious. Refreshing!No doubt the results vary much depending on what kind of fruit you choose to infuse. Lemons and limes offer a much more immediate effect because the juices of those fruits transfer much more readily into the water, and the “fruitiness” of the drink will be more powerful.At first I thought that the fruit might impart a certain cloudiness or bits of pulp or seed into the water, but I found this not to be the case. The water stays clear, while all aspects of the fruit remain inside the infusion tube, letting only flavor and juices through. This may vary with different kinds of fruits, however. For example, I wonder how watermelon would fair? I haven’t tried that one yet.Part of the fun of this product is experimenting with all the different kinds of fruits – maybe I’ll try some exotic fruits, such as starfruit.So far berries tend to be my favorite – raspberries are amazing and pomegranate is also pretty fabulous when infused using this set-up.As far as the functionality, I find little to complain about. The infusion tube twists on and off easily enough onto the underside of the cap. The top cap itself fits well, with an arrow on top that shows you where the cap should point and to stop tightening.  Everything fits snugly, with no rattling or looseness while the item is in use.Clean-up is easy enough. The only potential problem is getting some kind of build-up in the threads at the top of the infusion tube – but this simply has not been a problem for me.Note that I received this item for free in exchange for my honest and objective review. Whenever I get something free, I try extra hard to find something wrong with it – but in this case, all is well. The item deserves my 5-star rating. That’s my objective opinion.

This is dandy little device that works like a charm.It’s simplicity itself. Just plug the unit into your car’s cigarette lighter and a pleasant blue LED light appears on the face of the item. Next, you plug in your device – tablet, Kindle, smartphone – and you get juice from your car to your power-hungry tool. (UBS cable not included).This makes it convenient and easy to bring your devices with you on your road trips, and you can be sure your gadgets will have a charge and power.The blue light means you won’t fumble around in the dark to find the ports.There are two different UBS jacks, so you can charge two devices at once. One of the slots is stamped 2.1A and the other is 1.0A. I assume this means that the higher number is a faster charger. Either way you get a charge, and you can’t run out of power on the road.This charger has a solid, well-constructed feel. It’s not “cheapy-plastic-like” because the finish is brushed aluminum that gives a slightly heavy-metal feel that I like in gadgets.There is a really nice gripping band etched into the metal on the outer rim that makes an already-easy-to-handle little plug a cinch to grasp and control with your fingertips.This is one of those “simple solution” items that solves a problem – power to your devices while on the road – and does it so easily you may almost take it for granted – but you’ll miss it if you don’t have it with you!I don't know if this matters, but, the box my unit was shipped in identifies this item as the "SPEED BULLET" (Premium Universal Car Charger).Finally, this item comes with a 12-year warranty, so I don’t see how you can go wrong. For the price, it’s something worth having. So small, it’s easy to slip into a pocket, purse or briefcase – or maybe just keep it in the cubbyhole.Please note I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review. I can find no fault with it; it’s all good.

I own three dogs, but only one of them is the kind that needs a grooming ever so often – an energetic Border Collie/Australian Shepherd. He’s also inexplicably nervous about certain things, like strange noises.And so for me, this is a slight drawback to this otherwise solidly-built pet trimmer. That’s because when you click the power on it makes a surprisingly loud click, and then hums quite loudly as well as you operate it.However, there is way to reduce both the loud click-on noise and the ongoing buzz of the clipper: It comes with little tool that lets you turn a little embedded screw-type knob on the side. This will let you adjust the noise down – and it works well – but you sacrifice cutting power when you do that.In other words, the louder the buzz, the more power to the clipper blades, the quieter the less power you have. It all depends on how tough your pet’s hair is – all dogs are different.Another point: If you adjust the noise-level down, this may help your pet get accustomed to the trimmer. Once he or she realizes “it’s okay” you can probably turn it back up to full power – that’s the way it worked with my dog.  I Just want you to be aware of this noise factor. The noise suppression option is a solution – but perhaps won’t work for everyone.All in all, there is quite bit to like about this trimmer. Especially for the price, this might be a good choice for you. As I said, this clipper has a real “quality feel” in your hands – it’s heavy, has good power and is obviously a well-manufactured device.The blades are sharp and were able to adequately handle the hair of my border collie-shepherd. It comes with four interchangeable head guards that make it easy to cope with different lengths of hair. The head itself can also be adjusted up or down just slightly with a little black handle on the side.The cord is heavy duty and an excellent 6 feet and 5-inches long. With this kind of tool, you want a good long cord. High marks there.It also comes with a the fore mentioned sound-adjustment tool and a small brush for cleaning out between the blades after you’re done.I also like the very sturdy plastic carrying kit all of the above fits inside. It has a nice, easy-to-grip handle and shuts securely with some basic clips.As I said, when considering the low price, this is a surprisingly solid piece of equipment. I don’t give it 5-stars because I think the noise factor will be a problem for some – and there are obviously clippers that are more “high-end” on the market, if you are willing to pay a much higher price.But this unit is affordable, has a lot of little extras, and is definitely well built will gets the job done. It’s a 4-star for me – I suspect it will be a 3-star in the minds of some -- but also a 5-star in the minds of others.Please note that I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review.

The first thing I noticed after taking this lemon squeezer out of the box is its pleasant heavy and balanced feel. It’s of solid construction – an object of shiny, stainless steel beauty that rests smooth and cool in the hand.Expertly-machined, attractive, mirror finished and functional.So how does it work? It’s simple and terrific. Slice a fresh lemon, place it in the drainage bowl face down and press down with the handle. The juice flows right out, but pulp and seeds stay behind. You get pure fresh lemon juice or lime juice.This is light years better than any plastic lemon-lime squeezing device I have used. You'll never want to use one of those kind again, and this stainless steal model should last for years on end.The handles are thick offering good grip and leverage to apply pressure. I have a considerable case of arthritis, my hands and fingers are a bit gnarled, but I found this lemon squeezer comfortable to use.It’s easy to clean by hand wash or in your dish washer. Make sure you dry it well – I hand wash and use a soft dish towel to restore the polish of this attractive tool, which just looks good hanging on a hook in my kitchen. It’s a welcome part of the kitchen décor.I want you to know that I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review.Whenever I get a free item, I try extra hard to find something wrong with it, but this one is a no-brainer: It’s an elegant, simply, high quality tool, well made and works just as promised.

This is a high quality device that I am going to rate 5 out of 5 stars, with the understanding that, for some people, this may be a 4-star item. But I'm comfortable with giving it my top rating for the following reasons:HIGH QUALITY FEEL:When I first took this small recorder out of the box, I thought: "That's more like it!" I say that because it has that heavy, smooth, chrome-metallic feel that I like in a shiny electronic gadget.Just a few weeks ago I tested and reviewed a less expensive version - the iGearPro 8GB Digital Audio Voice Recorder - issued by the same company. But the less expensive recorder has a cheapy, plastic-like feel - and I did not like that.However, this device just feels metal-luxurious, like a slender silver ingot in your hand.RECORDING:The important thing to remember here is the primary function of this item. It's a DICTAPHONE. The dictionary definition of Dictaphone is: "A small recorder used to record speech for transcription at a later time."This means that this device is intended for close, upfront and personal recordings of voices - as in when you are making notes to yourself, dictating a letter, or just doing whatever personal recording you want to do. For this purpose, it's a perfect item because it performs flawlessly and easily. Just press the big red button on the front, and BOOM! You're recording.As a working journalist, I can also use this device to conduct interviews if I am face-to-face or standing next to my subject. It works great in that situation. But if I am covering a school board meeting, city council or county commissioners meeting - this item will not work very well to pick up all the voices in these kinds of large, public rooms. It's not intended to pick up voices from distances of more than, I suppose, eight to 10 feet.But always remember, this is a Dictaphone, and that means its primary function is to record your own voice up close and personal, or a person close to you. It does that well, so it delivers on what it promises.PLAYBACKThe playback speaker volume is adequate, but if you have dicey hearing like mine, you'll want to plug in the earbuds that come with this item, or use your own favorite set of earbuds or headphones. By Using earbuds you'll get superb playback sound that is as loud and clear as anyone needs, and the sound is high quality.EASE OF USEYes, it is easy to use - but there is a learning curve! You will need to read the instruction carefully and really twiddle around with all the functionalities before you get it down.Just as an example, adjusting the volume is not just a simple matter of pressing a button up or down. It's a multi-step task. To adjust volume, you "short press" the PLAY button, which causes the recording to go into "pause mode." Then you "short press" the "V" (Volume button) which causes the "volume line" to flash - and then to raise or lower the volume you press the "Next" button to raise the volume or the "Previous" button to lower the volume.See what I mean? You have to learn all these functional steps. It's perhaps easier than I make it sound here, but I just want you to know that learning the way all the functions work take time and patience, and reading the instructions carefully. Once you have it down, it's all super easy.FOR MUSIC OR MP3This device will definitely play MP3 files. You can also converted WAV files to MP3 using a software called Emicsoft Video Converter, which I'm fairly sure is a free download, but I'm not an expert.There is a USB cable that comes with this device that connects to your computer. The recorder will show as "Removable Disk" under devices - this is where you can transfer music files into the recorder.I'm not going to say much more about this because I am not an expert on music files, the different formats, etc. - I will say that I was able to download a song onto the device to test the quality, and the sound is absolutely terrific when you listen with high-quality ear buds or head phones.So if you want to listen to music on this - the sound is absolutely great with ear buds.SLIGHT DRAWBACKSI wish there was a way this device could be used to record telephone conversations more easily. It has no external mic jack, so you can't add an extra microphone of any kind, including one that will attach to a phone. I would love to be able to record telephone interviews using this - but I don't see how it can help in that situation.The great thing about this device is how small it is - and a drawback is - how small it is! If you have thicker "man fingers" like me, operating the little buttons is just a bit of a challenge.  The tiny screen is also challenging to view. I don't have perfect eyesight, but even with my prescription glasses and bifocal lenses, I still really have to squint to read the tiny symbols on the screen which is about 1-inch by 3/8 of an inch.I also wish there was some way to clip it to a pocket.BOTTOM LINEThis recorder is an item of very high quality construction, feel and performance. If you want a handy small personal recorder that can also play some music and transfer files (using it like a flashcard, sort of) this is an ideal item that delivers exactly what the manufacturer promises it will do. It's not an "all purpose" recording device - for example, it won't record public meetings or events in large rooms or outdoors very well - but that's not exactly what you would want this for ... it's your handy personal recorder.It will record up to a whopping 90 hours!So I give it five stars - and please note that I received this item free in exchange for my honest and objective review.

I had heard lots about Shilajit back in India but frankly never really paid too much attention to look into it. This is mainly found in the Caucasus mountain areas and has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for centuries & it is said to help a lot with various health issues. It took me awhile to try this out but after reading so much good about it I bit the bullet. At first I didn't know what to expect & what it would taste like. It actually looked like Tar & one day I finally did it. It tasted like crap as is & then I started mixing it in my tea & it was Fine, I wondered why I didn't do it (mix) in the first place. Once mixed in a beverage you don't really taste the Burnt Flavor of it. I have hypothyroid & have low energy to do things & decided to try it. It did help feeling energized. It was like a kick that I needed. I'm glad to have received this to test out in exchange for my honest unbiased opinion. It is definitely helping me & I feel better & able to do a lot more than usual.

This is seemingly two different products rolled into one.  The first is that it is a bluetooth scale that you use your iphone/iPad to read the weight on.  This hooks up to the Drop app to let you see how much is being weighed let's you tare the scale, etc.  The second part is more the meat of the scale, this is a series of recipes that are setup by weights.  You add the item and then it instructs you to do the next item etc.  This allows you to basically make a series of recipes without measuring, just putting it in the bowl on your scale.  The good part is you can adjust the ratios as well, automatically shrinking/expanding the recipe.  The app includes quite a few recipes, and not just food for dinner, but also ways to make cocktails and drinks (which is great since it's quick and more precise).The biggest downside of this scale is that you there is no visible read out on the scale itself.  That means if you want to pull it out and weigh anything (say one ingredient) you have to open up the app, which makes it a huge pain.  Would love to have both functionalities.  Would also be nice to maybe see third party apps have access to an api, this would allow for a coffee pour-over scale, measuring brew ratios and blooms, etc.

I received this item at no cost in exchange for an honest review.I was pretty concerned about getting a third party band, since it seems a lot of them have issues.  I've wore this for the last week, and it's so far been great.  I haven't actually felt or seen the Apple official milanese loop bracelet, but this feels like other milanese loops I've had for other watches (albeit this one has magnetic clasp).  The lugs fit in smoothly, solid click when they were hooked in, and haven't had a single issue with them so far.  (one thing to note is that the doubled over loop should be on the side closest to you).So now the not so great.  There is a very large BRG logo on the clasp (you can see it in the photos).  Unfortunately it feels pretty solid, so I don't think you're going to be able to scrape it off or anything.  The only other issue I've had is that the magnetic clasp wants to hook on to everything, other parts of the band, and if you're not careful it will click on to the bottom of the optical sensor as well (since there is a magnet there to hold the charger), it didn't  cause any damage, but something you need to be careful with (not sure if the Apple one has the same problem).

This is essentially some easy reading of a few case studies, focusing on Mercedes Benz and specifically how they try to make their customer service great.  There are a lot of items that will allow you to make changes in your business (and even in your life) here, but they are a bit simplified.  Nonetheless it's a good read and will get you thinking about things you might not have been.

This is a tiny little battery backup, providing about 3,000 maH of juice (This should be enough to fill an iPhone 6 up about 1.2-1.5x times, so it's still pretty beefy).  It comes with a little flashlight that sticks on the end (this flashlight uses the USB port, so you will not be able to have it on while charging something else).  Without the flashlight this is quite compact, holding a single standard lithium ion cell I believe.  Its light, small, and easy to throw in a bag, pocket for charging.  Carrying the usb cable to charge will probably be more of a hassle than this thing.

This is a large notebook, with a fake leather cover (it feels like rough leather, but the interesting part is they must have added a smell to it to make it smell like leather, and it smells good, but it's just slightly off).  The binding is ok, although a bit large, would have preferred something other than metal spiral bound, and there are only 80 pages in this notebook, so it is going to get used up fairly quickly.  However it's not designed just to be written it, each page is laid out to have meeting notes on the top of the page and action items on the bottom, nice way to keep organized and look through pretty easily.  The notebook is not very stiff, so you will need to be writing on a table, lap writing will not really work here.

This thing is huge.  I know it says t in the description and the title, but for home use, make sure you have a spot for it.  For instance it will not fit on smaller doors even in vertical orientation.  One side is vertical orientation the other for horizontal.  It's laminated, and it feels quite thick, but not enough that you cannot roll it (it comes rolled up).  Dry erase markers easy write on it, and also wipe off easily.It is a very functional calendar, no embellishment or fancy decoration on it, but that's not the point.  This is designed to show the entire year, show your dates in a very easy glance able form.

Andrew Jones is back and is now working with ELAC.  I believe ELAC is new and this is their debut line of speakers.  This 10" 400 watt sub is one piece, but they also offer floor standing, center  channel, rear/bookshelf speakers, along with a larger 12" 1000 watt sub, and a smaller 10" 200 watt sub.  I only have the sub so far, so this review will focus on that, but if the Pioneer Andrew Jones lined of products was any foreshadowing, all of these products are going to be fairy affordable while sounding great.This sub is unique in that you use your phone (iOS/Android) to setup and adjust the sub settings. Both this sub and the larger 12" have a EQ functionality where you position your phone close to the sub, and then where you listen and it will automatically EQ the sub.  This process is very quick and so far has worked quite well for my room (the room and sub have a peak around 100z, and this automatically lowered it).  The sub itself sounds great, kicks out some impressive lows for a 10" sub (The sub itself is down firing, the grill you see on the front is the passive radiator). The enclosure is quite small and compact, smaller than my old 10" 150 JBL subwoofer, and by quite a bit.  It also sounds considerably better, tight responses, low frequencies, and because of the EQ you never hear the boom it just fills in the sound near perfect.The app is not all that pretty on iOS, but it works without crashing, works quickly and I had no problems with it.  You can use the app to adjust the EQ (manually if you want), do the automatic EQ, adjust the sub mode (normal, music, cinema, night), adjust the volume (0-100), change the crossover level, adjust the phase (and you an adjust it in degrees) along with other tuning.This sub is the best I've heard and used, I can't imagine what the 12" can accomplish, maybe once I get the rest of the ELAC set.

STX is a brand that sells La Crosse equipment, Field Hockey and Golf equipment and apparel.  This set feels like they used their knowledge to build some good athletic clothes for kids.  A sleeveless shirt (really more of a tank top, but kind of between the two) and some nice shorts.  Grey black and lots of orange colors.  I like the heathered gray fabric, and the mesh material helps keep my son cool.

STX is a brand that sells La Crosse equipment, Field Hockey and Golf equipment and apparel.  Unfortunately this shirt and shorts set, while being athletic and designed for running around play only has the STX logo on it, no la crosse stick or other decoration.  That said the shorts and shirt are made of nice athletic material, nicer than most kid clothes that are out there.  The black with green accents of the shorts and green with black accents on the shirt make a nice combination.

Nice little set of boys clothes.  Shorts, Shirt (which has different colored sleeves) and a Sleeveless shirt that all go together (Matching colors at least, black, white and green with the opposite accents).  The clothes are a nice summer weight, they seem and have been durable so far.  The only downside is the STX labelling plastered all over the shirts (especially the sleeveless one is just STX, STX, STX, etc).  The other is a La Crosse stick with the brand.  STX is a La Crosse/Field Hocket/etc outfitter so that makes sense.  Nice little set.

Proactiv+ is a company that is serious about acne products, and this Shave Gel has benzoyl peroxide (in 2.5% concentrate) in it to help avoid acne.  It also has some cleansers in it to help clean your face.  It's a bit weird that it is combined with a shaving product, since I think you would want it as separate or as an aftershave lotion, but here it is.  Designed to be hypo allergic it seems, no noticeable smell and design to not be irritating.  A bit pricey, but works pretty well, although not the best shave gel I have used.

There are a couple of different ways to get humidity into the air.  Vaporizer style (by heating), ultrasonic (essentially vibrates the water and makes the mist) and cool mist via evaporation/wicking.  This model is the evaporation/wicking style.  There are some differences, namely that the evaporation based ones use wicks/filters to more easily evaporate the water, which need to be replaced.  Since they are cold, they should also be disenfected/cleaned as well.  What I enjoy though is that you don't have to worry about humidity, just turn it on and as it runs it water will evaporate and you can't ever get too much in the room (although to be fair it sometimes can be hard to get enough in the room, getting closer to a specific amount).This specific model has two modes, high and low, he high is about equal to our (quiet) air purifier, and the low is a whisper, you can barely hear it (essentially this adjusts the fan inside, which is fairly large, hence the low noise).  The water tank isn't very large (.8 gallons), but lasts a few days for us, it's also a softer feeling plastic, which lends itself to be more break resistant (I have broke a couple of these on other machines..) There is a spot for Vicks vapor rub packets, which is nice, but probably won't ever use.  Overall it's very quiet and it is very simple to use.  Wish it had a slightly larger tank, but having to fill it every other day or so isn't bad.

Pot-Pourri, first of all a slightly off putting name, but also very great (at least the people who might turn up their nose at it will see a fancy flowery bottle and never read it).Have used a few different scents and while they all smell similar (the stand out is the Royal Flush one which is in the black bottle), they use essential oils to basically make a strong and mostly pleasant scent to cover up your business.  It does say that you should spray it into toilet BEFORE going, but I much prefer using it after.The bottle is nice as is the sprayer, and it also has an indicator on the side showing how much is left (via a transparent toilet paper mockup).  The only annoying part is the cap likes to fall off pretty easily, would be nicer without that I think (you can just throw it away though).Overall it works really well, makes the house smell good.  Not sure it erases the scent, but it does a pretty good job.

A lot of times after a run or a workout I want a quick shake.  Normally I'm home so I use a blender bottle and mix up it up from my big tub of protein powder.  I also try to take powder in a bottle other times so I can make up one.  However sometimes I forget or don't have time to do it and these are great to keep in the car along side a bottle of water.  Protein shake whenever you want/need it.  Basically a disposable blender bottle all pre-measured.  Makes a good tasting shake, the only downside is the price is a bit high compared to buying powder and mixing it yourself.

These are little pouches of freeze dried food.  They are quite durable (instead of a glass baby food jar) and quite a bit less weight.  You simple mix with water/milk and you get a nice little food for the little one.  Because it's freeze dried you can also use as an additive for smoothies and other drinks.  We use this with our kids and it gives a good flavor and some health to a smoothie with little fuss.  Packs are a bit on the pricey side, but are nice for traveling and they are very convenient.

We needed a humidifier for our kids room, we've been using a vaporizer, but it gets messy and a pain to fill each night.  This humidifier is cool mist and also is ultrasonic so it means it's going to keep putting humidity into the air (which is great to get the humidity up, but can be a pain if you turn it on too high and make a rainforest in your room).This Vicks humidifier is a lot like some of the other ultrasonic ones we've used in the past, but there are a couple of things I like about it.  One is that instead of low/medium/high it has an 'infinite' adjustment for the humidity.  It also has a slot so you can put the vicks medication in (and it comes with the vapo rub one).  We haven't used it yet, but liked the idea since that was one thing we thought we were giving up with getting rid of the vaporizer.The other really cool feature is there is an LED light on the back pointing up, it has three options (sea life, jungle animals and stars) after you select one the LED rotates through each one a few seconds at a time (3 options, each have 3 things it rotates through).  Our kids really like it, gives them a bit of extra light and a fun thing in their room.Nice small size, do not have to refill often, has a place for 'medication' and the LED's, really great for our kids rooms.

Nice simple jump rope.  The cable is coated and the handles essentially use movable screw piece to keep them on the handle, and the handles allow the 'rope' to spin easily.  Jump rope is light and allows for quick jumping (you can really get this cranking).  There are a few jump ropes that are near identical to this one, and it seems Amazon Basics just added their own brand here.  The quality is good and price is good, no reason not to get this one.

The first thing you notice when you use this is the fairly strong perfume.  It's not off putting, and it's there to make this feel like an experience, designed to totally captivate you, and it kind of does, if you're not turned off the wave of perfume like scent.  The second thing you notice is the 'shimmer', little gold particles that catch the light, glittering.  I believe they are micro moisturizers as well, so they do have some purpose, and well they look cool.The shower oil works fairly well, like a soap, and is a nice switch from more sudsy soaps.

There is enough here that it will make your young detectives feel like they work for the crime lab.  It is heavy on the written side, with a largish book full of experiments and information and lots of charts/forms to fill in.  If you're child just wants a magnifying glass and a few other things, look elsewhere.Fingerprint powder, casts for making plaster footprints, all kinds of things that real detectives would and still do, which is pretty great.  The suggested age range is from 8-15 and I would say that's fairly accurate, and you might actually want a decent amount of adult supervision/help at the low end of that range.

This curtain rod is specifically designed for blackout curtains, since the side wraps all the way around to the wall allowing you to put light blocking curtains and not have any gaps at all.  The rod itself is not what I would call decorative, but it is functional, although the rod itself is pretty thin and small, so you'll need to be careful with how much the curtains get pulled on or moved around.

We have an earlier smartlab demolition kit, which has three 'bombs' that you can use to knock out tiles.  This kit mixes it up a bit, instead of the blasters you get a crane that you can swing at the different structures.  The intent is still the same, you get a bunch of tiles, some instructions and you build up your structure, then you release the crane on it and boom.  Even more fun is combing both sets and making even larger structures that get blown up.The setup takes a bit too long for my three and five year old but they are getting better, and even helping.  They of course love to wreck it.

Fun little setup.  You get blocks of soap that you microwave, then you can add coloring and the book gives you some tips on what else you can add (for instance some vanilla extract).  You poor into the molds, which are essentially just thicker pieces of plastic, and after it's cooled you can pop them out easily and you have a fun looking soap.  There are gift boxes included that you need to pop out of the sheet and fold to assemble -- they are all pretty adorable (and my daughter was super excited to put the soap in them).There are more advanced things you can do, pour different colored soap into one part of the mold, let it cool slightly and then pour the other color in to get a a beehive with a different colored bee on it for instance.Super simple setup for trying out the basics of soap making, my five year old loved doing it and was excited to make soap for her grandmas.  Now we can probably move into more advanced soap making and even use some of the same molds.
