This is a nice set, lots of different colors.  The barrels are triangular which helps them to be held and also prevents them from rolling off the table.  The set of colors is also really nice. The 'lead' is quite thick at 2.0mm but that's great for little hands.  These could be refillable, but doesn't appear that they are designed to be.The downside of these is that even though they are a lot of fun colors, when you write with them the colors are quite dull, and it's hard to get a lot of color on the page.  Our kids still like using them, but would rather use a marker/crayon to get easier/faster color.

FLIR is known for their thermal imaging cameras, although more recently they have branching out to other products (consumer security cameras, etc).This camera is a combination of a few things, but designed to track moisture.  It includes a thermal imaging camera, but specifically tuned/colored to find slightly cool places that would show evaporation.  So you won't get the red/orange/blue highlighting like you expect on a thermal camera, just shades of blue here, along with the gray of other outlines.There are two additional moisture sensors, a pin-less one which requires you to touch the device to it, and then a standard pin style, which has two probes and connects to the bottom of the MR160.The camera is a good way to discover things that could be leaking, walked around our basement where we've been having some issues and it outlined the places where it was wet.  The pinless moisture sensor works pretty well, although just grabs the surface which might not always be as accurate as you need it to be, the pin probe works as expected.The device itself is rugged, padding to protect for drops, thick rubber buttons, it looks like the camera itself is waterproofed, although I can't find much about it.  You can take photos with it, and then connect it via usb to gather them off later (no removable memory card).  It has a built in rechargeable battery as well, not user replaceable.

This is a nice little baseball and glove set.  The printing on the glove is quite amazing, full of color and covers both the back and front of the glove.  Love that it is designed for girls, and that it's the same glove otherwise.  Ideally they would just be the same, but this has my daughter interested as well.  The ball is softish, makes it easier to catch and throw.  Good ball and glove combo to get your frozen loving child.

This set is awesome, it looks just like the condiment setup you would get at a diner/restaurant but setup completely for play.  The ketchup and mustard bottles have a weight and a string in them so when you tip them over the string comes out, pretty slick.  The salt and pepper both have plastic chunks in them that look like salt and pepper and give it a nice sound.  The hot sauce bottle is a disappearing one, where when you tip it over it hides all the liquid in the cap.  A sturdy metal carrier holds them all together.

I found this machine both incredibly frustration and also incredibly amazing.Never having used one before I found it a bit daunting.  The instruction manual is very poor, it gives some guidance but no specifics.  The software installs easily, but is highly complicated and not easy to get going.  No easy walkthrough or anything.  My biggest thing was trying to figure out how to emboss and cut with it, the blade/embosser would just go way above the material.  It wasn't until I figured out that you need to layer some of the other platforms below the one you are using to get it high enough, maybe I missed this, but I had no direction on how this was supposed to work.  (The software will give some direction on cutting depth after you select the material).Couple of things to note, it comes with a fine embosser, wide embosser and a adjustable depth cutting tool.  It comes with the 8.5" x 6" version of those mats as well.  There are a ton of additional tools, different cutters, stipling tips, pens, tools for etching, metal, etc.  You can also get larger 8x11 (I think) versions of the cutting/embossing mats for larger items.Embossing is interesting because you have to buy their specific paper as far as I understand, since the tool itself just doesn't have enough strength to emboss normal paper or things like card stock.  Which is a bit sad since this is one of the tools that is included.  Trying out the cutting tool once you get a pattern setup is pretty amazing, super fast and incredibly precise.I'd recommend watching some videos on youtube on how to use it, there are tutorials where people make entire cards that combine embossing, cutting, drawing, etc and show you how to do it fairly quickly with some pretty cool results.  I haven't done any mixed mode things like that yet, but great to know I can.

Schleich makes amazing animals/figurines, so it figures that their playmats are great as well.  Finished edges, coating on the back, thick fabric.  The design on it matches some specific Schleich items, like the barn and horse washing station, which are all quite expensive, but even without those it makes a great play mat, and a for the quality, this mat is a bargain.

These little add ons for games you have played a lot can be fun, mix up a game you are used to.  This add on for Fluxx requires a main set of Fluxx cards.  It comes with 2 dice, 5 cards and some instructions.While this does mix it up, the downside is that it seems to mix it up a bit too much, it gets quite a bit more chaotic (to be fair it literally says this on the box).  Would recommend it for people who have played Fluxx a ton already and want to mix it up.

Two planes come in the package with suction cup fronts and one launcher.  The planes have a hook that hooks into an elastic/rubber band on the launcher, you pull back and send the plane flying.  The planes easily stick to glass windows/doors (our kids love firing them at the patio door...).  The launcher is a bit tricky for our 3 and 5 year old to figure out, they always wanted to launch them backwards, but they got it figured out.The only downside is that the wings are foam material, which makes them light, and it's fairly durable.  But if they get stuffed in a toy chest or stepped on, they will bend and eventually the plane will not fly straight and then potentially you may have a broken plane on your hand.  Wish they were a more durable plastic or other material.

Nothing like getting your children weapons so they can attach you, each other and your house.  This bow apparently is ok for indoor use, but I'd probably hide your breakables.  There are a couple of elastic loops that the arrow end slots into, there is a tab you use to then pull the arrow back and release.  Getting it lined up into both elastic pieces on either side of the arrow is probably the hardest part, and proved pretty difficult for our three year old.  Our five year old could do it, but took her awhile to do each one.The arrows themselves are pretty nice, they each have led lights (and come with batteries in them, smaller hearing aid like batteries), you flick the switch and it lights up.  Which means our kids immediately just played with the arrows and left the bow alone :).  You can clip the arrows into the bow it seems (there are 4 areas) but it's really tough to get them in and out.  We store it/put it away with them in there, but it is hard for our kids to get them out/in there.

It's a box of stakes.  Not much else to say here other than they are well made (straight, strong), they are made out of walnut and are nice and long (36 inches/3 feet).  End is pointed to allow easy driving into the ground.  Nice for throwing up signs or staking off areas in the garden.

These are pretty cute little fish scrubbers.  There is a loop around where the mouth would be, a little eye, little tail, and the scales are the alternating stitching. They are quite small, but easily would fit into a hand.  The only downside is that they are so cute that my wife wants to hang them and decorate with them instead of using them.

Love that grow lights have finally made it to LED.  Since this is a standard bulb (PAR38 floodlight) you can have some smaller areas now (just one lamp in a fixture) and just put it above a large plant or a few small ones, no more having to do giant bulbs (or buy purpose built smaller setups).The best part is that it only takes 17 watts.  The thing is built like a tank, it is dimmable and has an expected lifetime of 15,000 hours.  Great way for growing plants indoors, starting them, or just in the longer winters that we have in the midwest.

This is truly an old style pop gun, and while it's made out of plastic and looks retro the price is still reasonable.  When we first got it, I thought you had to thread the 'cork' back into the end every time.  Then my three year old took it from me, pulled the barrel back out, and boom automatically reseated itself.  Both my three and five year old could make this pop although not always as loud as they wanted.There were a couple of pieces that come off, but we reattached it and added some glue and it was fine.  It gets played with pretty rough, and there are some cracking o the end of the barrel (the plug really goes slamming back in there if you pull back on it hard), but it hasn't affected anything yet.Good old time fun, for a new generation.

I've had a few of Epson's smaller portable projectors, and this is one of the best I've used.  The brightness has been bumped up this year, this specific one does 3200 lumens, which is a lot, easily viewable in a light room.  The resolution is 'only' 1280x800, which is a good size for presentations and it means it can also do 720p for showing movies and such (which it can easily do, but this is designed first as a 'business'/powerpoint projector).These projectors have had wireless for a few years now, and this one comes with it built in.  You can have it attach to a network, create it's own network, and then you can stream images/documents to the projector right from your laptop without a cord or even right from your smartphone.It's small, very bright, and the resolution is quite good (if you need to step it up, Epson offers a higher model yet that ups the resolution).  Some of the setup is a bit clunky (wireless connection) but overall it works as it should and provides great value.

This is a fun game, more of an activity than a standard game.  You get a string that you have to route between some objects, and then you send the kids (or even the adults) through it.  They touch it, and it goes off. Boom.  Kind of like a kids version of Mission Impossible, and using string/cord instead of lasers.Some things to note.  The string isn't all that long, so you have to get a small enough place with enough areas to clip on to make it challenging, and it's a little finicky to get the tension setup right.  So probably a setup for parents in a lot of cases, but once it's setup it can be fun for the kids to try to get through.

SPD pedals are the solid workhorse of clip-less pedals.  Tons of shoes are compatible with these, lots of cleat options, tons of pedal options.  These diamondback ones are quite nice, they are fully metal for good durability, have double sided entry, and still don't weigh all that much.Can be installed with a wrench (pedal wrench most likely although a normal may work as well) or using a hex key.  They are also compatible with the shimano cleats so you could transfer between those pedals as well (and the other cleats/pedals that are compatible that way as well).

While I'm not a huge fan of mixed Shampoo and Conditioner, and still prefer that kind of product, I really enjoy this product.  It's just so over the top, sleek white bottle, the shampoo/conditioner inside is metallic green (yeah, awesome I know).  The smell is also great, it's sweet yet spicy, somewhat of an over the top evening cologne, but it smells very good in my opinion.As a shampoo/conditioner it does seem to leave my hair a bit dry, but I still use it because it smells awesome.

While I'm not specifically looking for VGA from HDMI, I do want to use a Amazon Fire TV stick on my projector, the biggest issue being that I don't want the sound to go through HDMI, but instead to a separate speaker, connected via 3.5mm jack.  This adapter allows me to use the FireTV stick, convert it to VGA, plug it into the projector and then plug in a 3.5mm male to male cable to connect up the speaker.  A little convoluted, but it makes hooking it up work without too many issues.

I loved this book. It is a serious look at a serious problem facing the church overall. In the last few years some very destructive teachings blew through Christianity and now even denominations that stood firmly on sound conservative doctrines are falling for the most basic errors. The Bible itself is under attack from pulpits and seminaries.It feels like a gigantic bowling game in which lethal cannonballs are launched by the enemy every second, and churches fly in every direction like bowling pins. The church has always been under attack by the enemy down the centuries but this is suddenly expanding in frequency and intensity around the world.Sifting is a good word for what is happening. As the author explains this term is used as the process of separating good from bad, wheat from chaff. And as the author makes clear, this sifting is something God is doing to separate believers from unbelievers and to test and determine our loyalty to God and His Word.But it's not just churches, it is individual Christians, seminaries, so called Christian schools & universities. All who call themselves as Christian are being tested & sifted.This is a comforting & encouraging book to help Christians stay the course. As I've read it, I've been comforted by the fact it is happening to others—not just me, that God is in charge, and that this is something that God is allowing to refine my faith, to get me to straighten up in areas, to remain faithful in other areas. As I read the book I was challenged to be more consistent in my actions, I was happy to see the long view. And I’m encouraged to see how this fits into a prophetic profile that Jesus Himself foretold.In fact as the author explains, persecution for your beliefs means you are actually reflecting Christ to a fallen world. They hated Him, and if you are like Him, they’ll hate you too. It’s a badge of honour. And it’s a sign of His soon return!!!This book puts suffering and persecution in perspective from God’s long view, the big picture, and it’s helped me really rejoice in God’s hand working in things that really perplex me right now. Overseas the rise of Muslim terrorism is resulting in wholesale slaughter and persecution of Christians. Here in the west, there are the increasing attacks on Christians for holding the Biblical belief on marriage out in the workplace. It’s hard to be a baker, or a photographer or a florist or even a pizza place owner now for fear of what the militant arm of the politically correct movement will do if you don’t agree with them. The author helps us see why God allows this, and what it does for the church.For a start, you can now tell who believes the Bible enough to endure persecution. For years we have had comfortable pews in Christendom. If we haven’t lived in a Muslim country, if we grew up in the West built on the foundation of Judeo Christian principles--then it’s been comfortable to be a Christian. So comfortable it’s been easy to blend into the culture and have the culture blend into us.Within the church, there has been so much "culture creep" as the author calls it. Compromise positions!And now God is proposing a litmus test to see who the cultural “Christians” are versus the Bible Believing God Honouring Christians are.Turns out, they are the ones willing to put their lives on the line for the cause of truth. They are the ones speaking out against the erosion of freedom of speech and religion on the behalf of bakers, pizza makers and florists who have drawn a line they will not cross even under fierce pressure and the loss of their business and their life savings and their very homes! Horrifyingly in the Muslim world, Christian martyrs are dying daily for their faith in Christ.It's a time of testing over all the world and it's amazing and encouraging sometimes as we see these Christians take a stand for Christ.This same litmus test applies to our treatment of the Bible. Will we believe God, and His Word? Or will we water it down, cut bits out, make it comfortable and lose our Christian distinctiveness along with our way.We see the rise of the Seeker Friendly & Purpose Driven church structure which is more influenced by marketing methods than the Bible, and by its obsession on becoming relevant to the culture it is rapidly losing its biblical distinctive to be different, to be salt & light!!! We have the Emergent movement which likes to self identify as evangelical while attacking the foundational principles that evangelicals have clung to for generations.Gilley in This little church went to Market explains it this way; not many years after the liberals of the early 1900s "won" their war against the fundamentalists, their churches went into a decline from which they haven't yet recovered. If the church isn't offering anything significantly different from the world the church is unnecessary. The liberal church of that time marginalized itself by compromise with modernism.How is it different today?The emergent, seeker friendly, purpose driven churches are going lemming like over the same cliffs as the liberal denominations of the last century. Just with a little more panache from the cafe culture in the foyer. We now have Karl Barth version 2.0 with a latte and a side of jazz.What is going on? Christianity seems to be taking a suicidal leap into every possible error, many of which past generations recognized and combated by building solid doctrinal bulwarks to guard the flock. The biggest bulwark is the Word of God.The Bible itself is under attack. Genesis is chopped to bits by seminarians pontificating on the origin of man (was it God’s direct act or did He just set evolution in motion?). How about Noah’s flood that they call a local flood while Jesus and Peter refer to it as a total flood. The Rainbow Promise of God in Genesis becomes a lie if those liberal theologians are correct because God said He wouldn’t EVER send another world wide flood, and gave the rainbow as a sign of that promise. If the flood was local, then God lied, and we can stop right there. There have been many local floods since then. God didn’t lie, but the liberal theologians who chop the Bible into bits they like and bits they don’t want, THEY are the liars.Christians who take God’s Word seriously have no problem with God creating a single man and woman from whom we are all descended. Because if we weren’t all “in” that single male ancestor called Adam when he sinned then who sinned causing the fall of all mankind? If we didn’t all fall in Adam, then the Cross becomes meaningless. And just how big and powerful IS GOD anyway? Big enough to create a whole universe and then some, in a literal 6 day event or a somewhat powerful someone who has to use a little evolutionary help along the way. Think about it.  As Ken Ham so ably puts it, when we chop up Genesis and Revelation, the stuff in between loses all meaning and relevancy. The Bible is a whole message from God to us and we don’t get to pick and choose which verses to believe and which to ignore. They are all relevant.In the middle of all this sifting, we see different Christians being raised up with a public voice, often explaining why it is so important to follow God’s Word that they will lose their bakery, their home and their entire life savings. Preachers who are unafraid to preach a clear true message are raised up. Churches willing to stand on the Word of God are losing the compromised and gaining the believing who are ready to be part of a church that really believes the whole Bible.THE TRUTH gets preached.And the rest of us figure out where our allegiances lie!God is with us, no weapon formed against us will prosper. We are to go -- go into all the world, preach the Gospel, be salt, be light. Spread the Word. Be ready, with an explanation for the Hope that is within us.The battle is in our minds and hearts, we are literally casting down speculations and other high and lofty ideas that set themselves up against the knowledge of GOD.We do this by being in the Bible, reading it daily, meditating on it, praying daily. Abiding in the vine, means staying in relationship to our Lord. Conforming our actions and our beliefs to what the Bible says.We aren’t to save society, we are to confront people with their need for a Saviour, and when they believe, they change and society changes for the better as a consequence.When we get too modern and missional to preach the Word of God that makes people get mad or get saved then all is lost. We need to be missionaries who make people uncomfortable so that they are given a decision for or against God. The kind of evangelism that God commands is what transforms society around us. But we have to be ready to take a few knocks along the way.Mike Henderson takes a long view & sees an overall trend. This is a day of division, of sifting, of seeing who really is on the Lord’s side. And this is a very good book. I’m glad he wrote it, and I highly recommend it.

I happily give this a 5 star rating. Many reasons.Ron writes in a kind and even handed fashion. Preface and Postscript he reminds the reader to debate, not divide, and to remain charitable throughout. He wants to help us understand the viewpoints of others within Christianity on these large debatable issues, so that we are not just setting up straw men in order to knock them over or yelling over each other’s heads.Unwilling to divide over non-essentials of the faith, he still understands the debates and is able to give a generous thumbnail sketch of each position. However if you need ammo for your next big round of the pre trib post trib rapture or the dispensational versus covenant wars, this is just a sketch to acquaint us with the landscape on which the battles are being fought.Ron gives us his position in each of the debates, but frames the arguments well enough that people from other positions will feel quite comfortable in his descriptions of their positions. He outlines strengths and weaknesses of each position including his own.Each section deals with one of these 8 debates, and includes chapters on major points within each debate.I won’t review each chapter but I’ll finish with a quick look at debates 1 and 2 as an example.Debate #1: Should Prophecy be interpreted literally or allegorically? In that section for example he has 2 sub chapters entitled 1. The Hermeneutics of Bible Prophecy: Literal or Allegorical and 2. Covenant Theology versus Dispensationalism.In that first chapter Ron looks at how the church began to move from a literal interpretation to an allegorical one and why. He points out that this makes a BIG HUGE difference to how we see things like the millennial reign of Christ or whether Israel was replaced by the church.In explaining the literal position he quickly removes a common straw man argument. He explains clearly that the literal method doesn’t eliminate figures of speech, the use of symbols and parables. He explains how this is determined within a literal understanding. So glad he covers this as it is one of the most annoying features in any debate between these systems and takes up a lot of time often obliterating the actual arguments pro and con. He does this sort of straw man clearing up throughout the book.The second chapter deals with Covenant theology versus Dispensational Theology. He gives a thumbnail sketch of both classical and modified covenantalism, along with traditional, revised and progressive dispensationalism. All 5 use a literal hermeneutic for the basics of the faith but begin to differ sharply when it comes to prophecy.I wish I’d had this years ago. I had a dear friend who was and is firmly amillennial. If I’d had more of an understanding of the Reformed Covenant Theology that she was coming from, maybe I could have explained things better. As it is, we have never argued about it, merely agreeing to disagree and laughing over the possibilities of meeting in the Rapture.Debate #2 Are Israel and the Church Distinct in Bible Prophecy gets right down to something sweeping thru the church and that is the theological underpinnings of replacement theology. Dr. Rhodes does a good job of that, For more on that Hal Lindsay wrote a really good book, long since out of print that I have and recommend called The Road to Holocaust. I just bought Dr Reagans newest book The Jewish People: Rejected or Beloved which I hope is along those lines, but I’ve not delved into it yet.Later in the book such popular topics as when the Ezekiel invasion occurs, how Daniel’s 70th week relates to Revelation and whether we CAN identify Babylon or not.Ron Rhodes is a gentleman and a scholar. More important he writes well, and is easily understood. This isn’t something only a person with a theology degree can plow thru, this is something for ordinary Christians to enjoy whether they know anything about prophecy or not. Highly recommended.

Brief 37 page booklet by a great mind of the past. Brings clarity to an often confusing subject as this author so often can. Well worth reading at any price. Very helpful that Ironside put full Bible quotations that he uses to make his points so that the modern reader doesn't have to go back and forth to prove whether these things be so, as HAI sticks it right in there. This man is one of the ones who can make complex ideas clear and easy to grasp. Glad I got it, it's one to read over and over as different points will come out each time.I'm a grandmother of 3 and my own dear grandfather used to read and love Ironside. It is refreshing to be able to dip into these books on kindle and once again see how timeless this man's teaching is.

Worth what it costs at 99 cents. This is a very short article focusing on the minimalist wardrobe often touted by magazines as quintessentially French. Like others I'd like to see more, but for the money, it's one of the better 99 cent booklets on the subject.

It's OK. I enjoyed the tongue in cheek humour which was the best part of this book.As for a sociological look at being Parisian, Oliver Magny wrote a more interesting and funny take on Parisian habits as did Ines de la Fressange. Mireille Guiliano's series based on French diet have more insight into what makes "them" tick if the "them" you wish to observe or emulate is the mythical French woman.Most of the "outsider looking in" at Paris genre of books are better if that is what you want. Perhaps because outsiders whether American (Entres Nous by Debra Ollivier or Jennifer Scott's Madame Chic books or Anne Barone's Chic and Slim series) or British (Helena Frith Powell in All You Need to be Impossibly French) do a far better job of nailing down the Paris way of living. Those who live the life don't always see the bits that make them different any more than a compatriot can spot someone with their own accent.That said, it's worth reading if only for the funny bits and the absurd lists.The reason I didn't give it higher marks is a certain distasteful treatment of men. How to upset them or make them think you are having an affair seems pointless. If you are a grown up, and you love someone you don't hurt them. If you don't love them, then why waste your time and theirs. Move on. Don't hurt someone for sport. If they hurt you, Move on! Life is too short to waste on petty nastiness or manufactured drama. Too much of the book dwells there and even though it is tongue in cheek, it has a certain pre feminist feel to it dating back to a time when we judged ourselves on the basis of whether we could attract lots of men and preferably ones with bigger bank balances. Pointless and stupid.However the genuine fun stuff does outweigh the distasteful comments and overall the book was fine. Probably better to get from the library first to see if you like it enough to buy it.

I really appreciate this book in it's thoughtful measured approach to dealing with the curve balls life throws at a woman after 50. From rosacea to hot flashes, picking out the dress to wear at your child's grad or their wedding day. How to camouflage bingo wings or a buddha belly and other difficulties that erupt.Kim is open and candid about her challenges from her weight gain around her belly, her new jowls along with the hazards of divorce, changing careers and dealing with a sharply reduced budget.Her closet has to change, but there are new realities that she never imagined as a fashion editor and co author of the chic simple book series (which I liked very much too).As she moves through her closet, aiming for comfortable chic clothing that makes her feel good and doesn't blow the budget she explains how to bend what you have to fit your new reality. This isn't a checklist of must have clothes for the chic over fifty woman. But she does explain the new realities so you can figure out what looks best on your, in your life, with your body.I got this in kindle and in hardcopy. I prefer to mark up my books, highlight bits, make notes in the margins and this is a very conversational book that almost begs you to do that.The only irritant for me wasn't the references to "the alien" which is her pet name for her new buddha belly but rather the constant "grown up girl" phrase. I'm a grown WOMAN, and girl sounds funny to my ears. I own my age--58, my wrinkles, my sunspots and changed shape. I AM a grandmother, a wife, a mother and an in law. What I am not, is a girl. I bumped into that phrase a lot in a few other books written by American women about aging successfully so it may be a cultural thing. Where I live that is almost a put down, a way of demeaning a woman calling her a girl or girly.As for the "alien" I saw it as a metaphor that encompassed her physical age changes but also the alien bits of her new life-- divorced, living on less money, changed career and all that entails. I actually found it endearing and made me understand the book and the author better because age is alien. When we were younger we felt sure we would age better somehow, do it with more panache. We wouldn't let ourselves slide. Now on the other side of the divide, I look at Catherine Deneuve and love that she put on some weight, looks happier and more grounded than ever, and is still a classic beauty but more of a queen than a princess. At no time does she lose her regal bearing. Aging is a process of dealing with stuff that happens unexpectedly, sometimes overnight. Divorce, or death change life drastically and for most women we outlive the men we marry if the divorce stats don't get us first. That alien she deals with is ours too.

Best in it's class for learning about colours that flatter the individual, NOT just their "season". I remember the old version, this is new and even improved. I liked the older book, but this has a fuller more updated set of suggestions and guidelines.First off, the colour theory. She sensibly explains how that may not work if you fall in between. She is right, I've had consultants label me spring, winter and fall. Her suggestions on how to determine the tones and intensities of each colour help narrow down the range that will look best, not just OK. She explains how a high contrast person (pale skin, dark eyes and hair) looks better in high contrast colours and prints while a low contrast person (beige ivory skin and beigey blonde hair for example or pale milk chocolate skin and medium brown hair) looks best with low contrast softer prints and colour combos.Secondly her advice on the lines that will suit different figures are WELL illustrated, and come thru very clearly on my kindle version. If you are unsure of which wardrobe book will give you the best visual guide to the best lines for your shape, this is the best, even above the "Does this make me look fat" classic by Leah Feldon or "How Not to Look Fat" by Charla Krupp. And this book has way more good advice on other aspects of choosing a wardrobe that works for you.Another chapter worth the price of the book just on it's own is how to make minor adjustments either by tailoring or using sleeve rings (she explains those too) or just how you tuck things in to look your best. The models she uses are real life women not models, and they come with all their real life flaws and challenges. The before and after photos are VERY instructive. The tone is encouraging and inclusive. This is for women of all backgrounds, skin tones, finances and figures.Another section on home sewing which will help anyone planning to start sewing, or even taking clothes to the tailor.Third she includes a whole tutorial on scarf and pashmina tying. Again, very well illustrated on my Kindle.She also has sections on closet organizing, shopping, and care and maintenance of the clothing you have.Finally for the closet minimalists and Parisienne closet mavens (and you know who you are) she gives a quick tutorial on the capsule wardrobe concept, using the 12 piece model. She includes work, leisure and dress up capsules and explains how to think about your real life needs based on how much time you live in each category. The accessory capsules are another chapter I consider worth the price of the book just on their own.She finishes with a short section on travel which from my own experience is MUCH easier using the capsule concept. You truly can pack light but make multiple outfits out of a capsule wardrobe.

I just read all the way thru. LOVE this. It is an extension of her first Madame Chic book, with more in depth lessons on moving through daily life in a graceful comfortable way. I'm a fan of her writing, having bought her first self published book (the first Madame Chic before it got redone by a publishing company) then buying the edited and slightly more finished version of that book. YES it's worth every penny.Now this one. Well worth the wait. I'm her mother's age group, my dd is a married mother of 3, the first 2 being similar ages to Jennifer's daughters. Some things sound like my daughter, coping with daily life caring for small people and a husband, dog, house and a writing career. Busy young mother.But it's also a compendium of things it took me YEARS, DECADES to learn. How to care for oneself in the midst of happy family chaos. Setting priorities. Dejunking. Enjoying where you are at NOW, not being so goal driven that you fail to appreciate the small moments of bliss in the present.Well done Jennifer!This book will appeal to the francophiles but I hope it will have a broader audience because what she is getting at is universal and it's a toolbox as she calls it. One that leads to a balanced and contented attitude in the middle of life being lived realistically.Yes it's written through a ~"French woman who has it all together" ~ filter, but that is just the beginning. It's culturally applicable to most western lives, and it's speaking to the need for all women to attain balance between being caregivers and caring for themselves as well. Not being people pleasers but charting their own life path.There is a bit more California in this book, referring to positive affirmations (nothing wrong there) and Feng Shui but the French connection is woven across the entire book. One of the many things I enjoyed was her music recommendations in each chapter. So much fun mixed into the practical reality of organizing a coherent life.Love it, well worth getting, and I have the kindle version which I'm delighted to say has a great table of contents and a good easy layout with pleasant line art illustrating each chapter.

Couldn't put it down! Sharp biting wit, intelligent observations on all kinds of topics. Funny, witty and well worth getting. I really enjoyed her little snippets about famous names like Marilyn Monroe, James Dean, Marlon Brando, Elizabeth Taylor and other people she has known over the years.Her comments on manners, compassion for others as well as common sense concerns about such things as flying and traveling safely nowadays are not at all politically correct or censored in any way, and in my opinion completely true.This is a keeper from someone with a biting wit and the ability to tell it as she sees it, no self censorship or pc babble allowed.I particularly enjoyed her comments on skin care and weight although she is very blunt particularly when it comes to weight which is actually helpful if you want to lose it and keep it off like people used to be able to do in the fifties. This is not sugar coated, and it may offend modern sensibilities. She doesn't see weight as a disability but as an end result in changes in the food supply along with changing attitudes to portion sizes. Couple that with bad dietary advice based on bad science promulgated by the likes of Ancel Keyes and you have a whole planet of people attempting to eat healthy and gaining weight, acquiring Type 2 diabetes and worse. Gary Taubes has written plenty on this subject if this idea is new to you but Joan's observations line up with the research done in the last few decades.She hit the nail on the head when talking about pregnancy;. She tells what a dietician told her to eat for a healthy pregnancy, and it mirrors what I was told. Whole grains up the wazoo, never mind the effect all those "healthy" carbs have on blood sugar, fat storage and so forth. Unlike her, I did what the dieticians of that era said, and gained over 60 lbs while eating as ordered. Needless to say I didn't lose all of it, and the next baby added on. I wish I'd had her common sense and courage to stick to her own usual food intake plus some vitamins and call it a day.I did not find her harsh on people with disabilities, as another review stated. She is big on personal responsibility for your own choices such as food, but she saves her real wrath for able bodied people who refuse to give up a seat on the bus for pregnant women or the elderly or infirm. She blasts those who ignore people who need help, and those whose selfishness puts others around them at risk.Some sharp and pithy observations on reality TV and it's effect on children and society at large round things out.Love the book.

Lovely book BUT the table of contents is badly flawed. Links don't work. However the content of the book is marvelous so dealing with some of the formatting within the kindle version is well worth any extra effort. Along with the link problem with the TOC, footnotes intrude inside the chapters rather than at the end of the chapter or at the end of the book making it difficult to read smoothly. Modern publishers should be able to create a kindle version of a book without a hitch so the publisher needs to fix this. Oddly enough the sample for the kindle had a fully functioning linked table of contents.The content is amazing. This is a person with something constructive to say about grief and loss. She experienced it in the loss of her beloved husband and out of that, built a road map for others to help them get through the pain.This is more than a book about loss, it's about adapting to change. Life is full of surprises, some are nice, many are not but living involves adapting to change. Rebuilding, renewing, recreating our lives when things unexpectedly happen.I want this in kindle and paper versions. It's that good.I loved her first book, and have it in paper and on my kindle as well. Dolce Vita is a terrific book on discovering the joy of living. This is the sequel, recovering the joy of living. Dr Mautner speaks from her own Italian background to help modern people reconnect with reality. Life isn't a series of facebook entries puinctuated with tweets and snapshots, it is something to be lived. Wealth isn't money, it's the life well lived and that is more about appreciation of the ordinary rather than being able to afford extraordinary things. Raeleen is able to explain the difference to over scheduled, stressed out readers and remind them of a simpler way of life.Highly recommend it, just consider buying it in the paper version first, then if you feel you want it with you while reading on the kindle as I do, get a kindle version but be aware the TOC is flawed.

I wear computer glasses at work and distance glasses the rest of the time.  So I needed a glasses holder at work to keep whatever pair was not in use handy.  This Face Eyeglass Display is just darling.  I keep it on my desk right beside my computer screen.  I have had so many compliments on it.  Everybody notices it when they enter my office.The holder is well-made and heavy.  The glasses fit onto the holder by folding the sidepieces in, fitting them into the slot behind the nose and resting the eyeglasses' nosepiece on the figure's nose.  I have lots of sizes and shapes of glasses -- to me, since I discovered how to order my glasses inexpensively from the internet at sites like Zenni, glasses have become a real fashion accessory -- and every pair fits perfectly into this holder.If there is any drawback to this item, it's that the face and hand are very feminine-looking, so I don't know how much a man would like this holder.  But I think it's just great.

I ordered this bra because of all the positive reviews.  I suppose that it is possible that the size was mislabeled in the bra I received, but this is the smallest C cup I have ever encountered.  I ordered my usual size -- 40C.  The cup is so small that the underwire rides up from the bottom of the bra and part of my breast falls out.  It is hideously uncomfortable.Definitely not recommended. Ouch!

These are absolutely darling shoes.  Comfortable and stylish.  The chocolate brown comes with two sets of laces.  One set is cotton and matches the shoes.  The other set is a darling light pink velvet.  The soles are white.  The leather is not too soft, but it gives a little and was perfectly comfortable right out of the box.I do agree with another reviewer who said that the shoe is short in the toe box.  (Thank you, Varda.). When I read that, I ordered a half size up.  I usually wear an 8-1/2 medium width.  I ordered a 9 in the medium width and the shoes fit perfectly.  I wear them with a medium-weight cotton sock.  I matched the soles of this shoe with the soles of a pair of Sperry Topsider lace-up oxfords that fit me well.  They are size 8-1/2 medium.  This shoe matched it exactly.  So I would definitely advise you to order a half size up from your usual size.Otherwise, a stunning shoe, especially for the price.

This set of push pins makes a very nice presentation.  The butterflies are realistic and beautifully rendered.  This would make a nice gift for an office Secret Santa exchange or a little retirement remembrance or a nice touch on a dorm room bulletin board.  Anyone who has a bulletin board or a cubicle that uses push pins would probably like these lovely little push pins. The butterflies are each about two inches at their widest point.My daughters really liked them for their apartments and their offices.The price is excellent and it's an unusual set.

There is nothing wrong with Milo's Dog Treats.  They are good and my dogs love them.  But I am leaving this one-star review so that Amazon customers will be aware that some third-party sellers are ripping them off.Be sure you check the price per ounce you are receiving.  For instance, third-party seller Smile 'n Save sells this 2.7 oz. bag of dog treats for almost exactly the same amount of money that you pay for the 18 oz. bag of MIlo dog treats elsewhere on Amazon.  Plus, they charge half-again the price of the treats for shipping.  It's a total rip-off.  I also think it's deliberatly misleading.  Customers see two bags of dog treats -- the photos make the treats look like they are about the same size -- and the price is almost exactly the same.  But the flavor is different.  So they order both bags.  Only one bag is huge and the other is the size of a sandwich bag.Totally not cool.  Check the price per ounce.

I love this writing set.  I have purchased several for gifts.  It contains a Moleskine ruled notebook (192 pages, 3-1/2 by 5-1/2 inches) and a black ink pen.  The box is totally cool.  It's lightweight, but sturdy.  It looks like it's just black, but the front is covered with embossed words related to writing and traveling like "Write," Stories," "Imagination," "Lyrics," and "dream."  Inside the box is an expandable pocket. Both the box and the included notebook have elastic fasteners so that they will stay closed.The gift box with its little notebook and pen makes a really nice presentation.  But afterwards, the user can take out the black foam insert which holds the two included items in place, and then there is room in the box for more notebooks, pens, Post-Its, little souvenirs like stones or feathers or leaves, photographs -- and all in a very portable little box you can take anywhere.I have one of these sets I use myself and I have given them as gifts to friends who write or travel.  Very much worth the price.

This book is a bit difficult to learn to use correctly.  I was stymied when I first paged through it.  But I followed the directions set forth in the essay at the beginning, and am finding the book very useful.The book is organized by sound group.  So you don't use it as you would a thesaurus by just looking up which words rhyme with "square" or "testify".  You have to figure out where your word fits in the various sounds made by speaking the word aloud, and then go to the grouping and subgrouping which fits the sound.Do keep in mind that the rhyming sounds used are the British pronunciation.  So there may be some words suggested by the book which sound odd to American ears.

I ordered these gloves in both black and white to use in doing marionette shows.  They are cotton, seem well-made for the price, and fit my hand fine. I can also imagine wearing these onstage in a show like "Pippin" where every needs gloves for the opening number.  I have never been in a marching band, so I can't speak to how well they would hold up under that kind of use, but they are fine for my purposes.I wear a size 8 in women's gloves and ordered the size recommended.  No problems at all.Recommended.

It's actually kind of funny, because the reason I ordered this particular set of miniature books was because of all the bad reviews.  One reviewer said that they were thin and flimsy.  One said that two would fit on her/his thumbnail.  That's what I wanted.  Something that looked like a book (kind of) but would fit through the mouth of a very small vial.Unfortunately, this set is really quite nice now if you are planning on using it for your dollhouse or need a real-looking little book that is on the one-inch scale.  They look exactly like the photograph, the titles are readable and the covers are bright and colorful.  The set has the titles on the front cover and on the spine. I've included a photograph of the set as I received it this morning.  As you can see, my thumb is in the photo, and one of the books would definitely be bigger than my thumb nail.Really disappointing for me (I needed those really cheap teeny-weeny ones), but good for truth in advertising and those who want this set for the traditional purposes.Recommended.

I adore iced tea, but dislike having to go to all the trouble of boiling water to steep it.  This is especially a problem at work.  I saw these cold-brewed teas, and since this particular brand had all the good reviews, decided to try it.  I was tickled when it arrived today.Yuk!  Tastes like Kool-Aid, without the sweetening.  It smells pretty good in the box, but once you "brew" it, following the directions on the box (1 -2 bags per 8 oz. of cool water -- I used two bags per 8 oz. because I like my iced tea strong -- and steep for ten minutes.)  After ten minutes I had a pitcher full of colored water with a weak slightly-bitter artificial peach taste.  Really gross.Guess I'm back to boiling water and making my pitcher of iced tea with a combination of black tea and Constant Comment -- yum!I definitely don't recommend this product.  Now I'm stuck with four big boxes of it. Maybe I can use it as sachet in my kids' sock drawers or in between sheets in the linen closet or something like that.  It really does smell nice when it's dry in the bag in the box. Just don't drink it.Ewww -- just took another sip.  DOUBLE YUK!

I live in Sperry Top-Sider's.  I have the slip-ons in just about every color they make.  They are great in all seasons, and I wear them to work with dress pants almost every day.  They are practically indestructible.  You can wear them with socks or without.  Even with shorts or a skirt.  But they are a bit on the casual side.  So I needed a more dressy shoe to wear to the office on those days I might meet with my boss or make a presention.This Sperry Top-Sider Women's Bedford Oxford fills the bill perfectly.  The leather uppers with contrasting brown sole and stacked heel, and the fact that they are tie-up oxfords rather than slip-ons, makes the shoe a little more dressy.  The detailing is a modified wingtip pinpointing over the toe cap.  It's really cute.But the best part is that this pair of shoes definitely has the exact same Sperry style and comfort.  I wore them, straight out of the box, at an all-day meeting where I was on my feet the entire time.  They were just as comfy as my three-year old tan Sperry slip-ons.  I wear an 8-1/2 medium width, and that's what I ordered.  They fit true to size.I love these shoes.  Highly recommended.

I purchased this pet bed in the "Born to be Wild" cover when it was on an Amazon Deal of the Day.  I thought that it would be nice for my 12-pound Bichon.  I ordered the small size.I was very disappointed in the product.  It is simply an overstuffed bed pillow with a washable cover.  (I don't know through personal experience that the cover is washable because I didn't keep it long enough to wash it, but it is described as washable.)It is so overstuffed that my Bichon could not stay on the pillow, despite her best efforts.  She kept sliding off.  Plus, the small was too small for her.  She's a twelve-pound dog!If all you want is a bed pillow and a washable cover, go to Walmarts or Kohl's or any place that sells bed pillows, buy one for under ten bucks and put an old pillow case or sham on it.  You would have this very same product for about a third of the price.I returned this "pet bed" for a refund.  I do not recommend it.

I bought this sparkling water for my husband who does not like artificial sugar, but likes flavored water. Not easy to find.He thought that the taste of this water was good, but he said that packaging the water in aluminum cans made the water taste a little like "can."  He wished we could get the water in glass bottles.It did help a little with the "can" taste if I poured the water into a glass and served over ice.  But since my husband likes to drink the water on the go, he won't go to all that trouble.  So this product is not what I was looking for.  Too bad.

I don't know what is supposed to be "plush" about this pillow.  It's very flat and hard.  The covering is nice, but there is no loft to this pillow at all.  I was looking for a foam pillow which is shaped like a pillow.  This pillow is just like a large rectangular pancake.The photographs makes it look as though this pillow is thicker than it really is.If you want a pillow which is flat (maybe three inches thick), and hard, then this is the pillow for you.  But I didn't, and I don't like these at all.

Other reviewers are writing that they were disappointed in the small size of these tea-light holders.  But I needed a cylindrical vase to put in an display in my office, and these were the perfect size and shape.  I love the little glass holder at the top so that you can fill the bottom with fresh flowers or shells or colored sand.  These would be really nice table decorations at a wedding, shower, retirement dinner or anywhere you need a pretty grouping for a centerpiece.The glass is thin, kind of like a test tube you might have used in science class in high school back in the day.  But I have had no problems with mine.I really like these vases.  And the price is right!Recommended

This lovely one-hundred percent cotton bathroom rug is covered with soft nubby "popcorns" which are about the size of a garbanzo bean.  They cushion and massage your feet when you are standing on the rug to do your makeup or getting out of the shower.The rug is machine washable in cold water.  It doesn't shrink or pill.  The directions say to wash it with like colors or separately.  I washed it separately, and I did wash it in warm water rather than cold and had no problem.  It did not shrink.  You can't put it in the dryer.  Lay flat to dry.I have the "stone blue" color.  It's kind of a bluish slate gray.  It does go with my bathroom decor, which is in shades of olive green and tan.The rug is made in India and seems to be quite sturdy and well-stitched.  It does have a warning on it not to use it near sources of "ignition," but that would be true for any cotton product.The only reason I took one star away is that the rug has no rubber backing.  I put an inexpensive under-rug non-slip cut-to-fit matting down and then this rug over top of it.  (This is available in any variety store like Family Dollar or Walmart.)  But I would be afraid to use a rug on my bathroom floor which is not non-slip.  It's too easy to fall getting in and out of the shower.Otherwise, recommended.

The decade of the 1970s was a time of change for Paul McCartney as he broke off from the Beatles and from his long-time writing partnership with John Lennon and set out on his own.  This excellent biography by Tom Doyle follows the "cutest Beatle" as he forms the band, 'Wings,' deals with writing and creating on his own, and establishes a personal and a working relationship with wife, Linda.  The ups and downs of family life are intertwined with business set-backs and the tedium of the road.  But through it all, Paul McCartney is becoming the legend in his own right that he is meant to be.This fascinating book is a must-read for all Beatles and McCartney fans.

Lonely Planet is the go-to guide for those of us who like information about the road-less-taken, the tourist spot which is not overrun with tourists, the hotel which has good prices and is memorable because it's not a cookie-cutter replica of all the other hotels in the area.With clear text, excellent up-to-date information, lots of extras and suggestions for side trips and shopping, the Lonely Planet guides are always worth taking along on your next trip, or using to plan your next vacation.  The photos in the book are good, too.  As are the maps and directions.This particular guide which outlines thirty differerent "Best Trips" in the New York and New England area of the US is particularly helpful.  My husband and I used it when deciding what to see and where to stop on our vacation this past summer.Lonely Planet guidebooks are the first guidebooks I look to for the best in how to use my precious vacation time.Highly recommended

These push pins are really small.  They don't really convey the Loch Ness Monster when they are stuck on my bulletin board.  I was kind of surprised that they are so tiny.That said, they do the job -- they hold up papers to a cork board.  But I was hoping for more of a cute statement.

I have two dogs -- a Standard poodle and a Bichon.  They are pretty picky.  They won't eat Milk Bones or even chew on raw hide chews.  But these treats are something special.  They look and smell like miniature hamburger patties.  But of my dogs adore them.You could also use them for training tidbits because each pattie (which is about the size of a wrapped after-dinner chocolate mint) could be easily broken into quarters.Milo's Kitchen produces quality treats for dogs.  My dogs love the Grilled Burger Bites.  Enough said.

Scotch-brand tape is the go-to tape for most any use.  Scotch-brand has proved its reliability over many years of making quality products.  This product is equally useful.  This printed strapping-type tape is for shipping packages.  It is lightweight, but very strong.  The interesting addition is the fact that this particular tape has a message printed on it advising recipients to check the seal on the package before accepting it or opening it.This tape would be very useful for those shipping to military members, to commercial businesses, to sellers on eBay, even to those of us who might need to return an item which we ordered off-line to let the recipient know that the package was sealed securely when it was mailed.With the holidays coming up, and so many people and businesses shipping packages all over the world, this tape should be on everyone's shopping list.Recommended.

I am reviewing this book as a layperson who writes murder mysteries.  This book is clear, stunning in its presentation and an invaluable resources.  I can't imagine a home without this book.  It should be as useful and necessary as a dictionary and a thesaurus.The book is a coffee-table-sized guide to the human body.  It is clear and easy to understand.  You don't need any special medical or anatomical knowledge.  The visuals are tasteful and accurate.This book could be useful to parents explaining illnesses, injuries or sexual reproduction to children; teachers for classroom use science classes; fans of medical television shows and movies; or as a general guide for anyone interested in how their body works and what their internal structures and organs look like.Highly recommended

Most of the shower totes you can buy in stores are metal or hard plastic. They work okay, but they are not the handiest thing to pack if you are going off to college or moving to a new apartment. This roomy tote folds flat for storage or packing. It's washable and sturdy. You can see all of your shower stuff through the mesh sides and the water just runs out the bottom.  No muss. No fuss.Recommended.

Elnora Comstock, the plucky, resourceful heroine of this classic novel, first published in 1909, is a character who is still relevant and fascinating for today's readers.  "A Girl of the Limberlost" was one of my favorite books as a girl, and it was one of my mother's and my grandmother's favorites.  Like other timeless literary heroines who overcome great odds to achieve happiness (such as Anne of "Anne of Green Gables" and Jo of "Little Women"), Elnora is eternally fiesty, admirable and loveable.When the novel opens, Elnora is determined to attend the high school in a nearby township.  Her neglectful, sometimes abusive mother, Katharine, is equally determined to discourage her and ruin her dreams.  Elnora and Katharine live in a cabin on the edge of the great Limberlost swamp, a place of wonder and danger, located three miles from the township where Elnora wants to go to school.  The hard, cold Katharine is haunted by the death of her husband on the very day Elnora was born.  She blames her only child for the death of her beloved husband because her birth kept Katharine from having the strength to aid her husband when he was drowning in the swamp.On the first day of high school, Elnora's tacky clothes and inability to fit in with the snooty mean girls, along with the fact that she learns she will needs an unexpected amount of money for books and tuition leads her to brief despair.  But her own ingenuity, along with the help of a loving neighbor couple, Margaret and Wesley Sinton, solve some of Elnora's problems.I love the many intricate details in this book about Elnora's life in a rural early twentieth century world.  For instance, the Sintons purchase clothing and accessories so that Elnora can fit in with her classmates.  One article is a wonderful leather lunchbox which contains lidded dishes to hold small sandwiches, salad, condiments, dessert, milk, utensils and a cloth napkin.  The descriptions of the different foods which are used to fill this lunchbox, and how Elnora's lunches eventually play a part in her meeting some destitute children whom she ultimately aides, are just fascinating.Elnora is able to earn her way through school by her mastery of the natural world around her.  She collects moths, butterflies, old Indian relics, bird's nests, specimens of tree leaves, flowers and grasses, and then either sells them or uses them to teach classes in natural history to grade school children.  Her forays into the Limberlost, and what she finds there are described in loving detail.The characters in the book are also memorable.  How Katharine Comstock comes to change her outlook on life, and learn some hard lessons about the importance of motherhood and the real character of her dead husband is told with great depth of feeling.  But this is not a cloying or overly sentimental book.  These characters are very real and hold up very well to a twenty-first century reader's more sophisticated tastes.Even the romance at the end of the novel, between Elnora and a handsome lawyer from Chicago, who are brought together by their love of the outdoors, is believable by today's standards.  A deliciously malevolent and spoiled ex-fiancee who seeks to ruin Elnora's chance at true love is introduced, but all ends happily for everyone.I recommend this novel highly.  Gene Stratton-Porter was an important, prolific writer, and if you like this book, you should seek some other titles, especially "Freckles".  "Freckles" is the prequel to "A Girl of the Limberlost" and is also a wonderful story about a young man overcoming adversity and finding love.This review is for the Kindle edition of the novel, which contains the complete text and is available free for download to your Kindle, as the novel has entered public domain.  The novel is also available in paperback and hardback editions, some of which contain copyrighted essays and criticism.

Although the plot sometimes gets lost in the wonderful characterizations, this book is well worth reading. The main character is bitter, intelligent and funny. She is visited by a priest from the Vatican whose job is it to determine if this young woman is a saint.  So she dictates her answers to the priest's questions, and in so doing relates the story of her Italian ancestry and her West Virginia roots. These wonderful stories all eventually relate to her journey through life as someone who bears the marks of geography on her body (she has a world map tattooed on her body from birth in port wine stains) and the fact that many say that she is capable of healing.The author weaves fantasy, myth and fantastic storytelling to tell the tale of a woman who rises above her birth to breach the echelons of power and become more than she is.The story is at once fantastical and realistic.  The characters are true and fascinating. This author relates a tale which will reach into a reader's heart, and which you will find yourself pondering long after you have finished it.Highly recommended.

If your high school or community theatre group is planning a murder mystery in its next season, check this one out.  It's audience interactive, really funny and clever, and has a nice age range mix for its characters.The advertisements for this play say it is one of the most successful of the interactive murder mysteries, and I can see why.  Our group put it on during a summer city-wide arts festival and we had to extend the run because of its popularity.There are songs, too, which adds to the enjoyment.  The story is a spoof of film noir-type stories like the Maltese Falcon.  We had lots of fun and made a nice profit on our run.Highly recommended.

This iced tea brewer is easy to use. It makes one glass at a time.  You put bagged or loose tea into the filter and pour cold water into the compartment in the back.  It only holds about 8 ounces of water. There is no steeping. As soon as the unit heats the water (which takes a minute or so), the tea stars coming out into the glass you have set below the spigot.  The directions tell you to put a hot/cold unbreakable glass filled with ice to catch the tea.  But I just catch it in a plastic cup and add the ice later.Pros:  The water heats really fast.  The tea is tasty. The unit is easy to clean and is small and easy to store.  It turns off automatically when the water compartment is empty. You can reuse the tea once the water has run through it once.Cons:  The darned thing spits tea droplets everywhere as the tea is dripping out into your glass.  This is really annoying.  I have this unit at work, and we have a white Formica countertop.  I have to wipe up those tea spittles immediately or they stain the countertop.It doesn't come with a hot/cold unbreakable plastic cup to catch the tea, and one of those costs about ten bucks.  If you use a styrofoam cup, you have to brace it with something on either side (like the salt and pepper shakers) because the driving, splattering tea coming out of the spigot walks the cup right out from under the dripper.This purchase was an experiment for me. I was spending a dollar a day at McDonald's for a large unsweetened ice tea to last me the day.  Since I ordered this from the "damaged" list (something was supposed to be wrong with the packaging, but it was just fine), I only paid a little over $15 for it.  It has already paid for itself.  But I think I will try one of the units which makes a whole pitcher next time, and I hope it doesn't splatter all over the place during the brewing process.  It is a little tedious making just one glass at a time.

Set in West Virginia, this novel sets up the intriguing premise of how the lives of three best friends, all beautiful struggling single moms, would change if they hit the largest lottery pay-off ever and ended up with $100 million each after taxes.  Much of the plot set-up rings true as each deals with vindictive ex-husbands and baby daddies; staying grounded; fighting off the intrusive media and indulging in fabulous luxury items such as homes, travel, clothes and cars for themselves and their loved ones.This book focuses on 39-year old Ava and her love affair with super-hot NHL star, Cian.  The meet-cute is well-done, as Ava, letting off a little steam in a local dive, picks up the younger Cian, not realizing he is her son's friend who has traveled to West Virginia to hide out from his crazy supermodel ex-girlfriend at her guesthouse.The main problem is that the book is desperately in need of editing for grammar, syntax and language choice.  Within the first twenty-five pages, Ava "has went" somewhere or other at least five times. Word choices are re-used, sometimes three or four times in the same paragraph. Characters constantly "set" instead of "sit."  The author's poor grasp of basic English distracts consistently from her storyline and her characters.Another problem with the novel is that it is derivative.  Many of the situations and characters in the book are partially cribbed from similar story lines in other romance novels.  That's really too bad, because the novel contains enough fresh ideas in the author's choice of heroine and location that one can easily see the bones of a truly different entry in the romance novel cadre.  I was genuinely interested in how sudden wealth might affect these working class women and their ability to find HEAs. Unfortunately, although that is the book this author sets up, that is not the book this author chose to write.

I have to admit I chose this pocket filer because of the color.  I love pink.  It comes with a cardboard wrapper which advertises that the pink color is actually honoring breast cancer awareness, which is even better.The filer is made of sturdy plastic, scored with little raised lines and a handle on top, so it is easy to carry and feels nice in your hand.  The clasp does its job -- keep the filer closed.  Inside are seven clear plastic dividers, with tabs on top and a scored piece of paper to write topics so you can label the files.  The filer holds quite a bit of stuff -- I have been carrying not only files and papers in it, but notebooks and a daily planner.At first I did not like it that the top of the filer is permanently bent in a crook-shape so that it automatically folds over.  I thought it made the papers hard to get in and out of the filer.  But I found that the plastic is thick and sturdy enough so that I can bend the top back so that it lays flat while I sort through the files, taking out and putting in.  Then it goes back to its regular shape when you clasp it shut.I just don't see a downside to this nice filer.  It has no sharp edges and will certainly hold up better than cardboard or paper, especially if you have to carry it outside in inclement weather.  I suppose that the color may show the dirt, but it's plastic after all, so it should clean nicely with any all-purpose cleaner.  I'm going to order a couple more.  I hope there are more colors.Recommended.

These black Sperry Top-siders are really my go-to shoes with black slacks on days when I have to do a lot of walking (and running) for work.  Days when I teach classes.  Days when I travel.  Days when comfort is really important and I am just not going to spend the day wearing heels which make my feet ache.The shoes are sturdy, comfortable, fit true-to-size, and they last forever.  I must have twelve pairs.  But these all-black ones are so great for work.  And you can never find this particular color in department stores.  So ordering them from Amazon really makes sense in terms of getting the color you want, and in the little price break you get.  I always check for sales on Sperry Top-Siders on Amazon. You can get some excellent deals.Highly recommended.

Keep your Raisinettes, Brach's has always made the best-tasting chocolate-covered raisins.  The raisins are plump and juicy, the chocolate is creamy and they taste just like they did when you were a kid and your mom bought them at the store.  It's harder to find them at the store these days, but you can get them online.  I like to mix them with cashews, sunflower seeds, sesame sticks and a pinch of sea salt for a great gorp.  But they are wonderful just on their own. Sneak some into the movies next time you go.  You won't be sorry.All of the above still being true, be sure that you look for the best price for this candy on Amazon.  Just do a little calculation.  A 12-ounce package for around $9.00 is about 75 cents an ounce.  Twelve  6-ounce packages for around $28 is 38 cents an ounce.  When you can find this candy at a store, a 12-ounce package is four dollars or a little less.  Comparison shopping for this product is smart.

Let's face it, travel is not as fun as it used to be.  And undue hassle can take the joy right out of a vacation before you even arrive at your dream destination.  But Mr. Elliott has written a concise, well-organized guide to avoiding most of the hassles of travel so that you can actually enjoy not only your time at the beach, but arrive unstressed.Elliott gives lots of interesting inside information about how different processes work, like obtaining a passport, retrieving a lost passport, how the travel industry works, how pricing works and how to minimize the chances of something major going wrong with your trip.  With the cost of travel rising, and the worries of security always on one's mind, this book is a necessity for planning your next trip.Recommended.

This clipper has saved me a bunch of money in the few months I have had it.  It is heavy-duty and does not heat up unduly during grooming.  I am really lucky that the DVD which accompanies the kit showcases a Bichon and a Poodle being clipped.  I own a Bichon and a Poodle.  The Poodle (who is a standard and weighs 75 pounds) was a little more skittish than the Bichon.  I finally took him to a local pet washing facility where they had a very short tie, and clipped him in there (cleaning the basin out with a towel afterwards.) That worked fine.There is definitely a learning curve, and I got better the more I used the clippers.  I agree with the other reviewers who say to always use one of the plastic blade guards when clipping your dog.  Otherwise, even if you don't accidentally nip the skin, you are going to have a bald pooch.A quality clipper.

This exercise DVD is excellent for those already in pretty good shape.  But for beginners, take it slowly.  The exercises must be approached slowly or you will end up with pulled muscles or soreness.  But the directions are easy to follow and I liked that the hosts explained the exercises and made it easy to follow them.However, working up to their level of fitness is going to take awhile, and this is perhaps not the best DVD for a rank beginner.  That being said, I would recommend it.

I did not realize before I ordered this French press coffee pot that it would work better with coarse ground coffee.  I did try it with the regular coffee I already had, and got grounds.  So I ordered a small bag of Tim Horton's coarse ground, and it worked beautifully.  The directions (which are on the outside of the box -- so don't throw the box away until you figure out the coffee maker) say to use a bit less coffee than I like.  But I like my coffee on the very dark, robust side, so the second time I used extra.The pot is easily cleaned and holds up well to daily usage.  I have it at my office.  It makes an excellent cup of coffee.  I think it's especially nice for the price.

There are over 1600 reviews of this flannel sheet set (I ordered the 190 gram velvet flannel), and the average star rating is almost five.  That makes perfect sense to me.  I usually would not add my opinion in a review of a product which is already so well-represented by Amazon customer opinion, but I just had to make an exception here.  This is one excellent sheet set.I ordered the gray and the ecru colors in queen size.  Both are lovely heavyweight flannel (but not too heavy or stiff).  The sheets have deep pockets which fit well on modern mattresses, including those with a pillow top.  They wash like a dream in hot water, drying on high, with little or no shrinking, and no pilling.  They are warm, cozy, easy-care and feel like a sheet costing a lot more money.  Such excellent value for the price!Have a gift-giving occasion coming up like a wedding shower or housewarming?  These would be perfect.Highly recommended.

For an author who is attempting to write a Bible-themed fanfic of "Pride & Prejudice" told from the point of view of a born-again modern Mr. Darcy, Ms.Helm certainly is not displaying much Christian charity to her readers.  This book is being marketed and sold as a "trilogy."  But a trilogy is a set of three books which, although they fit together, each volume stands on its own as a finished work.  This book is part of a serial, if the author finishes it.  It stops dead in the middle of the plot, practically in the middle of a scene, and leaves the reader hanging until Ms. Helm gets around to writing the next chapter.  Nice for her bottom line, but a pretty dirty trick to pull on her readers.Helm actually has some interesting ideas in this snippet of a novel.  A guy named Will Darcy from the 21st century magically changes places with the character of Fitzwilliam Darcy from the novel.  But interspersed is a bunch of witnessing and Bible thumping which is clumsily forced into the plot.  However I might have been able to stick with it if this book was a real book and not just the first third of a book.Shame on this author for tricking Austen fans into paying for three books when she is only writing one.

This the best of any of the P&P fan fiction I have read which is actually set in the period and retells Lizzy and Darcy's story.  (For fiction which concerns Austen, but is set in the present, my favorite is Shannon Hale's "Austenland.").This story starts with the iconic proposal at the Collins parsonage in Kent, but in this version, Lizzy accepts Darcy's initial proposal.  The author has written a lively, interesting alternate-universe version of how the couple would have interacted, and how all the main characters would have reacted to Darcy's rash choice of wife.Since the reader is expected to know all of the history which has come beforehand (such as Darcy separating Jane and Bingley, Mr. Collins' proposal to Lizzy, and Lizzy's attraction to Wickham), it's rather fun to see how it all plays out to arrive at about the same conclusion.  The author has added some additional information about Mrs. Bennet, Wickham, and even Anne de Borgh, which is quite in keeping with what we already know, but is rather delicious, all the same.  I also liked seeing Mr. Darcy just a little more love-struck, although he is very much his reserved self.I applaud this author for keeping the language and customs in the proper period while giving Austenites a really nice alternative story to savor.  If you enjoy Austen alternative fan fiction, this is a wonderful read.Highly recommended.

I have fine straight hair, but it's thick.  I wanted a product to give me body and make my stick-straight hair look full and lush.  I figured that a product called "Plumping Whip" would do that.  But no.  The only thing plump about this stuff is the price.This is not one of those really thick pastes or clays.  This jar contains a white product which is about the consistency of yogurt, maybe a little thinner.  The jar holds 2.82 ounces.I really gave this product a chance.  The directions say to apply a "walnut-sized amount" to the roots of towel-dried hair, and then heat style.  Walnut-sized?  Okay.  So a walnut like with its husk on, like in the bowl at Christmas time?  That would be about an ounce, right?  So that means that this little jar only holds about three applications? That didn't seem right, but I forged on.  So I applied that much to my freshly-shampooed hair and styled with a blow-dryer.  What I ended up with was a gooey, sticky mess.So I thought, it must mean a shucked walnut.  I shampooed again and tried about half the amount I tried before.  Again it took forever to dry, and my hair still felt sticky.  But the worst part was that even though it felt kind of gross, it wasn't even full-looking.  It was flat.I gave it one more try. Thinking I was still using too much product, I shampooed again.  This time I used a dollop about the size of a malted milk ball.  It didn't take as long to blow dry this time and the stickiness factor, while still a little bit of a presence, was not too bad.  But where is the plumping?  There's no plumping.  It's just flat, flatter, flattest.  I tried putting some volume into my hair with a curling iron, but the "plumping whip" had made my hair too slick to curl.  I had to add some mousse before the curls would take.So this little jar ended up right where it should be: in the trash can.

Although this memoir of life as a professional caddy at three or four of the larger golf courses/country clubs in the country is ostensibly about golf, there really is not enough written in depth about the game itself to satisfy a real golfer.
