The author often strays at length into side issues with his girlfriends, even including some sex scenes which might turn off a person who has picked up this book to look closer at activity on the links, not activities in the sack.The book is just not written in enough detail for a real golfer, and so the real golfers in my family who read this book said that their interest lagged about a third of the way in, and they struggled to finish the book.The book is well-written and the author is an engaging personality, but a book about life as the companion and advisor of golfers may be expected by many readers to focus on that subject. And this book just doesn't really do that.

My college-age daughter has dark brown hair which she has professionally dyed platinum blonde.  She wears it in a cute short spiked-type style which she achieves by blowing dry and straightening.  And as an active young woman, she sweats and washes her hair often, sometimes even twice a day.  So her hair goes through a lot.She has been using this deep conditioning mask for a month now.  She says it's the best product she has ever used to keep her hair soft and shiny, and to help protect against split ends and dry scalp.  She says that the mask is easy to use, and she likes that it has no scent.  She says that she likes wearing her perfumes, and doesn't like her hair products to interfere with their scent.  She uses the product just about every time she shampoos unless she is really pressed for time.  She says that her hair has never looked better.  She asked me to send her the Tresemme Renewal Shampoo and more of this conditioning mask before she runs out, so I know that she really likes it.  It may be a tad pricy for a college student's budget, but for what it does, I think the price is worth it.Recommended.

This product works, and I really tested it before I wrote this review.I have tried skin “primers” before, most recently from Mary Kay and from Clinique.  The purpose of a makeup primer is to apply a kind of undercoating to the skin so that one’s makeup looks better, kind of like paint primer prepares a wall for the final color.  These makeup primers tend to be expensive, and I did not see any noticeable difference or improvement in my makeup after using the two brands I mentioned.  In point of fact, my makeup tended to fade and become “patchy” after about eight hours with the Mary Kay product.  However the theory behind these products appeals to me, so it was with extremely cautious optimism that I tried this “Water Canvas Base Primer” by Vincent Longo.I am a middle-aged professional woman who wears a full makeup to work every day.  I am a normal weight and have combination skin, tending toward dryness and flakiness.  In my youth I had very oily skin and acne.  I have no acne now, but I have large pores, especially around my nose and on my cheeks.  I am fair-skinned and, although an outdoorsy person, have been religious about sunblock.  So I have very little wrinkling, although I do have crow’s feet and fine lines around my eyes.  Without makeup, my skin is most dry on my forehead and chin, and a little mottled-looking with a few light age spots.My makeup routine is as follows:  Every morning I cleanse with Estee Lauder skin cleanser for older skin,  moisturize and then apply a medium-weight full coverage foundation.  I dab a concealer under my eyes.  Then I put on powder blush, and the usual eye makeup. I use a eye crayon for lining my eyes.Following the directions for this product, I first cleansed and moisturized with my regular products, then I put a “pearl-sized” drop (probably about the size of large pea) of the Water Canvas on my finger and dabbed it on my forehead, cheeks, chin and down my neck.  Then I used a light touch to spread the Water Canvas over my entire face, including under my eyes.  The product feels a little waxy, but spreads easily and is not heavy or greasy.  I did wait about a minute to let it “set” before I applied my foundation and the rest of my makeup. (The directions do not say you have to wait for the product to set, but other primers I have used have had this direction, so I figured it couldn’t hurt.)First day.  Before I removed my makeup off after about twelve hours of wear, I looked in a magnifying mirror.  My makeup looked very good.  It had not faded or settled into the lines around my eyes.  The eye crayon liner was a little smeared, but that’s normal for me.  My pores appeared smaller.  But I wanted to be sure.Second and Third days.  I applied my makeup the same as usual, but I used the Water Canvas only on one side of my face.  Second day, the right side; third day, the left side.  On the opposite side of my face, I used moisturizer and foundation only, no primer.  At the end of each day, I studied my face in a magnifying mirror.  On both days, on the side WITHOUT the Water Canvas, makeup had settled into my pores, making them seem larger.  The fine lines around my eyes were not as affected as my pores.  But my under-eye crayon liner and concealer stayed on a little better on the Water Canvas side, and there was no settling of concealer or powder into the fine lines.I am sold on this product.  It works.  It really does make my makeup look better, and stay fresher longer.  Most everyone's makeup looks fine when it's first applied.  The test is how it looks after eight hours at work, then grocery shopping, exercising the dogs and horses, cooking supper, and reading or watching television with my husband before bed.  At eleven o'clock at night, Water Canvas under my makeup makes it look pretty much as good as it did when I applied it in the morning.  I will be purchasing this product again.Highly recommended.

If you like your romance meandering and pretty much PG-rated, then Shannon Stacy's Kowalski Family and their lives, loves and minor tribulations may be for you.This entry is about Liz Kowalski, who has been living in New Mexico, mainly supporting her artist-wannabe loser boyfriend.  After kicking her nowhere relationship to the curb, Liz decides to move back home, to Whitford, Maine where she grew up in a large, loving family.  The family business is a lodge which caters to sportsmen, hunters and ATVers.  Liz takes a job at a diner owned by her sister-in-law, and rents a house from another family member.The hero of our tale is Drew Miller, Liz's older brother Mitch's best friend.  Liz and Drew grew up together, but beyond that, they share the guilty secret that they hooked up for a quickie at a family wedding eight months previously.  Drew is the chief of police in small Whitford, and is divorced from his high school sweetheart who lied to him about wanting kids.  Drew wants to be a father.  Liz isn't sure what she wants to be, but she is trying to find out.Slowly the hero and heroine are pushed together during family outings and they discover that they have a real connection beyond that one-time quickie.  But Liz is worried that all Drew really wants is a baby mama, and Drew is worried that Liz is too unstable to commit to being a wife and mother.This book is very slow-moving.  And it is quite repetitive.  In the first hundred pages, both Liz and Drew agonize about Liz's brother finding out about their sexual peccadillo at least twelve times apiece.  And really, what's the big deal?  Both are in their 30s, and it's none of Mitch's business if Liz and Drew want to have sex any time the opportunity presents itself.  The way Liz and Drew talk about Mitch finding out about that wedding quickie makes everyone involved sound like they are in high school.  It's a non-issue, or should be.The characters in the book are likeable, and the ending is predictable, but not very satisfying.  Nothing is really resolved in any interesting or clever way.  If you have been following this family, and like this kind of gooey-sweet romance, then this is the book for you.I will pass.

Excellent tale about a half-breed Indian who was raised by a rich white ranching family, and is now running his own spread nearby, who tries to help a young woman escaping from a forced marriage to a disgusting older man. Ironically, she is caught at the hero's place, and a mob forces them to marry, and then attempts to kill the half-breed.  It's a horrendous scene, difficult to read.  But out of all this violence and heartbreak comes a really terrific love story about two people who decide to make a marriage work.One of the things I love best about the book is that the author obviously knows a lot about horses and horse training, so all of the details about the horse breeding and training operation the young couple is running is told with authenticity.  If you are a horse lover as well as a romance reader, this book is for you.I hope Ms. O'Connell continues to write such high-quality work.  I just sort of stumbled on this book, and I'm really glad I did.  It's a keeper.

I have purchased all of the previous books in this series, and a couple are on my keeper shelf to be re-read.  I especially love the paranormal romance, "Whispers in the Dark" between the imprisoned, tortured Nathan and the telepath/empath, Shea.  Lovely story and lots of action.  So what happened here?  This is Donovan's story, and it should have been first-rate, but it's just awful.The premise is good.  Rusty, the former runaway teen adopted by Dad and Ma Kelly who has blossomed into a gorgeous college student is running the Kelly hardware store while on summer vacation.  She hires a 15-year old boy, Travis, who reminds her of herself at that age, and whom she figures is in some kind of trouble.  Turns out her instincts are correct, and Travis has a beautiful older sister, Eve, and a sweet baby sister, Cammie, who are on the run from something horrible and living hand-to-mouth in a broken down trailer outside town.  Cammie is sick, and Travis is trying to earn money for medicine and food while Eve stays home to nurse Cammie.  Soon hunky Kelly brother Donovan is on the case, and there is immediate attraction between he and Eve.  So far, so good.But the story goes downhill so fast.  After an exciting chapter about a tornado which allows the little trio-in-trouble to be moved into Donovan's house on the KGI compound, nothing really happens.  The book is endlessly repetitive, the sex is boring and both Eve and Donovan are sort of icky as the heroine in trouble and her savior.  There's a quasi-plot about an evil stepfather chasing Eve and her siblings, but it's sort of glossed over so that Banks can relate page after weary page of Donovan saying that he loves kids and wants a family.  And not just any family -- THIS family.  But why?  Who are these characters?  Who cares?I LOVE Maya Banks' books.  I have read not only this series, but most of her other work also, including the really erotic BDSM stuff.  She has never disappointed me before.  But this book is dreck after the first forty pages.  I gave it an extra star because I hope that this is an anomaly for Banks.  I really hope she takes a vacation or something and gets her mind back in the game.  Wherever her mind was when this was written, it wasn't on creating a credible book.  Really sad.

Keep your Raisinettes, Brach's has always made the best-tasting chocolate-covered raisins.  The raisins are plump and juicy, the chocolate is creamy and they taste just like they did when you were a kid and your mom bought them at the store.  It's harder to find them at the store these days, but you can get them online.  I like to mix them with cashews, sunflower seeds, sesame sticks and a pinch of sea salt for a great gorp.  But they are wonderful just on their own. Sneak some into the movies next time you go.  You won't be sorry.All of the above still being true, be sure that you look for the best price for this candy on Amazon.  Just do a little calculation.  A 12-ounce package for around $9.00 is about 75 cents an ounce.  Twelve  6-ounce packages for around $28 is 38 cents an ounce.  When you can find this candy at a store, a 12-ounce package is four dollars or a little less.  Comparison shopping for this product is smart.

If your daughter or granddaughter doesn't like carrying a large purse, or needs a little purse for a night out, this is just the thing.  i bought it for my college-age daughter for Christmas.  It is so different. She adored it.  It is well-made and nicely priced.  It is just the thing to hold an ID, credit card, some cash and a compact and lipstick.  Or it could be used as a wallet in a larger bag.  Really a nice gift.Highly recommended.

I ordered this darling wristlet for my teenaged daughter for her birthday.  She loved it.  It is so unusual, attractive, nicely made and different.  I have never seen anything like it in a store.  It is just large enough for an ID, credit card, cash and some makeup for a date night or running to the store.  This model is especially cute because it is dyed as though the caterpillar has eaten part of the bright pink leaf.Highly recommended.

I needed a lamp for a dark corner which would provide atmosphere.  This is my lamp.  It's about 3 - 1/2 feet high, and it clicks on easily just by tapping my toe on the switch which sits on the floor.  The light is diffused and soft.  The shade is crinkled, but seems more durable than paper.  I really like it.  It adds a nice bright touch to my decor.Recommended.

For the money, this is one nice headboard.  It looks terrific, comes in a plush taupe color which would fit with lots of different color schemes, and is easy to assemble.  It comes with all the tools you need.  The cover does come off for washing.  I love it.

I ordered this leather wristlet for my college-age daughter for Christmas.  She adored it.  It's a perfect size for an ID, credit card, cash and a lipstick.  It is well-made and very different.  Cute, flirty, eye-catching, fashionable.  And reasonably priced.  I'm going to order one for myself.Highly recommended.

If you are a fan of Maya Banks' KGI series which features erotic romance, super hot alpha male military-type heroes and lots of fast-paced action, then it would seem that Laura Kaye's new "Hard Ink" series would be your cup of tea.  By its back cover blurb, it certainly seems as though that is the audience that Ms. Kaye is courting.  Unfortunately she has not hit upon the right mix of elements in her first entry of this series, "Hard as it Gets."  There's too much grit and crime investigation procedural and not enough romance and sex.Nick Rixey, a disgraced former Army Special Forces soldier, owns a tattoo shop (Hard Ink) with his brother, Jeremy, in Baltimore.  Rixey is one cranky dude because he was not only wounded in action, but he was betrayed by a trusted officer and forced out of the service with his Army record besmirched, along with four other survivors of a horrific ambush in Afghanistan.  So when beautiful nurse, Becca Merritt, walks into his shop asking for help in locating her brother who may have been kidnapped, Nick is less-than-welcoming.  Especially since Becca and her brother, Charlie, are the children of Rixey's ex-commander.  But Rixey's better nature prevails, and soon he, Becca and the four surviving members of Rixey's old outfit are up to their ears in some far-ranging conspiracy which seems to involve organized crime, drug dealing, the Army, the Baltimore police and maybe the US government.Ms. Kaye is a good writer, and this book moves along well.  But it is unclear just what audience she is writing for.  If she wants fans of Maya Banks, there's not enough romance and sex.  If she wants fans of Lee Child, there's too much female angst on the part of the heroine over her "relationship" with the damaged hero.I also have a problem with the way that the book ends.  I don't want to spoil anything, but the problem is that there really is no ending.  Even though each of the KGI books involves a romance and a fast-paced thriller plot with characters already established, each is a stand-alone book.  You don't have to read them in any certain order to understand them.  Same with Child's Jack Reacher books.  But this book just sort of piddles off at the end and sets you up for the next book in the series. The conspiracy it sets up is not solved.  I don't like that.  That just seems lazy and sort of greedy on the part of the author and her editors.  I can see love stories for all of the "Hard Ink" heroes who are introduced in this book, but they also need their own plot lines, not one plot line that all of them share.If you start the series and like it, you have to figure that you are in it for at least five more books in order to figure out the entire conspiracy/mystery plot started in this book.  The next one comes out in March, 2014.  I'm going to pass.

I admit that "The Taming of the Shrew" is my favorite guilty pleasure Shakespeare play.  It's so sexist, even abusive, by today's standards.  But the Elizabeth Taylor/Richard Burton movie is one of my favorite movies, and the battle between the headstrong Kate and the overbearing Petruchio is deliciously gratifying.That being said, I adore John Cleese, a Monty Python alum who was just magnificent in "A Fish Called Wanda."  I have always found him sexy, and I thought I would love him in this role.  But no, something is just off in this undertaking of "Shrew."  Cleese comes across as mean and callous, not as a man who is secretly in love with Katherine (as I always want to believe.)  Perhaps the casting of Katherine undermined the production.  The actress who plays her has the acting chops, but is not particularly pretty or sexy.Anyway, this production did not gel for me, and with deepest regret, I cannot recommend it.

My husband drinks at least five pots of tea a day, so this cup was for him.  I like that it is a different design.  The design is attractive, and really does insulate so that you do not burn your fingers when you pour in the hot liquid.  It does do beautifully in the microwave, and it despite the fact that the design is made of some kind of fabric-like material, it also comes out of the dishwasher as good as new.The problem I see with it is that it takes some getting used to.  Most people expect a handle on a porcelain mug, and some who are experiencing this mug for the first time might feel as though it is not very secure in their hands.  But it is along the same lines as a cup of hot liquid you would get from Starbucks (no handle there either), so I would just warn people the first time you hand it to them to be careful.The mug is a bit on the expensive side, although on the webpage the different designs you can get on the entire sets of the dinner ware are intriguing.  A set of these might make an unusual wedding or shower gift.I liked the mug, and it is easier to store in the cupboard than the mugs with handles.  I may purchase a few more so that tea drinker in our family can have his/her own.

I like Kristan Higgins' books, and have read quite a few of them in the past.  This is not one of her best.Honor Holland, who works at her family's winery in the Finger Lakes district in New York, is unlucky in love, to say the least.  She's 35 and when the book opens, she is being told by her doctor that her eggs are getting older and she should start thinking about having a baby if she is ever going to have one.  That sets up a funny bit all through the book where Holland's "eggs" send her hilarious chiding messages about choices she makes concerning men.  I liked that part of the book, and I liked Honor.  She a decent, self-deprecating, smart and sexy heroine.Honor has had an friends-with-benefits relationship with the love of her life, Brogan Cain, for seventeen years.  She decides to propose matrimony, and is rejected.  Two weeks later, Honor's supposed best friend, a really unlikeable character named Dana, is engaged to Brogan, and Honor is told in public about the engagement and ends up having a truly cringe-worthy catfight with Dana in their neighborhood pub.So Honor, desperate for a suitable baby daddy, meets the nephew of her grandmother's long-time friend, a Brit named Tom Barlow, who needs to marry in order to secure a green card. Tom wants to stay in the US because he is attached to his dead fiance's really horrendously unlikeable teenaged son, Charlie.The book is about the growing attraction between Tom and Honor, Tom's relationship with the sullen Charlie, and Dana and Brogan's weird romance.I think what turned me off about the book are the characters of Tom and Charlie.  Tom is just not that nice a person until the very end of the book.  He is supposed to have a sense of humor which manifests itself in teasing and smart remarks, but they come across as sort of mean.  I know that Charlie is probably a really true-to-life character in that he treats everyone so badly and makes every feel bad even when they are trying to help him, as disaffected fourteen-year old boys are wont to do.  But I don't read romance novels for their angst value (at least not in the secondary characters) and I found Charlie hard to swallow.The ending is a bit rushed, and I didn't really buy into Tom's falling madly in love with Honor.As always, Higgins' writing is good, and she makes her books interesting and detailed.  But this one just didn't do it for me.

I love how fast this curling iron heats up. I also love that it makes such interesting patterns in my hair.  I found that I could use it not only for crimping and waving, but for straightening and flipping the ends of my hair.The design of the iron makes it easy to hold, and manage.  My daughters especially loved it for their long hair, and have created some really cute hairstyles, even up-dos.Well-made and sturdy.  Recommended.

I tried this curling iron on my stick-straight hair.  I especially love the variable setting, and the design of the iron.  It is easy to use, and doesn't fry my hair.  I found that I could use less product in my hair because I could be more precise in making the curls.I had trouble keeping this curling iron in my bathroom because my teenage daughters kept borrowing it.  Their hair is much longer and thicker than mine, so they also liked that they could control the temperature settings so precisely.Highly recommended.

The true story of what happens when a hippie-type city lady moves to really rural West Virginia and begins life anew as a farmer.  By turns hilarious and heartwarming.  I especially identified with the author's descriptions of the long unpaved road (which runs through a creek) and makes accessing her property a true challenge in rain, snow or ice.  I have been on those kinds of roads, and they are quite memorable.The book takes the reader through the author's search for a farm with her boyfriend (who is older, and with whom she has a rather rocky relationship), her hardships and triumphs in such tasks as raising chickens, cows, sheep and a large garden, and her interactions with her sometimes odd neighbors.  The tone of the book is self-deprecating and irreverent.  I liked this woman and wanted to know more about her.

This foundation will change your mind about drug store makeup. I'm kind of a snob about foundation.  I can buy blush, eye shadow, mascara, even powder in the drug store, but I have never thought that drug store foundation was as good as the expensive stuff I purchase in the department store at the cosmetics counter.  But this is a really fabulous foundation.I ordered the Light Shade, and it goes on beautifully.  But most makeup does that.  It's what happens after eight hours that tells the tale.  This foundation holds up very well to my working day.  It doesn't fade or change color.  It isn't cake-y.  It takes blush and powder well.  I just really like it.I am a middle-aged woman with combination skin.  I still get a pimple or two once in awhile, but I also have dry patches.  This makeup covers, stays on for the long run and works well with my skin texture.  It doesn't settle into my crow's feet, and doesn't cake up around my mouth or neckline.I am very impressed, and would match this product against a department store foundation.  Highly recommended.

I know that since there are almost 2000 reviews of this book, adding my two cents is overkill.  But I just wanted to say that this is one of the most fascinating, original books I have ever had the pleasure of reading.  The book is part-fantasy and part-time-travel and part-artistic wonderment.  It's like a sideshow attraction for intellectuals.I can only echo two things which other reviewers have noted:  Please do yourself a favor and purchase this book in hardcover.  The photographs and letters are an integral part of the story and will be best seen in the hardback version.  And please put your order in now for this wonderful author's sequel, due early in 2014.  I can't wait.Recommended without reservation.

These sunglasses are very comfortable on my head. They are dark so they really block the glare from the sun when I wear them. I love the style of them and how they fit my head. They are plastic so you need to be cautious not to scratch the lenses but other than that, I think they are just as nice as more expensive sunglasses.

I have always had weak nails. Every time they grow beyond the quick, they become weak and brittle. I have never had a nice set of nails unless I use acrylics and the minute they pop off, my nails split. This Probelle Nail Hardener, so far has made my nails feel stronger. I work in retail and spend the day at a cash register sliding items over a RF scanner and bagging them. Some, like gallons of milk and cases of beer are heavy and my nails break when I handle them. Since I have used this nail hardener this week, I have not had a nail break. I will have to see what happens when my nails actually grow longer, but so far so good. I love the way even when it is dry, the nail hardener makes my nails have that wet shiny look. Eventually I am going to also use it as a top coat over nail polish to make my nails shine more. I received this Probelle Nail Hardener at a greatly discounted price for my review, but all opinions are my own.

7:16 MinsThese markers are a great way to individualize your wine glasses. They are fine tipped and are easy to apply to any glassware. You can use them on glasses, mirrors, and even windows. It says on the package glazed ceramic so I would think coffee mugs would work too although I have to say I have not tried it. I can see a table set up with wine glasses and markers so guests can make their wine glass all their own. When the party is over either hand wash each glass or put them in the dishwasher and they are ready to go for your next big event. I received these markers at a discounted price for my review but all opinions here and in my video are my own.

This scarf is absolutely beautiful. I love the coloring of the yarn and how well made it is. It has all the appearances of being handmade. It is very soft and can be worn long in a single loop, or I can double it up so that it is shorter and warmer around my neck. The blue color looks great with my jean jacket or my black leather jacket. This scarf can be worn with blue jeans for every day or with a nice wool coat and hat for a night out. Either way it looks great and keeps me very warm. I received this scarf at no cost for my review but that in no way influences my opinions.

5:08 MinsThis is a cute little coloring book that has many different goddesses. It has 30 different illustrations that have intricate designs in them. I love that each goddess is pictured and has her name and a bit of her history in the description below. There are goddesses that are familiar like Isis, Athena, Gaia, and Venus, but there are also lesser known ones like White Buffalo Woman and Mawu. Goddesses from different cultures like Inca and West Africa are depicted and teach about different culture's folklore.This book is a little smaller than I had anticipated, but for the price I paid, it is a good value. I think this book would be good for older girls around the 9 year old age bracket and up. Of course, it is also good for adults too. I am very happy that I decided to buy this one.

7:18 Mins I am a huge nature lover and animal advocate. Each page of this book has an intricate nature inspired drawing to color and words of wisdom from great authors like Ralph Waldo Emerson and Ghandi on the opposite page. It is a great way to unwind from a hard day and release your inner Picasso. I can unplug from the internet and cell phone and tune in to my inner child. I put on some nice calming music, like the Miles Davis jazz in my video and lose myself in coloring these great illustrations. I also love that 10% of my purchase price will go to animal rights and other important causes. It is a total win win situation as far as I am concerned. I was very happy that I was contacted to review this book. I did receive the book at no cost for my review, but that in no way influenced my opinions here or in my video.

4:44 MinsThis is a great flashlight to have in emergency situations. You don't have to worry about the batteries being weak because there aren't any. It has three light settings, 1 LED light, 3 LED lights and then a flashing 3 LED to call attention to  yourself. I usually do not buy oversized sunglasses so I was a little reticent in trying these out. I find them to be very pretty with the little accents on the stems that make them stylish. Now, I think they are too big on me as far as the lenses, but everyone I have shown them too say they look great on me. Maybe change is a good thing. I love that the lenses are dark and they block the glare of the sun very nicely. They are not polarized but they are 100% effective against harmful UV rays which is important to me. I do a lot of driving and when I head into direct sunlight the glare can be dangerous. I find with these glasses that they block the glare fairly well and I can drive safely. They are plastic and will scratch if you don't take care of them. They do come with a cloth drawstring holder to keep them in while not using them to help keep them protected. They are lightweight and fit well. I enjoy using them. I received these glasses at no cost for my review and all opinions are my own.

I love the way these look on me. The tortoise shell coloring and the cat eye shape of the frames kind of give it a retro look. They are very comfortable when worn and I had no sliding issues with them. The smoke colored lenses block the light well when I drive which is an important thing for me. I was a little leery at first because of the color of the lenses. I have never owned a pair of light purple sunglasses, I usually opt for dark gray or black lenses. These are actually very nice. I like these emery boards for a few reasons. The first of course is the animal print graphic's on them. There are 4 different designs and you get 3 of each for a total of 12. My daughter is already bugging me for the multi colored cheetah patterned ones. I also like that they are larger than ordinary emery boards and thicker as well. I think being larger and thicker they will last longer. A regular sized thin emery board usually lasts me a couple of weeks at best. These will likely last twice as long, maybe even longer. They are patterned on both sides and they have the same grade of sanding on each side as well. I personally do not have long nails but I break or snag them all the time so having a good emery board around is important. With these I can keep one in my purse all the time in case emergencies come up while I am on the go. Each one comes in its own plastic holder so you can keep them clean and dry for when you use them. I received these emery boards at a reduced price for my review. All opinions are strictly my own.

We have a small 1 quart crock-pot that is older than the hills. Because we have a big 6 quart roaster we have not been using the old crock pot at all. This 6 quart crock pot is such an upgrade. I love how the lid has a rubber gasket and actually locks down when cooking. This is also important when you are transporting it to either the table for serving or out of the home to family gatherings. The stoneware inside removes easily and is dishwasher safe as is the lid for easy cleaning. The stoneware is also microwaveable and can be used in the over but NOT the broiler. The lid cannot be used in the microwave or the oven so you need to be aware of that.I love the size of this crock-pot! We are a family of three but we love to make meals big enough to freeze a second potion. This crock-pot will make that easy to do. It is great for making spaghetti sauce, stews, chili's, braised short ribs, roasts, and all kinds of things. I am getting a slow cooker cook book and I can't wait to try new things in here. I received this crock-pot at no cost for my unbiased review. All opinions stated are my own.

Do you know the difference between an herb and a spice? I knew they were different but before reading this book I had no idea what the difference was. I know now that both are from plants but that herbs are the leafy parts of the plant while spices come from seeds, bark, roots, twigs, berries, or flowers. That was only one thing reading this book taught me. I call myself the queen of quick and easy when it comes to cooking. I have always wanted to experiment with different flavors but have been afraid to try because I didn't want to butcher what I was cooking. This book really helps me to understand herbs and spices and how to pair them. It lists 50 different spices and herbs that I can use and what they pair well with. There is also a few recipes at the end of each for me to play with. I love the section that shows the best ones to keep in my spice rack, how to store them properly and what fresh herbs are easy to grow and pick.I feel like this book will help even a novice like me enhance my chicken and pork meals. It tells where each spice or herb is from, a brief history, health benefits from using it, and what foods pair well. It will also tell you what other spices or herbs will work with it to make my own spice combinations. I didn't know there are two types of cinnamon or that it comes from the bark of trees. I also didn't know it is the ceylon cinnamon that is the one that lowers blood sugars. I also learned that garlic can lower blood pressure and cholesterol. I only thought it was good for warding off vampires. Did you know cilantro leaves are healthier than the seeds? I didn't but I do now. There is just so much to learn from this book.This book is easy to understand and has photos of each herb or spice it is describing. I think it will be good for even chefs that know something about cooking. I believe this is a book that every one will benefit from by reading it. I can't wait to try making pumpkin pie from scratch using fresh allspice in the filling this Thanksgiving.I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

This is an interesting little bottle of love. The scent is different on each individual, so that is amazing in itself. When the package arrived, I opened the bottle, loved the scent, and decided to give it a try.My first victim was the UPS guy (Go figure).  I read the back, where it stated to walk through the mist, but I think I sprayed too much,  because the UPS guy dropped the boxes and ran back to is truck, almost being hit by a moped that happened by. It could have been the rollers in my hair, but then again... eh, who knows.My second choice was my husband (yes, second choice) . I sprayed a bit in warm places as he was walking in the door from work. He mumbled something to me, took off his shoes, sat down on the sofa and began reading the paper. I sat next to him. began leaning toward him, and fell onto the floor. He asked me, "What is wrong with you?" I thought, "What the heck?"  I smiled awkwardly and slipped away.Hmmm... better think of another strategy to test this spray out. The mailman? No way, he would need his OWN bottle before I could even think of getting to close to that guy Yuck! Besides, he smells like feet.As the day went by, I decided to take a walk along the beach. As I approached the area where I stretch, a cute dog came running up. I smiled and walked away. When I looked back, he was behind me. Odd, that dog followed me all along the beach, and even home! He is still out there by my front door! What the heck?To make a long story even shorter, I love this spray, not because of the dog, but because in all actuality, it is a premium spray that has gotten me compliments, does not irritate my skin, and leaves a refreshing scent. Does it attract men? Who knows. I do know that my husband is still my husband, and if this spray gets him over for an extra kiss, I am happy. :) I received this product at a special promotional price in exchange for my evaluation and honest, unbiased review.

This product takes digital thermometers to a whole new level. I'm an IT manager, and work on computers, and stare at monitors all day. I recently started experiencing eye strain and learned about computer glasses and their benefits. I recently purchase a pair of Gunnar Wi-Five when they were on a lightning Gold Box sale. Unfortunately, they didn't fit my head and they had a bit of magnification that I didn't appreciate. I wasn't interested in trying a different pair of $100 Gunnars so I looked around Amazon for other computer glasses. I found Duco glasses and glad I'm did. I really like the style they offer, they had good reviews and I didn't see anyone mention anything about magnified lenses. I contacted Duco and asked if they would provide me a pair for testing and reviewing purposes in return for my honest review, good or bad. They obliged me and I ordered the Duco GX090 glasses for delivery the next day. I liked the way the GX090's look and fit my face perfectly. They have a nice tapered design on the arms that hold them securely but don't squeeze the sides of my head. The rimless design compliments my face as well.Today was my 4th day at work wearing them, I have noticed a decrease in eye-strain and reduction of eye fatigue. They are lightweight and I forget the are on until someone notices them for the first time and pays a compliment. They have a yellow tint, but is much lighter than hunting glasses, or the Gunnars. One other thing to compare to Gunnars... Gunnars come with a storage bag, Duco's come with a storage bag, hard storage case, a cleaning cloth and a screwdriver for making adjustments, for only $35 (at the time of this review).So after 4 days of daily use, I am convinced that there is benefit for me to wearing computer glasses, and that I don't need to spend $100 to get a quality set.Please note that I was provided a discount in exchange for testing and providing my honest review. Thoughts contained in this review are based on my experience and personal opinion. I hope this helps guide you in your search for computer glasses - Dan

I know coconut oil is all the rage, but there's a good reason for it. Great quality, small footprint, and once setup, is easy to use. The camera was set to record in HD, 1080p. It was a little challenging to setup the first time, but once that was done, it was plug and play in the vehicle. With the power adapter plugged in, it will turn on when the vehicle is started. It will also start recording, so it is hands-free, and I don't have to remember to hit the record button. I did notice that a 2GB memory card only records about 20 minutes, so you want to make sure you have a large card for longer record times in HD. Speaking of memory cards, I have a 64GB Sandisk MicroSD card that I use in my GoPro , but this dash cam wouldn't recognize it. Even after formatting it with the camera. The only things that I had trouble with was the setup, and the memory card, so it's getting a 4.5 rating.10/1/15 Update - Bumping this up to 5 stars. Yes, it was challenging for me to setup, but since working that out, it has been very easy to use, and to grab the card to upload the recordings. I love that I don't have to think about this, or remember to turn it on, or to set it to record. It is always recording when the vehicle is running, so should anything happen, I will have footage of it. The other thing I didn't realize is that the camera can be tilted up or down. When I first installed it, it was pointing a bit high, because of the angle of the windshield. When I realized you could tilt the camera lens, I pointed it down, and now it's perfect. Here are several videos showing the day and night recording quality, and another showing the ease of use.https://youtu.be/SMqi30gyP88 - This video was recorded at nighthttps://youtu.be/42CnHq9wesQ - This video was recorded during the dayhttps://youtu.be/9L9Xqx8HJR8 - This video was recorded a week after installation. You'll see the dash cam mounted in the vehicle, and just how easy it is to use with auto start with the vehicle start up.Like many of my reviews, I was provided a discount in exchange for testing and providing my honest review. Thoughts contained in this review are based on my experience and personal opinion. I hope this helps guide you in your search for a dash cam - Dan

"Five Portraits" is number thirty-nine in the sequence of Piers Anthony's "Xanth" comic fantasy stories which began with "A Spell for Chameleon" in 1977, and is a sequel to the previous book,  "Board Stiff (Xanth Novels)." "Five Portraits" features the same cast of major characters and is mostly set after the conclusion of "Board Stiff" though it features a flashback early in the book which explains some of the backstory of certain characters, particularly Astrid the Basilisk. Two characters who often appeared in early books as a nuisance and a menace respectively - Demoness Mentia and  Com-Pewter - are playing on the good team in both "Board Stiff" and "Five Portraits." Although there is continuity between these two books, however, each is a stand-alone story and you do not have to read them together.The series was a huge hit with fans and publishers - Piers Anthony is supposed to have said that the reason he is still writing Xanth books is to keep his publishers happy as the series is the only thing they ever pestered him for. Xanth is still going strong thirty-eight years of Earth time, a slightly higher number of books, and millions of copies after the 1977 debut."Five Portraits" and all the other books in the series are mostly set in a magical land called Xanth, a peninsular which usually looks a bit like Florida but can sometimes appear like other peninsulars such as Italy or Korea. All human residents of Xanth have a magic talent, which may vary from trivial to immensely powerful and from extremely useful to being a downright liability. The fauna, flora and geography of the land are based on a combination of legends and puns.This story is told particularly from the viewpoint of Astrid the Basilisk, a member of the party which went on a quest in the previous book to prevent all the puns of Xanth from being wiped out by a pun-killer virus. Astrid can change between human and basilisk form, but in both forms her direct gaze can kill so she has to wear dark glasses or be careful not to look directly at someone to avoid killing them. And being a compassionate person she does not like killing. She also wants to help when she finds a group of five children who need to be rescued from a most unusual situation ...The series as published and planned in November 2015 is as follows:1  "A Spell for Chameleon" (1977), link A Spell for Chameleon2  "The Source of Magic" (1979), link Source of Magic: Xanth Series, Book 23  "Castle Roogna" (1979), link Castle Roogna4  "Centaur Aisle" (1982)5  "Ogre, Ogre" (1982)6  "Night Mare" (1983)7  "Dragon on a Pedestal" (1983)8  "Crewel Lye" (1984)9  "Golem in the Gears"10 "Vale of the Vole" (1987)11 "Heaven Cent" (1988)12 "Man from Mundania" (1989)13 "Isle of View" (1990)14 "Question Quest" (1991)15 "The Color of Her Panties" (1992)16 "Demons Don't Dream" (1992)17 "Harpy Thyme" (1993)18 "Geis of the Gargoyle" (1994)19 "Roc and a Hard Place" (1995)20 "Yon Ill Wind" (1996)21 "Faun & Games" (1997)22 "Zombie Lover" (1998)23 "Xone of Contention" (1999)24 "The Dastard" (2000)25 "Swell Foop" (2001)26 "Up In A Heaval" (2002)27 "Cube Route" (2003)28 "Currant Events" (2004)29 "Pet Peeve" (2005)30 "Stork Naked" (2006)31 "Air Apparent" (2007)32 "Two to the Fifth" (2008)33 "Jumper Cable" (2009)34 "Knot Gneiss" (2010)35 "Well-Tempered Clavicle" (2011)36 "Luck of the Draw" (2012)37 "Esrever Doom" (2013)38 "Board Stiff" (2014)39 This Book, "Five Portraits" (2014)40 "Isis Orb" (forthcoming)41 "Ghost Writer in the Sky" (forthcoming)There is also a companion volume, "Piers Anthony's Visual Guide to Xanth" and the co-author of that book, Jody Lynn Nye, has written the adventure book "Ghost of a Chance (Crossroads Adventure : in the World of Pier Anthony's Xanth).A major part of the plot of the sixteenth book, "Demons don't dream" relates to a computer game about Xanth, and Legend Entertainment were licenced to bring out a real computer game shortly afterwards which had the same plot as the game in the book and the same name, "Companions of Xanth." This game was designed to run under DOS and is no longer available at Amazon UK although it can still be ordered from Amazon.com or downloaded as abandonware if you have a working computer old enough or flexible enough to run games designed for the specs and operating systems in place twenty years ago.If you have the right sort of sense of humour, particularly a love of dreadful puns, this book and most of its' successors can be quite amusing. These books are not meant to be taken seriously.Be warned that if you did take some of the Xanth books too seriously, they can come over as rather sexist even by the standards of the seventies, let alone those of today. Certain characters in the stories have unfortunate attitudes, to put it mildly, and the series has evolved its' own rather unique set of conventions about when nudity is or acceptable and how male characters react to the sight of a woman's underwear which may appear somewhere between childish, sexist, or just plain odd.However, many of the accusations of sexism against Piers Anthony over the Xanth books are based on taking out of context, and assuming that the author is endorsing, views which in context are clearly presented for the specific purpose of disproving them. In many Xanth stories the bad guys make serious mistakes by underestimating the female characters and the heroines often find that they can achieve far more than their initial low expectations of themselves.In context many of the antedeluvian attitudes to women attributed to characters in the Xanth books contribute to the failures suffered by those characters or are a sign that they are on the wrong side, and similar sexist perspectives initially attributed to heroes and heroines are sometimes there so that the characters concerned can grow by learning better.As you work through the Xanth series new characters and themes are gradually introduced and old ones fade away, so it is not essential to read this series in sequence, though I personally prefer to do so. Often, as with Com-Pewter in this story, characters who have faded out come back or figures who have been in the background, often as nuisances or opponents, move centre stage and sometimes become heroes..Worth a try if you enjoy fantasy and puns, are reasonably broad-minded, and able to avoid taking things too seriously or literally.

"Board Stiff" is number thirty-eight in the sequence of Piers Anthony's "Xanth" comic fantasy stories which began with "A Spell for Chameleon" in 1977, and features a most unexpected quest around the magic land of Xanth, some excursions into different genres, and a role reversal both for the main theme of the book - for the aim of the quest is almost the opposite of the role of the "Caprice Castle" characters from recent stories - and for one of the main characters, because this time Com-Pewter who was a nuisance or a menace in most opf the previous books, has a turn playing on the goodies team.The series was a huge hit with fans and publishers - Piers Anthony is supposed to have said that the reason he is still writing Xanth books is to keep his publishers happy as the series is the only thing they ever pestered him for. Xanth is still going strong thirty-eight years of Earth time, a slightly higher number of books, and millions of copies after the 1977 debut."Board Stiff" and all the other books in the series are mostly set in a magical land called Xanth, a peninsular which usually looks a bit like Florida but can sometimes appear like other peninsulars such as Italy or Korea. All human residents of Xanth have a magic talent, which may vary from trivial to immensely powerful and from extremely useful to being a downright liability. The fauna, flora and geography of the land are based on a combination of legends and puns.The primary heroine of this book is lady called Candy, or to give her full name, Irrelevant Candy. When she goes by her full name nobody pays her any attention: in the first of many terrible puns in the story, when she shortens it to I. Candy she gets too much of the wrong sort of attention from men who think she is nice to look at but good for nothing else.So Candy goes to a wishing well and asks for Adventure, Excitement, and Romance - only to find herself transformed into a flat, stiff board with two knotholes for eyes. (This is not a spoiler as it is given on the book description on the back of the book and on the publisher's description on this and every other site.)But Candy soon finds herself with a group of companions, some of whom know she is more than just a wooden board and some of whom do not. Following the inevitable challenge to get in and see the good magician, the characters find themselves on a quest to stop Xanth from becoming a flat and boring place - with some unexpected allies and opponents ...The next book in the series, number 39 "Five Portraits (Xanth)," is to some extent a sequel to "Board Stiff" in that it has essentially the same cast of characters and carries on where this book finishes. However, each is a complete story and can be read on its' own if that is what you want to do.The series as published and planned in October 2015 is as follows:1  "A Spell for Chameleon" (1977), link A Spell for Chameleon2  "The Source of Magic" (1979), link Source of Magic: Xanth Series, Book 23  "Castle Roogna" (1979), link Castle Roogna4  "Centaur Aisle" (1982)5  "Ogre, Ogre" (1982)6  "Night Mare" (1983)7  "Dragon on a Pedestal" (1983)8  "Crewel Lye" (1984)9  "Golem in the Gears"10 "Vale of the Vole" (1987)11 "Heaven Cent" (1988)12 "Man from Mundania" (1989)13 "Isle of View" (1990)14 "Question Quest" (1991)15 "The Color of Her Panties" (1992)16 "Demons Don't Dream" (1992)17 "Harpy Thyme" (1993)18 "Geis of the Gargoyle" (1994)19 "Roc and a Hard Place" (1995)20 "Yon Ill Wind" (1996)21 "Faun & Games" (1997)22 "Zombie Lover" (1998)23 "Xone of Contention" (1999)24 "The Dastard" (2000)25 "Swell Foop" (2001)26 "Up In A Heaval" (2002)27 "Cube Route" (2003)28 "Currant Events" (2004)29 "Pet Peeve" (2005)30 "Stork Naked" (2006)31 "Air Apparent" (2007)32 "Two to the Fifth" (2008)33 "Jumper Cable" (2009)34 "Knot Gneiss" (2010)35 "Well-Tempered Clavicle" (2011)36 "Luck of the Draw" (2012)37 "Esrever Doom" (2013)38 This book, "Board Stiff" (2014)39 "Five Portraits" (2014)40 "Isis Orb" (forthcoming)41 "Ghost Writer in the Sky" (forthcoming)There is also a companion volume, "Piers Anthony's Visual Guide to Xanth" and the co-author of that book, Jody Lynn Nye, has written the adventure book "Ghost of a Chance (Crossroads Adventure : in the World of Pier Anthony's Xanth).A major part of the plot of the sixteenth book, "Demons don't dream" relates to a computer game about Xanth, and Legend Entertainment were licenced to bring out a real computer game shortly afterwards which had the same plot as the game in the book and the same name, "Companions of Xanth." The Great War Syndicate by Frank R Stockton (1834-1902) is a science fiction novella by an American writer and humourist, best known for a series of fairy stories for children, innovative for the time, which were very popular in the latter decades of the 19th century, and for his short stories such as "The Lady, or the Tiger?.This story was written and is set towards the end of the 19th century at a time of increasing tension between the United States of America and the British Empire. When the tensions threaten to spill over into an actual conflict and the American public are demanding that their leaders declare a war which the United States is not well equipped to fight, a syndicate offer the US government a novel way to deal with the problem ...This is a comparatively short book - a novella rather than a novel, with the story taking up no more than 64 pages. It is a story of its' time, with the 2007 edition including the warning that it "does not reflect the same values as it would if it were written today. Parents might wish to discuss with their children how views on race have changed before allowing them to read this classic work."To try to describe the story without giving too much away, there are some clever ideas in the story, but many of them are a sort of fusion of Jules Verne and a Marvel comic strip - but without the heroes or human interest - with a strong dash of W Heath Robinson thrown in. With two very minor exceptions, none of the people in the story is given a name, all of them being referred to only by the position they hold in the syndicate or the armed forces or government of Britain or America. I ticked "one dimensional" as a description of the characters - if anything this overstates how developed they are, the book barely has characters at all.Stockton's skill in describing his proposed machines and making them credible is not in the same league as Jules Verne, and a few pages into this book I very nearly abandoned it on the basis that the author appeared to be projecting victory for his country by simply ascribing to the engineers of his "syndicate" the ability to construct whatever they wanted without needing to worry about whether the laws of physics would give any possibility of such equipment being built even with the technology of the 21st century, never mind the 19th. A bit like the sort of "and next our brilliant inventors will build suits of lightweight and totally bulletproof body armour and issue them to all our people" rubbish you expect to see in children's comics.There are however two things which lift this novella above the that. The first is that it is refreshingly free of Xenophobia or jingoism, with the sympathetic characters both American and British being concerned to minimise unnecessary bloodshed on both sides and the people who from the storyteller's view are the enemy being described as showing courage, skill, wisdom and common sense. The other is the whimsical sense of humour which comes through at several points of the story and once or twice made me laugh out loud.

Most of David Weber's work is military SF, but he has branched out into the swords and sorcery genre with his series about Bahzell Bahnakson which as of October 2015 consists of the following five books:1) "Oath of Swords (War God)"2) "The War God's Own"3) "Wind Rider's Oath (The Bahzell)"4) This book, "War Maid's Choice"5) The Sword of the South (Baen)I don't usually have much time for "Conan" style books even when they're written by authors of the calibre of Roland Green or Harry Turtledove, but this series is something else.Some of the particular strengths of the Bahzell Bahnakson series are things which are carried over from Weber's other work - good use of humour, brave but believable heroes and heroines, characters who have to overcome their own prejudices and mostly do so.One thing which I appreciate about David Weber as an author is that he does not find it necessary to insert a gratuitous love story into every book, even in this genre. Not that his characters are sexless or incapable of love, and without wanting to spoil things this series is not entirely lacking in romance, but Weber's characters fall in love when it fits the bigger story canvass and not for the sake of including a romance in every volume in some formulaic pattern.Perhaps the best feature of this book, like the earlier ones in the series, is that it is not entirely predictable and first impressions are not always right. For example, when one of the central characters meets someone who initially appears to be a bigoted blockhead, there is a roughly 25% chance that he or she really will turn out to be a hopeless case or a bad guy, and a 75% chance that he or she will actually be an honest person who is at least sometimes capable of doing the right thing. Equally some of those who appear at first to be good guys (or girls) turn out to be in the wrong, or even working for the dark Gods.The storyline is strong, if a little complicated. It is much easier to keep track of what is going on if you had previously read the first three books in the series.There are some irritating minor issues in the presentation of the book. It contains one map, of a scale such as to be fairly useeless.. There is a list of mortal characters at the back of the book with a list of Gods (good and evil) at the back. One or two key characters from previous books who are repeatedly referred to are missing from that list, such as Wencit of Rum, (Former leader and last survivor of the Wizard's council and very approximately the equivalent of Gandalf or Belgarath).Some excellent humour - for example, at one stage the line "You look like you've seen a ghost" is spoken by - a ghost.Bottom line: if you liked any of David Weber's other books, and provided it wasn't specifically for space battles, read the Bahzell Bahnakson books and you are unlikely to be disappointed. If you like the swords and sorcery genre generally, it is also very likely that you will like these five books. But if you do read any of these, make sure to read them in the right order.

"Project Fear" by Joe Pike is about a referendum campaign which went wrong and should be required reading for anyone planning to take part on either side in the forthcoming campaigns for and against British membership of the EU - if only as a terrible warning of the mistakes to avoid.I knew before I read this book that both sides had messed up during the Scottish Referendum battle but until I read this book I did not realise how badly.What "Project Fear" is:* a fascinating inside account of the "Better Together/No Thanks" campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, which continues to the 2015 general election and describes how the referendum result turned into a phyrric victory for most of the actors on the winning site as they suffered electoral annihilation the following year.* extremely interesting and entertaining* impossible to put down for anyone interested in politics* A "how not to do it" manual for anyone planning a referendum campaign (Vote Leave, Leave.EU, and "Britain stronger in Europe" please note)What "Project Fear" is not:* Strong on analysis* Entirely impartial - the author has obviously spoken to many people from both campaigns and clearly made a genuine attempt to fairly give both sides of the story but it is patently evident that he is much more closely connected to "Better Together" and Scottish Labour in particular than to the SNP or "Yes Scotland" and most, though not all, of the interesting insights in the book are on the "Better together" side.Ironically we find out in the early pages of the book where the expression "Project Fear" came from. It was coined within "Better together" not as a description of the campaign they wanted to fight but as how they thought the "Yes" campaign would try to paint them. The irony is that the term leaked and of course the SNP were delighted at the chance to do exactly that.The first thing which horrified me about this book was how the divisive nature of the campaign, the untrue statements put about by the Nationalists and over-concentration on negative arguments by the unionists, have left a legacy of distrust and anger which will scar Scotland for years.  Hence my comment about the referendum campaign having gone wrong, whichever result you would have liked to see.The second thing which horrified me on reading this book was the dawning realisation of how easy it would be for each side in the forthcoming European referendum to repeat the mistakes of one or both sides. The epilogue to this book notes that "The dynamics of the EU and SCottish referendums are eerily similar. It also notes that there have already been attempts to draw lessons that people involved in the one campaign can learn from the other, though the consensus view was that the main lessons to learn were the mistakes to avoid.And what mistakes!One side failed to do the heavy lifting of working out exactly how an Independent Scotland would work - the SNP's 650 page manifesto for a Scottish nation contained just one page of costings and their proposal that an Independent Scotland could keep the pound was, as Labour's Scottish leader rightly described it, like someone initiating a divorce but wanting to keep the joint bank account.The other side failed - until, arguably,  shortly before the end of the campaign - to come up with a compelling positive vision for Scotland within Britain and made far too much use of negative warnings about what could go wrong with Independence - many of which were in my humble opinion, entirely justified but some were silly and even certain of the valid points could be (and were) easily made by the SNP to look extremely petty.The book brings out the way the referendum campaign was also disfigured by highly abusive campaigning from some quarters: there were people on both sides who rose above this but others on both sides who did not. The manner in which the worst offenders on both sides, particularly some "Cybernats," went out of their way to make life hell for those they disagreed with and regarded as traitors was incredibly harmful and counterproductive: had they succeeded the new nation they created would have come into being in an atmosphere of intolerance and hate.The book also describes how that anger continued up to the General election. It has continued since then, as well, and one issue the book does not cover is that some of that anger and bitterness extends into the rest of the UK as well. Many English voters - and please, note, on this occasion when I say English I really mean English, not British - were thoroughly irritated by having to listen to months of hearing their part of Britain regularly blamed for all the ills of Scotland by the more extreme supporters of the Yes campaign in a manner which sometimes verged on anti-English racism. One of the reasons for the surprise Conservative victory in the 2015 general election was the reluctance of many English voters to risk the possibility that a Labour government might have to rely on SNP support.This book is mostly narrative, without very much in the way of analysis, but the narrative is a gripping one - even if it is a bit like a modern political version of a cross between a Greek tragedy and "Macbeth."Some people reading this review might ask, since "Better together" won the campaign, why I have praised this book as an account of a referendum went wrong. My answer would be that nobody can have been happy with the overall outcome. The Yes campaign didn't get independence: the parties who worked together in the "No campaign" won in 2014 but were slaughtered in the following year's general election; andIf I had bought this book believing that I was buying a comprehensive and balanced academic assessment or history of the campaign, I would have been disappointed and given it at most three stars, But "Project Fear" was presented as an inside account of the story of the campaign, and how an unlikely alliance left a Kingdom united but a country divided, and that it delivers in spades. It is on that basis that I have given it five stars.

"Exodus: Gods and Kings" by Ridley Scott is certainly a dramatic and entertaining re-envisaging of the story of Moses, and Christian Bale does a reasonable job playing Moses as a man of action  - a prince and general turned rebel leader rather than an elderly patriarch. If you want to watch a modern Hollywood version of the Book of Exodus, purely for entertainment value, you will probably like this.The action is well paced and exciting, the visual depiction of the magnificence of ancient Egypt is sumptuous. The battle and action scenes are well drawn - the depiction of the battle of Kadesh in particular - and the special effects are magnificent. Most of the acting is very good though one or two of the accents used were surprising: for example the High Priestess of Egypt has a cut glass English accent (she's played by Indira Varma, who is English) and a character who appears in the cast list as "expert" (Ewen Bremner) has a Scottish one. And far too many characters in the story were given blatantly 21st century attitudes - for example the Scottish "expert" produces a very secular explanation for the plagues, which is very close to what some modern scientists who think this section of the bible might be based on a real event have theorised.If you were hoping to see either a film which reflects the viewpoint of a religious believer or that of of someone who is interested in a rationalist view of what might have actually happened with minimal supernatural involvement, you may feel that this film falls between those two stools. I also felt that the film was cut down a bit too much, apparently to fit into an arbitrary time limit, and some of the "deleted scenes" on the disc would have been better left in. If there is a slightly longer "director's cut" released in the future it may work better.My biggest problem with the film is something which may be very much a personal and minority view but here goes. It's the fact that "Exodus: God's and Kings" takes the traditional view that the Pharaoh of the exodus was Ramses or Ramesses II, known as Ramesses the Great, and that the Hebrews escaped from Egypt in the 13th century BC. The date when the film starts is given as 1300 BC.I see why that view might make sense to the "Copenhagen School" of biblical minimalist historians who regard the Torah (the Old Testament of the Bible) as a collection of nationalistically-slanted legends assembled between 100 BC and 500 BC and of which the earlier books are of little value as historical source documents. I can also see why someone who was only interesting in making a dramatic film of the Book of Exodus might want to pit Moses against Ramesses the Great who was possibly the most powerful ruler in the entire history of ancient Egypt.However, this film appears to be an attempt to tell a story like the one in the bible in a way which makes at least some attempt to link in with real Egyptian history. And if you do think that something like the disasters which struck Egypt in the book of Exodus actually had a basis in history, then that was not the most plausible century to set this story.It is less likely that such a catastrophic series of events would have occurred during the long, successful, and comparatively well documented reign of Ramesses II (1279-1213 BC) yet without any mention in surviving Egyptian records of that reign, than that it could have happened in one of the less stable periods of Egyptian history from which far fewer records have survived. This is particularly true because some of the few records which did survive from some of those earlier centuries  actually do suggest cataclysmic events which might match the biblical account.Those reputable historians and archaeologists who think there might be a historical basis for the Ten Plagues - and although they are not currently in the majority, there are some - usually place that sequence of events between two and four centuries prior to the reign of Ramesses the Great, perhaps during the Second Intermediate Period of Egyptian history. For example it is known that the massive volcanic eruption which destroyed the island of Santorini, (also known as the Thera event) caused massive environmental disruption over a huge area of the planet, and could well have sparked off a series of ecological catastrophes in Egypt similar to the biblical description of the plagues. There is much debate about exactly when that eruption occurred, with archaeological, carbon dating, and tree ring evidence suggesting different dates but it was probably between about 1628 BC and 1500 BC  with the earlier date, which comes from tree ring data, currently regarded as the most likely.Some historians such as David Rohl, author of "A Test Of Time: Volume One-The Bible-From Myth to History" have argued that it would be more plausible to identify the Pharaoh of the Exodus with a ruler some centuries prior to Ramesses II, such as Tutimaos, of whom the ancient Egyptian chronicler Manetho was to write centuries later, "In his reign, for what cause I know not, a blast of God smote us."To be fair, most historians do not agree. Some of them think the entire story of the Exodus is complete fiction and literally never happened at all, others think that a small group of slaves, too insignificant to be worth recording in Egyptian records, may have escaped from Egypt at around the time of the reign of Ramesses the Great, become part of the group of tribes who were to become the Hebrews, and given rise to the Exodus legend. Both these groups of historians think the early books of the Old Testament are a collection of myths assembled as Hebrew religious and nationalist propaganda a thousand years after the events they purport to describe, are completely unreliable, and in the words of one professor, any attempt to integrate the events of the bible into a historical narrative is, in the words of one Professor "not only dubious but wholly ludicrous."I don't have the expert knowledge to argue that this view is wrong, but there's no point whatsoever in making a film like "Exodus: God's and Kings" conform to it, because if it is right you have absolutely nothing to make such a film about!If you ARE going to make a film like this, and you're also going to make any attempt to integrate it into real Egyptian history, you might as well make it match the arguments of the current minority view among the experts who do think something like the events of "Exodus" (the bible book and this film) could really have happened. In which case you should probably set it before the reign of Ramesses the Great.A few more points on the actual history. Many aspects of this are quite good, but others are open to challenge.The caption at the start of the film gives the time and place as 1300BC in Memphis, capital of Egypt, but it begins during the reign of Seti the first. There is debate about exactly when Set I came to the throne, but it was probably a few years after 1300 BC. The main capital of Egypt in 1300BC was at Thebes. However, Seti I, the Pharaoh in the early part of the film, did reign mainly from Memphis. His son Ramesses II who is Pharaoh for most of the film built a new capital at Pi-Ramesses in the Nile Delta.The depiction of the battle of Kadesh is quite good and reasonably historically accurate except that it conflates two campaigns. In real history, the city of Kadesh was captured by the Egyptians from the Hittites in the reign of Seti I, and the future Ramses the Great, who was then crown prince, was present during that campaign. A few years later, four years after Ramesses II had become Pharaoh in his own right, there was another military action at Kadesh which was the largest chariot battle in known history and in which, at one point, Ramesses nearly got cut off from most of his army and killed.In the film, the battle of Kadesh takes place during the earlier campaign while Seti I is still Pharaoh and Ramesses still crown prince, but apart from this and from the fact that a role has been found for Moses, it takes place in the film very much as it did in real history. There is a subsequent scene when the wording of the official record of the battle to be carved onto monuments is being agreed, and in which Ramesses says that he was cut off from his troops and saved by divine intervention. The scriptwriters took the trouble to get this exactly right and the wording agreed in the film is word for word identical to the most common translation of that account as it survives on real monuments of the battle.After seeing lots of films in which Morgan Freeman plays the part of God, the manner in which this film treats Him is very different. I'm not going to describe it to avoid a spoiler, but it was at least original.One change from the biblical story which is perhaps representative of the way Moses is presented in this film is that he is given a sword at the beginning. The various actions which Moses or his brother Aaron carry out with their staffs in the bible are carried out with Moses's sword in this film.Overall this film has a lot of strengths if you are looking for entertainment, though I can't help thinking that if you are looking for accuracy or plausibility it could and should have been better. As with Darren Aronofsky's recent film version of "Noah [DVD]," Ridley Scott was depicting a story from the bible and had to decide whether to present it as an openly supernatural series of events or try to show how the events of the story could have happened in a natural manner. "Noah" went for the former route and was a better film for not trying to sit on the fence. "Exodus: Gods and Kings" seems a little uncomfortable with aspects of the bible story but unwilling to completely abandon them, and in consequence is not quite as convincing.

The preface of this book begins as follows:"The economy of Greece is in shambles. Internal rebellions have engulfed Libya, Syria and Egypt, with outsiders and foreign warriors fanning the flames. Turkey fears it will become involved, as does Israel. Jordan is crowded with refugees. Iran is bellicose and threatening, while Iraq is in turmoil" Sound like a description of the present situation?"Yes. But it was also the situation in 1177 BC, more than three thousand years ago, when the Bronze Age Mediterranean civilisations collapsed one after the other."This is of course a bit of an oversimplification, but to be fair, the book itself does not oversimplify. It summarises in a readable and accessible way the evidence we have about how the civilisations of the late Bronze age in the Mediterranean area and the Middle East interacted and traded with each other, and how so many of them went down like dominoes early in the 12th century BC.I can recommend "1177 BC, The Year Civilization Collapsed" by Eric Cline as an interesting read in its' own right but also because the period described has so many parallels to our own age.

Admiral: Command and Conquer is the English Language release of a Dutch film about the great 17th Century Dutch admiral Michiel de Ruyter. With a prologue depicting a somewhat ahistorical version of the Battle of Scheveningen in 1653, the film depicts the de Ruyter's career, and Dutch politics, from the time he took over as Lieutenant-Admiral (which effectively meant commander) of the Dutch navy until his last battle in 1676.It's a dramatic and visually sumptuous film which is a must-see for fans of sailing navy action. Some aspects of the history are presented very well indeed, but be warned that other aspects of the history presented are so ridiculous that purists who like their historical fiction to bear some resemblance to actual history may find themselves reaching for something to throw at the screen. For example the very first words of the film are ‘The Seventeenth Century: the Netherlands is the only republic in the world.’DOH! What about Switzerland, Venice, and Genoa?The cover of the DVD box of "Admiral" gives the impression that Charles Dance is the central character: actually he plays Charles II of Britain, who is the villain. Of course, since this is a Dutch film about a Dutch national hero, and Britain and Holland were at war for almost all the timeframe of the film, making the king of an enemy nation the villain was not a controversial or surprising thing, but that DVD box is a bit misleading.British and Dutch historians who know much more about the 17th century and the navies of the time than I do have praised the depiction of 17th century "fighting sail" combat in this film. They had some fun teasing the film-makers about the fact that the Union Flag on British ships was shown in the wrong place (as an Ensign at the stern rather than a Jack at the masthead) though at least they did use a historically accurate version of the flag. The first Union flag created in 1606 following the Union of the English and Scottish crowns was a combination of the Cross of St George and the Saltire and this is correctly shown in the film. (The diagonal red bars of St Patrick's cross were not added until 1801.)The role of de Ruyter and "Grand Pensionary" Johan de Witt in reforming the Dutch navy (just as Samuel Pepys radically reformed Britain's Royal Navy at approximately the same time) is presented very quickly as if it was all done and dusted in one short meeting, but is broadly accurate. De Ruyter is indeed remembered as the founder of Holland's marine corps, though he was not the inventor of the concept (that goes back at least as far as the Romans!) De Witt is referred to in the film as "Prime Minister" which is probably the closest thing to an accurate modern equivalent of the title of "Grand Pensionary."Although the film covers a period of 23 years the viewer could be forgiven for assuming it was a much shorter period of time: De Ruyter's family do not age: for example, his son is presented as being a gangly adolescent throughout the film, which he was indeed at the time of Scheveningen, but he was a senior captain by the time of the Battle of Augusta. And as the time is rather shortened the enemy commanders are rolled together.The same actor plays the French admiral in command both at the battle of the Texel and at de Ruyter's last fight, the Battle of Augusta. That character is named in the cast list at the end of the film as Abraham Duquesne, which is the name of the Admiral in command at Augusta, one of the most successful French naval commanders of all time. Perhaps fortunately for the Dutch, Duquesne was not in command of the French fleet at the Texel: the French admiral at that battle was Jean D'Estrees. The film presents the French ships at the Texel as suffering a fate remarkably like what in real history happened to D'estrees' fleet five years later in the Caribbean.Similarly the British are shown as having the same command team, George Monck and Prince Rupert, at the Four Days battle in 1666 and the Texel in 1673. In reality Monck was the British Commander in Chief at the former battle, which Prince Rupert of the Rhine's squadron only joined on the last day. Prince Rupert then took over as commander of the British fleet. He still held that position six years later and was in overall command of the British and French combined fleet at the Texel.In the trailer the words "I think it would be unwise to underestimate de Ruyter" are taken from the film's depiction of a briefing of allied commanders before the Battle of the Texel.
