I don't want to say too much more about the plot to avoid spoilers, but Breslin and a character called Rottmayer played by Arnold Schwartzenegger have to team up to escape from the most secure prison ever created ...Lots of suspense, lots of plot twists some of which most viewers will seecoming a mile off and some which most people won't. Plenty of gallows humour and a few characters face moral dilemmas. Although there is a lot of action and some aspects of the plot don't make much sense, this is a more intelligent film than is common for the genre as Sly and Arnie have to use their wits as well as muscles to defeat the undefeatable barriers put in their way.OK, obviously it's not "Citizen Kane" nor does it try to be, but this film is entertaining and exciting nonsense rather than just nonsense. If you like action films and generally enjoyed Arnie and Sly's previous output you will probably enjoy this.

"The Marriage Game" by Tudor historian Alison Weir is a clever and entertaining romance about the love life of Queen Elizabeth the First of England.If you have read more than a few romances you will almost certainly have encountered some in which an infuriating heroine who cannot make up her mind leads the hero and often a host of other suitors a merry and highly frustrating dance. Both in real history and in this book, "Good Queen Bess" absolutely was that girl. Because the book makes the characters real enough that you identify with them, the reader often empathises with the feelings of frustration this must have inspired in both Queen ELizabeth's suiters in general, and Robert Dudley (later Earl of Leicester) in particular, and with Cecil and her other ministers. But there were good reasons why the queen acted as she did, and this book helps you get inside her thoughts enough to understand what it must have felt like from her perspective.When she came to the throne Queen Elizabeth already had good reason to be fearful and cautious about the dangers of love. She had been two years old when her father had her mother beheaded. A year after that the Queen for whom Henry VII disposed of Elizabeth's mother, Jane Seymour, died in childbed. When she was fourteen her last stepmother, Catherine Parr, also died in childbed. And shortly after that her stepfather Thomas Seymour who had married Henry VIII's widow Catherine Parr, was beheaded for High Treason on a number of grounds, one of which was that he behaved with improper familiarity towards Princess Elizabeth. This may have been part of a treasonous plot to marry her and gain the throne. Whether or not that was the case, the Regency council headed by Seymour's own brother were sufficiently convinced of it to have him executed.Having seen so many of those who were close to her die in such circumstances, Elizabeth had every reason to know that love could be dangerous. So she was determined to let no man be her master and never lose control of her feelings. However, the possibliity of marrying her was one of the strongest cards in her diplomatic hand, and she used it ruthlessly and repeatedly, dangling the prospect of marriage in front of all the eligible batchelors and many of the widowers in her court, and almost every unmarried prince in Europe. In an age of powerful dynastic rulers, the prospect of a matrimonial alliance was deployed time and time again as a carrot for heads of state whose friendship England needed.This alternated with Elizabeth describing herself as a virgin queen who was married to her country and would never take a husband.Had this been a work of pure fiction nobody could take seriously the elaborate game which Elizabeth played with all her suitors, domestic and on the foriegn stage, as described in this book. However, much of "The marriage game" is novelised fact, though it retreats into speculation about what the true relationship had been between the teenage princess and Thomas Seymour, and about what really happened between Elizabeth and her favourite Robert Dudley, later Earl of Leicester.A glittering and fascinating novel of a glitttering and dangerous era.

This excellent collection of essays by the author of "The Law" (Work expands to fill the time available for it's completion) were all topical in 1972 when the book came out but most of them have aged very well.I'm posting this review in July 2014, having been inspired to find and read the copy of this book which my father bought forty years ago by an article in this week's issue of the UK current affairs magazine "The Spectator" ("Killing Jokes" by Melissa Kite) about how political correctness and our eagerness to take offence is making humour almost impossible. I thought to myself "Didn't Parkinson write a comprehensive assessment of this problem many years ago" and sure enough he did - in the chapter on humour in this book, written before the phrase "political correctness" had even been coined but in which he predicted exactly the sort of problem which Melissa Kite's article was discussing.The essays in this book, mostly written in a humorous manner but making serious points, cover an astonishingly wide range of issues and all except one are as apposite in 2014 as they were in 1972. All are very accessible and easy to read - I wasn't even in my teens when I first read this but I enjoyed it and understood enough to recall the book forty years later.The title essay is a thoughtful critique of some of the long-term problems which might accompany the creation of a welfare state. Whether or not you agree with the present government's programme of welfare reform, I think most people who read this book would recognise some of the thoughts in that essay as predicting some of the issues which ministers from Frank Field to IDS in successive British governments have tried to address.Other issues discussed include "Revolting Youth" about student rebellion, a very thought-provoking analysis on genius ("A genius stands on the shoulders of other men")  and, in one of the few essays which has dated a bit unless you remember Laurence J Peter's book "The Peter Principle" Parkinson takes issue with the idea that "In a hierarchy every employee will tend to rise to his level of incompetence."I can strongly recommend this little gem, as I can almost everythin else that Parkinson wrote.

"Cauldron of Ghosts" is the nineteenth full length novel in the "Honorverse" group of novels set some 2,000 years in the future. It is the third novel, after "Crown of Slaves (Honorverse)" and "Torch of Freedom" in a sub-series about how two super-spies from star nations which were originally at war fought to help free "genetic slaves" and the "seccie" descendants of slaves from the tyranny of the government of the planet Mesa and the corrupt companies which run the planet.The particular enemy in this sub-series, though in all the "Honorverse" books set later it becomes clear that they are the ultimate bad guys, is a company called "Manpower" which is a front for a vast conspiracy known to its inner core as the "Mesan Alignment." Everyone assumes that Manpower is simply a rich and corrupt company out to make money by genetically crafting people who can be sold as perfect slaves. Unfortunately for the galaxy they are much, much more than that ...In the previous book in this sub-series two unlikely allies, Manticoran super-spy Anton Zilwicki and Havenite super-spy Victor Cachat went undercover on Mesa and discovered an outline of what the Mesan Alignment is really up to. They then returned to their home nations and explained what they had found.In this book Anton, Victor and some of their friends return to Mesa, hoping to get more information. Instead they arrive on Mesa as the planet is on the verge of disaster. In response to Anton and Victor's revelations the Mesan alignment has activated a ruthless continency plan called "Houdini," which they had ready to deal with the possibility that the rest of the galaxy gets an inkling of how big a threat the Mesans are."Houdini" was mentioned in both "A Rising Thunder" and "Shadow of Freedom" so anyone who has read either of those books will have some idea what it entails, but I don't want to say too much about it to avoid a spoiler. But it won't come as a surprise or a spoiler to say that when Anton and Victor return to Mesa, as a consequence of "Houdini," the planet has been brought to the brink of a civil war. The "seccies," nominally free but effectively second class citizens descended from slaves, are about to be made scapegoats and victims for atrocities which the reader knows were actually perpetrated by the Mesan Alignment. If Anton and Victor do nothing, millions of seccies and slaves will be murdered. But they're not going to let that happen without a fight ...If you have not read any of the "Honorverse" books and are interested in doing so, do not start with this one: I would recommend starting with the first book in the main Honor Harrington sequence which is "On Basilisk Station (Honorverse)."The first eleven Honorverse novels, despite being Space Opera stories set in the far future, had strong parallels with the story of Nelson's navy up to 1805. The central character of most of these books, Honor Harrington, is a bit like a female mix of Horatio Nelson and Horatio Hornblower. Assumed technology in the first group of stories imposes constraints on space navy officers quite similar to those which the technology of fighting sail imposed on wet navy officers two hundred years ago.Similarly, the galactic situation in the novels up to the battle of Manticore at the end of "At All Costs (Honorverse)" (which corresponds to Trafalgar) had marked similarities to the strategic and political situation in Europe at the time of the French revolutionary wars.However, having finished the interesting parts of the battles at sea between the Royal Navy and the French Navy, the story is turning into something completely different. In "Torch of Freedom" and "Storm from the Shadows (Honorverse)" (SFTS) the reader learned that the genetic slaver company called "Manpower" is merely a front for something far more powerful and dangerous, known to its inner circle as "The Mesan Alignment" who are planning to remake the galaxy in pursuit of their idea of a genetically purified paradise - and they don't care how many hundreds of billions of human beings and other sentient life-forms will die in the process.Albrecht Detweiler, head of the Mesan Alignment and the new primary "baddie" introduced in "Torch of Freedom" is an interesting and complex person for the reader to love to hate, combining as he does some of the characteristics of Ernst Stavro Blofeld (without the cat), Dr Soong from Star Trek Enterprise (without the scruples), and the Emperor of Cetaganda from the Miles Vorkosigan Universe (without the humour.)Interestingly, "Cauldron of Ghosts" reveals how much more dangerous the Mesans are than the good guys originally asssumed "Manpower" to be, when in this book for the first time one of their operatives proves that there are people who are willing to die for the Mesan cause. And when I write "willing to die" I do not mean just take risks, and I'm not talking about people who were programmed against their will to carry out suicidal commands by what the good guys call "assassination nanotech." I'm talking about people who care enough about the Mesan cause to willingly undertake suicide missions.The Galaxy's original view of Manpower, perfectly articulated by Honor Harrington's uncle Jacques at the end of the novella "Beauty and the Beast" in the collection "Beginnings: Worlds of Honor Book 6 (Honor Harrington), was that they were a bunch of crooks who were just in it for money, and although some of their people might be willing to risk death in a battle they expected to win, nobody on Mesa's side would willingly give their life for it.Up until "Cauldron of Ghosts" all the people who have done suicidal things at Mesa's behest were unwilling victims under the contol of tailored "assassination nanotech" which can be used to make them carry out very simple but lethal commands such as to grab a gun and start shooting people, hit the panic button that fires all a fleet's missiles, crash an aircar, or shoot themselves in the head.But one of the Mesan security enforcers in this book, a member of an elite security force nicknamed the "Gauls," demonstrates that the "good guys" in the story do not have a total monopoly of people prepared to die for their side.Let me give a contemporary if perhaps controversial example. In the real history of the 20th and 21st century most human beings would violently disagree with, say, the Waffen SS, or with Al Queda suicide bombers, but although most of the rest of humanity would regard them as sick and depraved both thought they were or are serving a higher cause and are willing to die for it.In this book it becomes clear for the first time that the Mesan Alignment appears to have people in the same category working for them. Although the Mesan alignment appears utterly evil to the heroes and heroines of these books and hopefully to the reader, they do have an ideology which some of their people are willing to die for.A "Gaul" enforcer in this novel, who cannot possibly have been under the control of "assassination nanotech" because his actions are too complex, and are clearly a deliberate and carefully executed use of his initiative in response to a situation which his superiors may have foreseen but could not possibly have predicted in sufficient detail to programme a course of action into him against his will, carries out his mission ruthlessly and effectivlely even when his own death is an inevitable consequence. (Can't give more detail without a spoiler.)This novel is the first time we have seen the Gauls, and I will be interested to see if there is more detail about them, and about why they are willing to die for the Mesan cause, in future books.LIST OF HONORVERSE BOOKSAs hinted at above, the Honor Harrington series (sometimes nicknamed the "Honorverse") has developed two spin-off storylines. Stories set in this Universe fall into three series set 2,000 years from now amd two prequel series set 1,500 years from now, although they link together in a reasonably consistent manner.There is the main sequence, currently of 13 novels, which follow the career of Honor Harrington herself. This main sequence is:1) On Basilisk Station2) Honor of the Queen (Honorverse)3) The Short Victorious War (Honor Harrington)4) Field of Dishonour5) Flag in Exile6) Honor among Enemies7) In Enemy Hands8) Echoes of Honor9) Ashes of Victory10) War of Honor11) At All Costs12) Mission Of Honor13) A Rising ThunderThere are currently six collections in the "Worlds of Honor" series of short stories by Weber and co-authors set in the same universe, and featuring a range of characters, some from the main series of books, others new.Some of these are espionage stories and the "Crown of Slaves" sub-series co-written with Eric Flint, in which this book is the third volume, brings together several of the most prominent spies from the novels and short stories. As explained above this series comprises "Crown of Slaves," "Torch of Freedom" and "Cauldron of Ghosts."And then there the "Shadow" series, dealing mostly with events in the Talbott Cluster and the relationship between Manticore and the Solarian Republic based on Old Earth. This sequence starts with "The Shadow of Saganami" and follows on with "Storm from the Shadows" and most recently "Shadow of Freedom".PREQUEL SERIESThere are two series set five hundred years before. The "Star Kingdom" series, currently a trilogy consisting of "A beautiful friendship," "Fire Season" and "Treecat Wars," tells the story of how Honor's ancestor Stephanie Harrington became the first human to form a telempathic "adoption" bond with a Sphinx treecat. Weber is also about to bring out the first of a new "Manticore Ascendant" trilogy about the early days of the Royal Manticoran Navy, set in the same century (it starts 11 years after the prologue of "A Beautiful Friendship"). This first book, which is co-authored by Timothy Zahn, will be called "A Call to Duty" and is due for publication on 7th October 2014.OVERLAPSCauldron of Ghosts is set at almost exactly the same time as "A Rising Thunder" and "Shadow of Freedom." But in my opinion this book is easier to follow if you have read those books first.At one point early in this book Admiral Honor Harrington excuses herself for leaving a meeting to make sure her fleet is ready to deal with an imminent event which those who have read "A Rising Thunder" will recognise as having taken place in that book. The Mesan Alignment are implementing throughout "Cauldron of Ghosts," in response to the revelations made by Anton Zilwicki and Victor Chachat, a pre-prepared contingency plan discussed by Albrecht Detweiler and his son in a conversation which appears in both "A Rising Thunder" and "Shadow of Freedom."And - apologies if this sounds Delphic, I am trying to avoid a spoiler - the final pages of this book are very closely linked to the final pages of "Shadow of Freedom" in a manner which IMHO makes the ending of this book easier to follow if you have read that book first.I found "Cauldron of Ghosts" to be interesting and entertaining and recommend this book.

"The Transformation of Miss Ashworth" is described by the author as one of a pair of Regency Romance novels with a "linking theme" but in fact this story is so thoroughly intertwined with that of "The Viscount's Scandalous Return (Mills & Boon Historical)" that it does not entirely work as a standalone novel.However in my opinion it does work as part of a double bill.The idea for the two novels, both set in 1814 when the Napoleonic wars first appeared to be over, is supposed to be that the heroine of this book and the hero of the other have returned to England after spending several years with Wellington's army, and "both have been changed by their experiences."This book is the story of Miss Bethany Ashworth, daughter of a colonel in Wellington's army and in her youth an arch tomboy who had tried to be the son Colonel Ashworth never had, who had gone out to the Peninsular with her father some six years before. The story begins as she is returning to her family home, The Grange near Stavely Court in the West country. Colonel Ashworth had died towards the end of the campaign and Bethany is now the owner of the property. She soon renews her acquaintance with her childhood friend, Sir Philip Stavely, who had broken her heart when he got proposed to her cousin instead of Bethany herself six years before.However, as usual with the Regency romance genre, the course of true love does not necessarily run smooth. And both Bethany and Philip are caught up in the affairs of an individual known to Bethany as "Major Darcy Wood" who had gone out to the Peninsular, serving under a false name after being wrongly accused of a double murder. Now that the war is over he wants to clear his name. This is the story which is completed in "The Viscount's Scandalous return."The two books are best read consecutively, this one first, as a double bill, and on that basis they are reasonably well-crafted and enjoyable. As with so many romances the story does sometimes overplay the theme of two people who are obviously in love but for some reason cannot see or accept that their feelings are mutual.Worth a try if you enjoy historical romances.

Nicholas Monsarrat is of course best known for his tales of the sea: his first written works were mostly about World War II, particularly his autobiographical accounts of convoy escort duty aboard the various anti-submarine vessels he commanded during the Battle of the Atlantic such as "Three Corvettes." He will always be remembered for his iconic depiction of that campaign, the classic novel "The Cruel Sea" which is undoubtedly one of the great war stories of all time.However, Monsarrat's skill with the pen was far broader than just the ability to write about war and the sea, he also wrote some very different books, such as The White Rajah" and this is another book which is very different from his nautical offerings."The Pillow fight" is the story of a marriage which begins against the background of injustice in South Africa under the apartheid regime.At the start of the story Kate Marais is a a successful and cynical career girl from Johannesburg, and Jonathan Steele is a passionate idealistic young writer preparing a book about Africa. Despite the huge gulf between their ideas, backgrounds and values, they fall in love and eventually marry.The twist to the story is that in the second half of the book their values switch in opposite directions: Kate has become more idealistic and ethical while Jonathon has tasted "the corrupting fruits of success" and become far more cynical. As Jonathon becomes a globe-trotter enjoying fame and wealth while seeking more of the same. Much of the second half of the book is set in Barbados and New York. Meanwhile, Kate comes to care about the people of Africa in the way the man she had married once did, and putting ever more strain on their relationship ...This is a well written and entertaining story and those who like romance and relationship stories with a harder edge will probably enjoy it. Just don't expect it to be anything like "The Master Mariner" or "The Cruel Sea!"

Susan Travers's autobiography "Tomorrow to be Brave" is a true story of events which no fiction writer would have dared to use in a novel.Susan Travers is unique in at least two respects - she and her father were, to the best of her knowledge probably the only father and daughter, and certainly the only English father and daughter, to both be awarded the Legion d'honneur by France, and she was also the only woman to serve in the French Foreign legion.This autobiography was published in 2000, when she was a widow in her nineties: she did not feel able to tell her story in full before her husband's death in 1995.The official announcement of her award of the Legion d'honneur in the Foreign Legion newspaper read as follows:"The Kepi Blanc is pleased to inform you of the nomination to the grade of Knight of the Legion of Honour for Chef-adjudant Susan Travers, married name Schlegelmilch, the only woman to be part of the history of the Foreign Legion (regimental roll number 22166). She served during the second world war as the driver of General Koenig and as a nurse in the Far East and North Africa."That gives only the faintest hint of Susan Travers' extraordinary story but I quote it because otherwise I would have had difficulty believing that this tale could be true. Truth really is sometimes stranger than fiction.The author tells the story of her life in a very engaging way, making no attempt to gloss over aspects of her story which might have been embarrassing to herself or anyone else, and with a most entertaining dry sense of humour. To give a couple of examples of her wit, she says of the pet dog she had as a child,"our black labrador, Duchess ... was bought as a gun dog for Father but turned out to be terrified of loud bangs and was thereafter confined to the nursery in disgrace."Of World War one, in which her father, a former naval officer who came out of retirement and volunteered for war service, earned his own Legion d'honneur while acting as a liason between Britain and France, she writes of her grandmother"My grandmother refused to allow anything as inconsequencial as the First World War to interfere with her social life ...Whether my grandmother deliberately flouted government calls on the weathy to be frugal and live simpler lives I don't know. I imagine she simply thought that they couldn't possibly be referring to her."This is a fantastic, frank, very entertaining and exciting autobiography of an extraordinary woman living in extraordinary times, and I strongly recommend it.

The ripped bag that drips. The collapsed cord tie. The glass jar that punches a whole straight through. The imbalanced bag. The bag swallowed whole  when  the first item goes in.Ask yourself this: is 6 extra cents a  bag (in comparison to the standard equivalents at Walmart) worth never having to deal with these problems? Is a dripping, dribbling mess worth $3 saved? What about the hassle of replacing shoddy ones with poor seals?I would offer a resounding 'yes,' noting that these are literally designed to be thrown away. Hefty Ultimate Flex Tall Kitchen Bags are seemingly 4-5 thicker than average bags. They literally snap on...and around...a tall garbage can with ease. The strings are of higher quality. The woven style provides needed stretch when the big is inevitably unevenly weighted. The odor control? Not as good as advertised.I think of these akin to buying cheap batteries. Sure, if you need the battery to run a clock and/or lower powered/end device, no problem. The same for bathroom/vanity wastebaskets. Any bag can do there. But for higher end/usage needs, cutting corners is simply not worth the hassle.These bags definitely made me rethink the garbage bag concept. Spend more, get more. I'm also confident that - due to  their durability - they don't need to be swapped out as often as cheaper counterparts. Thus, 6 cents becomes 4 cents.

I have weird feet. The kind prone to taylor's bunions, also sporting a bad case of plantar fasciitis.Unfortunately for me, shoe manufacturers nor workout studios don't give a damn. For the former, nearly every shoe I should be using is too narrow. On the latter, concrete/wooden floors are evil. Even more so when they involve jumping jacks, burpees, mountain climbers, pushups, and/or other exercises when pounding is inevitable.These shoes are awesome; the boost thing no joke. That little extra padding goes a very long way in transferring impact on landing. Also, I absolutely adore the stretchy mesh surface that gives my funky small toes a needed break.If you're color agnostic, these bad boys can be had for ~$40. Buy two pairs, amigos.I bought the Boost 2.0 for the better half (complaining of knee problems,)...and knee pain no more.

I would venture to guess I've now tried every dairy free, protein powder on the market. As a guy with IBD but also workout fiend, these powders are vital morning meals, needed recovery aids from hard fighting and cross fit-style training.What I dig about the Jay Robb Egg White Protein Strawberry is, well...everything. The strawberry tastes fantastic, no grainy nonsense others possess, no horrible chemical fillers, and a consistency that doesn't destroy sensitive innards.Going forward, this is the powder for me, hand down. Note there a coupon (ahem) that comes with it for future purchases...if one goes direct.

My entire dress sock collection was comprised of socks that lost elastic, socks with too much elastic, socks that tore, socks too tight on toes, and socks that simply look and feel cheap. The only pairs that stood the test of time were mid-upper quality Nautica ones.Dare I say, these new 4-packs are higher quality than their predecessors (purchased at Marshall's). The fabric is softer with more logical stretch, colors a nice texture, and I dig the striped toe. They also don't rub against dress shoes, one of my pet sock peeves. Coming out of the wash, no fading to be seen.At this price point, there's simply no way I'll wear any other dress socks but Nautica. I could care less about the branding; the quality and look far surpass equivalents (Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, etc.) I've since donated in lieu of these.

Believe the hype.Needing an upgrade over older Harbinger (beaten to death and now peeling) and BNooch (Velcro keeps falling aparty gloves, terrific reviews led me to purchase a pair of these bad boys.For my purposes, I want/ed a glove for lifting, one that can take the grind of pushups/mountain climbers on concrete/turf, sled pushes/rope swings, barbell/kettle bell lifts, etc. Also not get disgusting from heavy sweating (it is W FL, after all). In short, a 'beat the bejeebuz out them' glove set.These, my friends, are it. The pictures tell a tale of a seemingly bulky set of gloves...with a tail-length wrist wrap. Nope, and thankfully nope. Streamlined, well made, and with a nice support system that doesn't overwrap, these guys are a winner. Yes, they're around $10 more than I would've liked to spend, but - in this instance - you really do get what you pay for.On the sizing part, get yourself a $1 sewing kit...and properly measure hand radius, as described, with the included tape. Using this info,  I found these gloves a perfect fit...at a size larger than I usually purchase.

I've got several backup chargers out there...the credit card kind, the cylinder shaped, and the larger capacity brick. All perform as promised (noting I only buy higher end ones to avoid charging mishaps). They all, however, also have a knack for running out of juice when I need them the most. As a light/moderate user, these supplementary power sources barely get any TLC...until it's too late. Hindsight as 20/20 = a common theme for my outdated iPhone 4S.When Stunning Gadgets offered me the opportunity to review their SG Sport Solar Panel Charger, I welcomed an alternate way to manage a backup power source. I confess: I was skeptical...but ultimately quite pleased.To explain, the Sport Solar Panel Charger embraces the light handshake of both outdoor and - most importantly - indoor lighting, meaning, if you keep it exposed (via handy and included carabiner clip) to even an overhead flourescent....you don't have to think, period, about charging capacity. I turn my kitchen lights on, the little guy charges. I put it on a window sill, you betcha. For the road warrior, attaching the Sport Solar Panel Charger to a backpack means always having a backup power source on hand without any thought included. Included additional flashlight is a welcome feature.With this being said, you can manually charge the Sport Solar Panel Charger via a USB outlet/power source. Stunning Gadgets are thankfully intuitive enough to include TWO USB charge ports for manual charging, meaning you can use it...and charge...simultaneously. None of my other chargers can accomplish this feat.Duly note, however, that the Sport Solar Panel Charger only comes with one cable: USB to MicroUSB. Thus, for Lightning chargers, older Apple chargers, etc., you'll want to buy another cable. You've been warned.Related, Stunning Gadgets claims this bad boy near weatherproof. Not sure I want to test that claim. It's shell resembles what one would find on an OtterBox, with dual rubberized enclosures protecting ports. Would I risk drenching this? Probably not. I do, however, feel pretty safe letting it take mother nature's light rain if ports don't get over-exposed.I also found one of the charge meter lights inconsistent in brightness to others on the left. Not a big deal, but a minor QC mater.Finally - and for any review product - I always put customer service to the test. Many small businesses want Amazon reviews...but don't seem to know/care about their products. Stunning Gadgets is thankfully neither, a fairly responsive company that follows-up quickly and intelligently. Thus, I'm cautiously optimistic warranty claims will be met with professionalism and quick turnaround.All in all, the Stunning Gadgets Sport Solar Panel Charger is a surprisingly practical and energy hip device that does what it promises. I dig the prospect of not having to think ahead with a supplemental charger, also one that can take a bit of a knock.

The guys at Glasstic offered me a chance to review the Tribal pattern of this bottle in return for an unbiased review. Unbeknownst to them, I take my water bottles very seriously. I literally have over a dozen - in different shapes, sizes and materials - as them faithful allies everywhere I go (being a fitness junkie in sweltering West Florida). Thus, Glasstic: you are brave souls.I admit, I expected very little from this bottle...likely another small business custom making products with glaring loose ends. What I discovered, was anything but.To explain, this bottle oozes class. I dig the Tribal pattern, one that doesn't look pasted/stickered on. Related, the glass-inside-plastic enclosure is simply brilliant. My formerly favorite glass bottle - Contigo Purity Glass Water Bottle, 20-Ounce, Greyed Jade is glass throughout. Even with a rubber exterior, I'm always fearful my beloved Purity bottle is going to shatter and/or glass top crack with use. With Glasstic's plastic shell, I feel a bit more at ease by an obviously lighter and seemingly safer bottle. (I'm yet to throw it against a wall or drop it on rocks as I don't want a crime scene on my hands.) They also warranty the glass interior. If I need to use said warranty, something very wrong likely happened. (Eek!)Another smart aspect of the Glasstic bottle is the ability to completely remove/replace the top AND bottom components. Far too many of my bottle favorites end up moldy - even with dishwasher rinse - as I could never fully clean them. With everything coming apart, however, I was worried about seal. I shook the darn thing to oblivion, expected a shower...but got none. I would expect this seal to lessen after repeated dishwasher use (it's only  logical)...thus will stick to manual cleaning except once in a while.How does it drink? The sipping opening is admittedly a bit different, more of the pouring versus sports bottle (longer tube) variety. The lid and accompanying hook both bend back in a controlled fashion, making this a truly one-handed bottle. I admit it took me a bit of finagling to realize how the lid rests over the hook. I dig the lock latch, in tandem. It really does shut and seal.Perhaps the most useful part of this review is a reminder to fill out the post purchase email. You do this, and Glasstic sends a perfectly sized bottle brush...likewise a second set of different colored (mine were grey) top/bottom parts. This second set had a pouring top, one common to camping style bottles. They said they're working on including these with original purchase, going forward.If there's a criticism, it's recognition that the bottle is slightly smaller than competitors, 16oz versus 20oz. This makes it useful for one handed drinking, just not too far away from a water source. I would consider this a great gym/home bottle, but not ideal for long camping excursions.Once you factor in the freebies, this bottle is an arguable steal for $20. I peppered the heck out of Glasstic reps with questions, and they humored this water bottle fanatic. Hopefully they get the shipping bit figured out...also introduce bigger bottles down the line.

There's nothing not to like about Food Should Taste Good Multigrain Bean Chips.They are light to digest, have a wonderfully simplistic (in a good way) bean taste/texture them, and are one of the few snack food items that don't hit you over the head with hidden dairy (my arch nemesis) and/or salt/sugars. Bad ingredient content is extremely low for such a guilty pleasure, fiber content - however- quite high. In short: this is a terrific snack food option.Not so good? Buying chips online. My poor bag - despite inflated packaging protect bags, nice cardboard box - were somewhat smushed. Whole chips were more the norm than exception. Thus, I can't state - with complete confidence - you will receive your chips in full chip condition, via Amazon. This is not to state they were granules.Still, this bag was noticeably less solid than found in person at a Whole Foods store (or equivalent). I love this product, but this a product perhaps better purchased locally.

Call me a stickler...but these poor animals look like tasty blobs. It's hard to even discern what animal type they are, thus goes much of the fun and guilt of eating them slowly (sorry, elephants for years of cracker consumer torture),This is not to say they don't taste as remembered. Still addictive, nice and light, and a wonderful snack. Still, would be nice to know what member of animal kingdom whose snack life I'm limiting.

As an experienced Muay Thai practitoner also group fitness (kick/boxing) fan, I can't even begin to count the number of times tortured souls came to me asking what gloves to buy. Every single one of them was holding a lowest end Everlast or Title pair of vinyl gloves...and complained of horrific wrist and knuckle pain, occasional finger bleeding/blisters, and even headaches from the impact.They may chalk it up to being a beginner, and adjusting. Yes, there's some of that...but that tells a very small part of the story. I tried on these gloves and attempted to use them. I cried on the insane, giant crocodile tears.Cheap gloves have almost zero padding and/or wrist support. They get moldy faster. The vinyl cracks. They're not weighted evenly (leading to poor technique). Far too many people fall prey to Walmart Everlast availability and/or the pair the gym sells you. They're both awful. As are most of the handwraps (you'll want ones with elastic to provide a better fit/support). Ask yourself this simple question: what's cheaper...caring for broken bones or a pair of decent gloves (that can last 2+ years, minimum)As 99% of glove purchasers are doing so for fitness purposes, a quick, affordable fix are Twins Special, Fairtex or Venum Challenger gloves. (Knockoffs like RDX/Pro Impact are also decent being real leather.) All are fantastic mid level, durable leather mitts...ones that will last you a long time with proper care (use a sports spray/disinfectant after each use, let them AIR OUT). All are available on Amazon. Yes, they'll cost you $30 more...but see note above on injuries. Glove dogs are also nice to have around. 12oz at most for heavy bag. 10oz is fine for smaller women. Heck...order 2 or 3...send the ones you don't like back. Gloves are a personal thing, re: feel.Wraps? Skip Everlast and Meister. Go for - at minimum - wider Title or Ringside (my personal favorite based on price). Remember NOT to roll them up when wet or they'll get moldy. Let them sit on the shower floor while showering, step on 'em, easy washing fix in between heavier washes.While $75 seems a lot to invest in a sport/hobby you're not certain about...do it safely. These Everlast gloves are NOT the way.

Suffering from Clone Wars withdrawal is a terrible thing...so says the Savage Opress statue sitting in our living room.Yup, I'm a fan. The characters in this terrific animated series arguably possess deeper personalities than many of their movie counterparts, notably the varied spectrums of good versus evil.Without providing spoilers, Christie Golden successfully brings to print what the Clone Wars did to screen, and with it a terrific deeper dive into the already fantastic Quinlan Vos and Asajj Ventress characters. Specifically, the very fine line which separates the force from the dark side. Golden does a very good job in leaving interpretations of this line up to the reader, allowing Clone Wars fans to revisit earlier perceptions/conclusions about key characters (ie the Nightsisters) while doing so.Others have commented on the romance part; you've been warned. This aspect is weaved into a very easy read tale, one full of fun Star Wars tropes and references. In short, this is a book any Clone Wars fan is going to enjoy.All in all, Dark Disciple stands as one of the better tales in the Star Wars universe, featuring consistent writing quality and nice character development. A solid book.

I've always been a big fan of GermGuardian's smaller units, capable odor fighters for active kitchens. If there was a criticism of this unit, it's the uneven weight balance, also vents that tend to get clogged. Thus, when Guardian Technologies offered a review opportunity for its new iteration of GG1100, I jumped at the chance.This was a much needed leap, as my small laundry room was stinking to high heaven. Plagued by the mold/damp odor of a High Efficiency washer in West Florida...combined with endlessly stinky compression clothes, post workout...we needed help. Airing out the washer, washer tablets, an accompanying washer fan, also Safe T's deodorizer all fell short of the stinky dragon.The GG1100 is the dragon slayer. After 1.5 days, the odor is gone. I can walk into the laundry room, breathe deeply, and no remnants of workouts past. Logically the smell will return if new stench is added to the mix, but - like clockwork - there it goes 1.5 days later. This thing is incredible. If they weren't $40/each, they'd be in all 3 bathrooms in my house.Size wise, I didn't find it as obtrusive as others...but it's also on the lower part of a laundry room wall. Perhaps I'd feel differently if allowed more visibility.Finally and for those wanting to multitask (desktop counters, I gather), there's an accompanying USB charge port on its side. A nice added bonus if your cell phone needs some love.

Bless you, chiropractor to the stars, a wise chap who told me my hyperextended/dislocated elbow from MMA was - in fact - golf elbow. As a guy who's never played a round of golf in my life, I thought he was nuts.The man, however, was right x1000. I wore the Bracoo Strap religiously for every workout over 3 months' time...and no increased pain. It's incredible how something so small, so simple can do so much. It survived a lot of sweat, washes and use...and remains on constant standby for the next flare-up.For BJJ aficianados, consider this a great ally.

Purchased for my much better half, Asics Emma Racerback tops are absolute winners. So much so, I purchased them in almost every color I could find.To explain, they breathe like champs, even in highest intensity workout and on top of a compression sports bra. Racerback means no pull, excellent for workout requiring arm/shoulder flexibility. The Mrs. is also a very small person, (5'2'', 110#), and these are flattering while functional. They don't hang, nor look like poser clothing = too form fitting to be useful.Most importantly, they're durable and colorfast. They don't retain stench (as do cheaper ones), and hold shape after wash. In short: I can't recommend these enough!

I feel like an idiot.I've wasted far too much money on fragile Twins, Title, and other supposed gear bags, only too watch them deteriorate from moisture and/or zippers fall off in just under 6 months. To this day, I don't know why the heck it's so hard to design a bag that can hold fighting equipment, likewise transport their sweaty counterparts back home (until cleaning/drying).Goodbye peeling plastic from compression clothing. Sayonara snapped, cheap plastic zippers. Take a hike stupid hard plastic bottom inserts that don't maintain shape. While Meister products are very much hit or miss (their wraps and ankle braces are an abomination), this X-Large gear bag is a stud. Durable mesh, steel zippers, two big side compartments for mouthgear, keys, water bottle, etc. That's what I'm talking about.Speaking of which, don't buy the smaller version. If you have any hope of hoping shin pads, gloves, wraps, headgear, a towel, and change of clothes...the XL is where to be. I could even stick pads in their (albeit snug).UPDATE: Months in, I still love this bag. Meister tells me to hand clean it in a sink (cold water + detergent) air dry.

The Pridebit Julienne & Vegetable Peeler/Cutter/Slicer is one of those kitchen items you probably didn't think you needed...until you have it. Truth be told, I never would've thought to even attempt Julienne peeling unless Pridebit offered me a review copy at a discounted price.At $11, this is a surprising rock star at both traditional and Julienne peeling/slicing, a durable and evenly weighted device that punches well beyond its weight. The included pipe cleaner-esque brush helps keep the Julienne side clean. Speaking of Julienne peeling/slicing, this was our maiden voyage for this slicing type. Thanks to Pridebit, our stir frys now pack a chef like panache.The guinea pig was a willing cucumber, with smooth and even peeling to its external skin. Internal elements easily sliced into nice looking Julienne strands. The peeler/slicer never slipped from hands at both stags; it is properly weighted to not give in to wetter surfaces and occasional slip.All in all, I'm very impressed by the Pridebit Julienne & Vegetable Peeler/Cutter/Slicer. I've wasted oodles of money on similarly priced but poorer performing peelers/slicers. The Julienne bit is a welcome and nice touch.Finally - and customer service wise - these guys are very responsive to questions/concerns.

I admit it: I overtrain. My poor legs remind me of this daily, with endless spasms, aches, shin pains and the world's longest warmup period. While I'm a slave to compression shirts and shorts (cotton's sweaty embrace is deadly), I waited for too long to test compression calf sleeves.Placebo effect, be damned: the Shock Doctor SVR Recovery Compression Calf Sleeve is a rock star. Within literally 5 minutes of putting these on, my calves were already warmed up for light running. I put these bad boys to the test in 90+ degree Florida workout heat, specifically an hour of cross training where leg use was prominently featured.No cramps, no shin pain, no irritating 30 min before my legs woke up. Speaking of Florida heat, no disgusting trapped sweat either. I was shocked when they came off...they did so without a pool of sweat common to compression clothing. Thirty minutes later, my legs are not as tired as they typically are. These things really do work.Fit wise, the Large felt custom made for a 6'2'', 170 pound athlete. They literally fit exactly as they did in the picture. Easy to get on, only slightly harder (being wet) getting off. I did hear the usual fabric crunch at the bottom of the sleeve upon first use, one common to compression clothing (as they're breaking in). Still, no loose seams anywhere to give me cause for concern.All in all, the Shock Doctor SVR Recovery Compression Calf Sleeve far exceeded my expectations. I can only imagine how awesome these must be for runners in colder temps. Just be wary of size: I'm guessing most will opt for a medium.

The Amazon Collection is typically hit or miss, and - unfortunately - the 10k Yellow Gold Triangle Fashion Dangle is of the latter category.To explain - and while 10k gold - these earrings look and feel cheap. Engraving quality is inconsistent, with pattern depth noticeably non-uniform at places. Also, said engraving pattern is unimpressive for a $100 earring set. Note: these look much better in the close-up pictures than in hand.Related - and while 10k gold - these earrings have a weight and feel of much lesser metal. Meaning, unless someone knows this is 10k gold, they're likely to be very disappointed in how cheap these earrings feel. It doesn't help help they come packaged within a ziploc bag. Ouch.The one positive is that these earrings are extraordinarily lightweight. Thus - and while small-medium size - they are not bulky or heavy. Small victory.All in all, I unfortunately can't recommend the Amazon Collection 10k Yellow Gold Triangle Fashion Dangle Earrings. They don't look and feel as good as they should, with better options out there for less money.

What happens when you take a pretty standard product and give it the Paris treatment?That, my Amazon friends, is Pre de Provence Savon De Marseille's Liquid Soap (Lavender Sage). Everything about this soap oozes class: the lather quality, smooth texture, easy rinse-ability, moisturizing feel, and a terrific lavender (and barely sage) scent.The scent - per other reviewers - is a mixed bag. My wife and I absolutely adored it. Lavender is very hit or miss in this area, as the cheap stuff resembles the worst kind of bathroom spray. This is thankfully not of that variety. Now the scent - like top notch hand creme - is certainly noticeable...but loses potency within 5-10 minutes. It's no surprise this comes from the land of perfume. Pre de Provence got this right.If there's a criticism to be made, it's the Savon De Marseille's poor packaging and below average pump. Thankfully - unlike others - mine didn't come leaking and/or with the pump already engaged. Still, it's obvious this can happen (based on appearance), as the mechanism (and bottle) are not appropriate for something of this price point.Would I purchase this (as non-review product)? That depends on how long the bottle lasts. As typically hand soap containers - the $3-5 variety - last about a couple months, Pre de Provence Savon De Marseille Liquid Soap needs to double that to even warrant the leap. Fingers crossed, but ones smelling great and feeling moisturized while I wait.

Oh, the sad tale of the dish towel. Forgotten afterthought of the kitchen, left to whatever remains on hand at Walmart or Target at discount prices. Ironic, as seemingly no other kitchen item receives equal daily use.Behold, the DII 100% Cotton 16 x 19 dish towel set. This four pack features nice sharp colors, with surprisingly good stitching and weight for the price. No loose threads, uneven color dye, ugly stitches so common in lower priced, bulk cloth sets.I haven't tested machine washing them as of yet, but they certainly look/feel as durable as any other dish towel (that seem destined to survive the washing apocalypse).My only criticism is a fairly significant one, however, in that I would consider these more of the bar versus kitchen towel variety. Meaning, they're useful to attack larger amounts of water/liquids...but they don't perfectly dry items akin to regular dish towels. Wipe all you want, but these towels are seemingly not designed to finish the deed, in entirety.Still, they get most of what's there, keep stone/granite counters relatively dry, look and feel solid. It's hard to go wrong with these at $2.50 each. Hopefully they'll continue to look as spiffy after a few washes.

**UPDATE: For those using it on their face...and posting negative reviews and/or down-voting positive ones...these are NOT MEANT FOR THE FACIAL AREA. Also, these things worked SO well, I bought another batch.**Oh, body acne, the unfortunate bedfellow of a committed workout routine. Even more so with compression clothing, where moisture wicking tendsto trap oils/dirt beneath.After nearly a hundred wasted dollars on different butt/body acne products, Proactiv Clear Zone Body Pads does what all others fail to do. Granted with a little sting.To explain, Proactiv Clear Zone Body Pads are powerful allies in the fight against body acne. Boy, do they clean! Oils and dirt remnants appear on the pads post-use...accompanied by a noticeable zing after use. Also nice is the absence of a chemical smell. Finally, one pad goes a long way; there's a significant amount of cleaning agent on each.The next morning (as workouts are at night), applied areas feature slightly shrunken acne heads. (Rome wasn't built in a day, friends.)If there's a note of caution, those with very sensitive skin may find these too irritating. Second, be cognizant of wiping down sweat before application. More sweat...more sting. These work better on cleaner skin.All in all - and echoing other reviewers - Proactiv Clear Zone Body Pads are a terrific product for adult body acne sufferers...especially gym rats. As one pad does its thing and well, one can get ~2 months to tackle the formerly undefeated sweat beast.

Having taken the plunge on a natural - but very expensive - deodorant (via Vine review), I was amazed at the difference removing aluminum makes. I'm now convinced that my insatiable appetite to sweat less (via potent anti-perspirants) actually ended up clogging pores...leading to more sweat.While I liked the review product (My Goodness Natural Deodorant), the price point ($20 an oz) and application method (hand rubbing) didn't sit well. Thus, I took the plunge on the Tom's of Maine Lemongrass Natural Deodorant, I purchased one stick locally (~$6) in hopes of buying in bulk later via Amazon. Soon thereafter, the product was returned to CVS.I felt an obligation to write this review as I've never seen a new stick of deodorant act anything like this. It literally oozed liquid everywhere within my admittedly hot car, thankfully isolated to the bag I luckily didn't take it out off. It made a mess of everything beside it, with any/everything now smelling like Lemongrass. Which is not a bad thing. The pool of deodorant oils...a different story.A devil's advocate would point out that deodorant sticks do, in fact, crack at higher temps. My Speed Stick and Old Spice ones, for instance, are notorious for abandoning form when the stick drops to 1/3 capacity. Still, no deodorant ever left such an unsightly, oily mess as the Tom's of Maine Natural Deodorant Lemongrass Stick. If it can't maintain consistency sitting in a car, I wouldn't trust it absorbing odor/balancing moisture in armpits not much warmer. Let alone the disaster it could wreak in checked airplane luggage. Imagine an entire suitcase covered in deodorant stick oils...smelling like Lemongrass.If you live in higher temperature climates, I advise serious caution before purchasing and using this deodorant stick. I'm terribly disappointed, as it's seemingly a great concept (aluminum free), smell, and reasonably priced.

First things first: I saw little difference between the Proactiv+ Skin Purifying Mask and it's significantly less expensive counterparts. Thus, if this wasn't a review product, I would likely feel quite disappointed by the extra investment.To explain, I'm always on the lookout for skin care products capable of shrinking nasal pores, also remove dirt/oils from skin facial surface. Florida + very sweaty workouts can wreak havoc on skin tone and complexion.As someone with normal/dry skin, the Proactiv+ Skin Purifying Mask unfortunately provided almost no noticeable benefit in exception to a surface cleaning. My wife - who has the opposite skin type (oily) likewise found little difference between this and Queen Helene offerings. In fact, she deemed the latter  arguably more effective. We both complained of extreme dryness and subtle redness after recommended ten minutes of drying (then removal) time.Using the Proactiv+ Skin Purifying Mask reminded me of another review product, that being the Bjore charcoal facial cleansing bar. Both clean...but severely dry out skin...albeit rinse easily. Perhaps others will find more to love in these as facial cleansing agents, but not in this household. Even more so at $40.

It's hard to criticize a product when there's seemingly nothing else like it. Such is the case with the Proactiv+ Complexion Perfecting Hydrator, a moisturizer/toner that doesn't leave a dry, red mess in its wake. This is even more important for adult acne sufferers, where sensitive skin is first and foremost.Proactiv+ Complexion Perfecting Hydrator does what it promises. It leaves oily skin looking bright, definitely not dried out, and a little goes a long way. It also noticeably reduced the size of some acne wannabe's, also shrunk others that decided to hold court. Out with you, I say!If there are criticisms to be made, Proactiv+ Complexion Perfecting Hydrator doesn't smell good...and application is messy. The supplied plastic applicator certainly helps, but is far from perfect. Applying with fingers? Not a good idea.All in all, the Proactiv+ Complexion Perfecting Hydrator is a welcome product from adult acne sufferers, arguably worth the price being unique in what it does. All it needs is some aspect of fragrance and improved application method to be perfect.

Thankfully - as someone who leases vehicle - I'm yet to experience rubber seal failure on my car. Still, I've seen its effects first hand...even more so living in the very unforgiving heat of West Florida summers.To explain, color fading is never a good thing. Likewise what was once a pretty firm rubber seal begin to get floppy. There's only so much a car can do with a sun not afraid to take prisoners.I applied the 303 Rubber Seal to a barely 2 year old VW SUV - wow, there's a lot of rubber seal on this thing! - in just under 15 min. The rubber seal seemingly lapped the stuff up, absorbing near instantly, drying quickly...and leaving a fresh (non-chapped) touch. Akin to moisturizing leather, it's obvious when product and surface have a love fest. This is one of those instances.Application - as others noted - is a breeze. While it's near impossible to clean every surface of rubber pre-application (dirt is sneaky), 303's Rubber Seal Protectant application sponge fought capably through the messy stuff. A few strokes later, the brush head was clean again. No clogs, annoying drips either. Where some dirt was dragged, Meguilar's interior cleaner took care of that.One last thought: In applying this product, I was thinking how useful it would be to have in a wipes format. Perhaps the next go. Well done, 303.

After the lid hinge snapped on my Rubbermaid kitchen wastebasket, I decided to take the plunge on something slightly better. This wastebasket demise also made me realize the value of a good lid and closure system. Whew; things get stinky fast with a funky lid.Unfortunately, not much to choose from in the low profile, 40L range for wastebaskets. And I sure as heck wasn't going to spend $100 for something fancier.The simplehuman Slim looks and feels better than Rubbermaid's equivalent, with a more polished look to its plastic, also better quality on its hinges and step. Lid assembly was surprisingly tricky...and took longer than it should. (Frustration tends to mount quickly when attempts to assemble a seemingly simple product doesn't go as intended. I'm talking to YOU Kohler toilet seat!)The lid closes nicely, locks out odors well. I like the fact the lid doesn't slam immediately shut when closing (meaning, it's not 100% contingent on the pedal for operation.) The additional latch seal is the wastebasket equivalent of Ft. Knox. Easily to close...but a fair bit of effort to re-open. Probably a good thing for those with pets/rugrats. Not so much for me wanting to keep out last night's fish stir fry remnants from surrounding nostrils.Some complained of this being easy tip. I didn't experience this...but also not two of the four sides sit adjacent to walls.All in all, a decent purchase in a limited product space. Here's hoping I won't have to use simplehuman's warranty in 1-2 years...but at least it's there.

Thanks to the terrific reviews on this product - thank you, Amazon faithful - I too took the plunge on Seya's Modern Espresso Jewelry Box. Wonderfully built (no cheap wood frilling, mis-staining, poor drawer fit, loose knobs, etc.), also a terrific interior lining. Everything about this box feels high class.It's also a stunner, and looks a highest end piece of mini furniture. The dark brown (espresso) color is a perfect match for our big box bedroom set. Thus, it stands out in a subtle but good way.Finally - and unlike many wood based products - it's packaged well. REALLY well. Silica gel in every single drawer/compartment to keep humidity levels appropriate for the wood and lining. Triple wrap protection. Double box to avoid dinging (lord knows FedEx Home tried to test this concept based on exterior box damage). My only regret is I didn't buy this sooner.

I've been waiting for this figure to drop to a reasonable cost...and it finally has. The Inspirational One is one the best molds to date in  the basic line, complete with picture perfect facial expression, also hair and outfit. Simply put: Mattel nailed this one. The same can be said of the new Adam Rose and Sami Zayn facial molds. Terrific.Speaking of outfit, Bo's trademark 'Bolieve' is featured across the back of his trunks, something you can't see from the product description. It's a shame WWE removed this from his current character.Finally, please don't overpay for Basic Series WWE figures. I've fallen prey to this in the past ($30 Rusev...grrrrr), as Amazon doesn't sort them very well. There's literally dozens of redundant figure entries - at different price points - on the site. While not foolproof, begin your search with 'WWE Basic Series,' and take it from there. This will typically yield the lowest price (direct via Amazon, as well), except for Divas (often victim to low inventory and increased prices).

My armpits hurt. All the time. I also sweat...a LOT. Which makes little sense as I'm a very athletic guy, plus consume gallons of water day.I've tried extra strength anti perspire/deodorants, mainstream...also non mainstream products. I'm tired of the weird hard, chemical glob left on my undershirts, also the smell at the end of the day. I'm convinced the strong stuff is clogging my pores.My Goodness Deodorant is a nice change, albeit far from perfect. To begin, it stings upon initial use. Application is a tad nasty having to rub the product into your armpits. Even suggested dime size amount is awkward.Still...it works and well. The sting went away in about 30 min, and - after a full day of use, including an intense workout - My Goodness Deodorant holding fairly strong. Not 48 hour strong. Yes, a good bit was absorbed during said workout, but there's certainly no offensive stench. Also - and perhaps due to it not clogging pores - I sweated significantly less from my armpits. Dare I say less sweat than when using a supposed anti-perspirant. No glob on the undershirt, just normal moisture.I can't pinpoint what caused the initial sting, but perhaps I need to step down in My Goodness Deodorant strength. Being a Vine review, however, I can only review what I get. Hopefully they'll offer alternate strengths in review products. Either way, the sting sensation was significantly less on Day 2.I would also like an improvement on application method. As a dude, we're not fans of rubbing lotion onto armpit hair. While this product works well, I'd like a middle ground. Clearly lotion breaks down easier than roll on/powder. There's got to be something better than hand application, however.All in all, however, My Goodness Deodorant is a nice change of deodorant pace for an athletic dude. My armpits don't hurt for the first time in ages...no undershirt glob. I'm nearly a week into using the stuff, and I don't if I want to go back to traditional anti-perspirants/deodorants. I'm now convinced they made me sweat more by blocking the pores, also made my sweat smell a little funky. I have no idea what is symptom versus cure, but there's clearly something to be said about using a more natural deodorant.

These earrings are fantastic.To explain: they're nicely weighted to not be flimsy or heavy, possess an outstanding and easy-to-use clasp, and possess a beautiful but still subtle filigree pattern that resembles traditional Celtic jewelry. Most importantly, they don't look or feel cheap (like the ones in a Target/Walmart at similar price point).Functionally and being sterling silver, these earrings are subtle yet classy. This makes them wearable for casual to office attire. Being textured, they look terrific with curly/wavy hair, especially darker colors where the silver can 'pop' a bit.All in all, a wonderful set of earrings at an equal price.

Rare is the sauce that is so flavorful it stands alone. Minor's Chile Garlic is that rarity.With a thick texture that blends seamlessly at high heat, Minor's Chile Garlic sauce is the seasoning you never knew you needed. Even more so for Asian wok/stir fry style cooking, as it has the substance that my beloved Sriracha lacks...also holds it flavor a bit better as well. Duly noted, of course, that Sriracha is more an after versus during cooking condiment. I still love you, great rooster!I would deem Minor's Chile Garlic as a sweet yet distinct seasoning, where the garlic adds a nice omnipresent kick. The chiles don't seem to provide much other than to bind; little heat to speak of.Also - and worth noting - is there's tons of this stuff...even more so as a little goes a long way. 77 oz is monster bottle at 2tbsp per serving. Don't forget to refrigerate after opening!If there's one criticism to be had, the sodium content is way too high for my liking. This ended in combining the sauce with turmeric for final finish, and with it cut down on the nearly 600 mg of sodium per serving also 7g of sugar. Also - and at 45 calories per serving - you want to be smart or waste calories in the wrong places.For restaurants and/or cooks making big Asian style dishes, Minor's Chile Garlic is a no-brainer. It's a terrific, hassle free base that makes proteins, rice and veggies shine. Those making smaller dishes, however, be wary of the bad stuff in here. Not enough to be dangerous...but note the contents.

Samsil's Pop n' Store Medium Square Box is one of those clever storage solutions that simply gets it. Small enough as to not be obtrusive, portable but not flimsy, and a nice firm lid (thanks to metal corners) that stays on tight. Very attractive in white, and seemingly more so in other color choices.If there's a criticism to be had, it's the cloth bottom (that the cardboard slides onto to form box bottom) vulnerable to tear. Should this tear, there goes box integrity. I also had some difficulty breaking it back down...but not enough to recommend against it. I see the latter as a positive, as it means the box holds its shape. Not sure how these two aspects would impact larger sizes of said box...but at medium, it's a winner.Functionally, Samsil's Pop n' Store Medium Square Box's primary purpose was to replace a shoebox holding keepsakes that's seen far too much duty. This box fits the bill perfectly. Deep storage for its size, easy to move, and walls that don't give in to an array of objects.Every now and then I'm offered a review product that truly surprises in its value. This is one of them.

These bands - from thickness, to tension, also carrying case - reek of quality. They're not the flimsy plastic you see in lower grade handoffs at physical therapy places, and are equivalent to Thera Band (if not better). No odor, powdery residue, plastic shearing. Nice grip as well.In contrast to Thera Band, I trust B Nooch's  offering to hold up to some serious abuse. These are awesome for hip abductor/extensions, the dreaded duo that traditional exercise (non loop) bands struggle mightily with. I gave each of these bands a serious stretch and pull, and I would declare the clearly marked tension grades accurate. Stretching the darker color bad boys is certainly a workout.If there's a criticism, it's that they're very short. Which...isn't really a criticism, if you're looking to apply them to specific exercises. Aforementioned hip work, leg/calf extension, seated bicep curls, sumo squats (with spread), lateral triceps stretch, pelvic thrust...all well suited for these small bad boys.For a fitness customer: the B Nooch Workout Bands are wonderful supplements to an existing exercise routine...even more so if you're taking the show on the road. Everything fits easily and well in provided carry bag and therefore suitcase. Physical therapy customers will likely love these as well (as this primary audience).**Note: This product was provided by the manufacturer for review. Akin to my Vine reviews, I take pride in constructively praising and/or criticizing review product in  the interests of saving Amazon customers money.**

When it comes to skin products, few do it better than AHAVA. Dead Sea Water, minimum ingredients, and emphasis on highest quality mean awesome results at a mid-upper price point. No wonder the name translates to love in its native Hebrew language.The Mineral Hand Cream is yet another AHAVA winner. It goes on seemingly like the 'WATER' described on product face. So little does so much, with skin lapping up the stuff (notably in between fingers and on cuticles). It also smells absolutely terrific.There's a surprising catch: wow, there's a whole lot of chemicals in here. Lines and lines of them, in fact...and oodles of alcohol. As someone who buys AHAVA products with the 'less is more' philosophy, I can't give their Mineral Hand Cream a clean bill of health in this area. A five star product with a one star ding for this nuance.

When essie says 'tart,' they mean it. This nail polish is VERY bright...also a bit different in color than pictured (it has a bit more pink hue to it). Definitely a summer color...but not for the feint of color heart.As fair as nail polish goes (being the first foray into essie), I would compare this favorably to OPI. It applies evenly, takes a bit longer to dry (a sign of better quality), and no need for a second coat as the first did its job and well. It also bonds seamlessly with clear coat finish.It's also durable, staying strong after some rigorous exercise (sweat, pounding).All in all, a mid-upper tier summer color nail polish. I dropped a star due to color mismatch, but that's pretty much a given with any nail polish purchased online, it seems.

I confess: I never heard about peanut butter powder until an MMA training partner recommended this in lieu of high sugar peanut butter alternatives. (He recommended mixing it with honey for a peanut butter alternative). As you get what you pay for (in mot instances), I took the plunge on Hoosier Hill Farms.This powder is fantastic. Lower calorie, no additive nonsense, protein power! I included this as an every morning nutritional shake supplement, vital for a guy with Crohn's Disease where absorption + energy comes in low supply.Blends well, tastes fantastic, and purest of powders. For the fitness serious, an awesome addition.

What a difference a hundred dollars makes.Satisfied...but certainly not pleased...with my Homelegance Lift Top Storage Bench, I was curious to see quality control differences in Storage Ottomans for a little bit more cash. I don't even know where to begin.For starters, packaging is wonderful, weight balanced for dual lift (~50 pounds). No shenanigans with ripped liners and/or torn seating surfaces that plague Homelegance. Assembly literally took 60 seconds, as my wife and I easily screwed in the legs to Ottoman bottom. I'm guessing provided ring/washers are intended to protect/separate legs from the Ottoman based (as there's no mention of this in the instructions). Everything went together like a boss.Most importantly, quality control is exceptional. Bonded leather is very good, stitching looks like it can stand up to some good use (I inspected this quite closely). While CorLiving claims easy cleanup, I'm not sure I would use this color option as a footrest (being bright white). As a seating surface, however, it offers solid support (in comparison to the Homelegance model that feels flimsy), with nice firmness. I especially like the midrange quality controlled latches and pull tab, making storage use a breeze (as the bench stays open).Speaking of bright white - and for those trying to color coordinate - it's blends with standard latex flat white paint. Very similar colors, no wacky yellow tinge or pseudo ivory. Easy peasy there. Finally, note product dimensions. This is not a small bit of furniture, at nearly 4 feet across.In sum: If you're in the market for a storage ottoman via Amazon, I hope this review provides some pause in considering a slightly extra investment versus cheaper offerings. Quality differential between this and the very popular Homelegance model is night and day. I only wish I would've discovered CorLiving in the reverse order.

Let's just say Downy Fresh Protect is certainly a unique product. It's an air freshener, of sorts, for your clothes, and does an admirable job on standard cotton/poly fabrics. Best use, however, is arguably with cotton towels, where perfume/floral scent is more appropriate than smelling like a walking dryer sheet.Personally, I requested the product to offset the dri-fit odor blues. The same blues that every sport detergent can't seem to shake within exercise clothing. Downy Fresh Protect does mask the odor...but is really window dressing (drowning one scent out with another...versus replacing it). In all fairness, not much Downy can do, as dri-fit fabrics simply hold odor based on design, it seems. There is yet to be a sport detergent that can slay this stinky dragon.Big ups to my reviewing compadre, who noted I first tested this incorrectly. For those with HE washers, don't be like me. READ the instructions. Add this to the tub versus detergent tray up top. This discrepancy makes a world of difference in outcome. There were some stray non-dissolved beads left behind (after the wash), but nothing troublesome and apt to be victims of next wash.All in all...Downy Fresh Protect does what it advertises. It provides a powerful, 'fresh' scent supplement to clothes...if you want that sort of thing. Linens and towels a nice addition, not so much on regular and dri-fit clothing.

I confess: I'm a big Contigo fan. I've got countless numbers of their water bottles, as this a company with a healthy obsession for creating the perfect water bottle.Don't get me wrong: I love Contigo's Autoseal Fit Trainer. Its steel casing avoids the dense, cheap feel of counterparts, its weight more natural than very heavy Contigo glass counterparts. This bottle feels like I'm holding and drinking from an actual water bottle. The Autoseal Fit Trainer also features a terrific double seal, a wonderful way to ensure water doesn't leak from bumpy hikes and/or workout use. Finally - and a personal preference: steel tastes better than glass...let alone plastic Contigo PVC bottles. Steel is clearly the way to go.Where the Autoseal Fit Trainer hiccups is its seal. Specifically, its plastic top on steel bottom doesn't perfectly mesh. Threads don't line up well, with it my suspicion  this deadly duo a poor fit over time. Meaning, I would suspect the top seal to degrade over continuous use and washing machine clean. I'm hoping I'm wrong, or risk a very wet gym bag and boxing equipment.All in all, the Contigo Autoseal Fit Trainer tastes much better than PVC free plastic, slightly better than glass...at a significantly less weight. It traps water well, is clearly to quality. The only question mark resides in longer term seal properties. At $20, it's well worth the risk.

Wow; what a pleasant surprise! This Sterling Silver White Crescent Moon with Swarovski Elements Pendant Necklace is of surprisingly higher quality, sports a nice grade chain, good craftsmanship on the textured moon, and crystal placement that looks meticulous (versus the frequent Swarovksi 'shoved in there' look).For those considering gifting, this necklace is light but certainly not cheap weight, and small enough to be noticed...but not tacky. Related - and as with every Amazon Collection piece of jewelry - gift packaging is terrific in a double blue clam shell box. Thus, no need to pay extra for gift wrap option!I have to be honest: I didn't expect much of this necklace for less than $50...but it's an absolute winner. I see this as an excellent gift for a teenage girl, an affordable, fun, and seemingly durable piece of jewelry. Another hit from the Amazon Collection.

It's hard to truly critique something when there's no alternative.Akin to many fitness kickboxing gyms, mine sports wooden floors...making shoes a necessity. Even as a veteran Muay Thai kickboxer, my puppies can't take the pounding from the jumping these classes require.Nearly every athletic shoe on the market, however does not flex enough to allow posting on the ball of the foot and/or provide significant padding for poorly placed banana bags.The FightPro check both boxes...but at a literal and build quality cost. First things first: these are not cheap. But when there's nothing else out there...be grateful they exist. I almost want to buy 3 pairs to ensure Ringstar stays in business and/or prepare if they shut down.On fit: these are meant to be tight...and stretch after 2 weeks. Do NOT buy bigger sizes. It's dangerous when doing sparring and/or movements requiring good foot feel. I called the company - who was very responsive - and advised to wait it out. After 4 days of use, they fit like a glove. Speaking of said customer service, they remain awesome. Very responsive to emails...and stand by their products 100 percent.The padding at foot instep is OUTSTANDING, essential as this is where the majority of kicking injuries occur. Even after 6 months, the padding is holding up nicely.What is not holding up well are the ultra thin foam bottoms. I understand these meant for mats where friction isn't as prevalent. Wood, however, eats right through them. Almost immediately I required a pair of insoles to compensate for the reduced padding also complete absence of arch.After 6+ months of 3x a week use, these look like they've been through a war. Bottoms are thin and dirty, tongue area stripped away. Still, they do what they need to do...and keep your feet protected...and properly air out during and after use. I likewise bought a pair for the better half-slash-training partner for this reason, and will continue to do so when these eat away.Sure I wish Ringstar would improve its build quality, but I'm grateful these shoes exist. Just buy them noting limitations.

One Saturday morning I thought it a good idea to test my non existent Brazilian Jiu Jitsu skills via a robust MMA sparring session. One hyperextended elbow later, it was clear who won.This defeat became even more apparent as the elbow worsened, regularly keeping me up at night. Not one to stop exercising while it heals, that's when BracePal came to the party.In all fairness - and first things first - BracePal is darn affordable for a compression elbow sleeve. Almost half the price of brand name competitors. Thus, this review duly notes this fiscal reality.Performance-wise...pretty solid. Don't expect it to line up perfectly with your elbow (in the lighter area), and I would recommend the graphics side on forearm versus biceps or the decal will peel off. I expect these same letters - much like McDavid stuff - to disappear via repeated washes. Not a dealbreaker for me...but maybe for brand conscious.BracePal does not breathe that well...more on the retain heat versus pull moisture compression material type. Thus, while it will keeps the area warm and protected, it will stay sweaty after workout. Again, depends on what you're using the brace for = train through workouts versus recover AFTER them.In sum, I consider this a good brace at an equal price. I'm not certain what leaps in quality I'd get at higher price points...and I dig the low profile (meaning I can still train without bulk).

With my existing living room ceiling fan doing its best Studio 54, strobe light impression when attempting to turn it off...it was time for an upgrade. Old blinky was a big box purchase, meaning it cheaper (said manufacturer) to swap out versus replace/repair a wonky LED and/or remote.I'm not the savviest of ceiling installers, so I left the swap out to a professional. I was amazed at how many pieces this fan has...specifically, that every part needed to be assembled on to one another. Every screw, bracket, housing, you name it. Occasionally dropped parts danced down the step up ladder like rhythmic raindrops. The one big bright side...is this longer assembly allows selection of blade color. The big downside? Forget adding a remote after assembly. That means disassembling almost the entire thing to make it happen. Ignorant on such things - and not reading the fine print - I had no idea my wall remote would now become useless.Once installed, however, this thing is a beaut'. Silent as all get up, outstanding air moving performance, good room filling light from two energy efficient bulbs.
