A couple of pull chain extensions...and no longer a need for a remote.Speaking of reading said fine print: this is ceiling flush...thus no room for manipulation. Caveat emptor for lower ceilings. I think I dodged a bullet as a few more feet and this in an instrument of terror.All in all, it's clear why this fan is so much more expensive than big box, pre-assembled cheapies. It looks, functions, and feels (down to the pull chains) better than cheaper counterparts. A solid - if not perfect - Gold Box buy.

In all fairness to BrightHouse, they're not bankrupting me by any means at $4/month for existing cable modem. With this being said, I'm a big fan of less is more when it comes to renting equipment. Thus, took the plunge at the Gold Box price of $45.Modem arrived nicely packaged and looking quite new. It comes with an Ethernet cable should you need it (to connect to a device or wireless router).For customers experiencing connectivity issues...make sure to call your provider (with the device already hooked up) to 'provision your new modem' (swap out modems for your account). It took about 5-10 minutes to do so (via BrightHouse), and they were able to ping and test remotely. You will not get Internet access, period, until they do this. From that point forward, zero issues and I'm going on a week's use. Obviously mileage will differ based on provider.Also and while I'm no cable modem genius, I'm surprised that some couldn't get their modem properly provisioned due to being tethered to another user. This extreme anomaly means the modem originated literally in the old purchaser's exact market...and remained there for the new one...and the same provider.Also - and technically speaking - the cable provider should be able to re-provision any device, regardless of history, if DOCSIS compatible. Thus - and before you return it for wonky use - ask for a higher tier tech to provision the new modem to your account, remove the previous.Finally - and if you're a streaming king/queen - while DOCSIS 3.0...this model (SB6121) only allows for downloads speed up to 172mpbs. The supplied one via my cable company (SB6141) allows for twice that. With a package capping out around 30Mbps, not an issue for me...but worth noting if you're a heavy user.

My inlaws are from New England. Which means they're coffee addicts, naturally. This is the land that brought you coffee syrup to put in milk, mind you. When I discovered that recent health issues forced my mom-in-law to cease drinking coffee due to pain, it saddened me. Caffeine blasphemy is a terrible, terrible crime in Rhode Island.Thankfully the good people at Puroast came to the rescue. For the first time in ages, coffee no longer hurt adopted mama. The flavor distinctive enough to mesh with morning breakfast. Dare I say it...a second pot followed the first.Sure, there's monkey picked beans, top notch Kona, and better options out there. All moot points if you can't drink any of 'em. For coffee lovers with a rebellious digestive system, here's your passport back to a beloved caffeine buzz.

First things first: if you're buying this for a Star Wars fan, s/he is sure to want this regardless of cost. For these folks, consider an extra star.With this being said, keep in mind you're paying about $15 extra (versus comparables in quality) for said license and not much else.Worth noting - and forgotten in the description - is that the comforter is reversible; a cool feature if you want to match different sheet colors.Artwork on both sides plus pillowcase, however, is no where near as sharp as it looks on  the product page. One reviewer described these designs as 'rushed'...and I would agree. They have a cheap, sloppy sketch look to them, one that detracts from the overall presentation. Jay Franco and Sons probably would've done better with going full cartoon look. The pillowcase, in particular (of an x-wing fighter) is sad, visually.Also, the product description declares this microfiber...but it certainly isn't. (Looks like they carried over the description from Classic to Comforter and Sham set.) This is the standard polyester blanket you'll see at a Target or Walmart. Nice feel, decent stitching, and machine washable.All in all - and being a Star Wars fan myself - I still don't see this set worth the $50 price tag. There are oodles of better (and less expensive) licensed Star Wars bedding choices to choose from. The Force is stronger, elsewhere.

How I love Irish Spring soap bars. A terrific scent, strong but not harsh chemically, also an ability to withstand multiple uses without cracking apart.Perhaps knowing this, Irish Spring bars keep getting smaller over time to compensate for their value. Tsk tsk.Enter the Irish Spring Signature Hydrating Bar Soap. Yes, it's twice the price of traditional bars...but it's money well spent.Visually, each Signature bar is almost 4x the size of traditional ones, pack an equal winning scent, also a higher class bar texture well beyond its price point. I also dig the individual plastic wrapping for each bar to maintain shape. Classy!Functionally and thanks to shea butter, Irish Spring Signature Hydrating Bar Soap produces a thick and hydrating lather that gently emerges from said bar. (This is a long ways away from the soapy drip of traditional Irish Spring bar soap.) A more consistent lather equates to easier cleaning in crevices and feet. All good stuff.Using these Signature Hydrating bars is like discovering power windows for the first time. There's nothing wrong, per se, with traditional Irish Spring bar soap. The upgrade, however, is so much better that it seems almost illogical to stay in last generation. For Irish Spring aficianados, do yourself a shower solid and go Signature.

Apparently some things don't translate well...and such is the case for Fiber One cereal versus Streusel Bars. I had high hopes for these seemingly tasty and functional bars, only to find them falling woefully short versus much less expensive, generic counterparts.To explain, Fiber One Streusel parts don't taste very Streusel-like. They're far too firm for something designed to possess a cake texture. A similar faux pas to less than expected strawberry flavor. In comparison - and while the generics aren't winning food show awards - both the CVS and Walmart branded fiber fruit bars arguably taste better than Fiber One Streusel. Surprising, to say the least.Nutritionally speaking, Fiber One Streusel again falls short. To explain - and as a comparison point: there's more calories, significantly more saturated fat, and higher amounts of cholesterol in Fiber One Streusel than Walmart's Great Value Chewy Fiber offering. Most importantly, Fiber One Streusel Bars clock in an astonishingly low 20 versus 35 percent of daily fiber in comparison to Great Value. Let alone its absence of any nutritional value other than iron (which, again, Great Value equals).This is anything but an advertisement for Great Value, rather a warning to look beyond branding to side of a box. Save your money...and go for the generics instead.

I confess: the back hair - while minimal - was getting to me. Tank tops became a no-no because of the constant fear of hair peeking out. Truth be told, I tried to address this issue with a regular razor (egads, the burns!!!) and an older Panasonic body trimmer (about 4 years ago, oodles of irritation).Begrdugingly, I purchase the Philips Norelco BG2038/41, and hoped for the best.Wow, this exceeded expectations. Build quality is exceptional (nice weight), also groove (that fits wonderfully in my hand). The charger station is effective without being obnoxiously large. Time to put it to use.Even with the included back extension, it was still a bit awkward to shave that area...especially lower back...and it was anything but a perfect shave. Still, it got what it needed to do, and left zero irritation. Note I did NOT use any of the three included filters. Tanks tops audibly celebrated their release from shackles.Feeling confident, I ventured on to the chest area. It was like shearing sheep...and within minutes, smooth as can be. Sensitive areas around chest center cleaned up easily. Again, no irritation to speak...also not perfect but darn close.Finally, I went for broke down 'there.' With careful strokes, everything cleaned up surprisingly easily, on par with using a blade...but oh-so-less scary. Hair around there - like chest and back - came off easily.Rinsing was easy, albeit drips a bit post rinse out of the blade area. Nothing too bad, however.The ultimate test: the better half - who thinks dudes should have hair, that it wasn't an issue - was impressed with the results. Especially chest and upper back where muscle definition is now visible.All in all, this is a great product that - even if for one area of shaving - is a solid purchase, one much safer than a standard blade.

While there's a whole lot of terrific gloves out there, I doubt there many who care this much about their customers.To explain, I purchased two small size pairs (hey, I have little hands!) for my wife and I for sports performance cross-training. These gloves fit fantastic, and withstand kettle bells, pushups on turf and outside (on concrete), pull ups, squats w/ weights/bench press, etc. They breathe well, clean and dry easily.Still, one day the Velcro on my right hand glove started giving way. The seam attached to the glove started losing its string...a telltale sign of these becoming useless in a couple weeks once this inevitably spreads. Unfortunately, I was past the Amazon return date, and frustrated to know nearly $30 gloves were going to die a quick and painful Velcro death.As last ditch effort, I emailed the company (Brian), and conveyed my problem. I was ready to purchase another glove versus eat the $30. In less than 24 hours, I had a return phone call...and two emails...with an apology for my problems...an finally a tracking number for a free replacement pair. Two days later, it was sitting on my doorstep.Thus, if you're considering a good workout glove, B Nooch is a great choice for what happens AFTER purchase. Kudos to you, Brian: you earned this review.

As yet another reviewer with seborrheic dermatitis - the kind that leaves scalp red, semi-oily, sore - I'm constantly on  the lookout for products that can provide relief. Most provide a temporary fix, only to have the scalp return to its suffering state a couple hours later.Head & Shoulders Itchy Scalp Care w/ Eucalyptus is yet another good...but not earth shattering product for seborrheic dermatitis sufferers. It cleans nicely, has a pleasant scent, and rinses easily. Still - and like competitors- it doesn't retain its effect for very long. By competitors, I'm referring to tea tree oil based, tar variety, zinc, etc.In all fairness, however, I can't gauge its benefit specifically for itchy scalp and/or excessive flaking. For these individuals - and based on review comments - there's been some clear gain - and perhaps that fifth star. As a whole, it stands as a good value (based on amount) hair care product.

My laundry room is the point of no return, the too expensive front loading washer its partner in damp apocalypse. Endless moisture and mold despite a washer fan, leaving the door and detergent draw wide open a fruitless perpetuity tandem.Don't get me wrong: Safe T Air is damn expensive. But wow, does it work.I literally gagged at the first 24 hours of it working its gel magic, nasal recognition of the courageous battle of tea tree oil versus mold evil. Twenty-four hours later, however, and it's as if the thing is not even in the room. No odor, nor recall to days of Australian yore (where tea tree oil runs amok), and the first neutral air I can recall since I adopted said laundry room (via home purchase) a year ago.This little jar did the unthinkable, and I'm proud of it. Gold star proud. For those living in high humidity environments looking for a mold scent killer, you've found your true kryptonite. Well done, Safe T Air.If you've reached wit's end via such odors, give this little jar a go.

As someone with IBD...let alone lactase deficient...getting a proper daily, dairy free dose of vitamins and minerals is akin to climbing the powdered Everest.Vega One's All-in-One Nutritional Vanilla Chai Shake is my nutritional sherpa. The vanilla chai flavor blows away Vega One's chocolate protein  offering both in taste and ability to blend in almond milk or water. I actually enjoyed this shake's very pleasant aftertaste, and nary a disgusting powder clump left in consumption wake.Assuming your body properly absorbs the nutrients, this shake is nearly half a daily requirement of all the heavy vitamins/minerals hitters. Thus, Vega One's All-in-One Nutritional Vanilla Chai Shake is a rock star in being safe for the dairy sensitive while remaining nutritionally potent. Let alone the awesome protein and fiber, one-two punch!Unfortunately, however, this comes at a literal price. At nearly $3 a serving (for the small tub), this is a semi-shocking price point. I'm not saying it isn't worth the price of admission, but I would expect significant discounts at larger sizes. Which there isn't.Also, Vega One's claim of this being a meal replacement is a bit off. Unless you're packing 100-200 more calories via milk/ingredients to buoy the shake, 170 calories won't go very far. Thus, I would consider this a good morning or midday boost...but not breakfast/lunch, by any means.Still, this is a product I would watch very closely. If/when a price drop occurs, Vega One's All-in-One Nutritional Vanilla Chai Shake should be a daily nutrition staple for anyone looking for a top notch powder.

Thanks, Hoover!; cutting the cord to floor cleaners is such a terrific and long overdue idea. I couldn't believe how such a simple but important feature makes cleaning THAT much easier. The FloorMate's easy-to-read charge indicator is an obvious reminder on when it's time to remove the battery to its base. Speaking of said lithium battery, it's surprisingly big (which is a good thing = long charge times), likewise a snap to insert into its compartment on both the FloorMate and charging station. Good stuff here. Additional lagniappe lies in discovering this battery universal across Hoover's rechargeable line of products.Similar kudos for an upright dirty water tank as easy to remove as its cleaner counterpart. In contrast to a very good Bissell carpet cleaner, the Hoover Floormate doesn't mandate manipulating the cleaner base for access to the dirty water tank. No more disgusting interactions with the scrub brushes, nor water drips from tank removal at unit base. Well done here.The most important part: I couldn't believe how much gunk came off of a professionally cleaned floor only 4 days after said cleaning. The FloorMate was an equal champ on both hardwoods and tiles, and covered a solid room and kitchen using only one capful of cleaner. Meaning, the FloorMate is thankfully efficient on the not-so-cheap cleaning solution (of which it comes with one, by the way). If there's a criticism to be made, there can be some occasional water pooling during use. Running the FloorMate backwards one more time over these offending areas (on 'wet and dry'), however, almost always remedied.Finally, assembly and build quality lead to me believe the FloorMate is in it for the long haul. It's easy to put together, move around (even for smaller peeps among us), and stores very well due to foldable handle. Gaskets (on tanks, attaching to the unit) appears up to the challenge of longer term use. For those with hardwoods, this truly is a wonderful all-around unit.

After using a fairly reliable Panasonic Wet/Dry trimmer for years, I was curious what newer (non-cylinder) technology yields. Specifically, if it would cut down on tugging, plus offer better precision.All in all...almost no noticeable difference. It's a little more gentle than the cylinder version, but it comes at a functional price (of being less accurate). The eyebrow trim combs are a nice addition, and do an above average (but not great) job of evening eyebrows. Worth noting, however, I'm not a bushy eyebrow kinda' guy to begin with.The Philips Norelco NT3555/60 likewise struggled in trimming external, shorter ear hairs. I remain hopeful of an alternate to facial razors for these stubborn but small eyesores. Ear and nose trimmers - cylinder or not - don't seem up to the challenge.Finally, the twist on power is no doubt a product of wanting to seal from water (being washable). Still, this seems awkward (versus a normal power switch), and is apt for trouble if turned too far right (that opens up the battery compartment).In sum, it's hard to argue against the Philips Norelco NT3555/60. Good price, great warranty, and decent build quality. Albeit not much different than competing Panasonic products.

I've purchased many a heavy duty stapler over the years. At the end of the day, success: failure amounted to how many pages, how well, and the quality of staple shape in securing the pages.Rapesco's X5-90PS finally conquers the seemingly unthinkable, in being lower profile but fully functional. Yes, it takes a mild sacrifice in power due to smaller footprint, but conquers everything in its path with little hiccup. Commercial, heavy duty staplers are far too big for limited home use. This is not one of them.For mainstream home office users, the X5-90PS is the heavy duty variety everyone needs but didn't know. Affordable staples, stapling beyond 10 pages, and excellent build. There's a reason for these 5 star reviews: this is a top of the line, home office stapler.

Merrell's Captiva Buckle-Up Waterproof Boots are another winner in the Merrell line. This, of course, is not surprising, as Merrell is a long standing champ in providing durable but fashionable footwear.These Captiva boots were purchased to survive Florida rains and muds...but did yeoman's work in this year's (2015) New England winter. Great grips, equal warmth, and a 24.7 type boot that goes the extra mile. Literally worn in near sub-zero temperatures for days straight. You go on with your bad self, Merrell.As other reviewers stated, these boots are an athletic cut...meaning (to be blunt) be fit or go up a size. For the fit (admittedly coming from a family of gym rats), these boots are both flattering and comfortable. Compliments galore, in tandem, from those wondering where we got 'em.Functional and fashionable. It IS possible.

Simply put: there's a seemingly endless amounts of daily cleansers and exfoliators on the market. The Bjore Pore Penetrating Charcoal Bar is a welcome addition to this fray, albeit doesn't add anything you can't already find among competing products.To explain: Selecting a cleanser or exfoliator is normally a question of skin sensitivity and/or pH (dry versus oily), combined with amount of tolerance for chemical versus natural ingredients. The Bjore Penetrating Charcoal Bar is somewhere in the middle of the pack, in containing natural ingredients, and gentle enough not to irritate. It's scent is almost non-existent (a good thing), and lathers like a champ (meaning, longer life).Still - and while this bar does a good job cleaning facial oils and makeup - it doesn't provide promised exfoliation (among nasal and facial pores), and dries skin out considerably. It's that frustrating kind of dry, where minutes later oils rush back to compensate for excess dryness. Meaning, more harm than good.Thus, I would consider the Bjore Pore Penetrating Charcoal Bar a complimentary product to more aggressive exfoliators, and a good way to start a day and/or remove makeup at its conclusion. A good comparison would be Neutrogena's facial bar...with the Bjore version a bit harder working versus moisturizing.

Don't get me wrong; I love the three Brita water pitchers we have (one at home, two at respective offices). The water in Florida is borderline undrinkable due to chemicals and hard quality. Brita is therefore a godsend.Still, Brita pitcher filters are a significant hassle; too many sizes, unsightly black specs, and always wondering whether the filters are actually clean. Don't get me started on excess trips to Target to return Brita filters that didn't fit.Eureka! Someone at Brita finally got it. Universal size means no guesswork, likewise it trapping those flecks within the filter. Like every other carbon filtering mechanism does by default.Progress takes time...and it appears we're there with Brita pitcher filters. We've finally hit water pitcher filter utopia.

It's rare to find human anatomy toys that are, well, anatomically correct. Oh, the irony.Why is this important? Without true-to-life detail, anatomy toys have little educational or therapeutic value.T.S. Shure gets it mostly right, excellent in build quality and magnetic properties. Parts blend well and are nicely drawn. There's a solid diversity of body parts to choose from...veins, skeletal muscles, cardio-vascular, nerves, and clothes...although strangely lacking in the number of heads available. Ditto in body parts being exclusively white. These two latter points limits usefulness in therapy settings.Still - and as a whole - this is a great set for under $20.

The second book in the series, this is a excellent book that is bigger in scale and effort than the first book.  The writing is very polished and well researched, which makes the book both incredibly fun and easy to read.I love the characters, and the section about flying a kite was awesome, when they are discovering the new land. It is laden with hope and the desire to overcome great obstacles, with just enough myth and mythology mixed in to make it a lot of fun.I can't wait to read the next installment in the series and see where things are going next!  HIghly recommended series, if for no other reason than their historical value!

You won't even realize how well it is chopping the vegetables until you stop and open the container. It doesn't look like it does much, but it can shred onions to a paste in only a few pulls.I thought you needed an electric machine to chop food well, but when I got this I found something that trumps electric machines.  It is easy to pull and chops incredibly well.

Awesome and well built case, this does a perfect job protecting the screen. It's hard to find the right case because everyone makes them for newer products or niche products, so when I found this i was highly satisfied.  It fits perfectly and does what it is supposed to do, and it looks nice while at it.

Really great pair of sunglasses, I got them on sale and don't use anything else now. I used to use a different brand, but when the price went up I got these.  They are comfortable and stylish and hold up very well to mild abuse (I don't put them away nearly as often as I should).Easy to clean and the glass doesn't scratch without a lot of pressure, I would say grab a pair of these and try them out. You won't be disappointed.

I have never seen a puppy as excited about treats as mine is for these. My little pugamonster will bite my fingers off if I don't give these to him fast enough.Highly recommended for anyone with a puppy. They are soft and easy to chew and they love the flavor.
Great headphones, but a little on the quiet side.  If you want to get these, I would recommend getting an amplifier as well to punch up the sound.  All in all, though, the sound is crisp and clean.

My puppy loves these, and that's enough for me.He is a pugamonster and very picky about what he chews on (unless it is people) so I was glad to find something to distract him from his normal chomping behavior.

Great read. A lot of the book is about relationships he has been in, but the intro of the book and first several chapters are mind blowing in the sort of things he had to overcome. I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a good story about overcoming obstacles.
Very nice portable product, it allowed me to connect my device in ways I couldn't previously. It is light and fits easily in my pocket, so I have no complaints.

I am usually one of those people that stays away from books like this, because I'm worried about how much of the information would actually apply to me, and with this book I was surprised by how much I got out of it.First off, Chris does an amazing job of speaking directly to the reader in a concise and easy to understand way. This is great, because too often the writer tries to use lofty or profession-specific language instead of speaking to the audience.Secondly, a lot of the information was actually useful. There are lists of different groups to join on facebook as well as websites to check out for new marketing techniques.  Chris breaks down a lot of different services he has tried and his experiences, and then gives recommendation on how valuable services can be, and he does it without trying to sound like he is the complete authority. This is all personal experience.There are a few passages that aren't as relevant and several broken links to products/services that no longer exist, but that can be expected, and hopefully Chris will keep the book up to date with good information as time goes by.All in all, a solid reference for any aspiring author.
Really good story, and one of the better books I've read in a while.  Interesting and thought provoking.

It is small and doesn't really get in the way. I love having it around because we can watch tv in any room with little effort.  I have noticed that some apps don't work that well, especially when the internet is slow. Hulu seems to be the worst offender, but hopefully they can bring it together and release a patch that fixes their worst problems.All in all, it is highly worth it for the price!

Really soft and a lot easier to use than I was expecting. It is big, covering half of the face, and really light.I've never used anything like this, but sometimes the lights are on at night in case someone wakes up and needs to use the restroom, so having something like this made it a lot easier to get asleep and stay asleep.Highly recommended for anyone looking for a good night's rest that has trouble sleeping when lights are on.

This story starts present day and then gradually climbs its way to the future, and for a good chunk of the novel it is difficult to tell that it is meant to be science fiction. The characters are interesting, and we see a sort of blossoming romance caught up in the throes of youth, and it ends tragically, but this is actually before the real story takes place.I don't want to give anything away, but this is a very spiritual story with a deep rooted view of the galaxy and history that is very intriguing.  It has a powerful and meaningful ending that will leave the reader with a lot of personal questions, even if the story itself is coming to a close.Highly recommended for anyone interested in good science fiction with a spiritual message.

This story creates a future london that feels very similar to the present day world we all live in, but it has enough Novums to keep the flow moving forward and the story feeling unique and different.I'm a sucker for stories told from the perspective of journalists or news agents or anything of that sort, so this story really intrigued me in the ability to nail down a style.  The author says she drew heavily from referential material in creating this story and it shows because of how well developed the situations and storylines are.I like when stories can be sci fi and futuristic while still holding onto those aspects that make it human, and for that reason I would highly recommend this story to anyone interested in a great read!

This project was started as a black history workshop, and most of the voices contained herein are real, unpolished or practiced. That's what makes all of these poems so meaningful, because it feels like the words come from the heart rather than a script.Each of the students has a different and unique style. There are a few poems that really stand out, like It is Hard to Be, because of how well they handle repetition and the level of meaning they convey. When I am reading these poems I can truly feel the emotions being poured out, and it's as though I can hear the authors speaking directly.I think my only complaint with the project is the number, because there aren't that many poems, and different authors have different numbers of works enclosed. But, what it lacks in quantity it more than makes up for in quality.This is well worth a read by anyone interested in poetry, and since this is a first release by these students, we might see more from them, or the group from Kingston that put this book together, in the future.  I highly recommend checking it out.

Great combs, they really hold up well under pressure.  My hair gets twisted and knotted so having something like this makes it really easy to take care of my hair.If I need more combs I'll get some more of these!

Worth checking out. The author does a really good job of explaining things so that anyone can understand. One of the things I really liked about this was that he picked one strategy and explained it very well instead of giving us a few tidbits about twenty different strategies.  Makes it a lot easier to deal with and understand.If you are interested in Options Trading, then this guide will help you get started and make some pretty good decisions. He explains several terms that you'll need to understand, but it isn't too difficult to grasp the easy concepts, and he explains the harder ones in depth.

A very good read! This is a sort of introductory story, the beginning of a series where all of the dwarfs are brought together for the eventual trials they will undergo.They are all interesting characters on their own, with different personalities that will create interesting conflicts in the future.  I think Medicus is my favorite dwarf, because I've always been drawn to healers and the stories about them.Overall, a solid first entry into this series.  Not a lot of huge plot arcs are developed or solved, but it gives me hope for the books coming down the pipe. Worth the read!

Gummies come in handy and can be quite tasty sometimes, which makes it easier to take them on a regular basis. These aren't bad, but the flavor isn't quite as good as I was hoping for.That being said, they are easy to eat, by no means bad, and they get the job done.

Fits about perfect and the material is comfortable and strong. The buckle itself was a lot firmer than I'm used to in similar quality belts, which makes me feel it will be reliable in the long run as well.I wear belts fairly often, and it's difficult finding one that is really comfortable, so I'm glad that this one feels so good. I can see myself wearing it for a long time into the future!
Hard to apply, but well worth it once they are on.My dog likes to dig. She digs and digs and there are holes all over the yard.  This helps keep her from doing that, so it's worth it!

This story delves into life and humanity, the ability for people to overcome even in the earliest days of existence as a species.  It's a historical thriller about overcoming, but not like you've ever read before.The style employed is brilliant, at times poetic and always fun to read.  The characters come from different backgrounds and evolve over time, and it's a very relatable story.I recommend this book to anyone interested in historical fiction and look forward to more works by Kathleen!

These took some getting used to. They were much harder than i was originally expecting, and bigger as well. I'm used to soft insoles.But, once I got used to them, I noticed I had a lot more comfort than previous. My old insoles were falling apart and faded, but these have held up very well.They aren't perfect, because they are beginning to deteriorate as well, but I still enjoy them quite a bit.

We have a family dog named Arkantos who has been with us through many years.  He came with a fellow litter mate named Mephistopheles (who simply became Muffy-toes after a few months) who died from a spinal problem that paralyzed him.  After Muffy died, we got a few more puppies, but by then Arky was starting to get on in years.And, as time went on, he went from being a playful and exuberant dog to more tired and unhappy as his hips and bones started to hurt.  We tried a lot of different things to make him feel better, but nothing really worked.Until we tried this.  It worked really well after we started using it for a while, and I have to say I'm more than a little impressed by it.  He doesn't necessarily hate the taste, but he doesn't like it either, so we started mixing it into his food (which is what the company recommends anyway).  There wasn't a lot of improvement right away, but after a few days we started noticing it help.We also bought aspirin from this company, which worked very well for him.  The only family that doesn't like this is our new kitten, who is being chased and annoyed incessantly by our old dog now that he is feeling better!
These are perfect to keep on hand for a quick snack. easily portable, and don't require anything except a spoon or fork.  They have great flavor, too.
Great for a quick gift for a party.  Everyone might not love Wendy's, but few people will refuse to eat there...and everyone eats, so it's not like they won't use it!

Great scent, not overpowering but just enough to make the house smell pleasant. I burn them in the kitchen occasionally, and the scent lingers even after I blow them out.For the price, they are on par with candles twice as expensive.
An easy and tasty way to get vitamin C.  I never get enough, so keeping these on hand saves me a lot of grief.

These are so useful. They fold down to a comfortable package you can store easily under the bed or in the closet, then fold up into baskets. There are shelves they go with that are a perfect fit, so you can customize how you want.Get a couple just to keep on hand, because eventually you'll find a use for them.

A debut novella from an up and coming author, the story contained in these pages is vivid and brilliant.  When it opens, we have no idea what to expect, and we are quickly thrust into a scenario revolving around first contact.But it isn't first contact the way we are used to. Instead, this is a much deeper and more human look about the possibility of beings living amongst us.  There are many twists along the way that draw us deeper into the story and ask more of us as readers.I don't want to spoil anything, but I can say that the tone of the novel, the plot twists, and the themes are all on point.  There is a love story hidden between the lines that will drag you in and refuse to let you leave.  At the end of the novel, you'll feel hopeful for a possible future of humanity that is brilliant and life-affirming.  Once you pick this book up, you won't be able to put it down until you finish, so hopefully there is more to the story coming in a later work.Keep an eye on this author as more works are released, because the depth and breadth of her work will surely astound and delight you!

If you know what to expect, then this is a decent product.  If you don't, then this will be a let down.It is mid-range quality production, fairly good acting, and a decent story.  If you come into this expecting a 'B' film, then you will be pleasantly surprised with how much effort and care went into creating this story.  If you come into it expecting to be blown away by amazing CGI then you're going to be disappointed.Here's the thing: if you are a halo fan who thinks Halo is the greatest story ever, go back and play the games.  I can guarantee you after the nostalgia wears off you won't be of the same opinion.  You'll still think it is amazing, especially for when it was released, but it won't knock your socks of.  For that matter, go watch Lord of the Rings again, and this time judge the pacing and story without the 'new movie' blinders.  The thing is, this story IS a halo story, and its a fairly good one all things considered. With what they had to work with, I'm impressed they were able to do this good of a job (compared to most internet movies right now).So give it a watch but keep in mind it's a solid 'B' movie.  It isn't meant to blow your mind, just entertain you.  And, for the pretentious people who think they are professional critics, go make something better.

We love seafood, so these were the perfect thing to go with crab legs.  It's just like the restaurant, and these are very high quality and last a long time.  I highly recommend you pick some up if you love seafood or anything you can dip butter into because you won't be disappointed.

Got this for a seven year old on her birthday, and she's been so excited about her bear it's crazy.  Every day she asks if she can go build her bear, but it's just been too cold.I guess if you want to excite kids and give yourself extra work, then this is the perfect gift!

Love iHop and loved the convenience of getting these.  Had a birthday come up with a lot of family sharing a day, and getting this meant I could give them each a present without doing a lot of legwork.  Very convenient, works like a charm.

These worked pretty well.  They aren't quite as good as the brand new ones, but they were cheaper.  The cartridges were all high quality and the ink seemed about like normal, they just weren't quite as good.
Imitation is the big word here.  It's not that good.  I won't say its terrible, but it is when you say 'it's just like chocolate' because there is a distinct difference.

What can I say, the dog is more beloved by the family than most of us 'people'.  He's getting older, and I hate seeing him in pain.  He's also not a very vocal dog, so it's hard to tell whether or not the medicine really works.His hips are having pain, and when you touch them normally or he bumps them (which he does a lot) he winces, but with these he doesn't seem bothered by it as much.  I'm sure its just aspirin, probably no different than what I use, but I still feel better at least doing a little something for our pet.
Great stickers. Bought these for a birthday party for a six year old and the kids loved playing with them and sticking them on everything. I'm sure Magic Mountain didn't mind...
This can quickly become too strong, so don't use a lot of it. Just takes a little bit to get that flavor, so it'll last you forever.  Not very sweet but blends well.
Basically what I expected, needed for my class.  Too expensive to call it worthwhile.
A necessary textbook, not exactly enjoyable to read. It was a little bit dated, but not altogether bad,
Worked really well. A little thicker than I was expecting but adds a lot of flavor without needing to have the cheese on hand, so it's easy to cook with.

Works just like turbotax without all the extra BS they threw up this year.  I finally got a letter from turbotax saying "oops, we screwed up, please forgive us" but by that point I'd already moved on and purchased this program.  I don't regret it either, and will probably stick with block next year as well.
This is huge, so don't get it to go with pendants.  It's a thick necklace, very pretty, but you might look for something thinner to be all purpose.

This chain is awesome, but I got it a little longer than I would have liked.  The snap is the best part, really solid and easy to use, so we don't have to worry about it falling off or losing the amulet it is holding.Just make sure you get it the right length and you will keep it for a long time.
Great stickers for a birthday party.  They peel off really easily and stick well.

Comes with a lot for a low price, but they do leave annoying little specs of wax behind and burn way faster than normal candles.Put them on the cake, light, then blow out, then dump in water.  If you let them stay for a minute they will stain your cake a bit.It's non-toxic...but still annoying.  Then again, for the price, they are a lot of fun.  We had 3 people trying to blow them out.

These are awesome. Even the extra shipping cost is worth it because they look beautiful when they come.  She loved it and plans to keep it forever.  It's the most interesting and authentic card I've ever given anyone.They have a bunch of different ones, and they all say different things.  I picked this one and don't regret it, but I might get some other ones later for gifts as well.  The wood grain is the best part.

This was recommended by my doctor to promote heart health and track my lifestyle. They aren't terrible to wear, but also not amazingly comfortable.  The tracking, though, is awesome and works really well.It tracks sleep better than expected to, which is nice.  You can tell when things are going well and when they aren't.

I was lucky I didn't have to wait for After You as I just read Me Before You days before its release. Me Before You ripped my guts out so I knew there was no way After You could do any more damage. But did it make me whole again? Eh. A bit.Louisa has spent the year since Will barely living. She's still sad, she's still not speaking to her mother, she's working the odd bartending job, and she hasn't put Will's money to use.Out of the blue Louisa gets a visitor and she feels like she has a purpose again. Most of the book is Louisa and this person's relationship. But it's got Louisa back in London, talking to the family, and going to group therapy.But what happens when that purpose is fulfilled? Louisa finally gets a perfect opportunity abroad but is she healed enough and brave enough to take it? It takes her awhile to get there and I thought her journey was realistic and in the end it made me smile. I also liked how we got a glimpse of how well everyone is moving on. I definitely missed Will in this book but it was a pretty good follow up. I liked it.**I listened to the audio version.**

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**Bravo. What a great follow up to Virgin. I loved it even more. I have so many highlights from all the laughing I did. Here are some of my faves:I felt his p***s harden against my v****a. It rubbed against it and I moaned in pleasure. "Ow," he cried out. "What?" I asked in surprise. "Nothing, just a bit spiky," he said, and carried on kissing me. "Sorry?" I said in a strangled voice. He thought my pubes were spiky. They hurt his p***s. My mother****ing pubes were ruining my life yet again.It reminded me of the excruciating agony of getting a full Brazilian wax. Thank God I had eschewed those p*rn-originated pubic styles in favor of my trimmed, spiky little hedgehog. I gazed at it fondly and gave it a small stroke. Eight fifteen wasn't too late. I definitely had time for a quick wank."Is it okay?" I asked uncertainly. I was doing the Pilates table pose above him. My head was hovering by his p***s and my entire nether regions were inches away from his mouth - and his nose. Oh God, his nose. He would be able to smell everything and I'd pooed just before our date. I started to wonder if this was a good idea.It was kind of nice to be home alone. It was fun spending time with Nick, but I still didn't feel like I could a hundred percent be myself in front of him. I hadn't farted in days.Now that Ellie has lost her V card, she thought that would be just the beginning to having an enviable sex life. But she's still plagued with insecurities and men are not beating down her door. So she tries Internet dating sites and we're treated with the hilarity of those disasters.While Ellie and her girlfriends are out being fabulous, Ellie meets Nick. He's a fit banker and he's easy to talk to. But he's still kind of obsessed with his ex. Ellie doesn't make this a problem though, she sees Nick as the perfect guy to have casual sex with. She's sworn not to get attached too soon like she did with her first. Ellie and Nick's sex life is very "real life." That's what I loved so much about this book. All of Ellie's ramblings in her head have gone through ours as well at some point. Ellie makes her fair share of mistakes but I absolutely loved her transformation.This book is not about finding The One, it's about finding The O, loving yourself and all of your flaws, friendship, and empowerment. If you're a fan of girl power movies like Bridesmaids and Trainwrecked you'll love Not That Easy. Well freaking done!

Thrive is Kiss the Sky and Hothouse Flower retold from Lo and Lily's pov. But it's a good retelling. Lots of things happened in KtS and HF that affected them plus there were a few scenes that we didn't know how they played out that were interesting to read.I thought the Ritchies did a great job with the timeline, it could have been confusing but I kept up just fine. Rereading the fight between Lo and Ryke was heartbreaking, even moreso being in Lo's head. I just love this family.

Breaking Him is a tale of childhood friendship that turns into teenaged lust then love that grows into something indescribable and permanent then some mysterious circumstance ruined everything and turned that love into bitter hatred. But that permanence is still there keeping the two entwined forever.Scarlett had a very sad beginning to her life. It continued through school, she was constantly bullied even by adults. The only good thing in her life was her friend Dante and his grandma. Even though he was wealthy he was sensitive. He didn't like the injustice. He always stood up for Scarlett even though she could hold her own. She was a scrapper, never afraid to defend herself.Now as an adult she's a flight attendant and a not-so-successful actress. I liked how Lilley brought us back to the sky. But Scarlett is a prickly b**ch. She doesn't have many friends, she doesn't trust easily since the only friend she had betrayed her. She's all attitude. And Dante loves to antagonize her. But this time he's come to bring bad news.This story alternates between the past and present leading us to the point where it all went wrong. Too Bad! You're not finding out in this book. By the end you'll have your theories but nothing is confirmed. A monster of a cliffhanger.This story was a bit hard to get into. Scarlett's bitterness was almost a turnoff but she finally started to soften a little and by then I couldn't put it down.Dante and Scarlett remind me a little of Caleb and Olivia from Tarryn Fisher's The Opportunist. Complete with all the angst. So if that's your thing you'll love this. I most certainly did. I'm looking forward to Breaking Her. Please hurry!

Meh. I've loved the books and novellas up to this point but this novella didn't do anything for me. I've read stories like this before. Casey and Nate have a four month old daughter. Everything in their life is perfect, perfect, perfect. Except we're given a few scenes where the couple tries to get their mojo back with semi-disastrous results. They weren't realistic and they weren't even funny. Nothing original about it and nothing new was introduced.

**I received an ARC courtesy of the author in exchange for an honest review.**Wow. What an amazing read. What started out as pretty darn funny turned into a beautiful story with substance.Easie Reynolds is an out-of-work actress with a fiesty attitude. Her sister/best friend/manager gets her a part as a host slash reenactor for a new show called Quirks & Kinks which features real couples' bedroom fetishes reenacted by Easie and Anderson Evans.Anderson wasn't originally cast. Easie met him when he waited on her at a Mexican restaurant. She gave him attitude and he gave it right back which earned him some points. It also didn't hurt that he was gorgeous and trying to be an actor himself.I liked the originality of this story. Easie and Anderson have an effortless chemistry. It was believable. I got it. They had great banter and they managed to make their ridiculous scenes smokin' hawt.But it turns out Anderson has some quirks of his own. And it really touched my heart. The letters made me shed a few tears. I'm just so happy I read this. I'll definitely be reading more from Curtis. Well done!

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**You could knock me over with a feather I'm so surprised by how much I enjoyed this book. It's a cross between a trainwreck of a reality show, behind the scenes details of the making of an erotic movie, and True Hollywood Story.Amelia and Noah were successful child actors. Now all grown up, Noah is in the spotlight more for his bad boy antics than for his movies despite his massive talent. He's a sure thing for the role of Damon in the highly anticipated book to movie adaptation of Sinners Like Us. Amelia is ready to shed her good girl image in the highly coveted role of Blair playing opposite Noah's Damon.After a very public and humiliating split years ago in their teens, Noah and Amelia are having a hard time letting go of their bitter hatred of one another, both for different reasons, in order to get along or at least fake it for the sake of the movie.Childstar 1 is the first of a three part serial. Such a guilty pleasure. After Noah's juicy reveal I'm really looking forward to getting my hands on part two. Well done!

I'm impressed. Suite 269 is the story of Lexa, fact checker and bride-to-be who catches her fiancé, Kevin, in the act with her colleague, Sophia, on her couch. The colleague also happens to be dating one of Lexa's bosses, Jameson. Jameson and Lexa get to know each other socially while commiserating over their shared betrayal.Since it's too late for Lexa to get any refunds for the wedding, she decides to still have it...without the groom. You go girl. And since her ex-fiancé threw it in her face that she's not adventurous in bed, she decides to spend her three week honeymoon in Jamaica with Jameson making all of her fantasies come true.But their intensity in the sheets turns into feelings that both of them are afraid to admit. How can things go back to normal?I also loved the side story involving Alex and how that played out. It was clever. My only complaint was it took to the sixty percent mark to get to the good stuff. When it did it was awesome, but Zolendz was losing me a bit before then. But, all in all, a worthwhile quick read. Well done.

Millie Cross met Logan "High" Judd when she was eighteen years old. It was love at first sight. They were gone for each other in a way the rest of us can only dream to be. They had three years of that before Millie broke it off out of the blue.Twenty years later, Millie has an awesome job, house, and wardrobe trying to find that perfection elsewhere because she'll never find it in another man. Hasn't even tried.From previous Chaos books we know High was the hardest brother to convince to go legit. After he lost Millie he liked living dangerously. And even though he later married, had two daughters, and got divorced he never filled that hole that Millie carved out in his heart.After a chance run-in, Millie is determined to get closure and explain to High what happened all those years ago and apologize once and for all. Here is where I was angry with High and disappointed in Chaos. I didn't understand all the hostility. The only thing Millie was guilty of was breaking up with her boyfriend...twenty years ago. High is still extremely bitter and his treatment of Millie was despicable. I also understand High's brothers having his back but they were one step away from offing the poor girl and that didn't feel like Chaos to me.BUT...I'm still giving five stars. KA put me through the ringer with this book. So many feels. Every other page had me crying. Especially when we found out the truth about the break up. And if a book can touch me in that way that's some excellent writing. Whether you like what the characters are doing or not.It's usually hard for me to buy when characters are still hung up on each other five, ten, twenty years later. I just can't wrap my head around how you couldn't move on. But KA did a great job making me feel High and Millie's once-in-a-lifetime connection and I was happy when they finally started to work it out. I also liked that KA didn't make it easy. Just because they were reunited didn't mean all the wounds were automatically healed.I liked getting more of the story of the early days of Chaos. And things are getting more and more heated with Valenzuela. I hope Hound gets his own book, lots of good stuff there I think. And as usual I love the inclusion of the previous couples and Elvira is a hoot. Loved it!

**I received an ARC courtesy of the author in exchange for an honest review.**It's no secret I wasn't a huge fan of Shrinking Violet but I got to know Navie enough that I knew I wanted to read her story. Love Hate Relationship wasn't overly original but it did have that certain Prince charm that keeps me reading her books.Navie is going on her first interview as an administrative assistant what she doesn't know is she's already been hired to be the personal assistant to author, Rowan Locklaine. He's demanding and grouchy and an arrogant philanderer. But Navie isn't a quitter and she gives as good as she gets.There's some serious tension and they both find the yelling and name-calling hot but there's also trust and friendship forming. And when the two finally get it on it's pretty explosive. But Rowan has unresolved issues with his brother and he's been hurt by a woman before.I love books with jealous exes and misunderstandings. I mostly loved how Prince made Rowan see what he was doing to his brother by Navie doing it to him. Prince even managed to pull a few tears from me near the end. Hint: pay attention to the prologue.Overall, it was a very entertaining read. Well done.

Once again a brilliant read. I feel like I'm a part of the adventure with the Fraser clan. There were quite a few losses in this book and each of them were hard to bear in their own way. Everything that happened with Roger and Bree almost did me in but everything came full circle in the most beautiful ending I've ever read. It was perfection. Bravo.

Quinn runs Pixie Wheels, an automotive shop owned by her alcoholic father. It's her life, her love, and the only thing left of her deceased mother. Unfortunately, it's in arrears and Tazen, hot shot race car builder, makes an offer on the place. Quinn would rather die than sell it but, ultimately, it's not her decision.Tazen and Quinn have an attraction but they are combative. Quinn refuses to leave, she demands to be hired but Tazen is a Neanderthal and thinks women should only be receptionists not mechanics so he doesn't give her a chance. As they get to know each other, though, the animosity makes way for love and respect.I'm conflicted. My eyes welled up a few times at how passionately Quinn tried to hold on to her shop but Quinn and Tazen's relationship left me rolling my eyes a whole lot too. It was okay.

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**Stepbrother alert! When Billy aka Ghost was thirteen and Jessie was eight, his dad married her mom. Ghost and Jessie's older brother became close and Jessie was the annoying tagalong little sister. But when Jessie turned sixteen a kiss changed everything.After a loss and years of separation, Jessie hitchhikes her way, with just the clothes on her back, to Sturgis in desperate need to find Ghost. Before she finds him, however, she overhears something she shouldn't and now she needs Ghost's protection. But do Ghost and the Evil Dead MC have other plans?Not my favorite by James but it's a solid story with an enjoyable plot. Ghost and Jessie were likeable characters. I'm looking forward to Blood's story. Well done.

**I received an ARC courtesy of the author in exchange for an honest review.**I wanted to like this book more than I did. I liked the beginning. I thought the way Levee and Sam met was original and clever and I liked finding out later the person that connected them. That was sweet.But mostly this book was pure fluff. Levee is a famous singer addicted to charity and Sam is a chain-smoking carpenter. It was insta-love at its cheesiest.Martinez had an opportunity to dig deeper, especially with the subject matter, but she never quite took us there. It was disappointing.I didn't get Levee. She came across as nave and childlike in her actions. I liked Sam though. He always tried to do what was best for Levee. And his gift near the end had me swooning.Hits and misses. Not my favorite from Martinez but it was okay.

*2.5 stars*Commodity started out promising enough. Hannah is on her way to D.C. to testify against a human trafficker. Falk meets her at the Atlanta airport with his team of bodyguards to escort her safely.All hell breaks loose. Explosions. Men are dead. Women and children have vanished.Falk is still under the impression he has to see Hannah safely to the Capitol. I think the mission is what kept Falk going under these new conditions. I thought Savage painted a decent picture of what the early stages of the after effects of a major catastrophe would look like. The split povs with the time jump was a nice touch. And I liked the Ehd reference. That made me squee a little.But I thought it was way too much of a coincidence the circumstances involving Brett and Caeser. What are the odds? I love dystopian novels but I wasn't expecting this kind of cause for the end of the world. And to be honest - I thought it was kind of lame. The story was okay enough but this made it cheesy. Not my cup of tea.

**My review contains minor SPOILERS**Wow. First of all I have to say this sequel didn't go at all how I thought it would. Definitely a plus. It made the story unpredictable. Another surprise was Raze. Where did he come from?! He stole the show in my opinion. I don't know how Blake would have gotten out of her predicament without him and his story tugged on my heart strings.But, otherwise, I thought this follow-up was just okay. Blake and Madden had very little interaction. They were apart until the end. Which I didn't like at all. Transparent felt more like a second book than a final book. I'm a tad disappointed considering the long wait. *shrugs*

*Originally read December 2012**Reread October 2015*I am loving this series. The only thing that drives me nuts is that in this book and the 2nd book Evie doesn't give enough credit to the strength of the angels that love her. She's so hell bent on saving them that she goes off to fight on her own causing the angels to abandon a perfectly good plan and put themselves at even more risk to save her when she always ultimately gets captured. I wish she would just calm down and listen. I hope she does in the 4th book.

This book was completely unpredictable. Daisy and Ryke's story kept taking turns I didn't see coming. Some were pleasant surprises, some were meh.It's no secret Daisy isn't passionate about modeling anymore but she doesn't know how to stand up to her over-bearing mother. She's also having night terrors and as the youngest of the Calloway girls she's having trouble opening up to her sisters. One thing she can count on though is Ryke's unwavering friendship.I liked getting in Daisy's head. I felt for her because of all the pressure she was under, for feeling like the lesser sister, and for all of the bullying she put up with because of Lily's addiction. At times I thought she was a little too silly but I guess that comes with the age.Ryke has always been angry. Angry towards his father and now his mother. It was great finally getting his pov. He loves Daisy so much but he's fighting it for Lo's sake. He feels like the disposable one in the group, which broke my heart for him. I loved it when he and Lo finally cleared the air. It was hard to read but I think it was necessary. And when he finally claimed Daisy - Swoon!Lots of forward movement in the other couples stories as well. Some setbacks and some happy news. I still love the other couples more but this was another solid book from the Ritchies. Well done.

Unfortunately this novella did nothing for me. It wasn't worth the money or the long wait. We find out nothing new and it was over too quickly to feel any kind of connection to Marlee and Carter. I really liked Marlee in The Selection but this novella didn't remind me of that girl at all. It just felt lazy and I feel cheated.

The best and most emotional installment yet!Born to Endless Night is told mostly from Magnus's pov (YAY!). When an unwanted warlock baby is dropped off on the steps of the academy, Magnus and Alec must decide whether they want to embark on a new adventure. This was just the catalyst needed to move the Lightwood family on a path of healing. It was very touching.Simon is overwhelmed with praise and he's finally confident in his decision to ascend.Lots of good stuff in this installment. I just loved it and I'm looking forward to the final book.

*2.5 stars****My review contains SPOILERS***Darn. Another overhyped book that I fell for. I was excited to read Lev but I was pretty disappointed.Mina has been homeless on the streets for seven years. On the brink of starvation, she enters a gentleman's club hoping to seduce a man out of some money. Instead she takes advantage of an opportunity to steal a wallet.Lev runs the club with his brother and catches Mina in the act. He takes pity on her and feeds her, lets her stay in his home, and gives her a job as a bartender. But don't go thinking he's completely altruistic - he wouldn't have done that if she were ugly.For the most part I liked Mina. She was grateful and upbeat. She was like a hurricane in Lev's life. She forced him out of his shell. I thought she was a little too bubbly, there were too many exclamation points when she spoke. She adapted too easily. And I was rolling my eyes when we learned why she was homeless. It was completely unnecessary.I liked Lev okay too. It's implied that he's autistic but it felt like he sometimes was and sometimes wasn't. Like Aurora never fully committed to giving him the characteristics. Sometimes he was a jealous, take-charge alpha male, sometimes he was a sweet boy that couldn't process his or others' feelings.There were A LOT of secondary characters. This book has been labeled a stand alone but it felt like I was missing something. Like I should have met these families before. And I didn't really like any of them. I know it sounds like I hated Lev but I didn't. It really was just okay. But I won't be continuing the series featuring the other characters.

The Ritchies knocked it out of the park with this one. Their best book so far hands down. I really love their writing style. The books are long but there aren't any boring parts. They give us lots of details and they take their time delivering the story.I've been dying to get to Kiss the Sky. I adore Rose and Connor and I was looking forward to getting in their heads. I love their smart banter and I liked the reality show plotline. Connor is so patient with Rose and his life is filled with pressures that he doesn't let his friends see. Rose is so hot-tempered and in control but she's finally able to let Connor see her vulnerability.There's some serious sexual tension in this book but once it happens it's explosive. It was completely satisfying.The ending had me in tears. I was a mess. Partly from Connor's emotional news and partly from his swoon-worthy gesture to Rose.Once again the Ritchies don't just give us the main couple, we get the whole family. Just fantastic story-telling. I loved it.

Set in the 1950s, Swelter is the story of Lilly and brothers Rory and Bobby. One is her husband and one is the love of her life. They all grew up together. Rory was always the sensible one and Bobby the playboy. Lilly was all set to marry Rory but the night before the wedding Lilly and Bobby make their feelings known. But it wasn't enough to change anything. After the wedding Bobby disappears.Seven years later, Rory and Lilly are unhappy but their world is turned upside down when Bobby returns.From here things take a turn that I didn't see coming. And then Jones just kept them coming. I was quietly crying but then I got to the epilogue and I was a full blown mess. Such a sad, touching story of what could never be. I was impressed. Well done.

I was worried this book would be boring filler but I was wrong. That's not how I felt about it at all.Lo is coming home from rehab. With the help of Rose, Connor, Ryke, and her therapist, Lily went through her own version of rehab but she'll be put to the ultimate test now that Lo is home. But Lo has his own challenges. He needs learn how to live his life as a sober person. One thing we never doubt is whether Lo and Lily would function and heal better without the other. Their co-dependency has morphed into healthy support. I love them as a couple.I also liked how much all of the other characters we love played a part. Rose, Connor, Ryke, and Daisy all have their stories unfolding as well and I'm looking forward to diving into their books.The drama surrounding Lo and Lily's mysterious text messages threatening to out Lily's addiction came to a surprising conclusion. I didn't see that coming.So far I love Lo and Lily's progress. It feels organic. This series is just entertaining - plain and simple. On to the next one. Well done!

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**Hmm...so this book was just okay for me. Lex is now working for Maven in exchange for Maven's protection of Lex's niece, Charlie. Lex's first assignment is to discover what is causing the surge of magic in Boulder which is drawing in the werewolves, a bad thing for the vampires, and there's now some creature threatening the Old World and humans.Things between Lex and Quinn have also been heating up and Lex was finally allowed to make a decision regarding her brother-in-law, John, that I was happy with that I'm looking forward to seeing play out in the next book.Olson's storytelling and her heroine's detective skills are why I pick up her books but I didn't find the case terribly interesting in this book and that made it hard to get into and finish. But one so-so read in a sea of excellent books won't stop me from picking up the next one. Can't win 'em all.

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**This book was so easy to read. The flow was effortless. I was hooked.Annie is on the run. She took their last three grand and left her abusive husband and her farm. She finally settled in a trailer park in a no name town in North Carolina. She finds a cell phone the last tenant left behind in her trailer. It rings. She answers.Dylan is a former racing hot shot but now he's a wealthy recluse. He's had a deal with every tenant in that trailer to keep an eye on Ben, Annie's elderly next door neighbor. Not because Dylan cares about Ben but because he wants to be the first one notified when Ben is dead.But he finds Annie easy to talk to and Annie likes the new woman she can be with this stranger on the phone.  Lots of interesting stuff in this book. I really enjoyed it. FYI there's a killer cliffhanger.  I can't wait for book two.

*4.5 stars*Another winner by Yarros. My only complaint was I found this book a bit hard to get into but once I learned Grayson's secret I couldn't put it down. I had to buckle up and hold on for the ride. What a brilliant story.Grayson has always been wound tight. He's closed off and has a one track mind - flying Apache helicopters. Even his good friends/roommates, Josh and Jagger, don't know anything about where he sneaks off to on the weekends.Sam is friends with Ember, Josh, and Jagger from when they lived in Colorado. She had some trouble in college so she transferred to Alabama and moved in with the guys. Her presence is seriously affecting stone cold Grayson.Mistakes of their past are still affecting their present and the foreseeable future. I felt for Grayson, he really was stuck between a rock and a hard place but I also understood Sam's decisions. She really had no other choices.Just when you think all of the secrets are out they just keep coming.I loved it. Well done!

*4.75 stars*Charming Bastard:  5 starsI loved this short story. Boonie and Darcy have known each other forever. They live in a small mining town of Callup, Idaho. Over the years they've shared a few intimate moments but fate never seemed to be on their side. Years later, after Darcy divorced her high school sweetheart, Boonie has come to claim her once and for all. Well done!Sticky Sweet:  5 starsHorse's pov from when he first met Marie. He never stood a chance. This scene made me smile. I loved it.Skunked:  4 starsHorse and Marie have to take care of a smelly situation Horse's dog, Ariel, got into. Marie has a certain announcement and dealing with Ariel makes the moment unforgettable.Sugar and Spice:  5 starsThis is a few scenes from Melanie's pov about the first time she met Painter and the short time she was able to get to know him before he went to prison. I'm looking forward to their full story.

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.***2.5 stars*I made an oops. When I requested Darker the Release I didn't realize it was book two. But, to the author's credit, I caught on quickly and was able to follow the story with no hiccups.Kelly is using Caleb to get close to him because she suspects he is her father's murderer or at the very least called in the hit. It's the least she can do for her dying mother whose final wish is justice for her husband.But you start to catch feelings when you play this game. Kelly is finding it more and more difficult reconciling this wonderful, loving, generous man with a cold-blooded killer.I thought it was just okay. I had some issues. Kelly was playing a dangerous game and she went about it in such an amateurish and nave way. She was begging to be caught, possibly worse. People in the pharmaceuticals business don't mess around. Have you seen The Fugitive?! I also thought there was way too much sex. Every other scene and it went on for pages.And then in the end it seemed like it was all for nothing. Very lackluster. Didn't hate it but it's also forgettable.

Wow. This book was a little ridiculous. Nico had the fastest boom of all the brothers. He finds Sophie's cell phone, meets up to drop it off to her and boom she's the one. At least the other guys did a bit of chasing before it happened. Then he immediately wants to put a ring on it and a bun in her oven. Slow down!And, of course, Sophie is in danger. The ending to that situation and the person after her was so far-fetched. The whole book just felt lazy.*I read Until Nico as part of the Until box set*
That was wicked hot.  Jas, Noelle, and Lex give Dallas some stress relief.  Very short, just one helluva sex scene.  Looking forward to more.**I received the free download from Kit Rocha's website**

A really great sequel. At the end of Addicted to You both Lo and Lily recognized that they needed help. Lo went to rehab for ninety days and now Lily has to exist without him. With the help of her sisters, friends, and a therapist, Lily is ready to battle her own addiction.I really liked how the authors tackled this. Lily didn't just decide she's going to stop and that's that. She constantly worried she was going to cheat on Lo. She was hard on herself when she stumbled and she gave herself no credit when she succeeded. Ryke and Rose were excellent people to have in her corner and I'm glad Lily let herself rely on them.But it wasn't all heavy, there was some funny stuff too. I can't wait to continue. Well done!
Looks cute sticking out of my books while sitting on the bookshelf.  And they're made of thick plastic.  Very sturdy.  I'm happy with them.

**I received an ARC through Netgalley courtesy of the publisher in exchange for an honest review.**I think I may be in the minority here but Titan and Yve worked my last nerve.I never warmed up to Titan in Beneath This Ink. I didn't care for how he treated Vanessa with his blackmailing and his high-handedness and his eye-rolling arrogance. He isn't much different in Beneath These Scars.Yve works at a boutique called Dirty Dog that sells hip vintage clothes. Yve has an opportunity to buy the shop. She also comes from a long line of mistresses so she desperately wants to buy the shop on her own. She wants to be the one to put a stop to that particular legacy.So when Titan decides he wants Yve to be his, it's many, many pages of Titan's pushiness and Yve's obstinance. It became tiresome.Yve's abusive ex also enters the storyline which, I'm sorry to say, came to a cheesy conclusion. I saw that particular twist coming. I'm also wondering if Hennessy is the only cop in New Orleans because he seems to take the fact that these guys take the law into their own hands with a grain of salt. It was odd. Not sure if I want to read his book or not. And when we finally learn what, in fact, is beneath these scars it was more of a sizzle than a boom. Meh.This was not my favorite of the series by a long shot. I've enjoyed them up to this point.

Heed the warning! This book is full of brutality but I don't think it could have ended any other way. Javier is a mess. He's a broken man after the "loss" of yet another sister and he's taking it out on prisoners and other women. Meanwhile Esteban plans on taking advantage of Javier's preoccupation.I've never been a Javier fan but that doesn't mean I can't appreciate a great story. I thought Dirty Promises was an excellent finale. There were scenes that were hard to read but I thought Halle stayed true to Cartel life. So I can't say I fully enjoyed it but the plot, the action scenes, and the relationship drama kept me turning the page. Well done!

I'm very impressed with this book. I liked it even more than Beneath This Mask and I wasn't sure I would. I didn't know how I felt about Con at first but I ended up really liking him.Con comes from a wealthy family. He owns Voodoo, his tattoo shop, along with several other businesses including a gym where he helps New Orleans teen boys stay off the streets. He's also on a mission to find out who murdered his adoptive parents.Vanessa has always been Con's unattainable crush. And when he finally had his shot at one night with her, he was too drunk to remember any of it. But he intends to remedy that. Vanessa runs a foundation for charities and she needs something from Con. He sees this as an opportunity for a trade.I was hoping Vanessa's eating hang ups would have been explored more and Vanessa's so-called deal with Lucas never really amounted to anything so I kind of thought it was pointless but I really enjoyed the murder and corruption plot. It was unexpected. It kept me turning the page. Overall it was a great story. Well done!

Thank you. Finally. This is the first book I've read that doesn't romanticize sex addiction. So many authors' idea of a sex addict is really just a manwhore. When he is all of a sudden able to control himself when he meets The One and wait for her to be ready means he is NOT a sex addict. The Ritchies show us the ugly truth. And I think because the sex addict was a woman made it even more uncomfortable. There were plenty of times I was judgy, where I was tsking Lily for not having more respect for herself. But that's the reality. And that's what kept me engrossed in the story.Lily gets a high from orgasms. She has to have them when the mood strikes - sometimes alone, a lot of times with random men. And when she comes down it's the same as any other addiction - she feels shame, she's remorseful, she lies to her family, but then she's looking for her next fix. She also has an enabler. Lo has been her best friend for years. He helps Lily keep her secret and tries to keep her safe.But Lily also enables Lo with his alcoholism. She makes sure he doesn't drive and she sobers him up for family functions. They've relied on each other for so long things will only get better when they decide to take their relationship to the next level, right?I really enjoyed this story. I thought the ending was great. It made me happy even though this is only book one to a series. I'll be jumping into the next book, I'm anxious to see their story through. Well done!
Brilliant once again.  This book gave me heart palpitations.  I swooned and I cried.  Jamie and Claire's love story is epic.  So, so good.

This book started out well enough. Iris packed up her life in Florida and moved in with her older half-brother, Sonny. He also got her a job at a tattoo shop owned by Dex Locke. Dex is hot, of course, but he's an A-hole. Iris starts to get on with her life but her and Sonny's father gets into trouble that also affects their life. That's pretty much the whole story but stretched out over many, many pages.It wasn't all boring though. The sexual tension kept me turning the page and when it finally happened it was pretty hot. There were also quite a few times I lol'd. If this was shorter I might have rated it higher but, overall, I was underwhelmed.

Grayson and Kira had similar upbringings - they were both raised in a life of privilege. Kira was a pawn for her political father and Grayson, the product of an affair, was ignored and made to feel worthless. Their differences, however, is their outlook on life. Kira is upbeat and quirky with a generous heart but Grayson is angry and mistrustful.I liked the plot. As soon as Kira made her proposition I knew this was going to be good. Sheridan excels at writing a sweet, tortured man - Grayson was just slower to show us sweet. I thought the dragon and witch endearments were a little much but overall Grayson's Vow was another winner. It made me tear up as much as it made me smile. Well done!

*2.5 stars*I liked the idea of a female bounty hunter but Grace drove me nuts. It's like she was guilty of doing everything a man would tick off as reasons a woman shouldn't be in the business.After five years of proving herself, Grace is finally given a big case - bringing in Raide Knox. He's wanted for his sister's murder and he's skipped bail. But he's returned to his hometown to try and prove his innocence.Grace is going to get close to Raide by trying to seduce him. He's too big to try to overpower but she's stubborn and refuses help, help even male bounty hunters would ask for. And, of course, she has multiple chances to bring him in but she catches feelings.There are a lot of technical inaccuracies that were very distracting. I kept shouting, "That wouldn't happen!" But, like always, Jewel has that certain something that glues me to the pages and keeps me as a reader. The story wasn't all bad, I was mainly disappointed with the wasted opportunity to prove women don't always have to rely on sex appeal to get what they want.

I'm usually a fan of YA. Most YA authors do a great job building worlds and creating complex characters and storylines. But Until Friday Night was complete fluff. It felt like something a nine year old girl would describe as swoony and romantic. If I was the intended teenage audience I would be insulted. And this book was too short and too expensive for it to be anything but fantastic.I'm going to say it - I thought West was a p**sy. The way he dealt with his dad's situation was cowardly. He kept it from his friends like it was something to be ashamed of and he treated women like tissues to ease his pain. Oh brother.Maggie doesn't speak. She witnessed something horrific and she's now living with her aunt and uncle and cousin Brady. She's smitten with West immediately and I was rolling my eyes at her West-can-do-no-wrong worship.
