The Belkin case I am reviewing is black and case is made of a smooth, but still easily gripped, polyurethane (PU) and has fitted side and corner clips on the right side of the open folio to keep the iPhone 6 Plus safe and secure. Inserting was easy; just snap it in place. Integrated magnets keep the cover securely closed. The left inside of the open polio case has a nifty 3½" slotted pocket for storing such things as an ID, driver license, credit or AAA card; I was able to comfortably slide in two cards.As most folio cases do, this Belkin case allows full access to all of the important controls and ports without removing the smartphone, as well as cutouts for the camera and speaker. Evidently, this folio case will eventually come out in a variety of "vibrant jewel-toned colors with a luxurious, buttery smooth texture" (from Belkin website). However, right now it appears that this case is only available (on Amazon anyway) in black and navy blue.Another feather I liked a lot was that the back cover of the folio case can also fold into a convenient stand for hands-free viewing and also adjust to multiple viewing angles. I own a small Kindle reader with a folio case, so bending the cover around and securing it to the back for easy single-handed reading is commonplace. This Belkin folio case can also do this and the integrated magnets to a fairly good job of securing the front cover to the back cover for easy single-handed phone use.Even though this Belkin Classic Folio Case is relatively plain looking, I still like its sleek, understated and smooth feel and look. When I carry my phone and reader around with me, the last thing I need is to draw attention to them. I'm not a slave to fashion, nor do I wish make a fashion statement with my mobile gadgets. But if you do, Belkin printed the following concerning this Belkin folio case on their website:"Inspired by some of our favorite street style looks as well as the high-fashion runways, the Belkin iPhone 6 Plus Cases, Wallets and Folios have evolved beyond your basic protection to become the perfect fashion accessory."In my opinion, that is completely overstated. Though it is possible that after the cases with the "vibrant jewel-toned colors with a luxurious, buttery smooth texture" come out I may have to reconsider my subdued fashion opinion.I really like this Belkin folio case, mostly for its sleek, yet basic look and utilitarian design. In other words, it works as advertised and looks good while doing it. Recommended.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------(Side Note): For those who may be interested in knowing this, some of the statistical information on Amazon and the Belkin websites for this Belkin Classic Folio Case (size, weight, etc.) does not match the actual product. Both sites state that this case has a soft microfiber inner lining, but the inside of the case I have is made of polyurethane; there is no microfiber inner lining. Just to make this a bit more perplexing, the photos on both sites (Amazon & Belkin) and the photos on the back of the retail box match the product I am reviewing perfectly. The front of the retail box clearly indicates this case is for the iPhone 6 Plus. Neither the case nor the retail box has a product number listed for comparison purposes. I even checked the light brown micro printing on the back of the retail box with my wife's vintage graphic designer magnifier cup; nothing. Even the Vine Program label that is usually attached to the products was missing.

This Outdoor Tech Wired Chips® Universal Helmet Audio System is a specialty item designed for use inside helmets with a built-in audio liner inside. This type of sound system is most commonly used by motorcyclists and snow skiers, though I suppose a long distance bicyclist who was willing to use an audio fitted helmet could just as easily benefit from this product, too. One of my Air Force friends rides a Harley and loves these wired Chips®.A prospective customer should know that the photo on Amazon is a little misleading. It makes it appear that this product is a headset with a headband. What appears to be a headband is actually just the very flexible wiring that connects the two Chips® together. There is no headband since these wired Chips® are not a traditional set of headphones.This Outdoor Tech system comes with the two wired Chips® and a 53" in-line cable that includes a manual multifunction control device, plus two sets of instructions, one for quick Get Started set and another more detailed booklet. Connecting the wired Chips® is no different than any other media device. First, plug the 3.5mm jack nearest the in-line multifunction control into the left ear Chip® port and the other 3.5mm jack at the other end of the cable into your smartphone, iPod or other pocket-sized audio device. Then insert the Chips® into the helmet audio liner, clip the multifunction control onto your jacket collar or sleeve near your head (a clip is built onto the control) and you're wired up and ready to go.Actually, this is a dual button control system. Your media device can be controlled by the in-line control I mentioned earlier and a second controller is built into the right-ear Chip®. The advantage of the Chip® control is the large 1¼" diameter button in the Chip® can be activated by pushing or pushing and holding the button without having to look away from what you are doing; and this can be done without removing your gloves. I really like that feature. The one feature you cannot control from the ear Chip® is the volume; that has to be done by the volume wheel in the in-line multifunction control.The multifunction buttons can control the following functions on your media device:* Play* Pause* Raise and lower volume (in-line control only)* Skip Forward* Skip backwardThis multifunction audio system isn't limited to media devices (this is where is really gets good). It also answer, reject, hang up and mute phone calls from your smartphone as well as activate Siri! This is why the in-line control needs to be clipped relatively close to your head so you can use the built-in mic.I had to wait until my adult son came over with his smartphone (I only have a not-so-smart phone) and helmet to actually test out the speakers and controls. The sound from the 2" diameter Chips® was pretty good, depending on the song and genre, and the controllers worked well, just as indicated in the instructions. The Outdoor Tech website has a couple of videos that were helpful. One of the videos featured an older gentlemen who sounded, dressed and acted like he was straight out of vintage Woodstock era of the late 1960s. The instructions must have been written by the same guy because I can ever remember reading the phrases "This page was created to give you a 2-minute run down of how these babies work." "Can I get a hell ya?" "Rock out, make calls, and, you know, ski and snowboard and whatnot." And finally, "Well, we've all been there and know that this situation totally sucks."The most challenging part of using this Outdoor Tech Wired Chips® Universal Helmet Audio System is memorizing the controls: Short press once, long press for 2 seconds, press left ear button, etc., etc. Both instructions have charts that include function and action commands. The booklet is small enough to carry around with you, so it will just be a matter of time, and a few dropped telephone calls, until I have all of the commands stored away.A couple of warnings are worth noting: (1) Keep Chips® dry, (2) Keep Chips® away from direct sunlight or hot places (High temperatures will shorten the life of electronic devices. (3) Do not let the Chips® onto hard surfaces. (4) Do not use intensive chemical products or detergents to clean the product.One last thought that is completely irrelevant to enjoying this set of wired Chips®, so disregard the following if need be. Outdoor Tech calls this product a "Universal Helmet Audio System." But it doesn't fit in all helmets; just the ones with built-in audio liners. That doesn't seem like a universal system to me. Two additional accessories I almost forgot to mention: Comes with (1) two Outdoor Tech peel & stick company logos. (2) A soft white cloth pull-string carrying bag.I really like these, mainly because the system is so easy to set up and use (except for the memorizing part). The 40mm drivers produced a good sound experience and the connection cables look like they can weather a real workout, especially the 53" cable. It has what appears to be a tough nylon wrap around the cable for strength and durability. Nice idea! The Chips® can function in weather down to -4 degrees F / -20 degrees C. Recommended.

If you have tried to apply a clear screen protector to a mobile phone, iPad or eReader you are acutely aware that trying to get it on straight, and without those annoying bubbles and dust particles rarely had a completely satisfactory outcome. If you wanted it bubble-free, you paid a professional to apply it. Thankfully, that is a thing of the past. With the release of the new Kindle Voyage late last year, Moshi also released their iVisor XT Screen Protector for that device.I have a Kindle Paperwhite, so off I went to my favorite big-box store to test this screen protector on a Kindle Voyage. The Moshi iVisor XT comes packaged in a simple cardboard packet with a zip open top. Before I visited the store, I took some time viewing a few videos to become acquainted with how this Moshi iVisor should be applied. There are some excellent how-to videos on YouTube. I checked out the Moshi video, too, but it had no instructional audio so it was less helpful than the ones on YouTube.When I unpacked the screen protector it immediately reminded me of the old fashioned overhead projector slides (I'm really dating myself now!); the ones with the cardboard border and a clear film window. This Moshi iVisor XT has a black border with a much thicker, crystal clear protective screen. There is also a microfiber cloth included in the packet and the manufacturer recommends the front surface of the Voyage be thoroughly cleaned prior to application. One thing I noticed about this iVisor is it is really glossy . . . I mean REALLY GLOSSY! Since I wanted to successfully apply this screen protector without any dust particles or bubbles, I decided to clean the iVisor screen, too, before I applied it.The instructions for this product are very basic and mostly of the picture variety. This is why I usually recommend watching narrated videos for before I try applying or assembling anything I'm doing for the first time. Once the Voyage was cleaned the next step is to gently pull the tab on the backing down to remove it from the iVisor. One of the guys on a video recommended keeping the backing for future use if you decide to remove the iVisor you will have something to temporarily stick it on. What I found really nice about this screen protector was the adhesive is only on the black border and not on the screen itself. And the adhesive is not your typical sticky to the touch type of adhesive. The Moshi website described the adhesive as a polymer-based adhesive which allows the screen protector to be used, removed and applied again. According to Moshi:"iVisor's polymer-based adhesive provides for unlimited cleaning and reapplication cycles, making it the most durable and easiest-to-install protector on the market today."Once I removed the backing I was pleased to discover that the screen protector doesn't curl up like the old fashioned ones but remains flat, ready for installation. According to the video, and my customer associate friend at the store, the iVisor should be applied from the bottom first, ensuring the black border on the iVisor aligns with the bottom edge of the Kindle Voyage. Since the adhesive isn't particularly sticky, applying the iVisor was surprisingly easy. After it was applied, I checked around the edges of the Voyage to make sure it was a perfect fit. This Moshi screen protector covers the Kindle Voyage front surface from top to bottom and side to side. Once I had the fit I needed, I gently pressed the black border down first, and then the screen itself. After cleaning the iVisor again with the microfiber cloth to remove my fingerprints and any dust or lingering smudges, the store's Kindle Voyage had a BUBBLE-FREE, and removable screen protector! By the way, I did remove the Moshi iVisor Screen Protector, reattached it to the peeled off backing, inserted it back into the cardboard packet and took it back home with me.Like I mentioned earlier, this iVisor XT is very glossy, and that didn't change once I had applied it to the Voyage. The reflections were there depending on the angle I held the device. I was more interested in what the screen protector looked like with the Kindle Voyage on than when it was off. When I turned it on the Voyage the screen was highly transparent with only minor reflections every now and then, again, depending on the angle I held it; it wasn't bothersome. I did notice that when the device was turned off there was a rainbow-like distortion in the center of the screen protector. According to Moshi this is not a defect, but a natural occurrence. It isn't noticeable when the Voyage is on.Checking the screen sensitivity was my next test. The iVisor passed this test with flying colors. The full touch sensitivity of this iVisor was excellent. According to their website, Moshi uses: "MicroGrid technology to ensure optimal touch sensitivity."Here are a few miscellaneous features worth noting: (1) The screen protector stayed firmly in place while it was on the Voyage, yet it was also very easy to remove. (2) To my surprise, both sides of the screen protector can also be washed with water; this should only be done when the iVisor has been removed from the Kindle Voyage. (3) The Moshi iVisor XT for the Kindle Voyage only comes with a black boarder at this time. (4) The iVisor comes in XT and AG models, though I'm not sure the AG model is available yet (XT: Crystal Clear; AG: Anti Glare).I was impressed with this Moshi iVisor XT Screen Protector. Mainly because it is easy to put on and can be taken off just as easily and mistake free. And, of course, who couldn't enjoy a bubble-free, scratch-resistant screen protector? I couldn't find any legitimate defects or recommended improvements to this product, except possibly the glossy, reflective screen that caused other reviewers such consternation. Other than that this product is excellent and highly recommended.

Both of our adult children do some form of fitness training. So I decided to use them as my test subjects for this review. Though this Belkin Slim-Fit Plus Armband is specifically designed for the iPhone 6, my daughter discovered that it would also accommodate her iPhone 5 without any adjustments or problems. The Belkin armband that I am reviewing is for arm size small-medium.The first thing I noticed after unboxing the armband was how lightweight it is: only 2.1 ounces. At the same time the size much larger than I expected: 6½" long and 4" wide. Our daughter used an armband some years ago when she had a much smaller and not-so-smart phone; this Belkin product dwarfs that one. The Belkin Slim-fit Plus Armband is made of a very thin black and gray stretchable (and breathable) polyester fabric and the faceplate on the front is made of a flexible black rubber material. The actual strap is 2" wide and very smooth and comfortable to the touch and will accommodate a flexed upper arm with a circumferential size of 8" to 12". A strip of 1" wide black Velcro is stitched to the backside along the entire length of the adjustable strap. When the iPhone is inserted inside the holster a thin built-in clear plastic protective faceplate covers the phone's screen, protecting it from inadvertent scratches and water damage. There are reflective accents built into this Belkin armband for nighttime visibility; neither of our children run outdoors after dark so this feather wasn't something they considered useful for them. There is a two compartment pocket on the backside of the holster: one for the iPhone 6 and another one that can be used to secure personal items like plastic credit or key cards, keys and other small thin objects. I thought the card compartment was a nice idea and definitely a welcome accessory. Before inserting the iPhone into its pocket, there is a black cardboard insert that needs to be removed first. That may seem like a no-brainer, but since this product comes without instructions, just inadvertently pulling on parts may lead to damaging the product. In this case, however, it was the right thing to do. There is a polyester fabric flap that covers the opening of the holster which must be rolled up in order to insert the phone. The slit is pretty narrow so a phone case may need to be removed in order to insert it. I had no problem inserting both the iPhone 6 and 5 without removing the cases. Both phones fit snugly in the pocket and the polyester fabric flap over the opening stays closed preventing moisture, dust and other unwanted materials from getting inside the pocket; another nice feature. There is also a hole at the bottom backside of the holster that matched perfectly with the iPhone's headset jack.One feature I noticed while I was checking out the armband was a ½" wide black rubber belt loop that encircles the strap itself. When I pull the Belkin armband out to the box this belt loop was on the same side of the armband as the black rubber closure tab (the right side as you are looking at the front faceplate). It had the image of a set of headphones pressed into the rubber so obviously it must be related in some way. It wasn't until later when I was looking at the photos of this product on Amazon that it dawned on me that the rubber belt loop was on the wrong end of the armband. I slid it around to the left side (the same side at the headphones jack I might add) and the mystery was solved. It was a loop to hold the headphones cable against the armband, and thus the user's arm.Now it's time to find out what my two testers had to say about the Belkin Slim-Fit Plus Armband for iPhone 6 (Blacktop):Our twenty-something year old son has a gym membership and works out using both aerobic and anaerobic (strength training) exercises. He purchased an iPhone 6 late last year and was very interested in putting this Belkin armband to the test during his workouts. Our son liked the lightweight design and especially the easy insertion process, even with his phone case still on. He is 6' tall and weighs 175 lbs.; his body size is about average. He put the Belkin armband on in a straight arm, relaxed position with ease, but when he cinched up the adjustable strap he could barely wrap the rubber tab around side loop to secure the Velcro. He said the armband was comfortable until moved his arm into a casual flexed position. At that point it was obvious that he needed a larger strap. He had no problem navigating his iPhone's touch screen and was pleasantly surprised that this worked so well.Our twenty-something year old daughter confines her workouts to mostly dance routines, outdoor jogging and indoor stationary machines and small free weights. Likewise, she was also eager to strap on this Belkin armband for use during her exercise routines. She also liked the lightweight design and the fact that her iPhone 5 fit just as well as her brother's iPhone 6 did. She is rather petite so strapping on and securing the Belkin armband was a breeze. She also liked how smooth and comfortable the armband was once it was on her arm and the second pocket for storing things was definitely a big hit with her. She also liked the fact that the Belkin armband was hand-washable and especially that she could thread her headphones cable up through the black rubber belt loop so it wouldn't flop around while she was dancing or exercising. Navigating through the clear protective screen took a little more patience, but she said it wasn't a problem. The only thing she didn't like about the Belkin Slim-Fit Plus Armband for iPhone 6 (Blacktop) was the bulky size. Like I mentioned earlier, she is petite and so the large size of this holster on her small arm was a game breaker for her.Overall our opinion of this Belkin Slim-Fit Plus Armband for iPhone 6 (Blacktop) was very positive.

I have used ArmorAll products pretty regularly to protect and care for the exterior and interior of my cars. However, over the last several years I have become dissatisfied with the performance of their spray-on products. So when I saw this bottle of Chemical Guys Natural Shine product, I was ready to give it a try.I live in the Midwest and the weather can be brutal on cars. One of my vehicles is a 2001 Dodge Stratus that was really in need of some help. The Chemical Guys have been around for over three decades and when I visited their website I was impressed with the variety of products and tools to wash, restore and protect vehicles, old and new. They even offer classes on how to properly detail your car and more videos explaining and demonstrating more applications than I would ever use. They released this Natural Shine (Satin Shine Dressing) in September 2013, so it has only been on the market for a little over a year.So, how did it work? I decided to work on the interior of my Dodge first to get an idea how effective the Satin Shine Dressing actually is and how satisfied I was with the results. My dashboard is in pretty good condition, but it obviously needed some nourishment; a real pick-me-up! The first thing I noticed was the product smell. It didn't have a greasy, petroleum smell like ArmorAll, but instead left my interior a fragrance similar to a leathery new car smell. That's the best way I can describe it. And more importantly, it has a thicker more creamy consistency so I could easily determine what areas get the dressing and those that don't. By comparison, my ArmorAll is runny and difficult to control. Also, this Natural Shine is a water-based product with a UV blocker included; I really like that.As you may have guessed already, this Satin Shine Dressing doesn't come in a spray bottle. It comes in a squeeze bottle with a flip nozzle and is applied very much like a liquid car wax. There are simple written instructions on the plastic bottle: "Shake well--Clean Surface--Wipe or Sponge On--Allow to penetrate--Wipe Dry If Desired--Re-apply as Needed." I decided to use one of my round, palm-sized paste wax applicators to apply the Satin Shine Dressing to the top of my dashboard; it worked really well. I followed the example in one of the Chemical Guys videos and applied a modest amount of the Natural Shine dressing to the applicator by squeezing a single stripe across the center from side to side (they recommend two or three stripes for tires). I only applied the dressing to half of the dash, rubbing it in, because I wanted to compare the before and after results. Wow! Not only did the dash not feel wet or greasy, the satin shine was perfect for an interior. ArmorAll would leave a wet shine and stay tacky for a couple of days afterward. I couldn't wait to finish the rest of the interior:  the console, steering wheel, side panels, cup holders, glove box, door locks, steering column and every other piece of plastic, rubber and vinyl I could find.My dash and side panels have a grainy texture so I was pleased that the applicator I used was able to apply the dressing down into the grain. Since the Natural Shine is an off-white cream I was curious as to just how well it would work on a grainy black interior. The dressing applied with ease and the creamy white color disappeared, completely restoring these parts of my interior to a like new look.I had to wait to do the tires and other non-painted exterior parts until the weather warmed up enough to apply the dressing. My tires have more than a few thousand miles on them so I was particularly interested in how well the Natural Shine dressing would work on them. I thought about using a cloth to apply the dressing, but decided to stay with the same kind of applicator pad that I had used on the interior. The sidewalls of the tires have raised lettering and the video I watched recommended using the pad for that very reason. I applied the dressing according to the video and made sure I rubbed it into the sidewalls really well. Because the tires were older, I needed to apply a second application. Again, the satin shine was just right; not too dull and not too glossy and the dressing provided a nice synthetic polymer coating on my tires.I tried to put this product to the same test anyone else would have. With that being said, I just couldn't find anything to complain about, or even something I thought the Chemical Guys should have added or left out. I like this product. I like the video support this company provides to their customers and prospective customers. I like the easy application process with little cleanup afterward, and I even liked the smell of my partially restored interior. I especially like a product that produces the results advertised. Recommended.

This new FUEL iON iPhone charger was recently released by Patriot and unlike the standard USB cable method of charging a mobile phone this one uses a wireless magnetic charging system. Designed specifically for the Apple iPhone 5 and 5s, comes with a FUEL iON charging stand, a charging case for the iPhone and a USB connection cable for the stand. This new charger provides an amazingly quick and hassle-free way to connect an iPhone for recharging.The connection between the charging stand and the iPhone is wireless. Only the FUEL iON charging stand requires a power cable. A 39" USB cable is included with a standard size USB plug on one end and a micro USB plug on the other end. The FUEL iON stand can use a computer, an AC adapter or any other 5V/1 amp power source. In order for the iPhone 5 and 5s to use the charging stand the phone must be inserted into a special FUEL iON charging case. Of course that means any case you already have on the iPhone must be removed. Inserting the iPhone into the charging case is very easy: just slide down the connecting tab at the bottom of the case and then place the iPhone into the case, top first. Then push the tab on the case back up to insert the lightning connector into the charging port on the bottom of the iPhone so it can sync with the FUEL iON charging system. Once that is done, you're ready to charge the mobile phone.With any new product I always expect a clear and thorough set of instructions. Well . . . this product doesn't include anything even remotely resembling instructions. What poses as instructions are called "Useful Tips" and they are printed in a micro type font on a 2¼" x 3" piece of paper. Having said this, it is true that the charging system has so few pieces, anyone with a general knowledge of mobile phones and the recharging processes shouldn't have any difficulty figuring out how this system works. If you don't have at least a working knowledge . . . find someone who does before proceeding because you will find little, if any, help on or inside the packaging.The FUEL iON charging case is made of polycarbonate plastic and feels pretty substantial. The thick bottom, corners and '" wide sides provide ample protection. At least one drawback is the cutouts for the variety of iPhone features in the sides of the charging case also provide a significant amount of access to the sides of the iPhone. This concerns me. One other important concern I have with the charging case is the absence of any protection for the face of the iPhone. Because of the substantial cost of an iPhone 5 or 5s, maximum protection is absolutely essential. In my opinion, a case with an open face is not providing essential security. I'm not the first reviewer to mention this and I suppose Apply with ensure the open face problem will be addressed in the near future.The L-shaped charging stand isn't very large, only 4" x 3" x 2", and weighs less than 5 ounces. I suppose most of the weight comes from the magnets inside the stand. Once the charging stand is plugged into a power source all you have to do to start charging is place the encased iPhone in the charging cradle, matching the charging circle on the back of the case to the charging circle on the charging cradle. The neodymium magnet technology in this device is very strong; so strong that the first time I charged my iPhone the magnet nearly pulled the phone out of my hand, snapping it against the face of the charger. Charging took about the same time as the standard charging cable process, but the zero preparation time with this magnetic wireless system makes recharging a breeze. I keep the FUEL iON charger on my desk ready for recharging my phone.Oh, I almost forgot to add that the iPhone doesn't have to be docked vertically in the charging cradle. As long as the two charging circles are matched, you could place it horizontally, rotate it to a diagonal position, or any other position you may want or need to position it. And this can be done without any concern that the phone will disconnect and fall off the charging stand.If you're not near your FUEL iON charger and need to recharge the iPhone, a standard micro USB cable can be used without removing the charging case through a micro charging port on the bottom end of the case. Patriot also included a 4" extender cable with a headphone style plug on one end and a plugin receptacle on the other end. They added this because the case causes the headphone jack to be recessed too deep for a standard headphone plug to reach. So just plug in the extender cable through the case to the phone and plug headphones into the plugin receptacle at the other end and the problem is solved.I like the convenience of this wireless inductive charging technology. It's easy to set up and charges just as well as corded systems. My big concern, as mentioned earlier, is the iPhone's vulnerability while in the charging case. The Patriot website has several boasts concerning the impressive protection the charging case provides the iPhone: here is one: "Elevated bezel to protect against screen scratches." How can this case protect against screen scratches when the entire face of the phone is open and exposed to any number of threats? In another place on the Patriot website they make this amazing claim in reference to the charging case: "a fully protective case." In my opinion, if this kind of charging system is to be really successful, Patriot must solve the current damage risk problem to the iPhone from this case.This FUEL iON magnetic wireless charging system has built-in circuit protection against over voltage, over current, leakage and short circuit and comes backed by a 2-year limited warranty.

I recently purchased a Kindle Paperwhite and wanted a simple folio case that would protect it from damage and scratches and allow me to insert and remove the reader with ease. I saw this case from NuPro and thought I would try it out. This NuPro Folio Case comes in five solid colors (Black, Blue, Pink, Purple and Turquoise), measures 7¼" x 5" x ½" (with the reader inside) and weighs 3.7 ounces (without the reader).Even though the Kindle Paperwhite is visible around the edges, the cover extends enough over the edge of my Kindle Paperwhite that it is completely protected. Because it's a folio case the charging port and power button are easily accessible while the cover is on, so there is no need to remove it. The cover is made of polyurethane (PU) and has a pressed grain so it doesn't slip around in my hand and also doesn't leave visible smudges and finger prints. The cover does feel tough, with only minimal flex. The four corners opposite the binding are rounded so they minimize the bent corners so common in hardbound books. And NuPro has inset its company logo in the bottom right-hand corner of the cover.The inside is covered by a stitched in piece of charcoal colored microfiber fabric to protect the Kindle Paperwhite's screen. There are no fancy clasps or magnetic on/off closures in this case. Nor will you find a polycarbonate cradle inside that the device must be snapped into. When closed this folio can be secured with a ½" black elastic band that runs the top to bottom length of the case. Just roll the band over from the back to the front and the case is closed and secured. In the same way, the front flap can be folded backward and secured by the elastic band in an open position for viewing. On the inside, the Kindle Paperwhite or Kindle Touch is secured in place by an elastic band over each corner. None of the bands obscure the view of any part of the screen. Inserting and extracting the Kindle is a snap and leaves no scratch marks on the body of the reader like some cradles can do over time.This NuPro Folio Case is slim and lightweight, keeps my Kindle Paperwhite safe and secure, is easy to clean, if necessary, and looks nice. There is no fashion statement being made here; but it does do exactly what I want it to.

I thought this recently released Epson Pulsense PS-100 Heart Rate Monitor may be something I could benefit from since I have an Atrial Fibrillation heart condition that requires daily monitoring. This new Epson Pulsense comes in two colors (black and teal), two sizes (Small/Medium & Medium/Large) and is slim, slightly smaller than my Seiko wristwatch. The wristband is about ¾" wide, '" thick and is made of soft rubber. The face of this heart rate monitor (HRM) doesn't display numeric data like a digital watch does, but rather uses orange and blue LED light patterns to communicate a variety of heart rate information. Epson also has a Pulsense PS-500 that has a digital readout face, but it is much larger bulk wise and costs more.This Epson HRM is one of those products that requires some serious study time with the instructions (included) and Epson website videos. I mention this because the setup and functions do not fall into the "obvious" category. And, more importantly, there is a setup sequence that, if followed carefully, should minimize errors and the level of frustration. After going through this process myself, I have come to the conclusion that there will be a written test given by Epson at some point in the future.The first step is to fully charge the battery. Charging takes about 1½ to 2½ hours. According to Epson, a full charge lasts about 36 hours. There is a 15" USB charging cable included with this product. The cable has a standard size USB plug at one end and a charging cradle at the other end. Careful attention should be given to the instructions, product photos and Epson's Quick Start video when charging this device for the first time because inserting the HRM into the charging cradle correctly is very important; the trial and error method is not recommended. The cradle has two metal prongs that must be mated with two circular metal contacts on the HRM in order for charging to begin; an orange LED light on the HRM to let you know connection has been made and the battery is charging.Here are a couple of my thoughts on the charging cradle: Insert the HRM into a charging cradle with prongs seemed like a pretty old fashioned and precarious method of charging a device. I can remember back when these cradles (or docks) used to be common. However, with the proliferation of USB charging cables with standard-to-micro USB connectors, charging became simpler and safer. After practicing with the charging cradle, I became more confident and skilled at inserting the Epson HRM correctly. On my initial try, however, all I could think about was, "What if I snap it in and damage one or more of the prongs?" or "Break the plastic release tab?" Designing a USB port into this HRM device that would accommodate a micro USB connector would, in my opinion, make charging a breeze.Once the battery is charged the next two important steps in the setup sequence is to download the Epson Pulsense View app and launch and pair it to the Epson PS-100 HRM. According to Epson, the following mobile devices are supported by this product:*  iPhone 4s, iPhone 5, iPhone 5c or iPhone 5s with iOS 7.1 or later.*  Mobile devices running Android 4.3 or later with Bluetooth Smart.After carefully following the instructions, getting the app downloaded, launched and synced to the PS-100 was pretty easy, though pairing wasn't as quick as in the Epson video.The written instructions provide a chart that explains the meaning of the blue LED light patterns. When heart rate is in one of the zones, the blue LED light will light up or flash to let you know where you are at. Also, when you move from one zone to another the HRM will vibrate. Becoming familiar with the light pattern system will let you know the status of your heart rate. Such as:*  1 blue LED light means:  "Heart rate is below the fat burning zone."*  3 blue LED lights mean:  "Heart rate is in Fat burning zone."*  4 blue LED lights mean:  "Heart rate is in the aerobic exercise zone."*  1 orange LED light means: "The battery is low."The wristband that I am reviewing is the Small/Medium size. Epson recommends the HRM be worn on the "non-dominate" wrist and it should be worn snugly to collect more accurate heart rate data. There is a sensor on the underside of the HRM that touches the arm and records the heart rate.To take full advantage of the Epson Pulsense PS-100, you can view the collected data, such as heart rate, number of steps taken, calories burned, and even sleep data, from your PS-100 using the Pulsense View mobile app, as well as viewing it on your computer by creating your own on-line account. There is even an airplane mode! I have no idea what that is all about?By the time I finished tinkering around with this PS-100 HRM I realized there were more features built into this small device than I needed. My primary concern was monitoring my heart rate when I was outside of my home and on the go; alerting me when my rate was elevated. This Epson HRM did a better than average job of doing that for me. Having a good set of instructions like the one included with this HRM was invaluable. Much of the information in the instructions is also listed on the Epson website.This is my first portable heart rate monitor and, like I mentioned earlier, it has many more features than I will ever use. With that in mind, I was probably not the primary focus group for this product; but it does meet my need and being rather small and resembling a wristwatch, it doesn't attract undue attention.

It's that time of year again when boys and girls dream of making it onto the roster of a baseball team. Like any other sport it takes practice to hone the skills needed to excel at a sport. One of the distributors of sports training and practice equipment is SKLZ and one of their hitting aids is the SKLZ Bat Weight PL24. When I played ball it was called a "doughnut." It was a weighted hard rubber ring that slid on to the barrel of a wooden bat (yes, we used wooden bats; aluminum bats hadn't arrived yet) as a warm-up tool. The problem with the doughnut was if you were using it in the on-deck circle and it was your turn up to bat, getting the doughnut off the bat could prove very embarrassing if it wouldn't come off; unfortunately, I do speak from experience here.The SKLZ Bat Weight has eliminated that pesky problem. Their bat weight, or what some call a batting sleeve, is made out of rubberized PVC and is shaped in the form of a bat barrel. I still have several bats from when I played and coached Little League baseball and so I had a variety of sizes to try out the SKLZ Bat Weight. According to SKLZ the bat weight is supposed to fit all bat sizes. Inside the sleeve is a cleverly designed permanent insert that grips the bat barrel and, unlike the old doughnut I used, this batting sleeve won't scratch up the barrel of the bat; wooden or aluminum. The batting sleeve is approximately 7" long and 3" wide at the widest point and it worked just as advertised with each of my bats, T-ball to Senior League. This product comes with a Usage Guide which shows the correct way to install and remove the bat weight. Once the sleeve was on my bat, all it took was a firm tap of barrel end on the ground to secure the sleeve and a firm tap of the bat knob to remove it. No more embarrassing moments.The purpose of a batting sleeve is for stretching and warming up the upper body muscles prior to hitting. As a former baseball coach I know the value of stretching and warming up first. It can also be used for improving swing speed and accuracy. As with most of the SKLZ products they have a training video for this batting sleeve posted on their website as well as on YouTube. Coaches and trainers would do well to take advantage of these videos, whether you're using SKLZ products or not.Not surprisingly this product requires some care. The Usage Guide indicates the sleeve should be washed with a mild detergent when necessary and it should not be left outside in the elements for extended periods of time. As far as I'm concerned, no equipment should be left out...ever! It should be stored away for when it is needed next. The SKLZ Usage Guide says, "Do not store in extremely high or low temperatures to avoid damaging or reducing the life of the Bat Weight PL24."It also shouldn't be any surprise that the PL24 means the bat weight weighs in at 24 ounces (1½ pounds) and, according to SKLZ, it is actually used by some professional ballplayers. Even though the batting sleeve fit my T-Ball bat, I am of the opinion that at 1½ pounds this training device is too heavy for those in their early years of Little League baseball.This is a pretty simple device, so there really isn't anything not to like about it. It's easy to put on, take off, practice with, clean and store. It's better than the old doughnut I used so what's not to like?

I often hear people refer to an A-ha! moment; that moment when something they read, heard or saw just "clicks" in their mind or something they have been thinking about makes real sense for the first time. In his new book titled "AHA" author Kyle Idleman takes that basic idea and develops it beyond a momentary thought into the life-changing God moment that changes everything.Early in his opening chapter, Idleman briefly illustrates AHA:"I love witnessing AHA. I see it almost every weekend at the church where I serve. I listen to people as they tell about the spiritual awaking they have experienced. In the moment there was a beautiful collision. At just the right time, a person's life collides with God's Word and the power of the Holy Spirit, and everything changes."Instead of the traditional use of an A-ha! moment Idleman uses this general idea and then creates a three-point principle around the acronym AHA. He calls this principle "A Recipe for AHA." Without going into too much detail Idleman defines AHA in the following three principles:1. A sudden AWAKENING2. Brutal HONESTY3. Immediate ACTIONIdleman presents his AHA recipe using Jesus' story of the Prodigal Son. I've read other books that use this same story, unfortunately to their own embarrassment and with dreadful consequences. Usually because they fail to understand why Jesus told the story, who the story was deicting, its salient points and the dramatically shocking conclusion. To his credit, Idleman does a fine job of exegeting the Bible text and displays a healthy grasp of the story and its application.It should come as no surprise that this book is divided into three parts that correspond to Idleman's three AHA principles. Even though he uses the Bible as his foundational support, much of this book is propped up by anecdotal stories; in some chapters there is one story after another, after another. Though I enjoyed the way he developed his AHA acronym by way of biblical texts and real-life stories, the sheer number of stories packed into this book was sometimes overwhelming, often tempting me to flip ahead to see how much of the chapter was left. I guess you could say I got his point early on and didn't need the extra stories; but that's just me.One of Idleman's more valiant points in this book was when he spoke about the chilling moment when the Prodigal Son realized just how desperate his situation really was. The author writes:"It may sound harsh to say, but the number one contributor to spiritual growth is not sermons, book, or small groups; the number one contributor to spiritual growth is difficult circumstances. I can tell you this because of personal experience, reading spiritual-growth surveys, and my own anecdotal evidence after talking to thousands of people over the years. AHA comes out of the suffering, setbacks, and challenges of life. Many people could point to those moments as their greatest moment of spiritual awakening."I thought Idleman got his message across in this book in a fairly clear and concise way. Yet I still have at least two recommendations that may make this yet to be published book a better read. First, the book is really in need of an editorial scrub down before it goes to final print. Just so you know, I am using an Advanced Reading Copy, which may be the source of some of my consternation. Second, I felt Idleman's use of a single acronym (AHA) throughout the book was actually the source of some confusion in some places. There were times when he was referring to two different ideas but didn't take the time to distinguish them. For example, sometimes he was referring to an A-ha! moment (or more accurately a God moment as he puts it) and then other times he was referring specifically to his three-point recipe for AHA. If he would have used "a God moment" (or an A-ha moment) for those moments that describe the actual moment of experience and then the acronym "AHA" when he is talking about his three-point principle it would have been much easier to follow and much more accurate at the same time.Now that I think about it there was a comment in chapter three that I shouldn't overlook. Under the heading "Redeeming the Pain" Idleman makes the following comments:"Right now someone is reading this who is experiencing difficult circumstances. In your pain and disappointment, there is part of you that wants to turn from God and walk away. But don't waste the pain. Hear the alarm and wake up. In 2 Corinthians 7:10 we read, `For God sometimes uses sorrow in our lives to help us turn away from sin and seek eternal life' (Living Bible). It doesn't say `God causes;' it says `God uses,' and He wants to use these circumstances to draw you closer to Him."Idleman writes that God only "uses" and never "causes" sorrow in our lives to draw us closer to Him. Then four pages later while recounting the Bible record of Jonah he writes the following:"Jonah was on the ship heading to Tarshish when God sent a violent storm. When I'm on a boat, any storm is a bad storm. But a storm sent by God? This was the kind of storm that tossed the boat around like a toy in a bathtub. The ship's beams groaned from the violent waves, threatening to break apart. Scripture says that the sailors were terrified."Up to this point it was just a bad storm that had the crew terrified. Fast-forward the story to the point when it really got terrifying; for the prophet Jonah anyway. Scripture says that God prepared a great fish to swallow Jonah! I don't know about you but that would definitely cause me some serious pain and sorrow. My point is this: In one place Idleman writes that God never causes sorrow in our lives; then four pages later he adds one of the most hair-raising, sorrow-filled stories in the Old Testament; sorrow that was specifically caused by God. So which is it? Does the Bible really say God only "uses" and never "causes" sorrow in our lives to help us draw closer to Him?Although seeming contradictions like this one need to be cleaned up, I still think this book provides really sound teaching on the subject at hand. Going back to Idleman's central story about the Prodigal Son for a moment, it was the Prodigal's pain and sorrow that brought him to his senses, which should show us that God will bring anything to bear on those he loves to accomplish His divine purposes.

I have been looking for an effective mouthwash that was alcohol free because I'm tired of the "alcohol burn" that comes with many of the top-named brands. When I saw this new product from Colgate I thought I would give it a try.This new Colgate Total Advanced Pro-Shield is alcohol free and is advertised as an anti-gingivitis, anti-plaque mouthwash. The product I am reviewing is the 16.9 fluid ounce plastic bottle manufactured by the Colgate-Palmolive Company and comes with several fairly remarkable claims:~ 12-hour protection against germs, even after eating and drinking.~ Kills 99% of germs; kills germs that cause bad breath, gingivitis and plaque.~ 24/7 protection.When I first saw the 12-hour protection guarantee and then noted the 24/7 protection promise I thought, "Wait a minute!" I may not be a math wiz but those two claims don't add up. After closer observation I spotted the following recommendation: "Use 2X daily."A couple of things I did like about the container were (1) the plastic cap came with a safety sealed wrapper around it so the consumer can be assured that there has been no tampering (most mouthwashes come this way, but not all do) and (2) the cap just screws off; no tricky push-it-down and turn or press-in-the-sides and turn caps. Also, if you flip the cap over so you can see the inside, there is what appears to be a cap inside of a cap. I doubt it was intended for this, but I found the inside cap could be used as a measuring cup for dispensing the right amount of mouthwash. I suspect the double-cap design is intended to prevent leakage but I thought it also worked well as a dispenser, too. Even though this was a 16.9 fluid ounce bottle, I was surprised just how quickly I used it up; even when using the nifty pseudo measuring cup I had discovered.Now let's get to the questions most consumers have when they shop for mouthwash: (1) Does it work as advertised? and (2) what does it taste like? The product I have has a flavor that Colgate-Palmolive calls "Wintermint Rush." Now considering that I was looking for a mouthwash without a burning sensation or one with a soda pop taste I was hoping this "Wintermint Rush" also wouldn't taste like the title...a RUSH! After trying it out it definitely didn't have a burn or a rush. This mouthwash has a very mild, rather dull taste; no fizzing, bubbling, burning and definitely no rush; exactly what I was looking for. After rinsing I found the mouthwash left a fresh, clean taste in my mouth. But does it work like advertised? As far as I am concerned it does. My breath stayed reasonably fresh and free of an undesirable smell. I found the mouthwash left a pleasant coating on my lips, which my wife also found appealing. This new Colgate-Palmolive mouth also comes in two additional flavors: "Peppermint Blast" and "Spearmint Surge."The label comes with many of the usual list of active and inactive ingredients, warnings and and so forth. This product is intended for use by adults and children over the age of five. One recommendation I thought was excellent was children 6 years to under 12-years-old should be supervised while using this mouthwash.Overall I was pleased with this new Colgate Total Advanced Pro-Shield mouthwash. The fact that it doesn't have a strong flavor wasn't a problem for me. The taste isn't impressive, but then I don't purchase mouthwash for its jazzy flavor like I would the smell of my cologne. I buy it because it works; because it:~ Kills germs.~ Significantly prevents and reduces plaque.~ Helps prevent gingivitis.~ Has no alcohol burn.~ Freshens breath.Postscript (17 March 2014): I finished my bottle of Colgate Total Advanced Pro-Shield mouthwash this morning and I'm still impressed with this product. One additional note: I have been for decades prone to having minor, yet still annoying sores on the inside of my cheeks (not my gums) because of some prescribed medication I'm taking. After using this product for only a few days I haven't had another sore in my mouth. This was completely unexpected; what a relief.

My wife and I share an early generation model Apple iPad that still has the original Apple case that came with the iPad. It's time for a new case and I saw this one on Amazon just before I went shopping for a new case downtown. This recently released case (2013) was designed by Francois et Mimi specifically to fit the Apple iPad Air and comes with a choice of black, white or brown faux leather.The Francois et Mimi iPad case is noticeably lighter than the case on our iPad; almost 6 ounces and measures 9½" x 7" x ½". The light weight of this case initially raised the question of just how well it would protect the Apple iPad Air? Since I don't own one (it wasn't a prerequisite for doing this review), nor do I know anyone who does for that matter, I decided to drop by our local brand-name electronics store and let them help me test it out with an actual Apple iPad Air. While I watched, the sales associate put an iPad in the case and then ran through a list of consumer questions I had prepared at home before arriving at the store.The first comment Brian made when I pulled the case out of its box was how much he liked the brown color. He also expressed surprise that the case was faux (imitation) leather and not real leather. The case has the feel of a hard shell, with some cushioning from the imitation leather covering the front flap and on the inset of the plastic shell-like back. The front cover is actually made from three vertical pieces, hinged together by the imitation leather (see photo; photo has four vertical pieces, which is not the way the case I am reviewing is made). This tri-fold design allows the cover to be flexible when opening and closing the case and I'm sure also lessens the likelihood that the cover would be easily broken. The inside of the case is covered with a soft gray felt-like lining to cushion and protect the tablet from scratches. The Apple iPad Air the sales associate selected from his store display fit nicely into the case, sliding easily under the plastic side lips to secure the tablet into place. How secure the device would be in the case was one of my major concerns. Just looking at the case itself it doesn't appear to look all that well designed in this regard. But after handling the encased iPad myself in the store I was convinced that it was secure in the case. Without actually testing the case with an actual Apple iPad Air I don't think I would have been all that confident.Like our older iPad case, there are a number of cutouts that allow some functions to be completed without opening the case or removing the iPad. The most noticeable ones are on the backside which allow the camera to be used and also cutouts for the speakers, a headphone jack and mics. Another cutout on the bottom edge allows the charging cable to be attached without opening the case. Other cutouts provide easy access to some of the controls like the camera shutter button, power on/off and sleep/wake modes, volume control and screen rotation lock/unlock.This product doesn't come with any instructions, so when I wondered whether this case could double as a stand for an iPad Air (like the case on our aged iPad does) I had nothing to consult. I Googled this product but that also didn't produce any guidance; so I was on my own. The tri-fold cover does flip around backwards and the folds will bend into a triangular shape that seemed like it could support an iPad Air. Back to the electronics store I went to test it with an actual Apple iPad Air. It did work, however I'm not sure the angle of incline would be enough to ensure the safety of the iPad (preventing it from flipping forward). And I'm still not sure this Francois et Mimi case is actually designed to go through the contortions I am putting it through to create a stand.The one feature that I found most interesting was the virtually invisible magnet that is underneath the gray felt near the edge of the underside of the case cover. Once the sales associate pointed it out I was able to feel it by running my finger over the felt lining. When the case cover is closed it automatically turns the iPad screen off and puts the tablet into Sleep mode, which puts the iPad into a minimal power usage status. Open the case cover and the iPad immediately awakens from its slumber and is ready to go. Our aged iPad doesn't have this feature.The following is printed on the back of the case storage box:"The Francois et Mimi faux leather iPad case provides the necessary protection against everyday shock and scratches, with automatic wake & sleep functionality."For the budget-minded consumer this iPad case may be a reasonable alternative to Apple's $80 pale brown genuine leather case. When visually compared side-by-side in the store today, the sales associate opted for the less expensive, bold brown Francois et Mimi iPad Air case over the Apple iPad Air case. This is definitely an indiction that beauty (and frugality) is in fact in the eye of the beholder.

It's never too early to start training for baseball season. I suppose that would apply to just about any sport. As far as baseball is concerned practicing hitting, fielding, throwing, etc. before the season begins helps with individual confidence as well as overall skills. I volunteered to be a hitting coach for a couple of friends who will be coaching a coach-pitch team next season; they have sons and a daughter who will be on the team. I coached youth sports back in the 1980s so I needed some work on my skills, too.Hitting from a tee takes more practice than one might think; and doing it correctly takes even longer. I thought the SKLZ 360 Power Alley (Version 2) Heavy Duty All-Position Batting Trainer would help with the basics as well as improve the skills of the more advanced players. This batting tee definitely met most of our needs.There was not much assembly required and what needed to be assembled was easy to complete. The batting tee is constructed out of heavy duty rubber and heavy-gauge wire. The tee shaft attaches to the rubber home plate and can swivel around 360 degrees and lock into several positions for practicing hitting inside, outside and down the middle of the plate pitches. The tee shaft can be raised and lowered to accommodate hitters of different heights (22" to 36") as well as practicing line drives, fly balls, grounders and even bunts. In my experience, moving the the tee shaft up and down should be left to adults since the two pieces fit tightly together. One of the designs I liked about this tee was the added heavy-gauge wire frame added to the front of the home plate; it helps to keep the tee from tipping over when the ball is hit. It worked pretty well except when one of our "free swingers" came up.The winter weather in the Midwest usually doesn't allow for many outside practice. So I set up the tee down in my basement and began practicing with a plastic wiffle ball. These balls don't last a long time, but you can probably imagine what my basement would look like if I didn't use the plastic balls. My goal at this point is developing correct hitting form rather than hitting distance, so this hitting tee works very well for this exercise. Unlike the earlier version of this SKLZ hitting tee, this new version 2 model is made of thicker rubber so it takes a lot more punishment. The plastic balls stayed in the cup as do a hardball and softball.As mentioned earlier, the hitting shaft swivels and locks into different positions for practicing hitting pitches on the inside, middle and outside part of the home plate as well a low, knee-level and high strike-zone pitches. I thought the multi-positioning of the training tee was a real plus. Teaching how to hit inside and outside pitches takes a lot repetition and patience.SKLZ has an impressive number of training videos covering virtually every aspect of baseball instruction. Dozens are posted on their website and some addition videos on teaching hitting for youth baseball may also be found on YouTube. I like SKLZ sports training products and I appreciated the improvements they made to this new version 2 model, particularly its durability. I did notice that SKLZ also has a tee with a brush cup; unfortunately, I'm not sure how well that one works.I really liked the movable design of this tee as compared to the other SKLZ stationary tees. I do use a stationary hitting tee for T-Ball and some coach-pitch baseball. I can definitely give this new and improved hitting tee a two-thumbs-up rating.

I have had a number of deaths in my family during the past several years so this book by Joseph Primo, a former hospice chaplain, titled "What Do We Tell the Children? (Talking to Kids about Death and Dying) was of interest to me for obvious reasons. In his Prologue, Primo provided the reader with a glimpse into his early aspirations when in his own words he refers to himself as "a religiously fanatic teen" who longed to become the pope when he grew up. Musing over what this would be like Primo compares being the pope to being an American president:"Bill Clinton did not wear snazzy robes or drive in the white pope-mobile. In my mind, being a world religious leader for an indefinite amount of time totally surpassed the powers of the presidency. Oh, and believers kiss the pope's ring. That is the epitome of an instant ego boost. You don't get that in the White House!"Before delving into the heart of the book, Primo provides a 10-page Introduction where he describes his ministry as a chaplain for a fifty-four-bed hospice facility; the first of its kind in the United States. Most of the patients were middle aged or older adults, but many were also young children. This is where Primo practiced what he describes as the power of being present, listening, and showing that he cared. According to Primo, this is the process that started him "in the direction of becoming a caring presence, a witness, and a companion to those in need of support, rather than a 'fixer' or someone who could help resolve grief."This is not a long book; only 127 pages and eight chapters. To a some degree this book took on the form of a textbook on the subject of death and dying. Some might find this as morbid but instead Primo's style made it intensely interesting. I think the fact that it was not loaded down with cited quotes and reference material enhanced the readability and kept me interested (there are only three notes in the endnotes section at the back of the book). Though the author does cite some reference material within the text, much of his support comes in the form of anecdotal stories from his own life experiences as well as from actual encounters during his years working in a hospice.One of my favorite chapters was the one in which he discusses and corrects the misunderstanding and misapplication of the well-known book by Swiss psychiatrist Elizabeth Kubler-Ross. She is the creator of the "Five Stages of Grief" model in her 1969 book titled "On Death and Dying." According to Primo, most have applied the stages as linear steps through the grief process. Yet Primo insists Kubler-Ross never intended the "Five Stages of Grief" to be understood and used in this way.I have intentionally refrained from discussing or divulging much of the material in this book out of concern that I may misrepresent what the author has written. This isn't a novel, so due to the sensitive nature of the subject matter, and in deference to the author I have chosen to withhold further comment. In my opinion, this should be read and digested without my interpretive comments. Primo has written a very good, albeit a short book on the subject of how and when to include children in the grief process of death and dying. His book could be used for personal study, in a study group or even as a oft referenced refresher when a family or friend's child loses a parent, parents or a beloved guardian and needs to grieve in a helpful and healthy manner. Recommended.

This baseball tee is similar to the single-position tee that has been around for decades. The difference in this version of the baseball tee is SKLZ has taken the single-position design and expanded it into their "SKLZ 5-Position (Version 2) Traditional Batting Training Tee." By adding four additional hitting shaft positions SKLZ not only has a device that develops and improves swing mechanics and body positioning, but it also focuses on specific areas of hitting; inside, outside pitches and fastball and off-speed pitches. This 5-position tee trains the hitter for maximum plate coverage.Like other baseball tees the SKLZ 5-Position Tee is made of rubber, comes with a single adjustable hitting shaft (adjustable from 20" to 34") and five holes in the home plate for positioning and repositioning the hitting shaft for a variety of training exercises. I use the front two hitting positions to train hitting ahead of the pitch and stroking the ball to the opposite field, up the middle of the field or pulling the ball down the left or right field lines. The front two hitting positions also help teach the hitter how to hit the dreaded curve ball. The back two positions teach how to wait on the change-up or off-speed pitch. This tee is even helpful for instruction in the proper way to bunt (a lost art as far as I am concerned). As you may see, this isn't the same baseball tee that I used when I was coaching back in the 1980s.As I noted earlier, the hitting shaft is adjustable for use by younger/shorter and older/taller hitters as well as instruction in hitting the low ball and high strike-zone pitches. The two-piece hitting shaft fits pretty tightly together and therefore should, in my opinion, be adjusted by an adult. As with some of the other SKLZ baseball tees, the weakness I found in this tee has always been the durability of the hitting shaft, especially the cup at the top. It didn't take long before it began to show wear and damage. The earlier version of this hitting tee wasn't very durable in this area. However, SKLZ has definitely improved this version 2 model. It is made of heavier rubber and is able to endure more punishment.This hitting tee may be used for both hardball and softball training. Unlike other tees I have seen, the home plate has a built-in carrying handle along the front edge and the hitting shaft can be snapped onto the  plate  for easy transport and storage; I really found this feature very handy. One issue I have found with most hitting tees is there tendency to flip over forward when the ball isn't hit cleanly. Constantly repositioning the tee was a never ending nuisance. I often used plastic or metal tent stakes to anchor the front and back; they worked pretty well, but could still only take so much pounding. I did notice that SKLZ has added a heavy-gauge wire frame to the front of one of their other batting tees to prevent it from tipping over.This batting tee is a good training device. SKLZ also has a couple of dozen excellent baseball training videos on their website. Overall, I am satisfied with their new, version 2 SKLZ 5-Position Traditional Batting Tee. Though the stability of this new model is better, it still needs improvement.

I've had a couple of small shop vacuums through the years; one was just a vacuum and the other was both a wet and dry vacuum. Neither was very impressive and the wet vacuum died shortly into a crisis situation when our basement flooded. I don't have an actual shop, per se, so I just wanted a wet/dry vacuum mostly for cleaning our cars, the garage and disposing of liquid spills. Though our basement is now watertight our washer and dryer are downstairs so even with a nearby floor drain there is always the possibility of a significant spill or water backing up into the basement; I live only a stones-throw away from Lake Michigan. Thus, I had a genuine need for a good wet/dry vacuum.The Workshop Wet/Dry Vac (WS0500WM) seemed to have the potential to fit my basic need, and maybe more. It came with a nice complement of accessories and also included a couple of surprises; I'll mention those later. This vacuum comes with a huge owner's manual (54 pages). Anyway that's what I thought until I skimmed through it an found out it was divided into three different languages (English/Spanish/French). The smaller, 18-page manual still covers everything a user needs to know.This 5-HP, 5-gallon (medium-sized) shop vacuum doesn't come fully assembled; yes, some assembly is required but by following the owner's manual assembly is quite easy. This is a portable vacuum (no wheels) that is reasonably lightweight and easy to carry. It can also be mounted on a wall for storage only (one of the surprises!) or it can be used in a stationary mode (like the vacs at a gas station or self-help car wash). The owner's manual dedicates several pages on how the 2-piece hanging rack should be properly mounted; I liked that since I do plan on mounting the vacuum in my garage. The unit comes with two vacuum hoses (one 2-foot hose that expands to 7 feet; another 14-foot hose that expands to 21 feet) that snap easily into the front of the vacuum and can be used separately or connected together for a whopping 28 feet of hose! There are a variety of cleaning attachments for vacuuming carpets, sucking up water from hard floors and getting into those narrow, hard to reach spaces around the house and garage. Two hard plastic extension wands are also included for vacuuming floors and reaching into overhead spaces. The attachments can be stored in a handy removable storage bin that snaps on securely to the side of the vacuum, keeping al of the accessories together in one place.When my daughter came home from college recently she wanted to be the first one to use the Workshop Wet/Dry Vacuum to clean the inside of her car and the trunk. Once we had the shop vacuum assembled and transported to the garage it was time to plug it in flip the switch. This vacuum isn't any louder than a household vacuum and really packs a lot of suction power; definitely more than our Kirby. I would guess that my daughter had her entire interior and trunk vacuumed in about 15-20 minutes; and that included the removable floor mats. She used the extended 7-foot hose and a couple of the attachments to do the job. She said the vacuum was easy to move around (in and out of the car) and the hose was very flexible and easy to use. The detachable exhaust diffuser also does a good job of reducing the intensity of the exhaust stream, dispensing it over a larger area. (NOTE: The diffuser only has a thin sponge-like filter so it may not be ideal for indoor use). I did a simple test of the wet vacuum feature by spilling some water on the cement floor in the basement utility area. The suction was great and the large integrated filter worked very well.Here is the second of the two surprises: Earlier I mentioned that this unit had an exhaust port with a detachable deffuser. I was initially curious why does this vacuum have such a powerful stream of exhaust that it would require a diffuser? Well, I discovered why. This vacuum is also a blower that can be used for yard work and patio or garage cleanup! Just remove the diffuser, snap in the locking end of either hose (or connected hoses), add an extension wand (optional) and turn on the blower. Workshop recommends safety eye wear be worn while using the blower feature. I have a blower, too! What a nice surprise this was. I blew some leaves out of our flowerbeds as a test and the blower worked just as advertised. Of course, the blower power from the individual shorter hoses was greater than the 21-foot hose, but hat was to be expected.I was intrigued with the clever design of this compact vacuum/blower. With the exception of the 21-foot hose, all of the attachments, the shorter hose, two extension wands and the power cord can be stored on this self-contained unit at the same time. Even with all of this the vacuum/blower is still what I would consider a lightweight, easy to carry mobile product. The fastener clips that secure the top half of the vacuum/blower to the lower half are not easy to unfasten. I don't consider this a negative feature. In fact I would expect it to be snapped securely together considering this unit can carry gallons of liquid. I wouldn't want it any other way.The owner's manual begins with two pages of safety instructions; there are also numerous Warnings throughout the manual. This is no toy and failure to use this vacuum/blower in a safe manner may result in injury; possibly serious injury.This Workshop Wet/Dry Vac is definitely a keeper and is built to last a long time.Postscript (15 Jan 2014): Our 80-gallon water heater died this morning and spilled its contents on the cement basement floor. It took a minute or two to get the Workshop vacuum in place, snap the hose and plastic wand together and hooked to the machine. When I clicked the power on the vacuum sucked up the dirty water like a champ! After the job was done I emptied the last vacuum bucket load of water and washed out the bucket, removed the filter and rinsed it clean as instructed in the owner's manual and left them both to dry.

SKLS is not the only company to develop a basketball dribble stick. But after using the SKLZ version with my son, their Dribble Stick is definitely an effective basketball training device. It was difficult to understand just how the trainer worked by just looking at a few photos, so off I went to Google to see if there were any videos available on a dribble stick. In fact there are quite a number of introductory and training drills available. Some dribbling and conditioning drills are included in the three-page instructions that come with the SKLZ Dribble Stick. The written and photo drills are okay but the videos do a knockout job of showcasing just how useful this relatively simple device really is.It probably comes as no surprise that the Dribble Stick does not come fully assembled; yes, there is some assembly required. However their is no reason to worry about that as the instructions provided are definitely sufficient to complete assembly. And there are actually a minimal number of parts to put together anyway. Assembly is pretty easy and takes only about ten minutes once the parts are removed from the box and spread out for inventory. The SKLZ Dribble Stick comes with some practical warnings that should be followed; SKLZ also recommends this product be use only by those over seven years of age, and only with adult supervision for those under 18 years of age.According to their website, the stated purpose for this training device is as follows:"Improve hand positioning, stance, and speed with the ball using the Dribble Stick. Get immediate feedback on movements and mimic on-court dynamics against defenders. Easily adjustable arms enable a wide variety of drills for plyometrics, ball control, speed and agility."This was just what my son and I needed. He wanted to improve his overall basketball skills as well as augment his weekly exercise regime. For me, I just wanted to keep up with the other over-the-hill basketball guys at the "Y" and keep in shape at the same time. By the way, a health-issue warning from SKLZ comes with this product for guys my age since if used as intended the Dribble Stick can develop into a serious aerobics regime.The SKLZ Dribble Stick comes with a heavy base (12" x 12" and almost 5 lbs.) to anchor the device to the floor and an aluminum slotted center post (2 ¼" x 2 ¼" x 35"). Four 24" dribble arms (2 black & 2 gray) fit easily in the center post slots and can be moved independently up and down the post in a large variety of configurations. A large circular cap fastens onto the top of the center post and also acts as a storage location for the dribble arms and a basketball when the Dribble Stick is not in use. SKLZ: "To maximize the life span of the product, avoid leaving the Dribble Stick out in the sun or cold weather for long periods of time."The dribble arms are not flexible and are actually very stiff. They appear to be made out of fiberglass or some composite plastic. My son and I have hit them with the basketball quite a few times, but so far we haven't experienced what seems to be the most common complaint about this product from the other reviewers: broken dribble arms. I also see by the comments made to previous reviews that SKLZ has taken an active interest in this flaw and are or have already begun to include a better, more damage-resistant dribble arm with later Dribble Sticks. According to comments made by customer service reps, SKLZ will replace the older version arms if they break during proper usage. Contact information is included in the Dribble Stick Guide.SKLZ recommends storing the Dribble Stick when not in use to prevent unintended accidents and damage. Storing is a snap; just remove the four dribble arms from the center post and slide each down through one of the holes in the center cap and put the Dribble Stick aside or store it away. That's it.I usually include music during my ball handling and conditioning drills; I'm older and my attention span isn't what it used to be. The music helps me maintain my rapidly depleting sense of rhythm; I often work out to Sweet Georgia Brown! (If you don't get the humor in that you are just way too young {wink}). Having used it now for about five weeks, I am impressed with this training device and have benefited in the ball handling area the most; I definitely break a sweat and have lost a few pounds, too; that makes my wife happy and helps her put up with all of the dribbling that goes on down stairs. Overall, I can recommend this product. Two things still need to be done, though: (1) Get better quality dribble arms; (2) Put the instructional and drill videos on SKLZ.com that the Drills Guide says are already there, but aren't. In the meantime, "Just GOOGLE It!" to find the other on-line training videos I mentioned earlier. You will be glad you did.

This new McAfee LiveSafe software may be new on the market but the software is essentially a standard internet security anti-virus program. However, according to the advertisement on the slipcase and their website McAfee gives the impression it is more than that. Here is the statement I am referring to:"McAfee security software brings you the deepest protection available by taking advantage of technology in the very latest Intel processor."Sounds like McAfee (an Intel company) is implying this new LiveSafe software utilizes the Intel "DeepSafe" technology... but it doesn't. What is actually new with the LiveSafe software is a bundle of additional services. Please don't misunderstand what I'm saying. This basic internet security anti-virus program from McAfee does block malware, phishing and the latest virus attacks.I have had a particular internet security anti-virus program on my PC for quite some time now and a couple of years ago I was offered a free download of the McAfee basic software. I was concerned that the two programs would conflict with one another but they didn't. I mention this because instead of uninstalling the free McAfee security software I have on my PC and them install this new software I decided to install this one on my daughter's laptop instead. The LiveSafe software install and setup was pretty easy, with onscreen, step-by-step instructions. One thing I need to note is this software does not come on a CD.
